('46', 0, 0, 1, 0) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 1
('46', 0, 1, 2, 41) 1. WHAT COMPRISES FOREIGN GOODS?
('46', 0, 2, 3, 74) A gentleman asks: “Should we boycott all foreign goods or only some select ones?” This question has been asked many times and I have answered it many times.
('46', 0, 2, 4, 231) And the question does not come from only one person.
('46', 0, 2, 5, 284) I face it at many places even during my tour.
('46', 0, 2, 6, 330) In my view, the only thing to be boycotted thoroughly and despite all hardships is foreign cloth, and that can and should be done through khadi alone.
('46', 0, 2, 7, 481) Boycott of all foreign things is neither possible nor proper.
('46', 0, 2, 8, 543) The difference between swadeshi and foreign cannot hold for all time, cannot hold even now in regard to all things.
('46', 0, 2, 9, 659) Even the swadeshi character of khadi is due to circumstances.
('46', 0, 2, 10, 721) Suppose there is flood in India and only one island remains on which a few persons alone survive and not a single tree stands; at such a time the swadeshi dharma of the marooned would be to wear what clothes are provided and eat what food is sent by generous people across the sea.
('46', 0, 2, 11, 1003) This of course is an extreme instance.
('46', 0, 2, 12, 1042) So it is for us to consider what our swadeshi dharma is.
('46', 0, 2, 13, 1099) Today many things which we need for our sustenance and which are not imposed upon us come from abroad.
('46', 0, 2, 14, 1202) As for example, some of the foreign medicines, pens, needles, useful tools, etc., etc.
('46', 0, 2, 15, 1289) But those who wear khadi and consider it an honour or are not ashamed to have all other things of foreign make fail to understand the significance of khadi.
('46', 0, 2, 16, 1446) The significance of khadi is that it is our dharma to use those things which can be or are easily made in our country and on which depends the livelihood of poor people; the boycott of such things and deliberate preference of foreign things is adharma.
('46', 0, 2, 17, 1699) A person who loves his country and has concern for the poor would pass in review the foreign things he uses and would use indigenous articles in place of those foreign articles which he liked more and had been using so far for his pleasure.
('46', 0, 2, 18, 1940) On this tour itself I have observed that people place before me cakes of foreign soap, and never a single one produced in Madras, Mysore, Bombay and Bengal.
('46', 0, 2, 19, 2097) Those who do this are all khadi weavers.
('46', 0, 2, 20, 2138) These days wherever I go for propagating khadi, I ask for a khadi 
('46', 1, 0, 1, 2205) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 1, 1, 2, 2245) clad barber.
('46', 1, 1, 3, 2258) It is with some effort that such a barber is found.
('46', 1, 1, 4, 2310) Much of his equipment is foreign made: razor, brush, soap and mirror, and they are arranged in a foreign made box.
('46', 1, 1, 5, 2425) So I pay the barber his wages and explain to him the swadeshi dharma.
('46', 1, 1, 6, 2495) I can recount many such experience.
('46', 1, 1, 7, 2531) At present ink, fountain pens, etc., are manufactured in our country.
('46', 1, 1, 8, 2601) The thoughtful should be on the look out for such things and as far as possible use only those articles which are produced in the country.
('46', 1, 1, 9, 2740) If it is argued that not all the things made in the country are good, that of course is true.
('46', 1, 1, 10, 2834) But there are difficulties in the observance of dharma as such.
('46', 1, 1, 11, 2898) What is the value of practising something which offers no trouble?
('46', 1, 1, 12, 2965) Wise people can help remove the inconveniences if they use swadeshi things of their own will even putting up with hardships.
('46', 1, 1, 13, 3090) If I use indigenous soap, notice its shortcomings and draw the makers’ attention to them, they may perhaps try to remove them.
('46', 1, 1, 14, 3217) It is only thus that things have improved in quality and design and are still being improved.
('46', 1, 1, 15, 3311) At this stage we have to consider one thing more.
('46', 1, 1, 16, 3361) Do foreign goods mean only British goods or anything made outside India?
('46', 1, 1, 17, 3434) I know there is a difference of opinion about this.
('46', 1, 1, 18, 3486) I do not wish to discuss the problem from the point of view of non violence but to put it before you from the practical point of view.
('46', 1, 1, 19, 3621) We shall merely exhibit our weakness if we threaten to do something which we cannot do and will never be able to do.
('46', 1, 1, 20, 3738) It is my belief that we use many British things even against our will.
('46', 1, 1, 21, 3809) Those who are familiar with the figures of India’s imports know that the Government itself imports British goods worth crores of rupees and we use them; e.g., the rails for the track and a lot of other equipment for railways.
('46', 1, 1, 22, 4035) We use English books of our own will.
('46', 1, 1, 23, 4073) Another objection from the practical point of view is that, while differentiating between British and other foreign goods, there is a danger of our using British goods under the label of other foreign goods.
('46', 1, 1, 24, 4281) This has happened in the past and may happen in future.
('46', 1, 1, 25, 4337) Who can prevent a British manufacturer of fountain pens from writing on his products ‘Made in Australia’?
('46', 1, 1, 26, 4443) Some traitors among cloth merchants have torn off the British labels on British dhotis and have sold them as swadeshi dhotis.
('46', 1, 1, 27, 4569) Who can prevent British cloth from coming in via Japan as Japanese cloth?
('46', 1, 1, 28, 4643) We are not going to benefit in the least by importing articles other than British.
('46', 1, 1, 29, 4726) Then we shall have to make a second attempt to boycott this other foreign cloth and it may be difficult to do so.
('46', 1, 1, 30, 4840) Our aim is swaraj, independence.
('46', 1, 1, 31, 4873) We do not want other people’s
('46', 2, 0, 1, 4903) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 3
('46', 2, 1, 2, 4944) domination after getting rid of British rule.
('46', 2, 1, 3, 4990) Considered from all angles and from the practical point of view, we can take but one decision.
('46', 2, 1, 4, 5085) Pure khadi is pure swadeshi and one who realizes this will satisfy even his other needs by means of things produced in the country, giving up the use of those superfluous things that are not manufactured here.
('46', 2, 2, 5, 5295) [From Gujarati]
('46', 2, 3, 6, 5311) Navajivan, 12 5 1929

('46', 2, 7, 15, 5847) Of course there is nothing to worry about in this.
('46', 2, 7, 16, 5898) If it does not agree with me, I shall give it up.

('46', 3, 2, 3, 6100) NELLORE, Silence Day, May 13, 1929
('46', 3, 3, 4, 6135) SISTERS, There are only a few days to go before we meet again.

('46', 3, 3, 6, 6256) I don’t feel the heat much.
('46', 3, 3, 7, 6284) Your firmness in keeping up with the prayer classes, the infant school and the kitchen is, I think, a good gesture.
('46', 3, 3, 8, 6400) All the three are imperfect, and will remain so for ever.
('46', 3, 3, 9, 6458) It will be enough if we remain vigilant and keep improving them.
('46', 3, 3, 10, 6523) Even if we try to keep them going, some improvement will take place automatically.

('46', 3, 7, 14, 6773) 4. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI
('46', 3, 8, 15, 6803) Silence Day, May 13, 1929
('46', 3, 9, 16, 6829) CHHAGANLAL, Three letters from you of the 6th, the 8th and the 9th have piled up.
('46', 3, 9, 17, 6911) It is all right if you have changed the time for prayers and meals; you have done nothing wrong in that.
('46', 3, 9, 18, 7016) You must have sent an acknowledgment to Lady Ramanathan.
('46', 3, 9, 19, 7073) Has not the sum been sent to Tiruchengodu?
('46', 3, 9, 20, 7116) Has it not been acknowledged in Young India?
('46', 3, 9, 21, 7161) The money which we receive from France is not from a gentleman but from a lady.
('46', 3, 9, 22, 7241) It is the same Mirbel, who had once stayed in the Ashram for about a month.
('46', 3, 9, 23, 7317) Shivabhai must have recovered.
('46', 3, 9, 24, 7348) You need not insist on the students memorizing the verses of the Gita.
('46', 3, 9, 25, 7419) They themselves should insist on doing that.
('46', 3, 9, 26, 7464) All of us, of course, should know how to recite them correctly.
('46', 3, 9, 27, 7528) My having given up breakfast is not an act of sacrifice; it was
('46', 4, 0, 1, 7592) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 5
('46', 4, 1, 2, 7633) rendered necessary by my travels.
('46', 4, 1, 3, 7667) I feel helpless at not being able to go for morning and evening walks.
('46', 4, 1, 4, 7738) When I teach the Gita, I don’t set aside a special time for it; my enthusiasm shows me the way.
('46', 4, 1, 5, 7834) When I was there, I used the time allotted to spinning in discussions with inmates of the Ashram.
('46', 4, 1, 6, 7932) Here I give the first half hour to Prabhavati, and the half hour in the afternoon to the workers.
('46', 4, 1, 7, 8030) Since, instead of everyone joining in the recitation at the time of the prayer, a different person recited the verses every day, we could correct the pronunciation of the person who was doing his turn.
('46', 4, 1, 8, 8232) In this way we could effect much improvement.
('46', 4, 1, 9, 8278) People still commit mistakes, but they are getting fewer.
('46', 4, 1, 10, 8336) This does not impose the slightest burden on my mind or my time; on the contrary, it gives me more peace of mind.
('46', 4, 1, 11, 8450) The person who learns in this manner likes doing so.
('46', 4, 1, 12, 8503) He does not feel that it is a task.
('46', 4, 1, 13, 8539) It is only after I arrive there that I think I shall be able to write about the money received from Rangoon.
('46', 4, 1, 14, 8648) Do you examine the cash book every day?
('46', 4, 1, 15, 8688) Do you sign it daily?
('46', 4, 1, 16, 8710) Do you inspect the vouchers every day?
('46', 4, 1, 17, 8749) If you do not, start doing it.
('46', 4, 1, 18, 8780) Follow the rule no matter who is in charge of the work.
('46', 4, 1, 19, 8836) Sitla Sahai seems to be busy all right.
('46', 4, 1, 20, 8876) I was to reach Bombay on the morning of the 23rd; instead I shall reach on the evening of the 22nd.
('46', 4, 1, 21, 8976) I expect to return to the Ashram before the 28th.
('46', 4, 2, 22, 9026) Blessings from

Total Rs. 2,01,792, 14 3. Events are so crowded in one upon another that it is difficult to write about them all or to make a selection.
('46', 9, 1, 4, 17035) I must therefore be satisfied with giving only an outline of some of the most important ones.
('46', 9, 2, 5, 17129) UNTOUCHABILITY
('46', 9, 3, 6, 17144) This deadly snake of untouchability is scotched but not destroyed.
('46', 9, 3, 7, 17211) It shows its poisonous fangs even when you may least expect to see them.
('46', 9, 3, 8, 17284) I was certainly not prepared for the following letter:
('46', 9, 4, 9, 17339) I regret very much to bring to your kind notice, the following fact which
('46', 9, 5, 10, 17413) occurred soon after the ladies’ meeting held at Tanuku on the 22nd instant.
('46', 9, 6, 11, 17489) about 5 p.m.
('46', 9, 6, 12, 17502) there were present three to four hundred ladies in the meeting.
('46', 9, 7, 13, 17566) was whispered by some in the meeting that the young lady who was sitting by you was a Panchama girl.
('46', 9, 8, 14, 17667) As soon as the meeting was over, all the ladies who attended the meeting
('46', 9, 9, 15, 17740) directly went to the canal and took a plunge in the water to purify themselves
('46', 9, 10, 16, 17819) from the unpardonable sin of touching her.

('46', 10, 1, 2, 18294) As it so happens the young lady sitting by me was no other than Shrimati Prabhavati Devi, the daughter of Brijkishore Babu, the well known leader of Bihar.

('46', 11, 2, 5, 21565) A GREAT INSTITUTION The visit to the little village was preliminary to our entry into the area covered by the activities of the Gautami Sataygraha Ashram founded by Dr. B. Subrahmanyam in 1924. He left his lucrative practice in Rajahmundry for dedicating himself to national service.
('46', 11, 2, 6, 21849) He saw at once that he could not render that service unless he himself lived in the midst of villagers and put himself in direct contact with them.
('46', 11, 2, 7, 21997) Hence he established himself in Sitanagaram lying 14 miles from Rajahmundry; for, it was in a cluster of villages surrounding Sitanagram that the people had put up a brave fight with the Government in the heyday of non co operation.
('46', 11, 2, 8, 22230) Many were the village officers who had given up their jobs.
('46', 11, 2, 9, 22290) For their effrontery they were subjected to a punitive tax of nearly Rs. 5,000. The Ashram occupies about 10 acres of ground.
('46', 11, 2, 10, 22416) Khadi is its central activity and corollary activities are: rendering of free medical aid, Hindi prachar, library development, publication of a Telugu journal, service of depressed classes and general Congress work.
('46', 11, 2, 11, 22632) According to the statement lying before me “spinning has been organized in all the surrounding villages within a radius of 5 miles form the Ashram, so as to be within, the reach of a single worker to carry on his regular weekly visits from house to house”.
('46', 11, 2, 12, 22889) Six carders are kept permanently at work to produce slivers at the rate of 5 annas per 3 lb.
('46', 11, 2, 13, 22982) Professional spinners on the register of the Ashram number 193. Carders have up to now earned Rs. 795, the spinners Rs. 2,036. It is estimated that a spinner turns out from 6 to 9 lb of yarn per month enabling her to earn from Rs. 1 8 0 to Rs. 2 4 0. The count of the yarn ranges from 8 to 15 counts.
('46', 11, 2, 14, 23283) The wage to turn out 3 lb of slivers into yarn ranges between 12 annas to 14 annas.
('46', 11, 2, 15, 23367) 13 weavers belonging to the locality weave this yarn into towels, loin cloths, dhotis, shirtings, etc.

('46', 12, 1, 4, 23815) The Ashram has a branch at Pithapur where 450 wheels and 12 looms are controlled and their survey shows that 800 more wheels are awaiting work if capital can be found.

('46', 14, 2, 13, 29671) POLICE ATTENTION From the Ashram we were to go to Polavaram, 1 a village about 6 miles from Sitanagaram on the other side of the river.
('46', 14, 2, 14, 29807) We could therefore only cross by a ferry.
('46', 14, 2, 15, 29849) Polavaram is situated in an Agency area.
('46', 14, 2, 16, 29890) Agency means, I learnt, non regulation.
('46', 14, 2, 17, 29930) The police here I was told succeeded in frightening the ferry man away from the workers and he refused to carry us.

('46', 14, 2, 20, 30150) A crowded programme had preceded the morning of the visit and a crowded programme was in front of me.

('46', 14, 2, 22, 30458) The workers could get another launch to take us directly from Sitanagaram to Polavaram instead of our going by car in front of the village and then crossing the river.
('46', 14, 2, 23, 30626) I accepted the offer.
('46', 14, 2, 24, 30648) To go to the launch meant also some additional strain and time; but we successfully negotiated the visit.

('46', 15, 3, 22, 33077) 12. INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA
('46', 15, 4, 23, 33105) The office of the Agent of the Government of India in South Africa is certainly not a bed of roses.
('46', 15, 4, 24, 33205) Sir K. V. Reddi, I see from the mail letter received from South Africa, is having his hands full.
('46', 15, 4, 25, 33303) The greatest cause of anxiety so far as I can see is in connection with trade
('46', 16, 0, 1, 33381) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 17
('46', 16, 1, 2, 33423) licences in the area known as the Gold Area in the Transvaal.
('46', 16, 1, 3, 33485) The largest number of Indian traders in the Transvaal are to be found in this area and these trade licences are a matter of life and death for them.
('46', 16, 1, 4, 33634) They have built up large business in the hope of being able to have their licences renewed from year to year.
('46', 16, 1, 5, 33744) Having survived the danger in the Krugerregime of their businesses being summarily closed at any time, they have rightly or wrongly come to believe that their licences will be perpetually renewed so long as they carry on an honest trade.
('46', 16, 1, 6, 33982) I have certainly thought that the settlement of 1914 covered all these traders and their successors.
('46', 16, 1, 7, 34083) If these were not vested rights, I do not know what vested rights could be in the Transvaal for them.
('46', 16, 1, 8, 34185) But now I understand that municipalities are re fusing to issue these licences, taking cover under a section of the Gold Law.
('46', 16, 1, 9, 34311) Legally speaking, perhaps the Gold Law would prohibit Asiatics’ trading.
('46', 16, 1, 10, 34384) But that law was in existence even during the Kruger regime.
('46', 16, 1, 11, 34445) It was in existence in 1914 when this settlement was arrived at.
('46', 16, 1, 12, 34510) Therefore Sir K. V. Reddi should have no difficulty in securing protection for these traders.
('46', 16, 1, 13, 34604) The agreement which was brought about by the Habibullah deputation contemplates leveling up of the British Indian position in South Africa.
('46', 16, 1, 14, 34744) Levelling up will be a meaningless term for these traders if the only means up will be a meaningless term for these traders if the only means of earning their bread and butter is taken away from them.
('46', 16, 1, 15, 34945) It is necessary therefore for public opinion here to strengthen the hands of the Agent in South Africa and the hands of the Government of India in prosecuting the claim for the protection of these traders.
('46', 16, 1, 16, 35151) The matter is not free from difficulty I know.
('46', 16, 1, 17, 35198) There is the general election pending in South Africa.
('46', 16, 1, 18, 35253) The Union Ministers left to themselves will probably grant the protection that is so desirable.
('46', 16, 1, 19, 35349) And that should be considered as obligatory if there is to be an honourable fulfilment of the Cape pact.
('46', 16, 1, 20, 35454) But the electoral conditions in South Africa are not very different from these conditions in other parts of the world.
('46', 16, 1, 21, 35573) But however difficult the situation may be, these traders must be protected.
('46', 16, 1, 22, 35650) There is a proper, legitimate, easy way out of the difficulty apart from fresh legislation.
('46', 16, 1, 23, 35742) Law 3 of 188 of the Transvaal is still in existence.
('46', 16, 1, 24, 35795) The Gold Law does not supersede that law.
('46', 16, 1, 25, 35837) Therefore the Gold law has got to be read in conjunction with the law 3 of 1885. Now that law enables the Government to declare wards, streets and locations as proper for Indian habitation and trade.
('46', 16, 1, 26, 36037) It is open therefore to the Union Govern ment by administrative action to declare such areas where Indians are
('46', 17, 0, 1, 36148) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 17, 1, 2, 36189) now trading to be proper places for Indian trade and residence.
('46', 17, 1, 3, 36253) There are other matters equally delicate but I need not refer to them at this stage as the danger in connection with them is not imminent and as it is necessary for public opinion to be crystallized and to concentrate over this single imminent danger.

('46', 17, 3, 5, 36528) 13. ‘ALCOHOLISM OF THOUGHT’
('46', 17, 4, 6, 36556) An esteemed European friend approving of my decision in postponing the European visit that was contemplated last year makes among other things the following pregnant observations on the condition to which the European Press is reduced at the present moment: 1
('46', 17, 5, 7, 36816) You know that the first act of a modern State, when at war, is to ruin her adversary in the opinion of the rest of the world; and for that she stifles its voice, and fills the world with her own.
('46', 17, 5, 8, 37012) Yon know that the British Empire is a past master in that art, and that she is preparing by every means to blockade India, to isolate her from other nations, and to inundate those nations with her own propaganda.
('46', 17, 5, 9, 37225) It has already begun!
('46', 17, 5, 10, 37247) Last month the events in Bombay were a pretext for giving to the world the impression that India was in a state of fire and bloodshed.
('46', 17, 5, 11, 37382) Now, I have too much experience of the frightful intellectual passiveness to which the people of Europe are at present prone.
('46', 17, 5, 12, 37508) Since the first days of the War of 1914 their unhappy brains have been subjected to such a journalistic intoxication by the whole European Press that they have become incapable of refinding themselves.
('46', 17, 5, 13, 37710) It is another alcoholism, alcoholism of thought, which causes no less ravages than the other.
('46', 17, 5, 14, 37804) One can practically say that there on longer exists, in the Occident, a single free newspaper.
('46', 17, 5, 15, 37899) Notwithstanding the terrible handicap which this campaign of misrepresentation puts upon us, if we are strong in action, we may afford to disregard them and feel confident that our action, if it is true, will survive the calumny that is being spread in Europe and even in America and make itself felt.

('46', 18, 1, 2, 38303) 14. THE WAY TO DO IT
('46', 18, 2, 3, 38324) In one of the addresses received by me in Andhra Desha there occurs this passage:
('46', 18, 3, 4, 38406) We are grieved to admit that we can show nothing to our credit in the way of removal of untouchability, temperance propaganda and Hindi prachar.
('46', 18, 4, 5, 38551) request your help and guidance in suggesting to us ways and means of securing
('46', 18, 5, 6, 38629) the necessary capital and selfless workers for the above objects.
('46', 18, 5, 7, 38695) This is an admission of helplessness which it would be difficult to understand perhaps in any other part of the world.
('46', 18, 5, 8, 38814) For I am asked not merely to show how to secure the necessary capital, but also selfless workers.
('46', 18, 5, 9, 38912) The address comes from those who describe themselves “your most trusted, most humble followers, members of the Town Congress Committee”.
('46', 18, 5, 10, 39049) If I have any followers who are “trusted and humble”.
('46', 18, 5, 11, 39103) I expect them above all to be selfless.
('46', 18, 5, 12, 39143) Members of Congress Committees are unworthy to sit in a Congress Committee if they are not selfless.
('46', 18, 5, 13, 39244) Of course I know that at the present moment there is an unseemly rivalry even in Congress Committees for offices.
('46', 18, 5, 14, 39358) Yet every Congressman would admit that a Congress representative is nothing if he is not selfless.
('46', 18, 5, 15, 39457) And if the ‘salt loses it savour wherewith shall it be salted’?
('46', 18, 5, 16, 39521) If my followers and these Congress Committee members are not selfless, where shall I find selfless workers for such people?
('46', 18, 5, 17, 39645) The only way therefore I can show to my questioners about finding selfless workers is, ‘be such workers yourselves, and then I promise that the necessary capital will follow’.
('46', 18, 5, 18, 39821) Shadow invariably follows the Sun.
('46', 18, 5, 19, 39856) It is men who make money.
('46', 18, 5, 20, 39882) Money has never been known to make men.
('46', 18, 5, 21, 39922) It may give us hirelings, but hirelings will never be able to remove untouchability and do temperance propaganda and even real Hindi prachar .
('46', 18, 5, 22, 40065) Hirelings have no doubt a place in the world economy, but they come in after reform, they have never been able to initiate reform.
('46', 18, 5, 23, 40196) Congressmen have therefor to carry out the triple reform.
('46', 18, 5, 24, 40254) When untouchability has become a thing of the past, when temperance propaganda has become a popular thing and when everybody wants to learn Hindi, there will be no dearth of men who would give their services on hire and carry out the work that involves no risks.
('46', 18, 5, 25, 40517) What unfortunately I notice throughout my wanderings is that many Congressmen do not care so much for constructive work as forexcitement and work that will bring them into prominence without
('46', 19, 0, 1, 40708) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 19, 1, 2, 40749) costing them much labour, if any at all.
('46', 19, 1, 3, 40790) This mentality has to be changed before we can have a steady supply of workers.
('46', 19, 1, 4, 40870) Everywhere I am surrounded by healthy looking intelligent volunteers who spare no pains to make me comfortable and who under the impulse of service do not mind working day and night.
('46', 19, 1, 5, 41053) If they could but be induced to transfer this devotion to a person who really does not need all that volume of service and who is more often than not embarrassed by such attention, to the cause which he represents, the problem is solved.
('46', 19, 1, 6, 41291) Everywhere I am holding meetings of workers and I have found them to be enough for the work to be done if they will only apply themselves to it.
('46', 19, 1, 7, 41436) But it is these very workers who compose addresses of the type I have mentioned and who even at these quiet meetings ask me to produce money and men.
('46', 19, 1, 8, 41586) I therefore suggest to every Congress Committee to become business like and find out true workers, fix the scale of payment for them and set the constructive machinery going.
('46', 19, 1, 9, 41761) For this, Congress Sub Committees need not look for guidance to provincial bodies or to the central body.
('46', 19, 1, 10, 41867) Provincial bodies may have their provincial service or may not.
('46', 19, 1, 11, 41931) They may be too heavily encumbered to attempt any such thing.
('46', 19, 1, 12, 41993) Not so Taluka or Village Congress Committees.
('46', 19, 1, 13, 42039) They are absolutely autonomous.
('46', 19, 1, 14, 42071) There is nothing to prevent them from making collections and initiating any reform they choose.
('46', 19, 1, 15, 42167) Indeed during the interesting tour in Andhra, I have noticed that in some places efficient Committees have been doing work which other Committees have grossly neglected.
('46', 19, 1, 16, 42337) Let Congressmen not think of 1930. The first of January 1930 is not going to witness a miracle.
('46', 19, 1, 17, 42433) It would be an exact resultant of national activities during this year of grace and probation.
('46', 19, 1, 18, 42528) No sudden change will come over the nation on the first of January 1930. Let individual Congressmen therefore do their little best.
('46', 19, 1, 19, 42660) It is then possible for them to awaken the nation.
('46', 19, 1, 20, 42711) Let them not think that one individual can make no impression upon the nation or a cause.
('46', 19, 1, 21, 42801) After all causes are handled by an aggregate of individuals.
('46', 19, 1, 22, 42862) Someone has to make the beginning.
('46', 19, 1, 23, 42897) Let everyone therefore who understands the secret of success in any undertaking do his won duty unmindful of what the others do or do not do.
('46', 19, 1, 24, 43039) Let there be no shame about accepting remuneration.
('46', 19, 1, 25, 43091) A labourer is worthy of his hire.
('46', 19, 1, 26, 43125) And he is no less selfless because he accepts remuneration.
('46', 19, 1, 27, 43185) As a matter of fact, a most selfless man has to give his all to the nation—body, mind and soul.
('46', 19, 1, 28, 43281) And he has still to feed himself.
('46', 19, 1, 29, 43315) The nation gladly feeds such men and women and
('46', 20, 0, 1, 43362) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 21
('46', 20, 1, 2, 43404) yetregards them as selfless.
('46', 20, 1, 3, 43433) The difference between a voluntary worker and a hireling lies in the fact that whereas a hireling gives his service to whosoever pays the price, a national voluntry worker gives his service only to the nation for the cause he believes in and he serves it even though he might have to starve.

('46', 20, 3, 5, 43748) 15. NOTES
('46', 20, 4, 6, 43758) PANDIT SUNDERLAL’S BOOK
('46', 20, 5, 7, 43782) The U.P. Government is not satisfied with the outrageous confiscation of the copies of Pandit Sunderlal’s book History of English Rule, but it is now persecuting everyone suspected of having received a copy before the ban was declared.
('46', 20, 5, 8, 44018) Whether egged on by the U.P. Government or of its own motion, the C.P. Government has copied the U.P. Government and proclaimed the ban on the book.
('46', 20, 5, 9, 44167) The question a correspondent now puts is: what are the poor people to do who have got these books?
('46', 20, 5, 10, 44266) In my opinion it is no part of the possessor of these volumes to surrender them to the police.
('46', 20, 5, 11, 44361) There is no moral breach in possessing the volume.
('46', 20, 5, 12, 44412) And those who believe that this confiscation is a wicked act of robbery are not only not bound to assist the process of confiscation but by every legitimate means to thwart the authorities in their nefarious attempt to take possession of the books that have gone out of the publisher’s hands.
('46', 20, 5, 13, 44705) If I were a possessor of such a copy and I did not want to run the risk of a prosecution, I should burn the copy.
('46', 20, 5, 14, 44819) If I wanted to invite prosecution I would inform the police of possession of a copy and challenge them to arrest me.
('46', 20, 5, 15, 44936) If I did not wish to invite prosecution, but did not mind it if it came, I should still retain possession leaving the police to their own resources to trace the copy in my possession.
('46', 20, 5, 16, 45120) I understand that the C. P. Notification says that even the publication of extracts form the book would be considered a crime.
('46', 20, 5, 17, 45247) I hope this information is not true.
('46', 20, 5, 18, 45284) But if it is, it enables newspapers to show tangible sympathy for the author and the publisher as also to defeat the purpose of the Governments concerned by publishing extracts which can be sent by those who are in possession of the volume.
('46', 20, 5, 19, 45525) The Central Government and local Governments are providing us with opportunities for offering mild civil disobedience which those who believe in it should not hesitate to take advantage of.
('46', 21, 0, 1, 45715) 22 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 21, 1, 2, 45756) Terribly debilitating though the atmosphere is at the present moment, those who have not yet lost their nerve need not be affected by it, but they should seek every legitimate opportunity of giving hope and courage to the workers by challenging the Government to do its worst.
('46', 21, 2, 3, 46033) ABHAY ASHRAM
('46', 21, 3, 4, 46046) The readers of Young India are not unaware of this important national institution.
('46', 21, 3, 5, 46129) Its report of activities for the year 1928 has just been received.
('46', 21, 3, 6, 46196) It is a record of all round progress.
('46', 21, 3, 7, 46234) Its khadi department is its largest activity.
('46', 21, 3, 8, 46280) Here is the record of its progressively increasing sales: 1924 Rs. 21,822 1926 Rs. 1,42,960 1925 Rs. 70,620 1927 Rs. 1,42,820 1928 Rs. 1,88,091 The total wages distributed were Rs. 70,525 as under: Weavers Rs. 29,492 Spinners Rs. 30,453 Tailors Rs. 7,081 Washermen Rs. 3,494 The work is done through its 23 khadi centres which support 61 whole time workers controlled by an annually elected board.
('46', 21, 3, 9, 46678) The capital invested in this activity is Rs. 1,21,000, of which Rs. 55,000 is a loan from the All India Spinners’ Association.
('46', 21, 3, 10, 46805) It has to pay to the banks from which it has the balance of the loan a high rate of interest which amounts to Rs. 5,000 per year.
('46', 21, 3, 11, 46935) It is therefore up to the public to either pay this interest or to give loans free of interest but on the same terms as the banks advance them.
('46', 21, 3, 12, 47079) The Ashram is making experiments in dyeing and it claims now to be able “to dye fast colours of uniform shade without the use of any machine.” The report proceeds, “Our khaki which has been fast to sunlight, bleaching and perspiration, we specially recommend to our buyers.” The other activity of the Ashram is national education.
('46', 21, 3, 13, 47410) It controls 31 primary schools of which 17 are in the district of Dacca, 9 in Tippera and 5 in Bankura, serving 1,058 pupils.
('46', 21, 3, 14, 47536) It has three schools for secondary education, serving 199 students.
('46', 21, 3, 15, 47604) The total amount spent on education is Rs. 4,702 9 6. It has also a medical department with an outdoor dispensary, a hospital, a medical school and a seva samiti.
('46', 21, 3, 16, 47767) The dispensary served 3,157 patients, of which 721 were females.
('46', 21, 3, 17, 47832) The largest number of cases were naturally of malaria.
('46', 21, 3, 18, 47887) Next comes worms 277 cases and third kalazar.
('46', 21, 3, 19, 47933) The hospital has 20 beds.
('46', 21, 3, 20, 47959) 215 patients
('46', 22, 0, 1, 47972) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 23
('46', 22, 1, 2, 48014) were admitted during the year under review.
('46', 22, 1, 3, 48058) The expenses of the dispensary and hospital amounted respectively to Rs. 1,574 and 4,400. The medical school is training 20 students.
('46', 22, 1, 4, 48192) The main function of the Sevasadan is house to house collection of rice for the maintenance of poor patients in the hospital.
('46', 22, 1, 5, 48318) The Ashram is not a believer in untouchability or hereditary caste distinctions.
('46', 22, 1, 6, 48399) It does a little bit of agriculture and produced 200 maunds of paddy in 18 bighas of lands and it grew vegetables enough to last 6 months for the 50 inmates of the Ashram.
('46', 22, 1, 7, 48571) It has 6 milch cows and 10 buffaloes.
('46', 22, 1, 8, 48609) An attempt is being made to have a model diary farm at Dacca.
('46', 22, 1, 9, 48671) It has libraries at several of its centres.
('46', 22, 1, 10, 48715) The Ashram collected Rs. 37,000 for its different activities from the public.
('46', 22, 1, 11, 48793) Altogether it has received donations of one lakh and a half of rupees during the five years of its existence.
('46', 22, 1, 12, 48903) Its requirements for the next year are Rs. 50,000 for the khadi department and Rs. 50,000 for the other departments.
('46', 22, 1, 13, 49020) An institution like this should have no difficulty in obtaining necessary funds from a discerning public.
('46', 22, 2, 14, 49126) FOREIGN CLOTH BOYCOTT

('46', 22, 4, 16, 49312) COARSE KHADI

('46', 22, 5, 18, 49424) But if production of khadi is to be limitless the quality of khadi must suffer for a time.
('46', 22, 5, 19, 49515) By patient effort and instruction, A.I.S.A. has been able to show a progressive rise in the fineness and texture of khadi.
('46', 22, 5, 20, 49638) But when workers go out to raw spinners and ask them for yarn they may not dictate terms.

('46', 23, 1, 2, 50218) A.I.S.A. MEMBERSHIP
('46', 23, 2, 3, 50238) The reader will have seen a notice of the A.I.S.A. in last week’s issue of Young India announcing that it had decided to discontinue the ‘B’ class membership.
('46', 23, 2, 4, 50397) I think that this is a step in the right direction.
('46', 23, 2, 5, 50449) ‘B’ class membership was introduced only in order to conciliate somewho professed their inability to send 1,000 yards permonth of hand spun yarn.
('46', 23, 2, 6, 50595) Experience however has shown that not over many have taken advantage of ‘B’ class membership which meant spinning only 2,000 yards per year.
('46', 23, 2, 7, 50736) And when a limited power of voting for the election of members to the Council was announced, the absurdity of ‘B’ class membership became patent.
('46', 23, 2, 8, 50882) ‘A’ class members repeatedly applied for being classed as ‘B’ class members in order not to forfeit the right of voting.
('46', 23, 2, 9, 51003) The Council did not want to go back upon the rules that were framed for voting.
('46', 23, 2, 10, 51083) So the original list remained undisturbed.
('46', 23, 2, 11, 51126) But for all future occasions it was decided to have only ‘A’ class members.
('46', 23, 2, 12, 51202) And as the policy of the Spinners’ Association has been from the very commencement to have those only as members who have the fullest faith in the message of the spinning wheel, it was considered desirable to have only one class of members with stricter qualification.
('46', 23, 2, 13, 51471) This would no doubt considerably reduce the members of the Association.
('46', 23, 2, 14, 51543) But the Council has no hesitation in running the risk.
('46', 23, 2, 15, 51598) It does not show much faith in the message of the spinning wheel if members are not willing to devote even half an hour to spinning from day to day.
('46', 23, 2, 16, 51747) Apropos of this the Technical Department of the A.I.S.A. has written to the several agencies that the yarn which is sent to them as subscriptions for membership is not uniformly good.
('46', 23, 2, 17, 51931) It is packed anyhow and it is sent often without considering the cost of posting.
('46', 23, 2, 18, 52013) The note says:
('46', 23, 3, 19, 52028) In some cases to postal charges exceeded the price of the yarn sent.
('46', 23, 4, 20, 52097) one agency alone the postal charges for all the yarn received amounted to Rs.
('46', 23, 5, 21, 52175) 55, namely, 60 per cent of the price of the total yarn.
('46', 23, 5, 22, 52231) The suggestion therefore
('46', 23, 6, 23, 52256) made is that the yarn should be sent from one place in each province and it
('46', 23, 7, 24, 52332) should be by goods train.
('46', 23, 7, 25, 52358) In some cases the yarn sent was so uneven and rough that it was useless.
('46', 23, 7, 26, 52431) I have repeatedly said that where the yarn is useless, it really should not be accepted as subscription.
('46', 23, 7, 27, 52536) Yarn subscription means yarn that is weavable just as monetary subscription means money that would
('46', 24, 0, 1, 52635) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 25
('46', 24, 1, 2, 52677) be accepted in the market and not counterfeit coins.
('46', 24, 1, 3, 52730) The subscribing spinners should really know all the details about spinning and packing and this work is essentially one that the agencies should attend to.

('46', 29, 6, 22, 61209) 23. A POSER4
('46', 29, 7, 23, 61222) A young man who is an employee in a mill writes:
('46', 29, 8, 24, 61271) I am employed in the engineering department of a mill but I am sick of this business.
('46', 29, 8, 25, 61357) I have over half a dozen relations dependent upon me for support.
('46', 29, 8, 26, 61423) But not having been trained to any other profession I do not know how else I can eke out the necessary means to provide bread to them all.
('46', 29, 8, 27, 61562) My monthly requirement comes to one hundred rupees.
('46', 29, 8, 28, 61614) When I see the injustice that is daily perpetrated on the mill hands and the utter selfishness and heartlessness of the mill owners I begin to feel that service in a mill is even worse than Government service.
('46', 29, 8, 29, 61824) What would you advise me to do in the
('46', 29, 9, 30, 61862) 1 Kashi Gandhi, wife of Chhaganlal Gandhi 2 Jamnadas Gandhi 3 Ramniklal Modi 4 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan, 19 5 1929. The trans lation is by Pyarelal.
('46', 30, 0, 1, 62038) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 31
('46', 30, 1, 2, 62080) circumstances?
('46', 30, 1, 3, 62095) I am 26 years of age and have studied up to matriculation.
('46', 30, 1, 4, 62154) As an old English adage says you cannot eat your cake and have it.
('46', 30, 1, 5, 62221) Similarly you cannot leave off service in a mill and yet have your one hundred per mensem.
('46', 30, 1, 6, 62312) A close scrutiny of all highly remunerative professions in India will reveal the fact that they are almost all of them essentially products of British rule in India, and aresuch as serve in a more or less degree to sustain that rule.
('46', 30, 1, 7, 62546) A country where the average daily income per head is seven pice cannot afford to pay high salaries, for the simple reason, that it would mean so much additional burden upon the toiling millions of the land who are already well nigh crushed by their poverty.
('46', 30, 1, 8, 62804) It follows therefore that the only course for a person, who wants to escape from the system of exploitation which the mills represent, would be drastically to reduce his family budget.
('46', 30, 1, 9, 62989) This can be done in two ways: by a radical simplification of one’s life and by reducing the number of dependants that one has to support.
('46', 30, 1, 10, 63127) Every grown up, able bodied member of a family ought to be made to contribute his or her quota towards the upkeep of the family by honest industry.
('46', 30, 1, 11, 63275) We have a number of domestic crafts that can be easily learnt and practised at home without the investment of any large capital.
('46', 30, 1, 12, 63404) If he is not prepared to do any of these two things, he had better stick to the job in which he is engaged and do whatever service he can.
('46', 30, 1, 13, 63543) Let him, if he is employed in a mill, try to make a close and sympathetic study of the hardships and miseries that are a mill labourer’s lot and do whatever is possible in the circumstances to alleviate them.
('46', 30, 1, 14, 63752) Let him cultivate an exemplary purity, honesty and uprightness of conduct, and infect his fellow employees with his ideals.
('46', 30, 1, 15, 63876) If the subordinate employees are all upright in their conduct, they will thereby create a pure atmosphere which is bound to tell on their masters in the end and enable them to obtain justice from them for the mill labourers.
('46', 30, 1, 16, 64101) All action in this world has some drawback about it.
('46', 30, 1, 17, 64154) It is man’s duty and privilege to reduce it, and while living in the midst of it, to remain untouched by it as much as it is possible for him to do so.
('46', 30, 1, 18, 64306) To take an extreme instance, there can perhaps be no greater contradi ction in terms than a compassionate butcher.
('46', 30, 1, 19, 64421) And yet it is possible even for a butcher if he has any pity in him.
('46', 30, 1, 20, 64490) In fact I have actually known butchers with gentleness that one would hardly expect from them.
('46', 30, 1, 21, 64585) The celebrated episode of Kaushik the butcher in the Mahabharata is an instance in point.
('46', 30, 1, 22, 64675) It is an episode for all young men placed in a similar situation to this correspondent to carefully ponder over and digest.
('46', 30, 2, 23, 64799) Young India, 1 8 1929

('46', 31, 1, 2, 64862) 24. A MISCONCEPTION
('46', 31, 2, 3, 64882) A friend from Bombay writes: 1
('46', 31, 3, 4, 64913) I had heard this argument even before.
('46', 31, 3, 5, 64952) No physician has yet been able to provide a remedy for misconception.
('46', 31, 3, 6, 65022) Hence I have little hope that my arguments will make those caught in the love of B.A. or LL.B. to give it up.
('46', 31, 3, 7, 65132) For the benefit of those who may still have doubts, I present one or two facts.
('46', 31, 3, 8, 65212) The number of lawyers is negligible.
('46', 31, 3, 9, 65249) How many out of them serve the country?
('46', 31, 3, 10, 65289) Of those who do, how many make use of the law examination?
('46', 31, 3, 11, 65348) Gokhale was not a lawyer and yet no one has heard of anything lacking in his service.
('46', 31, 3, 12, 65434) Sir Dinshaw Wacha is not a lawyer; Dadabhai was not one, nor was Hume.
('46', 31, 4, 13, 65505) The lawyers who are in the field of public service shine not because they are lawyers, but because of some other capacity in them.
('46', 31, 5, 14, 65636) We shall find the names of only a few lawyers among the world’s great servants so far.
('46', 31, 5, 15, 65723) A country cannot be liberated through the intricacies of law.
('46', 31, 5, 16, 65785) That will require a sword made of either steel or satyagraha.
('46', 31, 5, 17, 65847) Rana Pratap, Shivaji, Nelson, Wellington, Kruger and others were not lawyers; Amanullah Khan is not a lawyer; Lenin was not a lawyer.
('46', 31, 5, 18, 65981) All of them had valour, selflessness, courage and such other qualities by reason of which they were able to serve their country.
('46', 31, 6, 19, 66110) It is not my purpose to disparage lawyers or their profession.
('46', 31, 6, 20, 66173) They have a province of their own.
('46', 31, 6, 21, 66208) Their contribution to the recent history of India is valuable.
('46', 31, 6, 22, 66271) My object here is merely to point out that in order to serve it is not necessary to be a lawyer and that in the service rendered by lawyers their legal practice played a minor part.
('46', 31, 6, 23, 66453) Moreover, to be a lawyer and to acquire a working knowledge of law are two different things.
('46', 31, 6, 24, 66546) If he so desires, every worker can acquire such knowledge of law as is necessary.
('46', 31, 6, 25, 66628) Certificates are a means of earning money, never of rendering service.
('46', 31, 7, 26, 66699) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('46', 31, 7, 27, 66736) The correspondent had said that a friend of his, studying in the senior B.A. class, though eager to serve the country, intended to take the LL.B. degree before taking up national work, believing that knowledge of law was essential for it.
('46', 31, 7, 28, 66975) How could this misconception be removed?
('46', 32, 0, 1, 67016) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 33
('46', 32, 1, 2, 67058) Finally, we need workers in thousands.
('46', 32, 1, 3, 67097) The lawyers are far too few.
('46', 32, 1, 4, 67126) The field of service is infinite.
('46', 32, 1, 5, 67160) Service is needed today; hence he who longs to serve will not engage himself even for a single moment in becoming a lawyer or taking some other degree.
('46', 32, 1, 6, 67312) He will easily gain the knowledge which he may need in the course of service.

('46', 32, 3, 8, 67427) 25. DR.

('46', 33, 9, 30, 70671) Sita is the last word in wifehood as much as it is in maidenhood.
('46', 33, 9, 31, 70737) Moreover it is my ideal to make a person lead a life of independence and purity in spite of being married.

('46', 34, 1, 7, 71363) Sati signifies freedom from passion.
('46', 34, 1, 8, 71400) Sita had two children.

('46', 34, 1, 10, 71573) It is not so today.
('46', 34, 1, 11, 71593) Now children are born as a result of passion; a person like me therefore regards begetting children as forbidden.
('46', 34, 1, 12, 71707) I am, of course, talking about the belief in regard to Sita and others; Sitashould not be regarded as a historical person but as our ideal woman.
('46', 34, 1, 13, 71853) We do not worship the historical Rama and Sita.
('46', 34, 1, 14, 71901) The Rama of history is no more now.
('46', 34, 1, 15, 71937) But the Rama to whom we attribute perfect divinity, who is God directly perceived, lives to this day.
('46', 34, 1, 16, 72039) Reciting the name of this Rama would save us; the Rama of history, who is qualified by attributes, good or bad, would not have the strength to save.

('46', 43, 26, 30, 87917) Total up to date Rs. 2,43,283 3 6. The tour has been no doubt exacting, the heat equally so.
('46', 43, 26, 31, 88010) Nevertheless it has been for me a matter of great joy to find the villagers responding in a most wonderful manner.
('46', 43, 26, 32, 88125) The rigour of the tour has been softened by the willing and unremitting attention of the volunteers, chief among whom has been Subbaramiah who gave up Government service and has ever since remained in Congress service.
('46', 43, 26, 33, 88344) But the one man who has been most responsible for my well being is Deshabhakta Konda Venkatappayya.
('46', 43, 26, 34, 88444) He has been taken to task for bringing me to Andhra at this time of the year and then making a heavy programme.
('46', 43, 26, 35, 88556) He is not wholly responsible for either.
('46', 44, 0, 1, 88597) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 45
('46', 44, 1, 2, 88639) programmehad to cover the whole of Andhra Desha.
('46', 44, 1, 3, 88688) He could not within the time allotted to him devise a less heavy programme.
('46', 44, 1, 4, 88764) The Andhra leaders did not want me to go in February.
('46', 44, 1, 5, 88818) And I was bound to give March to Burma.
('46', 44, 1, 6, 88858) It was therefore April and May for Andhra or postponement of the tour this year.
('46', 44, 1, 7, 88939) Postponements there have been many.
('46', 44, 1, 8, 88975) Any further postponement was impossible.
('46', 44, 1, 9, 89016) But no man could have made the tour less exacting than Deshabhakta.
('46', 44, 1, 10, 89084) He has worn himself out in trying to keep times, avoid noises and secure comfortable lodgings.
('46', 44, 1, 11, 89179) He is one of the gentlest of men it has been my privilege to be associated with.
('46', 44, 1, 12, 89260) But he assumed during the tour a severe and decisive tone, so unnatural for him, that the co workers beside him treated his severity as a huge joke, and his assumed rage over things going wrong, as they will do sometimes under all climes and in spite of the best of management, has broken for me the monotony of continuous motoring often along wretched roads.
('46', 44, 1, 13, 89620) I would repeat tours like this a hundred times under the supervision of a superintendent like Deshabhakta and amid a people like the Andhras.
('46', 44, 2, 14, 89762) UNIVERSAL PROVIDER Whilst writing of Deshabhakta Konda Venkatappayya I may not omit Deshoddharaka Nageshvarrao.
('46', 44, 2, 15, 89874) I have always chaffed him about making money out of a patent ointment with a sweet name.
('46', 44, 2, 16, 89963) And he has always smilingly retorted, ‘Yes, it is bad, what can I do?
('46', 44, 2, 17, 90033) I try to serve my country with the money I get from it.
('46', 44, 2, 18, 90089) And it is an inoffensive ointment.’ I have attended to the explanation with the same indifference with which I have joked about the patent ointment.
('46', 44, 2, 19, 90238) I was therefore not prepared for the agreeable discovery I have made during the tour that his depot has enabled him to become the universal provider for the many public activities of Andhra.
('46', 44, 2, 20, 90429) Never has a deserving beggar been turned away from his hospitable door.
('46', 44, 2, 21, 90501) Wherever I have gone the addresses have made mention of his charities.
('46', 44, 2, 22, 90572) If it is the Anand Ashram for the untouchables Nageshvarrao builds the substantial block of buildings for it; if it is a school that has needed assistance Nageshvarrao has been the helper; if it is Dr. Subrahmanian who wants a printery for his Ashram, it is again Nageshvarrao who comes to the rescue.
('46', 44, 2, 23, 90874) He is never so happy as when he is giving.
('46', 44, 2, 24, 90917) And so far as I have been able to understand, his left hand knoweth not what his right giveth.
('46', 44, 2, 25, 91012) I do not wonder that a public worker remarked during the tour, in answer to my joke about the‘patent loot’, “I wish he would be able to loot much more than he
('46', 45, 0, 1, 91171) 46 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 45, 1, 2, 91212) It will then all be used to help public activities.” I have been secretly criticizing the Andhra lavishness of titles on national workers.
('46', 45, 1, 3, 91351) But this Deshoddharaka has reconciled me to the title he had deservedly earned.
('46', 45, 1, 4, 91431) But I must pass on.
('46', 45, 2, 5, 91451) A REMARKABLE ADDRESS
('46', 45, 3, 6, 91472) I must leave several important matters for the next issue.
('46', 45, 3, 7, 91531) I propose to close these hurried notes, written against post time, with the mention of a remarkable address received at Ullavapadu in Nellore district.
('46', 45, 3, 8, 91683) It was in Telugu and Hindi, both written on ordinary thick paper with an ornamental border by a local artist such as could be produced in a little village.
('46', 45, 3, 9, 91839) The language of the Hindi address was what I should call standard Hindi without any attempt at Sanskritizing or Persianizing it.
('46', 45, 3, 10, 91968) It was written in the language one hears spoken in the U.P. by those who have not developed anti Hindi or anti Muslim prejudices.
('46', 45, 3, 11, 92098) The opening paragraph has mere courteous reference to my visit but contains no rhetoric or flowery adjectives.
('46', 45, 3, 12, 92209) Here is a translation of the body of the address: 1
('46', 45, 4, 13, 92261) In accordance with your instructions in Young India we beg to lay before
('46', 45, 5, 14, 92334) you as fully as we can the information asked for by you, in the hope that after
('46', 45, 6, 15, 92414) perusing it you will vouchsafe to us such guidance as may be warranted by the
('46', 45, 7, 16, 92492) peculiar circumstances of our village.
('46', 45, 8, 17, 92531) The greatest hardship that the people here have to suffer is from scarcity of drinking water.
('46', 45, 8, 18, 92625) This village has got a temple of Vishnu as also a dharmshala.
('46', 45, 8, 19, 92687) At the latter free meals are given to sadhus and Brahmins.
('46', 45, 9, 20, 92746) There are 897 members of the ‘depressed classes’ in this village.
('46', 45, 9, 21, 92812) They dwell outside the village in a special location and are divided into two sections.
('46', 45, 9, 22, 92900) Those two sections, while not observing untouchability as among themselves, do not inter dine.
('46', 45, 9, 23, 92995) Nor will one section allow the other the useof its wells.
('46', 45, 9, 24, 93053) They eat carrion even when animals have died of infectious disease with the result that leprosy is very prevalent among them, particularly in the Malang caste.
('46', 45, 9, 25, 93213) They are also very much addicted to the liquor habit.
('46', 45, 9, 26, 93267) There is no Congress Committee in this village.
('46', 45, 10, 27, 93315) There is no branch of the A.I.S.A. here.
('46', 45, 10, 28, 93356) There are 52 spinning wheels in this village of which 22 are working.
('46', 45, 10, 29, 93426) They are worked mostly in spare time.
('46', 45, 10, 30, 93464) The monthly aggregate outturn of yarn from these wheels is 10 seers.
('46', 45, 10, 31, 93533) The average monthly earnings per head come to Rs. 2. The count of yarn spun is from 20 to 25.
('46', 45, 11, 32, 93627) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('46', 46, 0, 1, 93664) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 47
('46', 46, 1, 2, 93706) There are 65 looms in this village.
('46', 46, 1, 3, 93742) Twenty six of these are ordinary pit
('46', 46, 2, 4, 93779) 12 of these use both mill yarn and hand spun yarn, 14 use mill yarn
('46', 46, 3, 5, 93847) The rest are fly shuttle looms.
('46', 46, 3, 6, 93879) None of these use hand spun yarn.
('46', 46, 4, 7, 93913) There is in this village a library and reading room.
('46', 46, 4, 8, 93966) It was established

THE NEED OF THE HOUR The Nellore District Congress Committee presented me during my tour in that district with the following illuminating statement 1 about its conditions: What is true of Nellore is, I am sorry to have to say, true of most Committees with which I have come in touch.
('46', 47, 3, 6, 96133) I share the opinion expressed by the Nellore Committee that the entry of Congressmen into the so called elective bodies has disorganized and demoralized the Congress.

('46', 47, 3, 8, 96498) Somehow or other constructive work and Councils do not seem to go together.
('46', 47, 3, 9, 96574) Those who are in the Councils and local boards have little taste or aptitude for constructive work, and those who are doing the latter have little or no taste for the elective bodies.
('46', 47, 3, 10, 96758) Both however profess faith in the constructive programme if their votes and their speeches are proofof that faith.
('46', 47, 3, 11, 96873) A device therefore should be possible whereby the Congress machinery may be worked at full speed and efficiently.
('46', 47, 3, 12, 96987) The A.I.C.C. should really tackle that problem to the exclusion of everything else if such exclusion becomes necessary.
('46', 47, 3, 13, 97107) I hear a great deal about the treasure chests of local committees being empty.
('46', 47, 3, 14, 97186) Those who speak thus do not realize that the constitution has provided automatic machinery for Congress finance.
('46', 47, 3, 15, 97299) If it becomes really a people’s institution, it need never be in want.
('46', 47, 3, 16, 97370) Nellore district alone had ten thousand members in 1921. No provincial Committee should have fewer than thirty thousand members.
('46', 47, 3, 17, 97499) That means a steady annual income of Rs. 7,500 enough for smoothly running a provincial organization.
('46', 47, 3, 18, 97601) And an organization that commands such membership should always be able to raise contributions for special purposes.
('46', 47, 3, 19, 97718) An honestly worked Congress organization should surely have on its roll

('46', 50, 1, 2, 101564) 44. INTERVIEW TO “THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE”
('46', 50, 2, 3, 101604) May 24, 1929
('46', 50, 3, 4, 101617) Had a time not come when the boycott would be made more effective by devising a definite plan of vigorous action?
('46', 50, 4, 5, 101731) Mahatmaji said everything that was possible was being done by the Foreign Cloth Boycott Committee and all that he could suggest at the present moment was that the people who believed in this movement and wanted to assist it should strengthen the hands of the Committee by carrying out its instructions from time to time.
('46', 50, 4, 6, 102052) Our representative suggested the formation of special boycott committees in which the Congress workers and also the mill owners could work together on the basis of co operation.
('46', 50, 4, 7, 102230) He did not think he could carry things further at the present stage.
('46', 50, 4, 8, 102299) Would the boycott not be materially advanced if the F.C.B. Committee were to co operate with other agencies which were also working for the boycott in their own ways?
('46', 50, 4, 9, 102466) Replying to this question Mahatmaji gave an assurance on behalf of the F.C.B. Committee that whatever assistance could be secured from other sources was being applied for and would be applied for in future.
('46', 50, 4, 10, 102673) Would a pledge embodying a solemn vow that the signatory would use swadeshi articles alone in any way accelerate the progress of the boycott movement?
('46', 50, 4, 11, 102824) He did not think, he said, that any pledge was necessary for popularizing the boycott movement.
('46', 50, 4, 12, 102920) He added that the question of pledge was considered by the F.C.B. Committee.
('46', 50, 4, 13, 102997) It was not pledge, he said, that was wanted but actual and immediate actions.
('46', 50, 4, 14, 103075) Asked whether bonfires should be restarted on a larger scale and in an organized manner, Mahatmaji replied that it was much better for the time being to carry on this propaganda in the way it was being carried on by the F.C.B. Committee.
('46', 50, 4, 15, 103313) Since our eyes are fixed on the coming battle that we are to begin in January next and since the problem of creating effective sanctions behind our national demand is staring us in the face, is it a wise policy that our energies should be frittered away over minor issues such as the acceptance of offices by Congressmen?
('46', 50, 4, 16, 103635) Mahatmaji’s prompt reply to this question was his usual diplomatic laughter followed by a still more diplomatic remark that it was a question which he was incompetent to answer.
('46', 50, 4, 17, 103813) Was it not a fact that he was acting as a mediator to bring about a reconciliation between the divergent views that had made themselves manifest within the Congress camp?
('46', 50, 4, 18, 103984) A loud laughter again came as a reply.
('46', 50, 4, 19, 104023) You have had enough.
('46', 50, 4, 20, 104044) You are now trying to pump out something from me which I am not prepared to give.

('46', 51, 7, 13, 104822) 46. SPEECH AND RESOLUTION AT A.I.C.C. MEETING
('46', 51, 8, 14, 104868) BOMBAY, May 25, 1929
('46', 51, 9, 15, 104889) In view of the campaign of repression which the British Government is carrying on all over the country, as evidenced by the conviction of Sjt.
('46', 51, 9, 16, 105032) Sambamoorthi, member of the Working Committee, and many other national workers, the wholesale arrests and barbarous treatment of the members of the All India Congress Committee and the labour leaders and workers now awaiting trial at Meerut, the unwarranted house searches and wanton confiscation of Pandit Sunderlal’s History of British Rule, the All India Congress Committee is of opinion that the nation should be prepared for efficient resistance to such methods; and as it is clear that no nation wide resistance is possible unless the whole Congress organization is reconstructed on a satisfactory basis, this Committee, therefore, calls upon the provincial organizations to reorganize their respective provinces so as to fulfil the following requirements: The Provincial Congress organization shall have not less than _ per cent of the total population of their province as original members, and not less than 50 per cent of the districts represented by it.

('46', 56, 3, 6, 114457) 52. LETTER TO V. G. DESAI
('46', 56, 4, 7, 114483) May 28, 1929
('46', 56, 5, 8, 114496) BHAISHRI VALJI, I have your postcard.
('46', 56, 5, 9, 114534) When I wrote I had you in mind.
('46', 56, 5, 10, 114566) Let me state what I expect from you if your health permits: (1) visiting every goshala and its management in India and carrying our message to them; (2) a general idea about dairies and tanneries to carry out this work; (3) a rough account in Gujarati of the dairies, etc., in Denmark and other countries which are models in this respect; (4) an article of practical value on this subject every week in Navajivan and Young India; (5) visiting slaughter houses and giving harrowing descriptions of them.
('46', 56, 5, 11, 115069) This is all I can think of at the moment.
('46', 56, 5, 12, 115111) On reaching there I shall give further thought to the question of accepting the yarn spun by me in lieu of subscription.
('46', 56, 5, 13, 115232) You may write in Navajivan about the sale of our milk.
('46', 56, 5, 14, 115287) We may take up the responsibility of managing the Vinchhiya Pinjrapole if we have someone who can take care of it and if we are allowed complete freedom.
('46', 56, 5, 15, 115441) I am surprised to learn about the jacket for Jodanikosh.
('46', 56, 5, 16, 115498) Now on I shall write in Navajivan about Rameshwardas’s money.

('46', 57, 7, 24, 116688) 54. FROM AND ABOUT SAROJINI DEVI
('46', 57, 8, 25, 116721) The latest letter from India’s non official ambassador in the West reads: 1
('46', 57, 9, 26, 116797) I have had since I last wrote to you one month of strenuous and
('46', 57, 10, 27, 116861) continual travelling across many thousand miles of country from Chicago to
('46', 57, 11, 28, 116936) Los Angeles and back through the wheat, copper, oil, cattle and cotton
('46', 57, 12, 29, 117007) countries, a vast area that bears testimony to the triumph of man over Nature,
('46', 57, 13, 30, 117086) of his courage, enterprise, endurance, resource, industry and vision that could
('46', 57, 14, 31, 117166) coax or compel such rich results in such a short period.
('46', 57, 14, 32, 117223) And yet, all the power
('46', 57, 15, 33, 117246) of man becomes no more than a feather or a ball of thistle puff in the presence
('46', 57, 16, 34, 117326) of Nature in the Grand Canyon of the Arizona Desert where time itself has
('46', 57, 17, 35, 117400) sculptured magnificent temples to the unknown God out of rocks that are dyed
('46', 57, 18, 36, 117477) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('46', 58, 0, 1, 117514) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 59
('46', 58, 1, 2, 117556) in all the colours of jewels and flowers.
('46', 58, 1, 3, 117598) Song itself is transmuted into silence
('46', 58, 2, 4, 117637) and silence is translated into worship in the midst of such awe inspiring beauty
('46', 58, 3, 5, 117718) and splendour.
('46', 58, 4, 6, 117733) The Arizona Desert is the home of many Red Indian tribes, who live their own picturesque and primitive lives, so strangely aloof and alone in the land that was once their ancestral heritage.
('46', 58, 4, 7, 117924) They are more akin to us than to the foreign Western peoples who have taken away that heritage.
('46', 58, 4, 8, 118020) There is a freemasonry that binds all primitive world races in a common bond, for the folk spirit, whether in India, Roumania, Zululand or the Arizona Desert expresses itself very much in the same symbols and reveals very much the same primal virtues through the folk music, folklore and folk dance.
('46', 58, 4, 9, 118320) Valour, I think, is one of the primal keyvirtues and nowhere does it find more stirring expression than in the dances I saw of the Hopi tribe on the edge of the Grand Canyon, the Eagle Dance, the Dance of the Buffalo Hunt and the Victory Dance.
('46', 58, 4, 10, 118565) You will be very much interested in what a proud young representative of an Indian tribe said to me at the conclusion of an address I gave in San Francisco.
('46', 58, 4, 11, 118722) He was obviously well educated and may have been a graduate of one of the Universities.
('46', 58, 4, 12, 118810) ‘Thank you for your inspiring talk about your country.
('46', 58, 4, 13, 118865) This country once belonged to me and my people.
('46', 58, 4, 14, 118913) We are dying out, but they may kill us, they can never conquer us.’ Yes, these desert children are children of the
('46', 58, 5, 15, 119028) Eagle and the Wind and Thunder.
('46', 58, 5, 16, 119060) Who can conquer their spirit?
('46', 58, 5, 17, 119090) I felt the truth of the proud boast when I went to Arizona.
('46', 58, 6, 18, 119150) California I loved, every flowering rood and foam kissed acre of that lovely land.
('46', 58, 6, 19, 119233) But one sorrow made a cloud for me in that horizon of dazzlingsunshine—the unhappy plight of the Indian settlers who after twenty or thirty years of prosperous labours on their own farm lands have by the recent immigration laws been deprived of all right to land and citizenship.
('46', 58, 6, 20, 119513) I have come to the conclusion after my visits to Africa and America that the status of Indian settlers can never be satisfactory anywhere till the status of India is definitely assured among the free nations of the world.
('46', 58, 6, 21, 119735) You are aware of my inveterate habit of studying the human document in all its phases and there is no record, plain or cryptic, that does not interest me and which I do not try to interpret and understand.
('46', 58, 6, 22, 119941) In the course of my travel, I sample not only every kind of climate and scenery but also every type of humanity.
('46', 58, 7, 23, 120054) This week I received belated reports of all events and incidents, I was almost going to say accidents, of the great National week in Calcutta.
('46', 58, 7, 24, 120197) Padmaja’s little word pictures were more vivid and illuminating than all the journalistic descriptions.
('46', 58, 7, 25, 120301) She writes, ‘The little Wizard has lost none of his
('46', 59, 0, 1, 120353) 60 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 59, 1, 2, 120394) ancient magic.’ But the supreme, the final, magic still awaits expression and fulfilment in a true and fruitful formula for Hindu Muslim friendship and unity of vision and action which alone can redeem India from her intricate sevenfold bondage.
('46', 59, 2, 3, 120640) Hearken to the entreaty of a Wandering Singer, O little Wizard.
('46', 59, 2, 4, 120704) Find the
('46', 59, 3, 5, 120713) formula, work the magic and help to ensure the realization of the wondrous
('46', 59, 4, 6, 120788) dream of a liberated India.
('46', 59, 4, 7, 120816) Good bye.
('46', 59, 4, 8, 120826) This letter is dated at Kansas city, 11th Feb., and would have been before the reader earlier but for my Andhra tour.
('46', 59, 4, 9, 120944) I have removed from previous letters all personal references.
('46', 59, 4, 10, 121006) But I dare not remove the reference in this letter.
('46', 59, 4, 11, 121058) It demonstrates Sarojinidevi’s passion for Hindu Muslim union.
('46', 59, 4, 12, 121121) How I wish I could realize her hope.
('46', 59, 4, 13, 121158) But the wizard has lost his wand.
('46', 59, 4, 14, 121192) He feels helpless though his passion for heart union is no less than hers and though his faith in the midst of ‘the encircling gloom’ is brighter than ever.
('46', 59, 4, 15, 121349) It seems however that Satan’s spell is not yet broken and mad fury must for a while take its own course before exhaustion overtakes it and it is self destroyed.
('46', 59, 4, 16, 121510) Turning however from this self musing, and returning to the songstress, it gives me joy to quote the following from Dinabandhu Andrews’s letter: 1
('46', 59, 5, 17, 121657) Sarojini Naidu’s visit has been amazing.
('46', 59, 5, 18, 121698) She has won all hearts, and I have been hearing nothing but praise about her visit everywhere I have gone, both in Canada and in the United States.
('46', 59, 5, 19, 121846) She must certainlycome back again and again.
('46', 59, 5, 20, 121891) For she has won the heart of the West, and they will never forget her.
('46', 59, 5, 21, 121962) Friendship such as she has won must never be lost.
('46', 59, 5, 22, 122013) Those who know Quebec best tell me that the next time she comes she will have a much warmer reception (if that were possible!) even than that which was given her on her present visit.
('46', 59, 5, 23, 122197) For she will start with a strong group of earnest friends eager to help her in every part of the country.
('46', 59, 6, 24, 122303) Young India, 30 5 1929
('46', 59, 7, 25, 122326) 55. APATHY OF MERCHANTS
('46', 59, 8, 26, 122350) Here is an extract from an argued address received during the Andhra tour.
('46', 59, 8, 27, 122425) Speaking of khadi it says:
('46', 59, 9, 28, 122452) If we had been able to enlist the unstinted support of the merchant
('46', 59, 10, 29, 122520) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('46', 60, 0, 1, 122557) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 61
('46', 60, 1, 2, 122599) community, we would have been able to put the constructive programme about khadi in full swing and set an example for the rest of our district to follow.
('46', 60, 1, 3, 122753) But sad to say it was otherwise.
('46', 60, 1, 4, 122786) A spirit of apathy has permeated the major portion of this district.
('46', 60, 1, 5, 122855) The remark made in the address is unfortunately true of almost every place in India.
('46', 60, 1, 6, 122940) Indeed when the mercantile community is converted to the national cause, we shall not be long attaining our goal.
('46', 60, 1, 7, 123054) As I have so often remarked it is the merchants who lost India to a foreign Government and it is they who can regain it.
('46', 60, 1, 8, 123175) They are after all the largest co operators with the Government.
('46', 60, 1, 9, 123240) And amongst these, piecegoods merchants take the foremost place.
('46', 60, 1, 10, 123305) It is really therefore a matter for every village Congress Committee to tackle this problem.
('46', 60, 1, 11, 123398) If these committees would enlist the co operation of these merchants, they must reason with them, show to them the folly of trading in foreign cloth.
('46', 60, 1, 12, 123548) I have no doubt that in many places success would attend such effort.
('46', 60, 1, 13, 123618) The work has to be of a twofold character, to persuade the foreigncloth trader as also the customer.
('46', 60, 1, 14, 123719) What I however find is absence of originality amongst Congress workers.
('46', 60, 1, 15, 123791) They are satisfied with enrolling a few members and going to sleep.
('46', 60, 1, 16, 123859) Even in canvassing original members, they, as a rule, go to those who can read and write or those who belong to the same caste or class, instead of taking the Congress message to every grown up man and woman.
('46', 60, 1, 17, 124068) For instance, I have now made it a rule instead of doing my own shave to send for a khadi clad barber.
('46', 60, 1, 18, 124171) It has meant peaceful propaganda.
('46', 60, 1, 19, 124205) Congressmen stare at me and are at their wit’s end to know where tofind a khadi clad barber.
('46', 60, 1, 20, 124298) They do not even realize that to procure a khadi clad barber is the easiest thing in the world especially in villages.
('46', 60, 1, 21, 124417) He would willingly wear khadi, if it is supplied to him cheap or even gratis.
('46', 60, 1, 22, 124495) He requires nothing but a small dhoti.
('46', 60, 1, 23, 124534) Happily he had never worn trousers, jackets, long turbans, etc.
('46', 60, 1, 24, 124598) His usual costume is a small dhoti.
('46', 60, 1, 25, 124634) And if Congressmen were to insist upon having a khadi clad barber for service, barbers will immediately realize that a class of customers has come into being which requires them to wear khadi and they will not make any ado about wearing it.
('46', 60, 1, 26, 124875) Add to this little bit of fellow feeling and therefore a lesson to the barber on what khadi means, and you have a convert to khadi.
('46', 60, 1, 27, 125007) Among my audience in Andhra villages it is difficult to distinguish between khadi clad men and men wearing foreign cloth, for the simple reason that both wear coarse cloth and when their
('46', 61, 0, 1, 125194) 62 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 61, 1, 2, 125235) simple dhotis have seen a fair amount of wear and tear, from a distance khadi is indistinguishable from foreign cloth.
('46', 61, 1, 3, 125354) There is therefore no difficulty that one finds with townspeople about fine khadi.
('46', 61, 1, 4, 125437) All that is necessary in the villages is honest propaganda and proper organization for khadi production.
('46', 61, 1, 5, 125542) And it is the villages after all that absorb crores worth of foreign cloth.
('46', 61, 1, 6, 125618) Therefore when the double propaganda amongst the merchants and amongst the customers is carried on systematically, persistently and honestly, there should be no difficulty in achieving boycott of foreign cloth and replacing it with khadi, which can be manufactured almost in every village.
('46', 61, 2, 7, 125908) Young India, 30 5 1929
('46', 61, 3, 8, 125931) 56. NATIONAL ORGANIZATION
('46', 61, 4, 9, 125957) For the assistance of Congressmen I quote the working resolution 1 of the A.I.C.C. in full: The substance of this resolution is that before the end of August next there should be on the Congress register at least 7_ lakhs of men and women who have received the message of the Congress and who have accepted the Congress creed and that they should be from all the parts of India including villages.
('46', 61, 4, 10, 126355) This is one eighth of what I had originally intended.
('46', 61, 4, 11, 126409) It is also one eighth of the number of electors registered as qualified to vote for members for the legislatures.
('46', 61, 4, 12, 126523) Moreover Indian States, non regulation tracts, Burma and Frontier provinces are excluded.
('46', 61, 4, 13, 126613) Every amendment in the shape of making the burden light was accepted.
('46', 61, 4, 14, 126683) The resolution was enthusiastically passed.
('46', 61, 4, 15, 126727) If the members were earnest the resolution ought to be carried out long before the time limit is reached.
('46', 61, 4, 16, 126833) If it is honestly worked, we should have as in 1921 an actively working organization responding to the demands that may be made upon it from time to time.
('46', 61, 4, 17, 126988) This necessary if the special committees regarding three boycotts, i.e., Foreign Cloth, Liquor and Untouchability, are to be well organized.
('46', 61, 4, 18, 127129) The question of the khadi franchise was raised.

('46', 62, 1, 2, 127459) Congress member.
('46', 62, 1, 3, 127476) Many including Government spies have thus found themselves on the Congress register.
('46', 62, 1, 4, 127561) But at the time of voting at Congress meetings these have to be habitual wearers of khadi.
('46', 62, 1, 5, 127652) This clause may be a hindrance to the proper running of the Congress machinery but not to setting it up.
('46', 62, 1, 6, 127757) Whether the clause should or should not be removed from the constitution is a question which may be specially re examined by the Congress and debated on merits.

('46', 62, 3, 17, 129269) 57. PROGRESS OF F.C.B1.
('46', 62, 4, 18, 129293) The F.C.B. Committee presented the A.I.C.C. at its meeting last week with a report of its work which, I hope, everyone interested in the movement will secure from the Secretary, Congress House, Bombay.
('46', 62, 4, 19, 129495) I would advise correspondents to send oneanna stamp for postage.
