('46', 62, 4, 21, 129613) Satisfactory as the
('46', 62, 5, 22, 129633) 1 Foreign Cloth Boycott
('46', 63, 0, 1, 129657) 64 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 63, 1, 2, 129698) progress may be considered, it would have been far more so, if we had a responsive Congress organization working full speed.
('46', 63, 1, 3, 129823) Municipalities and local bodies are slowly moving in reply to Sjt.
('46', 63, 1, 4, 129890) Jairamdas’s appeal.
('46', 63, 1, 5, 129910) Not more than thirty have as yet sent in their replies.
('46', 63, 1, 6, 129966) Every local body that has been captured by the Congress should surely carry out the boycott resolution.
('46', 63, 1, 7, 130070) Meagre as the response from organized public bodies has been, the movement has already made itself felt.
('46', 63, 1, 8, 130175) From the many extracts quoted in the report I take the following from a speech of Mr. J.C. Roberts, president of the Delhi Piecegoods Association:
('46', 63, 2, 9, 130322) Another disturbing factor which was causing no little anxiety to the commercial community was the present unstable political situation in the country and its off shoot in the shape of the threatened movement for the boycott of foreign cloth.
('46', 63, 2, 10, 130564) Manufacturing centres were also not free from the effect of the present depression in India and by reports from home it was seen that about one third of the total textile mills in Great Britain had to be closed down on account of absence of demand from India and the failure of the Indian buyer to take froward contracts....Matters were going from bad to worse and the future looked rather gloomy and uncertain.
('46', 63, 3, 11, 130976) The propaganda has produced a marked effect on the sales of khadi which show a rise upon last year for the same period of 50%.
('46', 63, 3, 12, 131103) But says Tattersall regarding Calcutta:
('46', 63, 4, 13, 131143) There have been indications of more demand in piecegoods.
('46', 63, 4, 14, 131201) With regard to India there are more signs of Calcutta being in need of bigger supplies especially in dhotis and rather freer buying taken place.
('46', 63, 5, 15, 131346) Upon this the report says:
('46', 63, 6, 16, 131373) Calcutta imported last year 2,821 lakhs of rupees worth of foreign cloth out of a total of Rs. 6,516 lakhs for the whole country.
('46', 63, 6, 17, 131503) Its share came to 43 per cent.
('46', 63, 6, 18, 131534) It is thus the chief port of entry of foreign cloth.
('46', 63, 6, 19, 131587) This fact only increases the significance of the above comment.
('46', 63, 6, 20, 131651) Let Calcutta Congressmen take note of the warning.
('46', 63, 6, 21, 131702) Many people seem to fear that presently there will be no khadi on the market and that then we shall be as before at the mercy of the indigenous mills with the danger of being once more bamboozled and fooled into taking foreign cloth in the guise of Indian mill made cloth or at least paying exorbitant prices.
('46', 63, 6, 22, 132012) The danger is real if we will not devote our time to producing khadi in all the ways open to us.
('46', 63, 6, 23, 132109) The ways are: 1. Spinning for self,
('46', 64, 0, 1, 132145) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 65
('46', 64, 1, 2, 132187) 2. Spinning for hire, and 3. Spinning for sacrifice.
('46', 64, 1, 3, 132240) The first is the most important, universal and never failing once it is organized.
('46', 64, 1, 4, 132323) Time for effective propaganda in this direction has only just been reached.
('46', 64, 1, 5, 132399) Satis Chandra Das Gupta of Khadi Pratishthan has realized this and is organizing it on a large scale.
('46', 64, 1, 6, 132501) It is the cheapest method of khadi production, for it does away with the bother of having to find a market for the production.
('46', 64, 1, 7, 132628) The second is spinning for hire for which there is great scope.
('46', 64, 1, 8, 132692) But this needs capital for stocking cotton and organizing sales.
('46', 64, 1, 9, 132757) But of course it also taxes out business capacity, makes us resourceful and enables us to build up a vast organization and find honourable employment for the middle class people.
('46', 64, 1, 10, 132936) The third method is noble but can be taken up only by a select class.
('46', 64, 1, 11, 133006) If the nation realized the necessity of sacrifice, it could be a means of producing an unlimited quantity of yarn.
('46', 64, 1, 12, 133121) All the schools conducted by municipalities can give us yarn to clothe lakhs of people.
('46', 64, 1, 13, 133209) City dwellers giving half an hour per day to the wheel can give at least 100 yards of good yarn.
('46', 64, 1, 14, 133306) Let no one thoughtlessly retort that they can better employ their half hour than by merely spinning yarn.
('46', 64, 1, 15, 133412) A banker finding himself stranded in a waterless desert cannot better employ his hours than by collecting fresh water.
('46', 64, 1, 16, 133531) An India bent upon achieving boycott of foreign cloth during this year cannot better employ the time of even the best of her inhabitants than in spinning yarn till that boycott is achieved.
('46', 64, 1, 17, 133721) We do not see this simple obvious truth because we do not feel the necessity of this boycott.
('46', 64, 1, 18, 133815) At nay rate all the three methods are being tried and there is no danger of khadi famine if all of us would work at them to the best of our ability.
('46', 64, 2, 19, 133964) Young India, 30 5 1929

As I said at my farewell speech at Adoni, of all my many tours, this has been the longest and the most intensive I have yet had in any single province, and the subscriptions too, so far as I recollect, the largest yet collected in any single province save of course during the year 1921. I entered Andhra Desha on 6th April and left it on 21st May making exactly 45 days.
('46', 66, 1, 5, 137067) In that period 319 villages were actually traversed, Guntur and East Krishna leading with 52 each and East Godavari 50, West Godavari 48. I hope next week to publish a consolidated statement that is being prepared for me by the Deshabhakta and Sjt.
('46', 66, 1, 6, 137316) Narayanmurti who has indeed been preparing the weekly lists.
('46', 66, 2, 7, 137377) ITS LESSON
('46', 66, 3, 8, 137388) The tour has been a perfect study for me.
('46', 66, 3, 9, 137430) Andhra has limitless possibilities for khadi production.
('46', 66, 3, 10, 137487) It can be easily organized for other Congress work.
('46', 66, 3, 11, 137539) There are workers but they need to be drilled, they need strong and yet sympathetic leadership.
('46', 66, 3, 12, 137635) There is the spirit of sacrifice.
('46', 66, 3, 13, 137669) But the workers do not know what to do and how to do it.
('46', 66, 3, 14, 137726) Dissensions divide them.
('46', 66, 3, 15, 137751) Different and often conflicting programmes and policies confound them.
('46', 66, 3, 16, 137822) Khadi is slowly but surely binding them and putting them under discipline.
('46', 66, 3, 17, 137897) I am hoping much from the conference I am having with the workers who have followed me to Sabarmati.
('46', 66, 4, 18, 137998) A TIP TO ORGANIZERS
('46', 66, 5, 19, 138018) I may draw the attention of workers to the moving platform which I may claim to have discovered.
('46', 66, 5, 20, 138115) It is not a discovery of intelligence but of necessity, which is the mother of most inventions and discoveries.
('46', 66, 5, 21, 138227) I have a weak body which objects strongly to rise and sit to dictation.
('46', 66, 5, 22, 138299) To get off cars and push, through admiring and shouting crowds, mount platforms sometimes threatening to give way and at times making good the threat, to dismount, push again through more pressing crowds and with difficulty to remount the car and finally to sink in the seat to be again called upon fifteen minutes after
('46', 67, 0, 1, 138620) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 67, 1, 2, 138661) to go through the same ceremony is more than my body would now undertake.
('46', 67, 1, 3, 138735) I therefore suggested to my head gaoler that the car should be brought to the centre and should serve as platform.
('46', 67, 1, 4, 138850) I should sit on the edge of the back of the car and address meetings therefrom.
('46', 67, 1, 5, 138930) He readily agreed.
('46', 67, 1, 6, 138949) The contrivance saved time, energy, space and money.
('46', 67, 1, 7, 139002) No platform, no chairs, no decorations, save the decorated hearts of the people.
('46', 67, 1, 8, 139083) The arrangement proved to be perfect.
('46', 67, 1, 9, 139121) And where many meetings have to be addressed, I suggest it for adoption by organizers.
('46', 67, 2, 10, 139208) KHADI CLAD BARBER
('46', 67, 3, 11, 139226) Generally I do my own shaving.
('46', 67, 3, 12, 139257) This time I discarded the safety set given by a friend and returned to an old Bihari razor left by Maganlal Gandhi.
('46', 67, 3, 13, 139373) It is a first class instrument, if it is kept properly.
('46', 67, 3, 14, 139429) I have not yet mastered the art of using the stone and the strop which our barbers use with ease and native skill.
('46', 67, 3, 15, 139544) I therefore sent for a khadi clad barber at an early stage of the tour.
('46', 67, 3, 16, 139616) It is the easiest thing in Andhra to procure a khadi clad barber; it is difficult in , say, Bombay.
('46', 67, 3, 17, 139716) I gave him my tackle and had a luxurious shave.
('46', 67, 3, 18, 139764) I saw that thus to secure a khadi clad barber was good khadi propaganda for the chairman of the Foreign Cloth Boycott Committee.
('46', 67, 3, 19, 139893) It gave me an opportunity of preaching the message of Daridranarayana to a class than whom one cannot imagine better propaganda agents.
('46', 67, 3, 20, 140029) But I saw that if I got the barber to use my tackle, I could not carry the message of full swadeshi to him nor give him a lesson in sanitary hygiene.
('46', 67, 3, 21, 140179) Next time therefore I allowed the barber to use his own instruments, which had to be first washed and cleaned.
('46', 67, 3, 22, 140290) At one place a khadi clad barber was produced with the latest razor from the West, a Western shaving soapstick, a Western brush, a Western looking glass, etc., nicely packed in a Western box.
('46', 67, 3, 23, 140482) I have suspicions that all this belonged to my khadi clad generous host.
('46', 67, 3, 24, 140555) I realized the falsity of the situation.
('46', 67, 3, 25, 140596) I had now to see that the instruments the barber brought were swadeshi so far as possible.
('46', 67, 3, 26, 140687) Here then is another tip for workers.
('46', 67, 3, 27, 140725) Let them carry the message of swadeshi to their barbers, washermen and others with whom they come in daily contact.
('46', 67, 3, 28, 140841) Let us not treat them as illiterate dependents unworthy of our notice.
('46', 67, 3, 29, 140912) Let us treat them as fellow citizens whose services are as necessary for the advancement of the nation as those of the tallest among us.
('46', 67, 3, 30, 141049) There was another lesson this barber incident brought home to
('46', 68, 0, 1, 141111) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 69
('46', 68, 1, 2, 141153) We often think that we have carried out the full message of swadeshi when we have adopted khadi.
('46', 68, 1, 3, 141250) We treat it as a passport for the use of everything else from non Indian sources and for the introduction of the latest fashions from Paris.
('46', 68, 1, 4, 141391) This is a travesty of swadeshi and a denial of the message of khadi.
('46', 68, 1, 5, 141460) Whilst khadi is an obligation for all time in India, surely it is equally an obligation to use India made things wherever we can get them even though they may be inferior to foreign articles.
('46', 68, 1, 6, 141652) There are several swadeshi things on the market which are in danger of disappearance of want of patronage.
('46', 68, 1, 7, 141759) They may not be up to the mark.
('46', 68, 1, 8, 141791) It is for us to use them and require the makers to improve them wherever improvement is possible.
('46', 68, 1, 9, 141889) Rule of the best and the cheapest is not always true.
('46', 68, 1, 10, 141943) Just as we do not give up our country for one with a better climate but endeavour to improve our own, so also may we not discard swadeshi for better or cheaper foreign things.
('46', 68, 1, 11, 142119) Even as a husband who being dissatisfied with his simple looking wife goes in search of a better looking woman is disloyal to his partner, so is a man disloyal to his country who prefers foreign made things though better to country made things.
('46', 68, 1, 12, 142364) The law of each country’s progress demands on the part of its inhabitants preference for their own products and manufactures.
('46', 68, 2, 13, 142490) Young India, 30 5 1929
('46', 68, 3, 14, 142513) 60. TRIALS OF PUNJAB
('46', 68, 4, 15, 142534) It seems as if the Punjab Government is trying to thwart the Congress preparations in the Punjab in every way open to it.
('46', 68, 4, 16, 142656) The use of the central site chosen by the P.C.C. has been refused.
('46', 68, 4, 17, 142723) Now workers are being arrested, their houses searched and in other ways molested.
('46', 68, 4, 18, 142805) Even the Secretary, Dr. Satyapal, has not been left free.
('46', 68, 4, 19, 142863) It is however a happy sign that the Punjabis are undaunted and are prosecuting their preparations with unabated zeal.
('46', 68, 4, 20, 142981) I hope that the Punjabis will make a resolute effort to ensure the success of the forthcoming Congress and show the Government that repression will only refine instead of crushing their spirit.
('46', 68, 5, 21, 143175) Young India, 30 5 1929

('46', 71, 0, 1, 145631) 72 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 71, 1, 2, 145672) 64. PACE OF BOYCOTT
('46', 71, 2, 3, 145692) The Foreign Cloth Boycott Committee has been conducting its work in accordance with its regulations.
('46', 71, 2, 4, 145793) Since I am its President, I certainly cannot take credit for its regularity.
('46', 71, 2, 5, 145870) All the credit for it goes to its enthusiastic and dutiful Secretary.
('46', 71, 2, 6, 145940) Ever since he accepted that office, Shri Jairamdas 1 has forgotten all other things.
('46', 71, 2, 7, 146025) No one in the world has been able to do justice to any secretaryship without such concentration.
('46', 71, 2, 8, 146122) If this Committee receives full assistance, it will experience no difficulty and take no time to make the boycott an established fact, because the main thing to do in this matter is to organize.
('46', 71, 2, 9, 146317) If the Congress principle becomes a living thing and workers are actuated by true faith, there is no reason at all to doubt that the people are ready for boycott.
('46', 71, 2, 10, 146480) It is necessary to explain their duty to them and to prove to them that even prominent persons have given up foreign cloth and begun to wear khadi exclusively.
('46', 71, 2, 11, 146640) But the thing we lack is sincerity among these prominent people themselves.
('46', 71, 2, 12, 146716) Some of them pretend to wear khadi, some wear it only on occassions, etc., and some others flatly refuse to wear it and yet remain in the Congress.
('46', 71, 2, 13, 146864) Misusing their high positions they do not abide by any rules and hence there is not as much impact on the people as there should be.
('46', 71, 2, 14, 146997) The mass of people are not foolish but intelligent.
('46', 71, 2, 15, 147049) They understand some things by a mere hint.
('46', 71, 2, 16, 147093) This is one of the reasons why the pace of khadi, that is, of boycott, is slow.
('46', 71, 2, 17, 147173) But whether we call the pace slow or fast, we can see from the two months’ report which the Boycott Committee has published that it is certainly beginning to have its impact on England at any rate.
('46', 71, 2, 18, 147371) Mr. Roberts, President of the Cloth Dealers’ Association of Delhi, has said in his speech that even Manchester has begun to feel acutely the effect of the boycott.
('46', 71, 2, 19, 147535) He says that almost a third of the cotton textile mills in England have closed down.
('46', 71, 2, 20, 147620) But since our enthusiasm lasts a short while and cools off, such impact does not last for ever.
('46', 71, 2, 21, 147716) In order that it should do so, we should be honest and make constant endeavours.
('46', 71, 2, 22, 147797) The pace has increased so much at present that many fear that khadi will be in short supply.
('46', 71, 2, 23, 147890) But if we have digested the mantra of khadi, there is no reason why supplies of khadi should run out.
('46', 71, 2, 24, 147992) Ifanyone were to complain that there was a shortage of rotlis in spite of the
('46', 71, 3, 25, 148070) 1 Jairamdas Doulatram
('46', 72, 0, 1, 148092) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 73
('46', 72, 1, 2, 148134) availability of wheat flour and be struck with fear, there would be no justification for that fear; in like manner there will be no fear of a shortage of khadi as long as there is cotton in India.
('46', 72, 1, 3, 148331) If we now entertain such fear, it is because we have forgotten the power of khadi and have even lost our faith in it.
('46', 72, 1, 4, 148449) It is as easy to spin yarn and weave khadi as it is to bake rotlis in every home.
('46', 72, 1, 5, 148531) Khadi depends on supplies of yarn.
('46', 72, 1, 6, 148566) Even now, we come across weavers almost anywhere.
('46', 72, 1, 7, 148616) But we do not get male or female spinners so easily.
('46', 72, 1, 8, 148669) There are three ways of producing hand spun yarn: the first is the way of self reliance, the second is doing it for wages and the third is that of sacrificial spinning.
('46', 72, 1, 9, 148838) The first can be the most extensive and it should be considered the easiest.
('46', 72, 1, 10, 148915) It is that the agriculturists should themselves spin yarn for their requirements of cloth and get it woven, whereby khadi so made will be cheaper for them than mill cloth.
('46', 72, 1, 11, 149087) And in this way one can save oneself the trouble of finding buyers for one’s khadi.
('46', 72, 1, 12, 149171) City dwellers and thoser who are not agriculturists should get ready made khadi.
('46', 72, 1, 13, 149252) The second way is for them, i.e., to pay and get yarn spun.
('46', 72, 1, 14, 149312) This method is most prevalent today because the khadi movement was started and was possible only that way.
('46', 72, 1, 15, 149419) It started with the middle classes, the educated class of people.
('46', 72, 1, 16, 149485) They were not in a position to produce khadi on their own and wear it.
('46', 72, 1, 17, 149556) In India, there is one class tormented by hunger, which will be able to ward off its misery if it gets a few pice a day.
('46', 72, 1, 18, 149677) Thus yarn began to be spun for wages.
('46', 72, 1, 19, 149715) There is a great advantage in this too.
('46', 72, 1, 20, 149755) That is, it has increased the organizing capacity of the middle classes, has given rise to a great agency of service, has brought into existence a class of people selling khadi for the benefit of others and has opened up a major new source of honourable income for the middles classes.
('46', 72, 1, 21, 150041) This is no ordinary gain.
('46', 72, 1, 22, 150067) The third way is to produce yarn by sacrificial spinning.
('46', 72, 1, 23, 150125) This has been going on very slowly on account of lack of proper environment.
('46', 72, 1, 24, 150202) If an atmosphere of sacrifice can be created, crores of yards of yarn can be produced by this method.
('46', 72, 1, 25, 150304) In municipal schools where thousands of boys and girls study, yarn can be produced every day by means of the takli with the greatest ease.
('46', 72, 1, 26, 150443) That will involve very little expenditure and the work can become enduring.
('46', 72, 1, 27, 150519) The yarn produced can be immediately sent to a weaver and got woven, and thereby confidence can be created in the people.
('46', 72, 1, 28, 150641) This work can be easily organized.
('46', 72, 1, 29, 150676) Thus, if all the three ways are fully used, there willnot be the slightest difficulty in India producing as much yarn as is required, that is to say, to produce khadi in the quantity needed.
('46', 72, 1, 30, 150867) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 2 6 1929
('46', 73, 0, 1, 150903) 74 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 73, 1, 2, 150944) 65. COMMITTEE FOR REMOVAL OF UNTOUCHABILITY
('46', 73, 2, 3, 150988) The Congress Working Committee has set up a separate committee for the removal of untouchability, of which Bharat Bhushan Pandit Malaviya is the President.
('46', 73, 2, 4, 151144) Its Secretary is Shri Jamnalalji.
('46', 73, 2, 5, 151178) Its office is at 395, Kalbadevi Road, Bombay.
('46', 73, 2, 6, 151224) The main objects of the committee are: 1. to get public temples thrown open to the Antyajas; 2. to secure for the Antyajas the use of public wells; 3. removal of the restrictions which face Antyaja children in public schools; 4. to improve their condition in respect of cleanliness; and 5. to induce them to give up their habit of eating carrion and taking liquor.
('46', 73, 2, 7, 151589) The committee expects every Hindu to help in educating public opinion for this work.
('46', 73, 2, 8, 151674) Those who are willing to assist in this task should correspond with Shri Jamnalalji at the above address.
('46', 73, 2, 9, 151780) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 2 6 1929
('46', 73, 3, 10, 151816) 66. GUJARAT’S CONTRIBUTION The All India Congress Committee has decided that by the end of August, every province should enrol 1 per cent of its population, excluding that of the Princely States and the Excluded Areas, and that at least half the number of districts and half the number of talukas in them and ten villages in each taluk should be covered.
('46', 73, 3, 11, 152171) This proportion is certainly not too high.
('46', 73, 3, 12, 152214) If a province cannot enlist even this percentage, it ought not to have the right to send a representative to the Congress.
('46', 73, 3, 13, 152337) If the Congress is at all ready to carry out the constructive work decided upon by itself and if it cannot influence one man in every four hundred, it will have no value.
('46', 73, 3, 14, 152508) The programme of constructive work is such that everyone can take part in it.
('46', 73, 3, 15, 152586) It is not like that of the legislature in which only a few people whose number can be counted on one’s fingers can participate.
('46', 73, 3, 16, 152714) If we can find volunteers, we can get work from crores of people.
('46', 73, 3, 17, 152780) Khadi work is such that the boycott
('46', 74, 0, 1, 152816) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 75
('46', 74, 1, 2, 152858) cannot at all be an accomplished fact without the enthusiasm and help of crores of people.
('46', 74, 1, 3, 152949) The removal of untouchability means the consent of 23 crore Hindus.
('46', 74, 1, 4, 153017) Prohibition implies the effect of true self purification on lakhs of Hindus and Muslims.
('46', 74, 1, 5, 153106) These things can be done only if the Congress organization is alive, alert and pervasive.
('46', 74, 1, 6, 153196) And if the Congress cannot even do this work, the job which we hope to accomplish by January 1 of the coming year will never get done.
('46', 74, 1, 7, 153331) Hence I hope that even in this work, Gujarat will, as in the past, make a bigger contribution than its share, and well before the end of August.
('46', 74, 1, 8, 153476) And if we want to do that, we must take a map of Gujarat and decide how many men must join the Congress from every part, that is, from every taluk, and the work must then be distributed accordingly.
('46', 74, 1, 9, 153675) We easily recall, while considering this subject, that the Congress constitution has in it the stipulation regarding yarn.
('46', 74, 1, 10, 153798) A number of people wish to get exemption from that clause in many ways.
('46', 74, 1, 11, 153870) I presume that the workers of Gujarat do not have such persons in their midst.
('46', 74, 1, 12, 153949) But, perchance, if there is any such, I must state for his benefit that the condition is not applicable at the time of enrolling himself in the Congress.
('46', 74, 1, 13, 154103) He who accepts the Congress objectives and gives four annas or 2,000 yards of yarn can compel a worker to register his name in the Congress office.
('46', 74, 1, 14, 154251) The obligation to wear khadi applies to a man who wishes to exercise his voting right.
('46', 74, 1, 15, 154338) It is necessary to understand this distinction.
('46', 74, 1, 16, 154386) It is also meaningful.
('46', 74, 1, 17, 154409) A man joining the Congress may be a lover of foreign cloth and even revile khadi, but we hope that, after coming into contact with us, after being served by us and experiencing our love, his fascination for foreign cloth will disappear and he will begin to use khadi.
('46', 74, 1, 18, 154677) Perhaps, he may be moved to wear khadi if only out of a desire to earn the franchise.
('46', 74, 1, 19, 154763) And despite all this, if he will not wear khadi, he will forfeit his voting right at least for that time.
('46', 74, 1, 20, 154869) This is how the Congress had understood the utility and necessity of khadi.
('46', 74, 1, 21, 154945) I have very often written that it is our duty to remove the condition regarding khadi if a number of people hold that that restriction retards the work of the Congress and that it must be done away with.
('46', 74, 1, 22, 155149) But I have no doubut whatever in my mind that, as long as that condition stands, it must be implemented honestly.
('46', 74, 2, 23, 155263) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 2 6 1929
('46', 75, 0, 1, 155299) 76 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 75, 1, 2, 155340) 67. KARACHI KHADI BHANDAR
('46', 75, 2, 3, 155366) I had paid a visit to the Bhandar when I was in Karachi, but I was not able to pay much attention to it.
('46', 75, 2, 4, 155471) Moreover, as I had heard complaints about its high prices, I had kept silent on that subject.
('46', 75, 2, 5, 155565) The manager of the Bhandar, Bhai Dayaram Topandas, complained against my silence.
('46', 75, 2, 6, 155647) I gave him the reason therefore.
('46', 75, 2, 7, 155680) Thereupon, he produced before me proofs of the fairness of his transactions, which included testimonials from Sadhu Vaswani 1, Acharya Gidwani 2 and others.

('46', 76, 1, 2, 157457) nothing novel in the above sentence.
('46', 76, 1, 3, 157494) A child means a boy or girl under the age of ten or anyone who apears to be of that age.
('46', 76, 1, 4, 157583) Education does not mean a knowledge of the alphabet.
('46', 76, 1, 5, 157636) This type of knowledge is only a means to education.
('46', 76, 1, 6, 157689) Education implies a child’s learning how to put his mind and all his senses to good use.
('46', 76, 1, 7, 157778) That is to say, he really learns how to use his hands, feet and other organs of action and his nose, ear and other organs of sense.
('46', 76, 1, 8, 157910) A child who has acquired the knowledge that he should not use his hands for stealing or for killing flies, nor for beating up his companions or younger brothers and sisters, has already begun his education.
('46', 76, 1, 9, 158117) He has started it, we can say, when he understands the necessity of keeping his body, his teeth, tongue, ears, head, nails, etc., clean and keeps them clean.
('46', 76, 1, 10, 158275) That child has made good progress in education who does not indulge in mischief while eating and drinking, eats and drinks alone or in society in a proper manner, sits properly and chooses pure foodstuffs knowing the difference between pure and impure food stuffs, does not eat like a glutton, does not clamour for whatever he sees and remains calm even if he does not get what he wants.
('46', 76, 1, 11, 158663) Even that child has advanced on the road to education whose pronunciation is correct, who can recount to us the history and geography of the country surrounding him without knowing those terms and who understands what his country means.
('46', 76, 1, 12, 158900) That child has made very good progress in his education who can understand the difference between truth and untruth, worth and worthlessness and chooses the good and the true, while rejecting the bad and the untrue.
('46', 76, 1, 13, 159116) There is no need now to dilate on this point.
('46', 76, 1, 14, 159162) The reader can supply other attributes himself.
('46', 76, 1, 15, 159210) Only one thing needs to be made clear.
('46', 76, 1, 16, 159249) In all this, one sees no need of a knowledge of the alphabet or of any script.
('46', 76, 1, 17, 159328) To engage children in learning the script is tantamount to putting a burden on their mind and other organs and is like putting their eyes and hands to bad use.
('46', 76, 1, 18, 159488) A child who has received true education easily picks up a knowledge of the alphabet at the appropriate time and in an interesting way.
('46', 76, 1, 19, 159623) Today, knowledge becomes a sort of burden to children, their best time for development is spent uselessly, and in the end, instead of writing a beautiful hand and reading in a beautiful way, their handwriting is like the housefly’s legs, and they read mostly what should not be read and even what they do read, they read wrongly.
('46', 76, 1, 20, 159953) To call this education is blasphemy, or sacrilege.
('46', 76, 1, 21, 160004) Before a child receives a knowledge of the alphabet, it should have received primary education.

('46', 85, 5, 12, 176890) 78. CONSOLIDATED STATEMENT
('46', 85, 6, 13, 176917) The following is the consolidated statement I promised to publish of the Andhra Desha collections.
('46', 85, 6, 14, 177016) It has been prepared by Sjt.
('46', 85, 6, 15, 177045) Narayanamurti as auditor of the A.I.S.A. 2 and checked by Deshabhakta Konda Venkatappayya: I have never before had the opportunity or the inclination to supervise the conduct and expenses of tours during the past eight years as I had of this eventful Andhra tour.
('46', 85, 6, 16, 177309) I had noticed before too much laxity about expenses and too much lavishness in ordering things.
('46', 85, 6, 17, 177405) Much of it was done out of personal affection.
('46', 85, 6, 18, 177452) But even that affection became a questionable thing when the expenditure was deducted from purses collected in the name of Daridranarayana.
('46', 85, 6, 19, 177592) In Andhra Desha therefore, I took the law, as far as possible, in myown hands and insisted upon no deduction being made from cash collected without vouchers being produced and accepted by me.
('46', 85, 6, 20, 177784) I further insisted upon all the railway expenses of my party being paid by me so that they might not become a charge upon the purses.
('46', 85, 6, 21, 177918) I also insisted that all feeding expenses of my party should be paid by me when they were not paid by the local host.
('46', 85, 6, 22, 178036) Thus the certified expenses include generally only motor hire, petrol, railway travelling of volunteers and the like.
('46', 85, 6, 23, 178154) These expenses do not amount to more than
('46', 85, 7, 24, 178196) 1 Started in 1921 by Prem Vidyalaya Society to impart, besides the three R’s mannual training such as spinning, weaving, carpet makingm carpentring, etc., board and instruction being free 2 All India Spinners’ Association

('46', 86, 1, 2, 178460) five per cent of the collections.
('46', 86, 1, 3, 178494) To have brought about a great awakening in 319 villages was worth the expense incurred.
('46', 86, 1, 4, 178582) Having said as much in defence of the expense, I must confess that even though the sums collected may be large, we cannot afford to fly from place to place and pay high motor charges.
('46', 86, 1, 5, 178766) Whilst the tour was on, I published the full details 1 of one bill which the reader should recall if he will understand the full significance of my statement.
('46', 86, 1, 6, 178925) There was even there considerable room for improvement and economy.
('46', 86, 1, 7, 178993) It may seem ungracious to write thus of a tour which has been the most economic of all I have known.
('46', 86, 1, 8, 179094) But it would be wrong to be easily satisfied or be satisfied with anything but the highest.
('46', 86, 1, 9, 179186) Easy satisfaction means arrested progress leading to stagnation and finally retrogre ssion.

('46', 87, 2, 6, 181173) 80. ATROCIOUS
('46', 87, 3, 7, 181187) Though house searches, arrests without even reasonable ground or suspicion of innocent and respectable men, putting them in veils and handcuffs are in the air, I was wholly unprepared for the search of the offices of the well known magazine, The Modern Review, much less the house of its equally well known Editor, Sjt.
('46', 87, 3, 8, 181507) Ramananda Chatterjee.
('46', 87, 3, 9, 181529) Therefore when I heard of the search I wired for particulars and Sjt.
('46', 87, 3, 10, 181599) Ramananda Chatterjee has sent me the following letter: 1
('46', 87, 4, 11, 181656) On the 24th instant when I returned from my office at about 11.30 a.m., my second son told me that a Bengali police officer had come to search my house in connection with Dr. J.T. Sunderland’s India in Bondage: Her Right to Freedom..
('46', 87, 5, 12, 181890) I entered the sitting room, where I found a man in plain clothes seated in a chair....
('46', 87, 5, 13, 181977) The officer asked me whether I had any printed copies of India in Bondage, etc., any manuscripts thereof, and any correspondence with the author relating to it in the nature of any business agreement.
('46', 87, 5, 14, 182178) Thereupon I gave him one printed copy of the book…there was no other copy in my house…and two typewritten copies of the Indian and American editions.
('46', 87, 5, 15, 182328) I also gave him the original copy of the agreement with the author signed by Dr. Sunderland by which I had bound myself to give him 25 per cent of the face value of each copy of the book sold.
('46', 87, 5, 16, 182521) I gave the man the covering letter also..
('46', 87, 5, 17, 182563) He then wrote out an inventory of the things taken, got it signed by two local search witnesses, gave me a carbon copy, and went away.
('46', 87, 5, 18, 182698) The warrant he had with him was only for searching my house.
('46', 87, 5, 19, 182759) He was throughout polite..
('46', 87, 6, 20, 182786) Another Bengali police officer had gone to my press and office..
('46', 87, 6, 21, 182851) His warrant was for searching the premises and arresting Mr. Sajanikanta Das.
('46', 87, 6, 22, 182929) printer and publisher of the book.
('46', 87, 6, 23, 182964) ...the officer took away 42 copies of the second edition.
('46', 87, 6, 24, 183022) one copy of the first edition, the manuscript from which the
('46', 87, 7, 25, 183083) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.

('46', 88, 1, 2, 183162) book was printed, and a few cash memos and other documents to show that copies of the book had been sold and sent by V.P.P. The printer and publisher was also arrested at my office and released on bail then and there on his signing a bond for Rs.1,000. His trial for sedition will commence on June 4 at the Presidency Magistrate’s Court.
('46', 88, 1, 3, 183500) At my office also the police officer was polite.
('46', 88, 2, 4, 183549) I have asked my office to send you by post a copy of the second edition of the book in order that you may be able to form your own opinion of it, if you can make time to do so.

('46', 89, 5, 13, 186885) There is no reason why the programme for enrolment of Congress members adopted by the All India Congress Committee at its recent meeting at Bombay should in any way interfere with the carrying out of this new boycott programme.
('46', 89, 5, 14, 187113) On the, contrary the enrolment programme will give very great opportunities of carrying the message of the boycott of foreign cloth to the thousands whom you may have to approach for enrolment as Congress members.

('46', 89, 5, 16, 187482) I hope you will be able to show a far better record of boycott work done in the next four months than you have been able to do during the last five months.

('46', 93, 2, 9, 194476) 83. WANTED SELF CONVERSION
('46', 93, 3, 10, 194503) It was at Kurnool during the Andhra tour that I received an anonymous letter complaining that members of the local reception committee who were surrounding me were khaddar clad only for the occasion and that they were habitual wearers of foreign cloth and given to foreign fashions.
('46', 93, 3, 11, 194786) At the meeting itself, I saw a fair display of foreign garments.
('46', 93, 3, 12, 194851) I therefore referred to the contents of the letter whilst at the same time I criticized the anonymous writer for hiding his name.
('46', 93, 3, 13, 194981) The anonymous writer who must have heard my speech promptly wrote to me disclosing his identity.
('46', 93, 3, 14, 195078) As the letter does credit to the writer and is otherwise instructive, I give it below in full:
('46', 93, 4, 15, 195173) Secrecy is a sin.
('46', 93, 4, 16, 195191) But owing to the reasons set forth below, I did not give out my name in my letter of yesterday.
('46', 93, 4, 17, 195287) I am a Government servant.
('46', 93, 4, 18, 195314) You are fully aware of the fact that as a Government servant I am not expected to express even my sincere opinion about my country’s state or its needs.
('46', 93, 4, 19, 195467) This is high treason.
('46', 93, 4, 20, 195489) But still I could not bear to see the palpable insincerity of many of those that came to attend on you yesterday.
('46', 93, 4, 21, 195603) That was torture to me to see.
('46', 93, 4, 22, 195634) The duty of the literate lies in convincing the masses.
('46', 93, 4, 23, 195690) But it is very wrong on the part of the literate to think that the illiterate masses can be made to believe by insincere behaviour.
('46', 93, 4, 24, 195822) If everyone takes into his head to live by your advice even within his own home, I am sure the time will not be far when India can hold up her head as a free and independent country.
('46', 93, 4, 25, 196005) Utter want of sincerity cannot convince the masses.
('46', 93, 4, 26, 196057) We set a bad and a damaging example by our hollowness and we give occasion to the world to mock at us.
('46', 93, 4, 27, 196160) My mind was ill at ease with all these thoughts and I therefore wrote to you.
('46', 93, 4, 28, 196238) Though very poor,
('46', 94, 0, 1, 196256) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 95
('46', 94, 1, 2, 196298) I do not care whether it is well or ill for me as a Government servant to give out my name, as long as I feel convinced that I have done no wrong.
('46', 94, 1, 3, 196445) I do not also much mind whether my telling out my name to you will jeopardize my position (as a Government servant) which is my sole means of livelihood.
('46', 94, 1, 4, 196599) The writer and others who may write to public journals with a reputation to keep should know that editors are bound to withhold from the public names which the owners give only for editors’ satisfaction.
('46', 94, 1, 5, 196803) The writer therefore may rest assured that his name will never be disclosed.
('46', 94, 1, 6, 196880) If it is any satisfaction to him he may know that I destroyed the portion containing his name as soon as I had finished reading the letter and that I could not recall the name myself even if I tried.
('46', 94, 1, 7, 197080) In my opinion, even if he had written his letter for publication with his name, he could have come to no harm.
('46', 94, 1, 8, 197191) The letter is perfectly innocent and such as any Government servant can write with impunity.
('46', 94, 1, 9, 197284) We often hesitate to do the right only because of needless fear.

('46', 94, 4, 16, 197861) 84. DHOTI CUM SOLA HAT
('46', 94, 5, 17, 197884) Pandit Durgashankar Mehta of Seoni writes:
('46', 94, 6, 18, 197927) I was a practising lawyer but non co operated in 1921. Circumstances have driven me back to law but I am a strict khaddarite.
('46', 94, 6, 19, 198053) I have given up the use of trousers and ties and attend court and the local legislature in dhoti.
('46', 94, 6, 20, 198151) As Chairman of my District Council, I am running Famine Road Works, which require my being out in the sun.
('46', 94, 6, 21, 198258) Recently I got a touch of the sun and went in for a hat, which has been specially made of pure khaddar.
('46', 94, 6, 22, 198362) This has started a controversy.
('46', 94, 6, 23, 198394) Will you take part in it?
('46', 94, 7, 24, 198420) This is an old controversy.
('46', 94, 7, 25, 198448) My narrow nationalism rebels against the hat, my secret internationalism regards the sola hat as one of the few boons from Europe.
('46', 94, 7, 26, 198579) But for the tremendous national prejudice
('46', 95, 0, 1, 198621) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 95, 1, 2, 198662) against the hat, I would undertake to become president of a league for popularizing sola hats.
('46', 95, 1, 3, 198757) In my opinion, educated India has erred in taking to (in this climate) unnecessary, unhygienic, inelegant trousers and in betraying general hesitation to take up the sola hat.
('46', 95, 1, 4, 198933) But I know that national likes and dislikes are not governed by reason.
('46', 95, 1, 5, 199005) That Scotch Highlander will run the risk of being singled out by his kilt as an easy target for the enemy but will not abandon the awkward kilt.
('46', 95, 1, 6, 199150) I do not expect India to take kindly to the sola hat.
('46', 95, 1, 7, 199204) Nevertheless workers like Pandit Durgashankar need not be ruffled by criticism and may certainly wear khadi imitations of the sola hat.
('46', 95, 1, 8, 199340) It is in reality an easily portable umbrella that covers the head without the necessity of one hand being occupied in carrying it.
('46', 95, 1, 9, 199471) The Calcutta policeman who shades his head from the fierce sun by sustaining an umbrella in his belt puts himself under a double handicap when pitted against his European fellow member.
('46', 95, 1, 10, 199657) Those who have strong prejudice against sola hats, should study the contrast I have described.
('46', 95, 1, 11, 199752) I may here draw the reader’s attention to an indigenous and effective equivalent of the hat that is very generally worn by the poor farmers of Malabar.
('46', 95, 1, 12, 199904) It is an umbrella without the handle, made of leaves with a bark hoop to fit the head.
('46', 95, 1, 13, 199991) It is cheap, thoroughly effective and in no way akin to the hat and yet almost just as serviceable.
('46', 95, 1, 14, 200091) Young India, 6 6 1929

('46', 96, 1, 2, 200487) 86. SPINNING V. WEAVING
('46', 96, 2, 3, 200511) Shri Moolchand writes from Khadi Ashram, Ringas 1 : I feel that it is the duty of khadi workers to teach the art of weaving to those peasants who wish to learn it.
('46', 96, 2, 4, 200675) But it cannot be considered as important as carding nor can it be propagated as successfully.
('46', 96, 2, 5, 200769) Carding is an indivisible part of the process of spinning, as preparing dough is of that of making chapatis.
('46', 96, 2, 6, 200878) If a person knows how to make chapatis but cannot prepare the dough he cannot be said to have mastered the art of making chapatis.
('46', 96, 2, 7, 201009) So it is as important to teach carding as it is to teach spinning.
('46', 96, 2, 8, 201076) Weaving is quite a separate process, a distinct occupation.
('46', 96, 2, 9, 201136) Moreover, it has not become extinct.
('46', 96, 2, 10, 201173) India’s poverty and weaving are in no way inter connected.
('46', 96, 2, 11, 201232) It is the extinction of spinning which is responsible for the greivous plight and the utter poverty in which our peasantry finds itself today.
('46', 96, 2, 12, 201375) Even when we wish them to become self reliant it is not necessary to teach them weaving.
('46', 96, 2, 13, 201464) Self reliance does not mean in any way that each man must do everything himself.
('46', 96, 2, 14, 201545) It would be useless and harmful to attempt it.
('46', 96, 2, 15, 201592) Man is a social being and depends on society.
('46', 96, 2, 16, 201638) Self reliance means only that each village ought to produce all the grain and all the cloth it requires.
('46', 96, 2, 17, 201743) There has to be a division of labour in the villages.
('46', 96, 2, 18, 201797) Only spinning will be essential for everyone.
('46', 96, 2, 19, 201843) It was so in the past.
('46', 96, 2, 20, 201866) So it should be now and in the future.
('46', 96, 2, 21, 201905) Even a little reflection will make it clear that if spinning is to be done by hand, as it should be, then this is the way to do so.
('46', 96, 2, 22, 202037) We should not feel for a moment that because the weavers are not honest in their dealings, the peasants should learn how to weave.
('46', 96, 2, 23, 202168) Our job is to make the weavers better.
('46', 96, 2, 24, 202207) They are also a part of society.
('46', 96, 2, 25, 202240) Of course one thing must be done…some of the khadi workers should learn to weave well so that they can influence the weavers and also save them from the injustice they have to suffer because of our ignorance.
('46', 96, 2, 26, 202449) [From Hindi]
('46', 96, 3, 27, 202462) Hindi Navajivan, 6 6 1929

('46', 109, 3, 7, 227680) Its pages are an evidence of the immense conscientious labours they have put into the work entrusted to them, within the limits prescribed by the reference whose operative sentences (including an abvious grammatical slip) were word for word as the people’s representatives had drawn up.
('46', 109, 3, 8, 227967) Though therefore the actual finding on the question of the amount of assessment is, as Mahadev Desai has, in my opinion, conclusively pointed out, 1 faulty, Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel and the ryots of the tracts concerned are bound to accept it.
('46', 109, 3, 9, 228211) It is upto them however at least to reason and point out to the Government the defects in the finding and to leave it to their honour to remedy them.
('46', 109, 3, 10, 228361) Throughout the brave fight the people put up, the question never was one of rupees, annas and pies, burdensome though the assessment was.
('46', 109, 3, 11, 228499) The question was one of principle and justice.
('46', 109, 3, 12, 228546) Resentment was felt against the high handed and contemptuous manner in which the people’s case was treated.
('46', 109, 3, 13, 228654) The authors of the report have completely vindicated its justice.
('46', 109, 3, 14, 228720) The Officers were to
('46', 109, 4, 15, 228741) enquire into and report upon the complaints of the people of the Bardoli Taluk and Valod Mahal and Chorasi Taluk…
('46', 109, 5, 16, 228855) (a) that the enhancement of revenue recently made is not warranted in terms of the Land Revenue Code,
('46', 109, 6, 17, 228957) (b) that the reports accessible to the public do not contain sufficient data warranting the enhancement and that some of the data given are wrong; and they were to find, that if the people’s complaint is held to be justified, what enhancement or reduction, if any, there should be upon the old assessment.
('46', 109, 7, 18, 229263) On all these points the Commissioners have substantially found in favour of the people.
('46', 109, 7, 19, 229351) As to the first complaint the Commissioners have found that the authorities have offended against the spirit of
('46', 109, 8, 20, 229463) 1 In Young India, 23 5 1929, under the title “The Bardoli Report: An analysis”
('46', 110, 0, 1, 229542) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 111
('46', 110, 1, 2, 229585) Section 107. The Commissioners’examination of the second comp laint is detailed, exhaustive, able and instructive.
('46', 110, 1, 3, 229700) It is the best part of the report and covers 40 out of 77 pages of the body of the report.
('46', 110, 1, 4, 229791) This examination proves to the hilt almost every one of the charges brought by the people against Messrs Jayakar and Anderson.
('46', 110, 1, 5, 229918) There could be no better vindication than this:
('46', 110, 2, 6, 229966) We are bound to hold that the complaint referred to in point (b) of the terms of reference is substantially justified.
('46', 110, 2, 7, 230085) The data in the reports, apart from the rental and sale statistics, are obviously not sufficient to warrant either the general increases sanctioned in the maximum rates, or the much higher increases in the case of particular villages.
('46', 110, 2, 8, 230320) The rental and sale statistics have been carelessly compiled, are demonstrably incorrect in a large number of cases, and in general must be regarded as completely unreliable.
('46', 110, 2, 9, 230495) Further, the established method of using the statistics is in our opinion unsound in theory, and however it may work in practice in other districts, is not capable of giving satisfactory results in this part of Gujarat, where leases and sale transactions are affected by such a variety of disturbing factors.
('46', 110, 2, 10, 230804) In view of this conclusion we submit that the present settlement cannot be allowed to stand in either of the two taluks.
('46', 110, 3, 11, 230925) Having thus found that the increase made by the Government had offended against the spirit of Section 107 of the Code and that the data relied upon by the Government were insufficient and faulty, the Commissioners had to say what the increase or the reduction, as the case may be, on the old assessment there should be.
('46', 110, 3, 12, 231245) Though in my opinion the case before the Commissioners was for a substantial reduction in the old assessment, such a proposal was evidently beyond their ken.
('46', 110, 3, 13, 231403) Revision has traditionally come to mean an increase, be it ever so slight, in the general rate of assessment.
('46', 110, 3, 14, 231513) Though therefore they have rejected the Government rate of 22 per cent increase as excessive, they have proposed an increase of 5.7 per cent.

('46', 111, 1, 2, 232325) village in our programme, and their detailed knowledge of individual cases not infrequently enabled us to obtain more accurate information that would otherwise have been available.

('46', 112, 1, 2, 234806) 102. PANDIT NEHRU’S APPEAL
('46', 112, 2, 3, 234833) Pandit Motilal Nehru has addressed the following appeal to Congress members of the legislatures:
('46', 112, 3, 4, 234930) You must have read with interest the recent pronouncement of the Viceroy and of some provincial Governors extending the life of the legislatures.
('46', 112, 3, 5, 235076) As you are no doubt aware, the A.I.C.C. 1 and the Working Committee considered this situation and decided to call upon all Congress members of the legislatures to abstain from attending them till further notice.
('46', 112, 3, 6, 235288) They were further asked to devote all their available time to the furtherance of the Congress programme in the country.
('46', 112, 4, 7, 235408) It is clear that the real strength of the nation is built up by work outside the present legislatures, and even our Council work carries weight only to the extent of the organized strength behind us.
('46', 112, 4, 8, 235608) All indications point to an approaching crisis and by the end of this year at the latest we must be ready to face this crisis with confidence.
('46', 112, 4, 9, 235751) The A.I.C.C. has therefore laid down a special programme of reorganisation for the next three months, failure to comply with which will lead to the disaffiliation or non recognition of the Committee concerned.
('46', 112, 4, 10, 235961) Those of us who are members on behalf of the Congress of the Central Legislature or the Provincial Councils have now to demonstrate that we can work outside the Councils as well as inside.
('46', 112, 4, 11, 236150) Even from the point of view of future Council work it is essential that we should work in our constituencies and consolidate the position of the Congress.
('46', 112, 5, 12, 236305) I write this letter to appeal to you to give some time and energy to working for this Congress programme.
('46', 112, 5, 13, 236411) You would naturally prefer working in your own constituency.
('46', 112, 5, 14, 236472) This is right.
('46', 112, 5, 15, 236487) I would suggest however that you should immediately get in touch with your Provincial Congress Committee so that full advantage may be taken of your time and your efforts may be co ordinated with those of others.
('46', 112, 6, 16, 236700) You may of course concentrate on any item of the Congress programme.

('46', 114, 2, 3, 238978) There is more of pomp and show and less of religion in the way the marriage rites are performed in the Hindu society these days.

('46', 121, 4, 13, 252986) 113. DUTY OF REFORMERS
('46', 121, 5, 14, 253009) I received last week a letter dated the 29th ultimo from a reform society of Ahmedabad.
('46', 121, 5, 15, 253097) It is as follows: 2
('46', 121, 6, 16, 253117) The matter of this letter must perhaps have become old by now but the incident which has been narrated in it, is likely to recur often.
('46', 121, 6, 17, 253253) There is no doubt that the bad habits which are ingrained in us will not go all at once.
('46', 121, 6, 18, 253342) To get rid of them, the same efforts are needed which we are making for winning swaraj.
('46', 121, 6, 19, 253430) Such efforts will produce and are producing the same strength, which results from our efforts for swaraj, for both things are the same.
('46', 121, 6, 20, 253566) We labour under the illusion that we are unable to do anything because we are powerless.
('46', 121, 6, 21, 253655) The other illusion is that nothing happens because we are small in number.
('46', 121, 6, 22, 253730) I have no doubt that our strength will grow if we try to destroy evil, immorality and rot wherever we see them.

('46', 123, 1, 2, 256830) 114. RAW V. COOKED FOOD 1
('46', 123, 2, 3, 256856) Some look upon me as a fool, a crank or a faddist.
('46', 123, 2, 4, 256907) I must admit that wherever I go I am sought out by fools, cranks and faddists.
('46', 123, 2, 5, 256986) One can conclude from this that I must be having the characteristics of all these three types.
('46', 123, 2, 6, 257081) Andhra has its fair share of all three.
('46', 123, 2, 7, 257121) Some mad men come as far as the Udyoga Mandir in Sabarmati.
('46', 123, 2, 8, 257181) So, when I went Andhra, how could I escape running into them.
('46', 123, 2, 9, 257243) But I do not wish, at the present moment, to introduce all the three types to the readers.
('46', 123, 2, 10, 257334) Among my fads is the one concerning experiments in diet.
('46', 123, 2, 11, 257391) I wish to present one such faddist, because I have begun the experiment which I wish to describe and which I am undertaking under his influence.
('46', 123, 2, 12, 257536) His name is Sundaram Gopalrao.
('46', 123, 2, 13, 257567) He lives in Rajahmundry.
('46', 123, 2, 14, 257592) He runs an institute of hydropathy and dietetics; I have been told, and I do believe, that many have benefited by his treatment.
('46', 123, 2, 15, 257721) This Gopalrao has been living on uncooked food for the last one year.
('46', 123, 2, 16, 257791) He believes that fire should not touch man’s food.
('46', 123, 2, 17, 257842) The sun is a sustainer, fire is a destroyer.
('46', 123, 2, 18, 257887) The sun matures food, fire takes away its essence.
('46', 123, 2, 19, 257938) When food comes in contact with fire, its essence is burnt out.
('46', 123, 2, 20, 258002) In accordance with this reasoning, he gave up cooked food and after gaining experience, he made the experiments on his patients.
('46', 123, 2, 21, 258131) He holds that the most delicate intestines which digest cooked food will necessarily diget uncooked food as well.
('46', 123, 2, 22, 258245) I have believed for many years that one should not eat cooked food.
('46', 123, 2, 23, 258313) I had given up cooked food at the age of 20, but that state could not last beyond 15 days.
('46', 123, 2, 24, 258404) I tried it again in the year 1893 in the Transvaal; and then too could not proceed beyond 15 days.
('46', 123, 2, 25, 258503) I have been tempted by what Gopalrao says and by his experience and I have commenced at 60, an experiment which I had abandoned out of fear in my youth.
('46', 123, 2, 26, 258656) In point of results, theexperiment is very important and hence I shall tell the reader what it is.
('46', 123, 2, 27, 258755) I have lived on raw fruit and dry fruit continuously for six years.
('46', 123, 2, 28, 258823) But I have not lived for a long time on uncooked cereals and pulses and I have believed that a man like me could not digest it at all.
('46', 123, 2, 29, 258958) It is the opinion of contemporary Western medical men that our diet should contain a certain element in the absence of which a man cannot preserve his health.
('46', 123, 2, 30, 259117) It is known as “vitamin”.
('46', 123, 2, 31, 259143) Vitamin means
('46', 123, 3, 32, 259157) 1 Vide also “Food Faddists”, 13 6 1929.
('46', 124, 0, 1, 259197) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 125
('46', 124, 1, 2, 259240) the vital essence.
('46', 124, 1, 3, 259259) Chemists cannot detect it by analysis.
('46', 124, 1, 4, 259298) But health experts have been able to feel its absence.
('46', 124, 1, 5, 259353) Having studied the effects of many types of diet, they have found out that this vital essence is a necessary thing.
('46', 124, 1, 6, 259469) They believe that if any vegetable is cooked, this essence is destroyed.
('46', 124, 1, 7, 259542) They have divided this essence into classes.
('46', 124, 1, 8, 259587) Of them, vitamin A is to be found in leafy vegetables and germinated grains of cereals.
('46', 124, 1, 9, 259675) Hence, they have been recommending for years now, the consumption of foods containing vitamins and therefore many people take raw vegetables, pulses, wheat, etc., which have sprouted after being soaked in water.
('46', 124, 1, 10, 259887) But many experts hold and Gopalrao cites his own experience in support of it that uncooked and cooked foods should not at all be mixed.
('46', 124, 1, 11, 260023) If one wants to benefit fully by uncooked food, one must give up cooked food altogether.
('46', 124, 2, 12, 260112) I have faith in this argument.
('46', 124, 2, 13, 260143) This view is becoming stronger day by day.
('46', 124, 2, 14, 260186) We see support for this view even in the chapter on diets in the book by the T.B. expert, Dr. Muthu.
('46', 124, 2, 15, 260287) Apart from health, there is for me a great attraction in this diet.
('46', 124, 2, 16, 260355) I regard the destruction of even vegetagbles as violence.
('46', 124, 2, 17, 260413) Man cannot help such destruction.
('46', 124, 2, 18, 260447) But despite knowing that, one who believes in the dharma of non violence, will indulge in a minimum of such destruction.
('46', 124, 2, 19, 260568) Moreover, diet has an intimate connection with physical celibacy.
('46', 124, 2, 20, 260634) It has been the primary object of all my dietetic experiments to find out which diet is most helpful in the observance of physical brahmacharya.
('46', 124, 2, 21, 260779) It is also the purpose of all my dietetic experiments to find out which diet can be taken in the least time and at least expense and can fully safeguard health.
('46', 124, 2, 22, 260940) I saw all this included in Gopalrao’s experiment and so I too have plunged into it.
('46', 124, 2, 23, 261024) None should hastily copy my experiment.
('46', 124, 2, 24, 261064) He who has no experience of such experiments should never do so.
('46', 124, 2, 25, 261129) My experiment has not yet proceeded beyond the initial stage.
('46', 124, 2, 26, 261191) I cannot even claim that it has succeeded.
('46', 124, 2, 27, 261234) I do not have Gopalrao’s faith.
('46', 124, 2, 28, 261266) It is not even as simple as he believes it to be.

('46', 125, 1, 3, 261835) Now I shall describe my diet: Eight tolas of germinating wheat, eight tolas of almonds ground to a paste, eight tolas of green leafy vegetables crushed, eight sour lemons, five tolas of honey.
('46', 125, 2, 4, 262028) When I do not take wheat, I take an equal quantity of germinated gram.
('46', 125, 2, 5, 262099) From this week, I have started taking wheat and gram together.
('46', 125, 2, 6, 262162) I sometimes take the grated kernel of cocoanut in place of almonds, and, if there is scope, I take dried grapes or some other fruit in addition to the five constituents.

('46', 125, 2, 9, 262526) I do not take it at present.

('46', 125, 2, 16, 263056) It is more useful in this poor country.

('46', 126, 2, 3, 263814) WARNING TO ME When my article entitled “Is This Humanity?” 1 had caused an uproar and I was being inundated with letters, there was one I had preserved because it was written with good intention.
('46', 126, 2, 4, 264010) It was dated 15 10 1926. As that letter served as a warning to me, I kept it in my file.
('46', 126, 2, 5, 264099) When every week I open my Navajivan papers, my eyes fall on the stanzas from Akha 2 in it.
('46', 126, 2, 6, 264190) The stanzas are: Subtle maya is a silent sword Killing pleasantly; Once she plunges, she will not withdraw, She eats up a learned scholar from within.
('46', 126, 2, 7, 264341) Myriad are the roles she plays, Taking what form she chooses, where.
('46', 126, 2, 8, 264410) If sense perchance dawns in any Turned scholar, like an innocent She will pray, A thing that deserves discarding That itself is made a victim, sings Akha.
('46', 126, 2, 9, 264565) Many are the forms that maya takes; We find them displayed wherever we look.
('46', 126, 2, 10, 264642) The letter is a long one.
('46', 126, 2, 11, 264668) It contains an argument against my article.
('46', 126, 2, 12, 264712) But its gist is this: whether, having fallen a prey to maya, I have not committed adharma in the name of dharma.
('46', 126, 2, 13, 264825) I did not feel so at that time and do not today.
('46', 126, 2, 14, 264874) But what of that?
('46', 126, 2, 15, 264892) It is indeed true that maya sweetly kills.
('46', 126, 2, 16, 264935) If I have been caught by maya and know it, how then can it be maya?
('46', 126, 2, 17, 265003) If a blind man can see, how can we call him a blind man?
('46', 126, 2, 18, 265060) How can I know when I shall be caught up in maya…I who am engrossed in many activities and finding retirement in them?
('46', 126, 2, 19, 265179) Hence by publishing the above stanzas and describing the context, I gain peace praying to God to save me from maya.
('46', 126, 2, 20, 265295) The thoughtful reader should certainly draw a lesson from this.
('46', 126, 2, 21, 265359) None should act beli eving that what I say is gospel truth because I am called a “mahatma”.
('46', 126, 2, 22, 265451) We do not know who a “mahatma” is.
('46', 126, 2, 23, 265486) It is a good

('46', 127, 3, 9, 266170) 116. A STUDENT
('46', 127, 4, 10, 266185) PREM [VIDYALA]YA, [June] 1 [6, 192]9 1
('46', 127, 5, 11, 266224) A student means one who hungers for knowledge.
('46', 127, 5, 12, 266271) Vidya means knowledge that is worth knowing.
('46', 127, 5, 13, 266316) Atma is the only thing worth knowing and so vidya is the knowledge of the Self.
('46', 127, 5, 14, 266396) But to acquire knowledge of the Self, one must study literature, history, geography, arithmetic, etc.
('46', 127, 5, 15, 266498) These are all means to an end.
('46', 127, 5, 16, 266529) Knowledge of the alphabet is necessary to get knowledge of these subjects.
('46', 127, 5, 17, 266604) But we know of persons having such knowledge without the knowledge of the alphabet.
('46', 127, 5, 18, 266688) Those who know this will not hanker after the knowledge of literature, etc., but they will seek the knowledge of the Self.
('46', 127, 5, 19, 266811) The student should forsake all those things which are obstacles in the pursuit of this knwoledge and should cultivate what is helpful.
('46', 127, 5, 20, 266946) The student life of one who understands this, never comes to an end and he goes on gaining knowledge while eating, drinking, sleeping, playing, digging, weaving, spinning or doing any other activity.
('46', 127, 5, 21, 267146) To be able to do this, one must develop a habit of observation.
('46', 127, 5, 22, 267210) Such a one does not need a group of teachers daily; in other words, he regards the whole world as his teacher and he goes on learning leasons from it.

('46', 128, 9, 22, 268405) We are today weighed down by our own selfishness and parochialism of outlook, we must cast it out.

('46', 129, 0, 1, 269288) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 129, 1, 2, 269330) In your annual report, you have referred to your financial diffi culties but I would ask you not to be disappointed by these difficulties but on the contrary, to regard them as a blessing in disguise.
('46', 129, 1, 3, 269531) If the advice of a person with an experience of 40 years of public life and public institutions at his back, as I claim to have got, can have any value for you, take it from me that a little financial stringency instead of being a misfortune to be deplored, is a thing to be welcomed as a blessing in disguise by any public institution that really wants to serve the people.
('46', 129, 1, 4, 269906) I hold that no institution that is worth its salt can be starved for want of funds.
('46', 129, 1, 5, 269990) More institutions are smothered by opulence than are killed by poverty.
('46', 129, 1, 6, 270062) Constant dependence on the public for funds teaches an institution the lesson of true humility and keeps it on the alert.
('46', 129, 1, 7, 270184) On the contrary, an institution that is altogether independent of the public for its support is liable to succumb to inertia and become lax in the performance of its duties.
('46', 129, 1, 8, 270358) The amount of public support that an institution can command affords a true measure of its utility.
('46', 129, 1, 9, 270458) I would therefore advise every institution that is faced with financial distress to curtail its activities so as to bring it within compass of its means rather than to keep up appearances by borrowing funds.
('46', 129, 1, 10, 270666) In the former case, the institution though reduced in size, will still retain its pristine health, in the latter case, its bloated size will only be a sign of its diseased condition.
('46', 129, 1, 11, 270849) I would therefore earnestly beseech you to keep clear of this fatal error.
('46', 129, 1, 12, 270924) I am glad to find that your institution has dedicated itself to khadi work and has given to the spinning wheel a central position in its activities.
('46', 129, 1, 13, 271073) But that is not enough.
('46', 129, 1, 14, 271097) I want you to understand the inner significance of this little wheel and to realize the full potency with which it is charged.
('46', 129, 1, 15, 271224) Twenty one years ago, I made the discovery, and since then I have never been tired of repeating it in season and out of season that there is no mightier agent for bringing together and tying in an indissoluble bond the teeming millions of India from Peshawar to Cape Comorin and from Karachi to distant Assam than the frail thread that is spun on this spinning wheel.
('46', 129, 1, 16, 271592) I would therefore suggest to you that you should not measure its worth in terms of rupees, annas and pies but in terms of the strength that it can generate, among the people.
('46', 129, 1, 17, 271767) Above all, I would ask you to keep your faith unsullied and untarnished in this age of scepticism and disbelief and never to lose heart.
('46', 129, 1, 18, 271904) For, remember that whilst it is given to man to strive, it is God alone who fulfils.
('46', 129, 1, 19, 271989) Young India, 27 6 1929

('46', 130, 1, 2, 272055) 119. LETTER TO SATIS CHANDRA DAS GUPTA
('46', 130, 2, 3, 272094) June 17, 1929
('46', 130, 3, 4, 272108) DEAR SATISBABU, I have your letter.
('46', 130, 3, 5, 272144) I see you are making steady progress in self supporting method.
('46', 130, 3, 6, 272208) I see also that you have plunged into the uncooked dietary.
('46', 130, 3, 7, 272268) I do not mind it so long as you can do it well without injuring the body.
('46', 130, 3, 8, 272342) I have found that pounding injures the vitality and the electricity as Dr. Muthu calls it.
('46', 130, 3, 9, 272433) It seems that this germinating seed food is as delicate as milk and perhaps equally, if not more, efficacious.
('46', 130, 3, 10, 272544) It seems never to cause disturbance if taken whole, it does cause disturbance when it is pounded.
('46', 130, 3, 11, 272642) If you have good teeth, insist upon taking the whole seed and the raw vegetable and fruit cleaned and chopped but not pounded.
('46', 130, 3, 12, 272769) Mastication is an indispensable condition of doing justice to uncooked food.
('46', 130, 3, 13, 272846) To avoid swallowing, let your morsels be small and well chewed, concentrate on that morsel you are chewing and see that it is reduced to a liquid before it passes down the throat.
('46', 130, 3, 14, 273026) This method may take 45 minutes per meal.
('46', 130, 3, 15, 273068) Do not grudge that time and have nobody near you at the time save the nearest companions.
('46', 130, 3, 16, 273158) When you have acquired the habit of proper mastication, you will do your work whilst eating.
('46', 130, 3, 17, 273251) For, uncooked whole food is clean and dirties nothing and can be carried about and even eaten whilst gently walking.
('46', 130, 3, 18, 273368) I used to chew my nuts and fruit walking during the marches in the Transvaal.
('46', 130, 3, 19, 273446) Uncooked food must contain nuts from which you get the oils.

('46', 136, 1, 2, 282135) 128. SPEECH TO CHRISTIAN COMMUNITY, ALMORA 1
('46', 136, 2, 3, 282180) June 18, 1929
('46', 136, 3, 4, 282194) Gandhiji’s reply which opened with a reference to his numerous Christian contacts in India as well as abroad and particularly his close friendly relations with the late Principal Rudra of St. Stephens’s College, Delhi, was a feeling appeal to the Indian Christians completely to identify themselves with Indian ideals and Indian nationalist aspirations, and not to regard India’s ancient culture and civilization as a relic of barbarism to be looked down upon and despised but to treasure it as a precious heritage that had to be enriched and enlarged.
('46', 136, 3, 5, 282747) Surely a civilization that had produced such a galaxy of saints and prophets as India had, that boasted of sons like Chaitanya and Tagore and which was built on penance of so many pure souls, could not be a thing wholly evil.
('46', 136, 3, 6, 282973) He held all religions to be true though at the same time no man expounded religion could claim perfection which was the attribute of God alone.
('46', 136, 3, 7, 283117) Similarly it was their duty not to disassociate themselves from their fellow countrymen who professed a different faith from theirs but to cultivate an attitude of sympathy and broad tolerance towards them, to understand and appreciate their viewpoint and to help them not by proselytizing them but by making Hindus better Hindus, Mussalmans better Mussalmans and all of them better Indians.
('46', 136, 3, 8, 283509) Young India, 27 6 1929
