('46', 138, 0, 1, 285710) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 139
('46', 138, 1, 2, 285753) 131. KHADI AND BOYCOTT
('46', 138, 2, 3, 285776) Our disbelief is an extraordinary phenomenon.
('46', 138, 2, 4, 285822) We have no faith in our ability to do anything.
('46', 138, 2, 5, 285870) If it is total prohibition, it is regarded as impossible.
('46', 138, 2, 6, 285928) Hindu Muslim unity is a day dream.
('46', 138, 2, 7, 285963) Removal of untouchability in the face of Sanatanist opposition is unthinkable.
('46', 138, 2, 8, 286042) Boycott of foreign cloth through mills we did not achieve, through khadi we cannot achieve.
('46', 138, 2, 9, 286134) There thus remains nothing that we can possibly do.
('46', 138, 2, 10, 286186) Hence swaraj is an impossible proposition and slavery our natural condition.
('46', 138, 2, 11, 286263) This is a most debasing state for anyone to be in.
('46', 138, 2, 12, 286314) Our disbelief is the greatest stumbling block in our march towards swaraj.
('46', 138, 2, 13, 286389) Let us just examine the proposition that boycott cannot be achieved through khadi.
('46', 138, 2, 14, 286472) It is said that khadi production is not enough for our wants.
('46', 138, 2, 15, 286534) Those who talk or write thus do not know the A B C of khadi.
('46', 138, 2, 16, 286595) Khadi is capable of infinite expansion because it can be as easily made as bread if we have the will.
('46', 138, 2, 17, 286697) I need not go into the economics of khadi for the purposes of boycott.
('46', 138, 2, 18, 286768) Supposing England and Japan ceased to send us their cloth and our mills somehow or other could not work, we would not think of the economics of khadi but we would simply manufacture the required quantity in our own homes.
('46', 138, 2, 19, 286990) The merchants who had lost their piecegoods trade would all be occupied in khadi production.
('46', 138, 2, 20, 287083) It is only because we have created a vicious atmosphere of impotence round ourselves that we consider ourselves to be helpless even for the simplest possible things.
('46', 138, 2, 21, 287249) But for our hopelessness, there is no reason why we should not feel that what Bijolia has been able to do without the stress and incentive of boycott, we should certainly do under the great and patriotic incentive.
('46', 138, 2, 22, 287464) It is being done today in Bardoli on such a scale that the technical department is unable fully to cope with the demand for wheels and accessories.
('46', 138, 2, 23, 287612) Undoubtedly the movement will fall flat if everybody becomes a critic and bystander and nobody says, “It is my business.” This movement depends for its success upon the willing and organized co operation of millions.
('46', 138, 2, 24, 287829) This co operation can be had for the asking if the thinking class will put their hands to the wheel with the fixed determination to succeed.
('46', 138, 2, 25, 287970) Let them remember that this is a movement which has a growing and vigilant organization with a modest capital.
('46', 139, 0, 1, 288081) 140 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 139, 1, 2, 288123) has only to be worked by the nation to its fullest capacity and success is a certainty.
('46', 139, 1, 3, 288211) Let it be remembered that there is no other constructive scheme before the nation for effective action on a universal scale.
('46', 139, 1, 4, 288336) I have repeatedly pointed out in these pages how production of khadi can be indefinitely increased.
('46', 139, 1, 5, 288436) I have described the three methods, viz., spinning for hire, spinning for self and spinning for sacrifice.
('46', 139, 1, 6, 288543) 1 Once the spirit of true sacrifice seizes the nation, it is possible to inundate the market with hand spun yarn.
('46', 139, 1, 7, 288657) And I have shown that the secret of khadi production lies in increased production of yarn.
('46', 139, 1, 8, 288748) There are over ninety seven lakhs of pupils studying in all the schools of India.
('46', 139, 1, 9, 288830) It makes a miserable percentage of less than 4 per cent of the total population, but the number is enough for easy organization of sacrificial spinning.
('46', 139, 1, 10, 288983) This figure takes no account of several other institutions that can be also similarly organized without much effort, if the determination is reached that we must achieve boycott through khadi.
('46', 139, 2, 11, 289176) Young India, 20 6 1929
('46', 139, 3, 12, 289199) 132. NOTES
('46', 139, 4, 13, 289210) SHETH JAMNALALJI’S ACTION As a self respecting man, Sheth Jamnalalji could not have acted otherwise than he had in reply to the request of the Deputy Commissioner of Police, Bombay, to deliver the copy in his possession of Pandit Sunderlalji’s History of British Rule.
('46', 139, 4, 14, 289479) He rightly regards the action of the U.P. Government as “high handed and tyrannical” and house searches all over India as “highly insulting,objectionable and vindictive”.
('46', 139, 4, 15, 289650) He claims to have read the book which in his opinion is “unobjectionable and a praiseworthy endeavour to inculcate the lesson of non violence”.
('46', 139, 4, 16, 289794) The action of the police in searching his house and offices in spite of his assurance that the book was not in any of them affords additional justification, if such was wanted, for the language used by him.
('46', 139, 4, 17, 290001) The object of the search was clearly not to find the book but to insult Jamnalalji.
('46', 139, 4, 18, 290085) The proper answer to this insult is for everyone who has Pandit Sunderlal’s volume in his possession to inform the police in his or her district and the press of such possession
('46', 139, 5, 19, 290263) 1 Vide “Progress of F.C.B.”, 30 5 1929
('46', 140, 0, 1, 290302) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 141
('46', 140, 1, 2, 290345) and challenge search or prosecution or both.
('46', 140, 1, 3, 290390) If this course is adopted by the public and if there are many copies still untraced, the Government will soon discover that it will make of itself a laughing stock by continuing the fruitless searches of numberless houses.
('46', 140, 1, 4, 290613) Searches, imprisonments and the like are effective only so long as they frighten people.
('46', 140, 2, 5, 290702) “GITA” IN NATIONAL SCHOOLS
('46', 140, 3, 6, 290729) A correspondent asks whether Gita may be compulsorily taught in national schools to all boys whether Hindus or non Hindus.
('46', 140, 3, 7, 290852) When I was travelling in Mysore two years ago, I had occasion to express my sorrow that the Hindu boys of a high school did not know the Gita.
('46', 140, 3, 8, 290995) 1 I am thus partial to the teaching of the Gita not only in national schools but in every educational institution.
('46', 140, 3, 9, 291110) It should be considered a shame for a Hindu boy or girl not to know the Gita.
('46', 140, 3, 10, 291188) But my insistence stops short at compulsion, especially so for national schools.
('46', 140, 3, 11, 291269) Whilst it is true that Gita is a book of universal religion, it is a claim which cannot be forced upon anyone.
('46', 140, 3, 12, 291380) A Christian or a Mussalman or a Parsi may reject the claim or may advance the same claim for the Bible, the Koran or the Avesta as the case may be.
('46', 140, 3, 13, 291528) I fear the Gita teachingcannot be made compulsory even regarding all those who may choose to be classed as Hindus.
('46', 140, 3, 14, 291643) Many Sikhs and Jains regard themselves as Hindus but may object to compulsory Gita teaching for their boys and girls.
('46', 140, 3, 15, 291761) The case will be different for sectional schools.
('46', 140, 3, 16, 291811) I should hold it quite appropriate for a Vaishnava school for instance to lay down Gita as part of religious instruction.
('46', 140, 3, 17, 291933) Every private school has the right to prescribe its own course of instruction.
('46', 140, 3, 18, 292012) But a national school has to act within well defined limits.
('46', 140, 3, 19, 292073) There is no compulsion where there is no interference with a right.
('46', 140, 3, 20, 292141) No one can claim the right to enter a private school, every member of a nation has the right presumptively to enter a national school.
('46', 140, 3, 21, 292276) Hence what would be regarded in the one case as a condition of entrance, would in the other be regarded as compulsion.
('46', 140, 3, 22, 292395) The Gita will never be universal by compulsion from without.
('46', 140, 3, 23, 292456) It will be so if its admirers will not seek to force it down the throats of others and if they will illustrate its teachings in their own lives.
('46', 140, 4, 24, 292601) 1 Vide “ Students and the “ Gita”, 9 9 1927

('46', 141, 1, 2, 292687) A CONTRADICTION The reader will recall a paragraph 1 I gave to a letter from an Andhra correspondent who had complained that the ladies at the women’s meeting at Tanuku had a purificatory bath after the meeting under the belief that the Antyaja girl Lakshmi was with me at that meeting.
('46', 141, 1, 3, 292974) Two correspondents have sent letters energetically protesting that the charge is wholly false.
('46', 141, 1, 4, 293069) I gladly reproduce one of the letters: 2
('46', 141, 2, 5, 293110) We were all surprised to read your note in Young India for the 16th
('46', 141, 3, 6, 293178) instant entitled “Untouchability” about the ladies’ meeting at Tanuku.
('46', 141, 4, 7, 293249) remarks are justified if what your correspondent wrote is true.
('46', 141, 4, 8, 293313) But I am sorry to
('46', 141, 5, 9, 293331) say your correspondent has erred grievously.
('46', 141, 6, 10, 293376) I was at the place of the meeting as the ladies of my family had been to
('46', 141, 7, 11, 293449) the meeting.
('46', 141, 7, 12, 293462) I am a Brahmin and my ladies have not had a purificatory bath.
('46', 141, 8, 13, 293525) know many ladies who attended and they assured me they never contemplated
('46', 141, 9, 14, 293599) such a thing.
('46', 141, 9, 15, 293613) Some might have bathed as they had to cook the evening
('46', 141, 10, 16, 293668) But to suggest that they did this to purify themselves from the touch of
('46', 141, 11, 17, 293741) a so called untouchable, is a gross libel.
('46', 141, 11, 18, 293784) Both the correspondents have given their names.
('46', 141, 11, 19, 293832) I have no reason to disbelieve their statements and I am sorry for hurting the feelings of the ladies who attended the meeting.
('46', 141, 11, 20, 293960) I had the name of the correspondent who had made the charge now contradicted.
('46', 141, 11, 21, 294038) I have therefore written to him to inquire how he came to make the serious charge.
('46', 141, 11, 22, 294121) it is a matter of joy to me that ladies nowadays resent the imputation that they would regard as pollution the presence of the so called untouchables at meetings attended by them.

('46', 141, 12, 24, 294324) 133. A FEW QUESTIONS A gentleman has asked me some questions.
('46', 141, 12, 25, 294386) This letter begins with praise of me.
('46', 141, 12, 26, 294424) He has described me as completely free from fear and ill will, a perfect tyagi 3 and a perfect satyagrahi.
('46', 141, 12, 27, 294531) Such adjectives are nearly always used in addresses, but as addresses are given to exaggeration, their use there may be considered excusable.
('46', 141, 12, 28, 294673) But the use of such adjectives in letters is unpardonable and discourteous.
('46', 141, 13, 29, 294749) 1 Vide “In Andhra Desha [ V]
('46', 141, 14, 30, 294778) 2 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('46', 141, 14, 31, 294815) 3 One who has renounced the fruit of action
('46', 142, 0, 1, 294859) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 143
('46', 142, 1, 2, 294902) uncivilized to praise a man to his face.
('46', 142, 1, 3, 294943) I have noticed such praise specially in Hindi letters.
('46', 142, 1, 4, 294998) That’s why I have mentioned it here.
('46', 142, 1, 5, 295035) In fact, I am not completely free from fear and ill will, nor am I a perfect satyagrahi or a perfect tyagi.
('46', 142, 1, 6, 295143) If you take the word ‘satyagrahi’ in its literal sense, I could perhaps be considered a perfect satyagrahi, because it is easy to insist on truth after we have understood its value.
('46', 142, 1, 7, 295325) One must also remember that insisting on truth is not the same thing as following truth.
('46', 142, 1, 8, 295414) I am fully aware that I am not completely free from fear and ill will or a perfect tyagi.
('46', 142, 1, 9, 295504) Mere external tyaga cannot make one perfect in these respects.
('46', 142, 1, 10, 295567) Internal tyaga is a highly difficult affair and I cannot claim at all that my heart is free from fear,ill will and the like.
('46', 142, 1, 11, 295692) It is true that my constant endeavour is to master my mind.
('46', 142, 1, 12, 295752) But the difference between effort and achievement is as great as that between earth and sun.
('46', 142, 1, 13, 295845) Therefore no one should think that I can never be wrong.
('46', 142, 1, 14, 295902) I try to see things dispassionately…with a mind cleansed of all impurity, and say only what I so see.
('46', 142, 1, 15, 296004) But one is free to reject it if it does not appeal to one’s reason.
('46', 142, 1, 16, 296072) Blind faith has caused us great harm.
('46', 142, 1, 17, 296110) I don’t wish others to have blind faith in me, I wish to avoid it.
('46', 142, 1, 18, 296177) It is a barrier in my way.
('46', 142, 1, 19, 296204) I will now discuss the questions put by this gentleman.
('46', 142, 1, 20, 296260) He and other readers can give them intelligent consideration.
('46', 142, 1, 21, 296322) This is the first question:
('46', 142, 2, 22, 296350) What are the ways and means needed to develop spiritual strength apart from listening to or recitation of scriptures?
('46', 142, 2, 23, 296468) I mean the kind of spiritual strength Prahlad and others had.
('46', 142, 2, 24, 296530) It is difficult, if not impossible, to acquire spiritual strength if we totally ignore listening or recitation.
('46', 142, 2, 25, 296642) Hearing pious things serves as the spark to light the fire of awakening during the time when the soul is asleep.
('46', 142, 2, 26, 296755) However, with the attainment of the inner seeing…the intuition…the need to hear good things vanishes.
('46', 142, 2, 27, 296857) Prahlad had this capacity of inner hearing in an abudant measure.
('46', 142, 2, 28, 296923) For the common man, the outer hearing is the first step.
('46', 142, 2, 29, 296980) The second qestion is this:
('46', 142, 3, 30, 297008) Is there no way of dealing with the problem of widows in India except
('46', 142, 4, 31, 297078) remarriage which lowers the banner of chastity…a way which will safeguard their
('46', 142, 5, 32, 297158) virtue and at the same time enable them to participate in work for the country?
('46', 142, 6, 33, 297238) India, there are more girls than boys and more widows than widowers.
('46', 142, 6, 34, 297307) How then can
('46', 142, 7, 35, 297320) this problem be solved by remarriage?
('46', 143, 0, 1, 297358) 144 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 143, 1, 2, 297400) To say that widow remarriage leads to loss of chastity is wrong.
('46', 143, 1, 3, 297465) To forcibly prevent a widow from remarrying, when she wishes to do so, would be harming chastity and dharma as well.
('46', 143, 1, 4, 297582) Only by marrying a child widow can we safeguard dharma and chastity.
('46', 143, 1, 5, 297651) We can safeguard brahmacharya only by respecting the widows, by providing them means of education, and by granting them full freedom to remarry.
('46', 143, 1, 6, 297796) Mental and physical prostitution is widespread today and the reason for this is the coercion used against widows.
('46', 143, 1, 7, 297910) It cannot be proved that there are more girls than boys or more widows than widowers.
('46', 143, 1, 8, 297996) It is true of a few castes.
('46', 143, 1, 9, 298024) It is however to be desired that the too many castes now existing should disappear.
('46', 143, 1, 10, 298108) There can be no more castes than the four varnas.
('46', 143, 1, 11, 298158) The Hindu Shastras do not authorize the existence of the innumerable castes found today.
('46', 143, 1, 12, 298247) It may be that the multiplication of castes served some useful purpose.
('46', 143, 1, 13, 298319) But today, castes serve no purpose and meet no need.

('46', 143, 2, 15, 298412) 134. SPEECH AT ALMORA
('46', 143, 3, 16, 298434) June 20, 1929 I have noted what you wanted to tell me in your addresses.
('46', 143, 3, 17, 298507) But at the moment, my heart is with Padam Singh…the man who was crushed under the car when he came to see me.
('46', 143, 3, 18, 298617) The doctor had hoped that he would survive and I had shared this hope.
('46', 143, 3, 19, 298688) But his life thread has snapped.
('46', 143, 3, 20, 298721) I have done a great deal of travelling and I have been doing it for the past many, many years.
('46', 143, 3, 21, 298816) I have taken part in many gatherings and in order to do this, I have travelled a lot by car, but in my old age, this is the first time such an unhappy incident has taken place.
('46', 143, 3, 22, 298993) I will never be able to get over it.
('46', 143, 3, 23, 299030) I believe that I have no fear of death.
('46', 143, 3, 24, 299070) All of us have to die one day.
('46', 143, 3, 25, 299101) Padam Singh has become immortal by meeting his death in this manner.
('46', 143, 3, 26, 299170) My unhappiness stems from the fact that I became the cause of his death.
('46', 143, 3, 27, 299243) I have always felt that riding in cars makes men proud.
('46', 143, 3, 28, 299299) The chauffeurs who drive are vain and hot tempered.
('46', 143, 3, 29, 299351) One should beware of drivers with a hot temper.
('46', 143, 3, 30, 299399) But under the illusion that I will be able to serve better, I continue to use cars.
('46', 143, 3, 31, 299483) I have reaped the fruit today.
('46', 143, 3, 32, 299514) And yet, I cannot promise to give up the use of cars, as I canot give up the fond desire to serve the country.
('46', 143, 3, 33, 299625) I must therefore content myself with expressing
('46', 144, 0, 1, 299673) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 145
('46', 144, 1, 2, 299716) my sorrow at this meeting.
('46', 144, 1, 3, 299743) The chauffeurs should remember that they must not be easily excited.
('46', 144, 1, 4, 299812) I could see that the driver of this car had a hot temper.
('46', 144, 1, 5, 299870) Padam Singh forgave him and gave a generous statement before the magistrate.
('46', 144, 1, 6, 299947) But I do not consider myself or the driver free from blame.
('46', 144, 1, 7, 300007) The unforgivable fact is that I should have got down in that crowd and it was the duty of the driver not to drive fast.
('46', 144, 1, 8, 300127) But that’s what he did.
('46', 144, 1, 9, 300151) How can I forget this sad fact?
('46', 144, 1, 10, 300183) Padam Singh was brave.
('46', 144, 1, 11, 300206) Yesterday, he was able to talk without effort.
('46', 144, 1, 12, 300253) But to die thus was his fate and it was my misfortune to witness his death, and now he is gone, I would like you to learn a lesson from this incident.
('46', 144, 1, 13, 300404) Caught in the jaws of Death, we are like puppets in the hands of Fate, more delicate than a piece of yarn.
('46', 144, 1, 14, 300511) In a short while, we all have to depart from this world.
('46', 144, 1, 15, 300568) Then why stray from the path of duty?
('46', 144, 1, 16, 300606) Why waste time in anger and in pleasure seeking?
('46', 144, 1, 17, 300655) In your address you say that you want freedom and swaraj for India.
('46', 144, 1, 18, 300723) You have also mentioned that swaraj can only be attained through peaceful means.
('46', 144, 1, 19, 300804) You must therefore remember that yourwork should be faultless.
('46', 144, 1, 20, 300867) It is easy to make it so.
('46', 144, 1, 21, 300893) The District Board address mentions that young pupils do spinning.
('46', 144, 1, 22, 300960) I would like to congratulate you on this.
('46', 144, 1, 23, 301002) You have said that you spend as much as 60 per cent of your income on education and that you consider even this insufficient.
('46', 144, 1, 24, 301128) Since you are working hard in the field of education, I would like to speak to you of my experience.
('46', 144, 1, 25, 301229) Even if we have crores of rupees, it is impossible to impart education in India in this way.
('46', 144, 1, 26, 301322) Education should pay for itself.
('46', 144, 1, 27, 301355) That is, we should not have to spend any money on it.
('46', 144, 1, 28, 301409) If we are successful in doing this, we will be able to achieve two things.
('46', 144, 1, 29, 301484) Firstly, we shall save money and secondly, we shall impart true education.
('46', 144, 1, 30, 301559) The eduaction given to our boys and girls today makes them unmindful of their morals, unhealthy and restless, whereas by making education self sustaining, we will be making them mentally poised and morally excellent.
('46', 144, 1, 31, 301776) I would request the District Board to try this out in two or three schools.
('46', 144, 1, 32, 301852) There is no doubt in my mind that you will be successful.
('46', 144, 1, 33, 301910) I am grateful for the purse.
('46', 144, 1, 34, 301939) As to the few presents given to me, you know now that I do not require such presents and I cannot accept them for my personal use.
('46', 144, 1, 35, 302070) If I do so, I shall stray from the right path and it will also detract from my fitness as a leader.
('46', 144, 1, 36, 302170) I will make an

('46', 148, 1, 2, 306969) 139. THE CONGRESS AND KHADI
('46', 148, 2, 3, 306997) Shri Chinoy writes: 1
('46', 148, 3, 4, 307019) We are reaping as we have sown.
('46', 148, 3, 5, 307051) As we have been indifferent in doing khadi propaganda, we are facing a difficult situation today.
('46', 148, 3, 6, 307149) I shall never advise enrolment of members by keeping the people in the dark.
('46', 148, 3, 7, 307226) On the contrary, I would not even say bluntly to those people: ‘You become members, but you will not get voting rights until your wear khadi.’ I would put in their hands a pamphlet for the purpose of explaining the position.
('46', 148, 3, 8, 307451) I would include in it the Congress provisions concerning khadi and set out the benefits and explain their duty of becoming members.
('46', 148, 3, 9, 307583) Our aim is not to frighten the people away but to attract them to the Congress.
('46', 148, 3, 10, 307663) The problem relating to students and lawyers is a difficult one.
('46', 148, 3, 11, 307728) They do understand everything.
('46', 148, 3, 12, 307759) If they do not like khadi, how can they be convinced?
('46', 148, 3, 13, 307813) Or, I would say to them: ‘If you believe in the Congress as a great force and not in khadi, join the Congress, wear khadi if only to observe the rules and try to get the khadi clause abrogated.
('46', 148, 3, 14, 308007) Congress work is carried on by majority opinion; hence, submit to the khadi clause until it is abolished and be proud to be its members.’ I would say that those who do not understand even this much are not fit to remain in the Congress or any other organization because they do not appreciate the first condition of remaining in any organization…submitting to rules.
('46', 148, 3, 15, 308374) They behave as if they were obliging the organization they join.
('46', 148, 3, 16, 308439) Such patrons cannot serve the Congress and no help will be forthcoming from them in winning swaraj.
('46', 148, 3, 17, 308539) Whichever organization they happen to be in, they will be a bruden to it.

('46', 148, 3, 19, 308747) I would only appeal to that category not to insist on the condition described by Shri Chinoy.
('46', 148, 4, 20, 308841) 1 The letter is not translated here.

('46', 148, 4, 22, 309014) There were at the time only 70 khadi wearing members on the register.
('46', 148, 4, 23, 309084) The rule that no member who did not wear khadi could vote or fill executive positions in the Committee stood in the way of enrolment.
('46', 148, 4, 24, 309218) The president of the local Youth League, too, had declined to enrol himself for this reason.
('46', 148, 4, 25, 309311) The correspondent could not enrol members keeping them in the dark about this condition.
('46', 148, 4, 26, 309400) So what was he to do?
('46', 149, 0, 1, 309422) 150 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 149, 1, 2, 309464) Our real task is to reach the classes we have neglected so far.
('46', 149, 1, 3, 309528) They are the merchants, craftsmen, farmers and labourers.
('46', 149, 1, 4, 309586) I believe that these classes will not advance the argument which the president of the Youth League is believed to have offered.
('46', 149, 1, 5, 309714) A bulletin meant for them would contain a short history of the Congress from its inception up to date, an account of its main activities and the benefits of joining the organization.
('46', 149, 1, 6, 309897) Whether they become members or not, such a movement itself constitutes the political education of the people.
('46', 149, 1, 7, 310007) It is my firm belief that where the Congress volunteers have been working and they are known , there should be no difficulty in enrolling the said classes as Congress members.
('46', 149, 1, 8, 310183) Now there remains the last question: What if, after everything is done, people do not enrol themselves because of the khadi clause?
('46', 149, 1, 9, 310315) In that case, this matter should be communicated to the Congress and we should get the khadi clause rescinded.
('46', 149, 1, 10, 310426) Or, if they themselves value khadi as much as swaraj, they should have patience till the people begin to believe in khadi.
('46', 149, 1, 11, 310549) Do we not have in India people who say that they do not want swaraj?
('46', 149, 1, 12, 310618) Again, if swaraj is interpreted to mean independence, more people will get alarmed.
('46', 149, 1, 13, 310702) Even if this happens, those to whom swaraj is their life breath will not relax the condition relating to swaraj.
('46', 149, 1, 14, 310815) I am personally neutral on the khadi clause.
('46', 149, 1, 15, 310860) Khadi is the very breath of life to me.
('46', 149, 1, 16, 310900) Hence I wish to see khadi wherever I am.
('46', 149, 1, 17, 310941) But I do not wish to insist on retaining the khadi clause in the Congress constitution.
('46', 149, 1, 18, 311029) If my other colleagues do not have as much faith in khadi as I have and if, in their opinion, that clause hampers the work propaganda will be continued even despite that.
('46', 149, 1, 19, 311200) And my belief will remain unshaken forever that swaraj will come near us by as many yards as the number of yards of khadi by which we step up its production.
('46', 149, 1, 20, 311358) To my mind, swaraj without khadi is as unthinkable as a barren woman having a son, becuase it would be no swaraj at all for the millions.

('46', 152, 3, 4, 315328) MIRA, 1 It is well you do not want me to speak to you tomorrow on the incident.
('46', 152, 3, 5, 315408) But I did want, after witnessing the exhibition, to reduce to writing my thoughts.
('46', 152, 3, 6, 315491) I do that now.
('46', 152, 3, 7, 315506) The exhibition is proof of the correctness of my statement.

('46', 152, 3, 9, 315655) You want to be with me in my tours occasionally, it is true; you want to come to the Ashram leaving your work at least every four months.
('46', 152, 3, 10, 315793) You recognize these desires as limitations.
('46', 152, 3, 11, 315837) I make allowance for them.

('46', 152, 3, 13, 315978) If you were not what I have described you to be, you would disease, but they are symptoms of a deep seated disease which has not rejoice over my drawing attention to the disease and courageously strive to overcome it.
('46', 152, 3, 14, 316196) Instead, you simply collapsed, much to my grief and anxiety.
('46', 152, 3, 15, 316257) This disease is idolatry.
('46', 152, 3, 16, 316283) If it is not, why hanker after my company!
('46', 152, 3, 17, 316326) Why touch or kiss the feet that must one day be dead cold?
('46', 152, 3, 18, 316385) There is nothing in the body.
('46', 152, 3, 19, 316415) The truth I represent is before you.
('46', 152, 3, 20, 316452) Experience and effort will unravel it before you, never my association in the manner you wish.
('46', 152, 3, 21, 316547) When it comes in the course of business you will, like others, gain from it and more because of your devotion.
('46', 152, 3, 22, 316658) Why so helplessly rely on me?
('46', 152, 3, 23, 316688) Why do everything to please me?
('46', 152, 3, 24, 316720) Why not independently of me and even in spite of me?
('46', 152, 3, 25, 316773) I have put no restric tions on your liberty, save those you have welcomed.
('46', 152, 3, 26, 316848) Break the idol to pieces if you can and will.

('46', 152, 3, 28, 316943) But you must give me the liberty to issue warnings.
('46', 152, 3, 29, 316995) My diagnosis may be wrong.
('46', 152, 3, 30, 317022) If so, it is well.
('46', 152, 3, 31, 317041) Strive with me cheerfully instead of being nerve broken.
('46', 152, 3, 32, 317098) Everyone but you takes my blows without being unstrung.

('46', 156, 5, 7, 321996) 149. A QUAINT ADDRESS
('46', 156, 6, 8, 322018) Among the Andhra notes still lying unattended to, I find the following extracts from a quaint but instructive address presented by the working hands of S.L.N. Factory, Nallagaka:
('46', 156, 7, 9, 322197) It was in the year 1916 we could see for the first time our cotton being
('46', 156, 8, 10, 322270) ginned by foreign mechanism driven by steam power.
('46', 156, 8, 11, 322321) Till then ginning
('46', 156, 9, 12, 322339) cotton in these parts was done by handgins when we had work enough for three
('46', 156, 10, 13, 322416) months of summer to feed ourselves and our children.
('46', 156, 10, 14, 322469) Our factory can now gin
('46', 156, 11, 15, 322493) the produce of 20 villages and only a limited number of us are allowed to work.
('46', 156, 12, 16, 322573) About the year 1920 when you were beginning to revive hand spinning
('46', 156, 13, 17, 322641) in storm beaten and almost worn out Northern India, there were few among
('46', 156, 14, 18, 322714) agricultural and labour classes in these parts who could buy cloth for daily use.
('46', 156, 15, 19, 322796) Eight years have rolled by.
('46', 156, 15, 20, 322824) Mill yarn has appeared in the market.
('46', 156, 16, 21, 322862) cheapness and evenness have attracted us.Self spinning has lost its
('46', 156, 17, 22, 322930) importance.
('46', 156, 17, 23, 322942) We have almost come to the stage of buying cloth, woven mainly
('46', 156, 18, 24, 323005) out of mill yarn by local weavers majority of whom come from the suppressed.
('46', 156, 19, 25, 323082) We still consider mill made cloth and foreign cloth to be matter of luxury only
('46', 156, 20, 26, 323162) fit to be used by Brahmin and Vaishya communities, the foremost to adopt
('46', 156, 21, 27, 323235) foreign cloth for daily use.
('46', 156, 21, 28, 323264) We have still belief in the quality of khadi cloth
('46', 156, 22, 29, 323315) and always prefer that if available at a reasonable price.
('46', 156, 23, 30, 323374) We generally use in these parts eight spoke charkha with an iron axis, all complete, costing Rs. 6, handgin costs Rs. 1 8 0, the cost of 20 tolas of
('46', 156, 24, 31, 323523) seedless cotton as.
('46', 156, 24, 32, 323543) 4, spindle costs Re.
('46', 156, 24, 33, 323564) 0 0 6, carding charge for 52 tolas of
('46', 156, 25, 34, 323602) cotton as.
('46', 156, 25, 35, 323613) 6 to 8, spinning 20 tolas costs as.
('46', 156, 25, 36, 323649) 2, arranging yarn to make cloth
('46', 156, 26, 37, 323681) of 30’X27” is as.
('46', 156, 26, 38, 323699) 3, weaving charge of cloth 30’X27” Re.
('46', 156, 26, 39, 323738) 1, male dhoti measures 10 1/2’X30” weighing nearly 30 tolas and female sari measures
('46', 156, 27, 40, 323823) 1 In reply to his telegram dated June 24 from Ahmedabad received at Almora on June 26, which read: “Please wire Ashram where when can I meet you this week.”
('46', 157, 0, 1, 323980) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 157, 1, 2, 324022) 30’X30” weighing nearly 140 tolas.
('46', 157, 1, 3, 324057) Carding is done by a professional carder,
('46', 157, 2, 4, 324099) carding and weaving charges are often paid in cholam grain, the chief food
('46', 157, 3, 5, 324174) crop of the district.
('46', 157, 3, 6, 324196) The labourer gets his cotton as wages when picking up
('46', 157, 4, 7, 324250) cotton from fields.
('46', 157, 4, 8, 324270) Fortunately your visit to these parts has happened in a
('46', 157, 5, 9, 324326) spinning season.
('46', 157, 5, 10, 324343) You can see some of the villagers, quite illiterate of the
('46', 157, 6, 11, 324402) present day civilization, still plying their charkhas.
('46', 157, 7, 12, 324457) Though our number is small (only 50), we represent the important
('46', 157, 8, 13, 324522) religions of the district, besides almost all communities and their sub sections
('46', 157, 9, 14, 324603) among Hindus.
('46', 157, 9, 15, 324617) We observe untouchability as regards food and drinking water.
('46', 157, 10, 16, 324679) One community of Hindus do not even drink water from the hands of another.
('46', 157, 11, 17, 324754) Among the suppressed there are more than four sub sections.
('46', 157, 11, 18, 324814) One sub section
('46', 157, 12, 19, 324830) of them does not allow another to touch even drinking well.
('46', 157, 12, 20, 324890) These suppressed
('46', 157, 13, 21, 324907) classes are made to live outside the villages and their chief occupation is
('46', 157, 14, 22, 324983) scavenging, spinning, weaving and shoemaking.
('46', 157, 15, 23, 325029) Muharram festival in these parts (we speak only of the villages) is
('46', 157, 16, 24, 325097) mainly conducted by Hindus funds and help.
('46', 157, 16, 25, 325140) Mohammedans help Hindus in
('46', 157, 17, 26, 325167) celebrating Hindu festivals.
('46', 157, 17, 27, 325196) In processions some of them actually carry on
('46', 157, 18, 28, 325242) their shoulders Hindu idols.
('46', 157, 18, 29, 325271) Hindus worship Muslim saints and are called by
('46', 157, 19, 30, 325318) Mohammedan names, and Mohammedans worship Hindu gods and are called by
('46', 157, 20, 31, 325389) Hindu names.
('46', 157, 20, 32, 325402) Though this is all through our illiteracy we seem to follow the
('46', 157, 21, 33, 325466) Sanskrit saying:
('46', 157, 22, 34, 325483) Buffalo is the chief milk producer and cow is scarcely reared for milking.
('46', 157, 23, 35, 325558) Oxen used for agriculture are imported from Northern Circars.
('46', 157, 23, 36, 325620) We have not got

('46', 159, 2, 4, 328712) 151. A TRAGEDY
('46', 159, 3, 5, 328727) Throughout a life of continuous bustle lived among crowds for nearly thirty years I cannot recall a serious accident though I can many narrow escapes.
('46', 159, 3, 6, 328878) But in Almora on the day of my entry, i.e., 18th instant, and after a crowded meeting, as I was returning to my host’s house, a villager named Padam Singh who came rushing as villagers do to the car for darshan met with what proved to be a fatal accident.
('46', 159, 3, 7, 329134) He could not dodge the car in time, fell and the car ran over him.
('46', 159, 3, 8, 329201) He was quickly carried by kind bystanders to the hospital where he received the utmost attention and hope was entertained that he would survive.
('46', 159, 3, 9, 329346) He was strongly built and brave.
('46', 159, 3, 10, 329379) He lived for two days, his pulse was good he was taking nourishment.
('46', 159, 3, 11, 329448) But the heart suddenly stopped on 20th instant at 3.15. Padam Singh died leaving an orphan boy 12 years old.
('46', 159, 3, 12, 329557) Death or lesser accidents generally do not give me more than a momentary shock, but even at the time of writing this I have not recovered from the shock.
('46', 159, 3, 13, 329711) I suppose it is because I feel guilty of being party to Padam Singh’s death.
('46', 159, 3, 14, 329788) I have found chauffeurs to be almost without exception hot tempered, easily excitable and impatient, as inflammable as the petrol with which they have to come in daily contact.
('46', 159, 3, 15, 329965) The chauffeur of my car had more than a fair share of all these shortcomings.
('46', 159, 3, 16, 330043) For the crowd through which the car was struggling to pass he was driving rashly.
('46', 159, 3, 17, 330125) I should have either insisted on walking or the car proceeding only at a walking pace till we had been clear of the crowd.
('46', 159, 3, 18, 330248) But constant moter riding had evidently coarsened me, and freedom from serious accidents produced an unconsious but unforgivable indifference to the safety of pedestrains.
('46', 159, 3, 19, 330420) This sense of the wrong is probably responsible for the shock.
('46', 159, 3, 20, 330483) It is well with Padam Singh.
('46', 159, 3, 21, 330512) Pandit Govid Vallabh Pant has assured me that the son will be well looked after.
('46', 159, 3, 22, 330593) Padam Singh received attention at the hospital which moneyed men might have envied.
('46', 159, 3, 23, 330677) He was himself resigned and at peace.
('46', 159, 3, 24, 330715) But his death is a lesson to me as, I hope, it would be to motorists.
('46', 159, 3, 25, 330785) Although I may be twitted about my inconsistency, I must repeat my belief that motoring in spite of all its advantages in an unnatural form of locomotion.
('46', 159, 3, 26, 330940) It therefore behoves those who use it to restrain their drivers and to realize that speed is not
('46', 160, 0, 1, 331037) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 161

('46', 161, 2, 9, 333839) 153. THE EVIL OF PURDAH
('46', 161, 3, 10, 333863) The belief that anything old is good is a source of numerous wrong practices.
('46', 161, 3, 11, 333941) If all that is ancient is considered good what about sin?
('46', 161, 3, 12, 333999) It is very old, but it will ever deserve to be discarded.
('46', 161, 3, 13, 334057) Untouch ability is also old, but it is a sin, therefore we should give it up.
('46', 161, 3, 14, 334135) The same is true of drinking and gambling.
('46', 161, 3, 15, 334178) If a thing which lies within the province of reason…which can be proved to be right or wrong with the aid of reason, does not appeal to reason, it would deserve to be immediately given up.
('46', 161, 3, 16, 334367) However old purdah may be, reason cannot accept it today.
('46', 161, 3, 17, 334425) The harm it has done is self evident.
('46', 161, 3, 18, 334463) We should not try to justify purdah as we do in the case of many other things by putting an ideal interpretation on this custom.
('46', 161, 3, 19, 334592) In fact the way it is now observed, it can stand no such interpretation.
('46', 161, 3, 20, 334665) The truth is that purdah is not an external affair, it is something internal.
('46', 161, 3, 21, 334743) Many women who observe purdah externally are found to be immodest.
('46', 161, 3, 22, 334810) However, a woman who retains her modesty without observing external purdah deserves to be worshipped.
('46', 161, 3, 23, 334912) And fortun ately there is no dearth of such women in the world even today.
('46', 161, 4, 24, 334987) In the scriptures we find many terms which had an external meaning at one time but which are interpreted at present anaogically.
('46', 161, 4, 25, 335116) One such is yajna.
('46', 161, 4, 26, 335135) Now we know that the killing of animals is not a true yajna.
('46', 161, 4, 27, 335196) True yajna consists in burning up the animal passions within us.
('46', 161, 4, 28, 335261) One can quote hundreds of such examples.
('46', 161, 4, 29, 335302) Therefore those desirous of reforming and saving Hindu society need not be afraid of ancient conventions.
('46', 161, 4, 30, 335408) We cannot find better principles than the old ones.
('46', 161, 4, 31, 335460) But the way they are to be put into practice must continue to change.
('46', 161, 4, 32, 335530) Change is a sign of growth while stagnation is the beginning
('46', 162, 0, 1, 335591) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 163
('46', 162, 1, 2, 335634) of decay.
('46', 162, 1, 3, 335644) The world changes every moment.
('46', 162, 1, 4, 335676) Only the dead do not change.
('46', 162, 1, 5, 335705) Immobility is thus a sign of death.
('46', 162, 1, 6, 335741) We are not talking here of the immobility, the calmness of the yogi.
('46', 162, 1, 7, 335810) In the calmness of the yogi there lies hidden the speediest motion.
('46', 162, 1, 8, 335878) There is in that calmness the utmost wakefulness of the atman.
('46', 162, 1, 9, 335941) We are talking here of inert immobility…in other words, of inertia.
('46', 162, 1, 10, 336009) Enslaved by this inertia we are driven willingly to acquiesce in all old evil customs.
('46', 162, 1, 11, 336096) It prevents us from making any progress.
('46', 162, 1, 12, 336137) This very inertia comes in our way in the attainment of swaraj.
('46', 162, 1, 13, 336201) Now let us see how the purdah causes us harm.
('46', 162, 2, 14, 336247) 1. It prevents women from receiving education.
('46', 162, 3, 15, 336294) 2. It makes them timid.
('46', 162, 4, 16, 336318) 3. It ruins their health.
('46', 162, 5, 17, 336344) 4. It comes in the way of normal relationship between men and women.
('46', 162, 6, 18, 336413) 5. It engenders in them a sense of inferiority.
('46', 162, 6, 19, 336461) 6. Women lose contact with the outside world and as a result they are deprived of their due experience.
('46', 162, 6, 20, 336565) 7. It prevents a woman from performing her role as man’s better half.
('46', 162, 6, 21, 336635) 8. Those women whose observe purdah cannot play their full role in the struggle for swaraj.
('46', 162, 6, 22, 336727) 9. Purdah comes in the way of children’s education.
('46', 162, 6, 23, 336779) Considering all these ill effects, it is the duty of all intelligent Hindus to do away with this evil custom.
('46', 162, 6, 24, 336889) As with the other reforms so also with the purdah.
('46', 162, 6, 25, 336940) Charity must begin at home.
('46', 162, 6, 26, 336968) When others observe the good results of our actions, they will naturally emulate our example.
('46', 162, 6, 27, 337062) It is, however, important to remember one thing: A reformer must always be gentle and courteous.
('46', 162, 6, 28, 337159) If in doing away with purdah our aim is observance of restraint, then it is our duty to take this step and we will surely succeed in our effort.
('46', 162, 6, 29, 337304) But if what we aim at is not restraint but licence, it will not be possible to remove the purdah, because the public will then resent the move and in anger may even support this evil custom.
('46', 162, 6, 30, 337495) The people are pure in their hearts and cannot respect a movement with an impure objective.

('46', 175, 1, 2, 367355) Who is there that has not experienced the daily conflict within himself between the forces of Evil and the forces of Good?
('46', 175, 2, 3, 367478) DISCOURSE II By reason of delusion, man takes wrong to be right.
('46', 175, 2, 4, 367543) By reason of delusion was Arjuna led to make a difference between kinsmen and non kinsmen.
('46', 175, 2, 5, 367634) To demonstrate that this is a vain distinction, Lord Krishna distinguishes between body (not self) and atman (self) and shows that whilst bodies are impermanent and several, atman is permanent and one.
('46', 175, 2, 6, 367836) Effort is within man’s control, not the fruit thereof.
('46', 175, 2, 7, 367891) All he has to do, therefore, is to decide his course of conduct or duty on each occasion and persevere in it, unconcerned about the result.
('46', 175, 2, 8, 368031) Fulfilment of one’s duty in the spirit of detachment or selflessness leads to Freedom.
('46', 175, 3, 9, 368118) 30. This embodied one in the body of every being is ever beyond all harm, O
('46', 175, 4, 10, 368194) Bharata; thou shouldst not, therefore, grieve for anyone.
('46', 175, 5, 11, 368252) Thus far Lord Krishna, by force of argument based on pure reason, has demonstrated that atman is abiding while the physical body is fleeting, and has explained that if, under certain circum stances, the destruction of a physical body is deemed justifiable, it is delusion to imagine that the Kauravas should not be slain because they are kinsmen.
('46', 175, 5, 12, 368599) Now he reminds Arjuna of the duty of a Kshatriya.
('46', 175, 6, 13, 368649) 31. Again, seeing thine own duty thou shouldst not shrink from it; for there
('46', 175, 7, 14, 368726) is no higher good for a Kshatriya than a righteous war.
('46', 175, 8, 15, 368782) 32. Such a fight, coming unsought, as a gateway to heaven thrown open,
('46', 175, 9, 16, 368853) falls only to the lot of happy Kshatriyas, O Partha.

('46', 176, 1, 4, 370051) He then (32 37) shows how the highest truth and the performance of duty incidentally coincide with expediency.

The ignorant, revelling in the letter of the Vedas, declare that there is naught else; carnally minded, holding heaven to be their goal, they utter swelling words which promise birth as the fruit of action and which dwell on the many and varied rites to be performed for the sake of pleasure and power; intent, as they are, on pleasure and power, their swelling words rob them of their wits, and they have no settled attitude which can be centred on the supreme goal.
('46', 176, 6, 13, 371413) The Vedic ritual, as opposed to the doctrine of yoga laid down in the Gita, is alluded to here.
('46', 176, 6, 14, 371509) The Vedic ritual lays down countless ceremonies and rites with a view to attaining merit and heaven.
('46', 176, 6, 15, 371610) These, divorced as they are from the essence of the Vedas and short lived in their result, are worthless.

('46', 181, 1, 3, 381292) What must be borne in mind is that just as all Nature’s movements and processes are mechanical and yet guided by Divine Intelligence or Will, even so man must reduce his daily conduct to mechanical regularity and precision, but he must do so intelligently.

('46', 183, 2, 4, 386381) DISCOURSE IV
('46', 183, 3, 5, 386394) This discourse further explains the subject matter of the third and describes the various kinds of sacrifice.
('46', 183, 4, 6, 386504) 6. Though unborn and inexhaustible in My essence, though Lord of all beings, yet assuming control over My Nature, I come into being by My mysterious power.
('46', 183, 5, 7, 386660) 7. For whenever Right declines and Wrong prevails, then O Bharata, I come to birth.
('46', 183, 6, 8, 386744) 8. To save the righteous, to destroy the wicked, and to re establish Right I am born from age to age.
('46', 183, 6, 9, 386846) Here is comfort for the faithful and affirmation of the truth that Right ever prevails.
('46', 183, 6, 10, 386934) An eternal conflict between Right and Wrong goes on.
('46', 183, 6, 11, 386987) Sometimes the latter seems to get the upper hand, but it is Right which ultimately prevails.
('46', 183, 6, 12, 387080) The good are never destroyed, for Right…which is Truth…cannot perish; the wicked are destroyed because Wrong has no independent existence.
('46', 183, 6, 13, 387219) Knowing this let man cease to arrogate to himself authorship and eschew untruth, violence and evil.
('46', 183, 6, 14, 387319) Inscrutable Providence…the unique power of the Lord…is ever at work.
('46', 183, 6, 15, 387388) This in fact is avatar, incarnation.
('46', 183, 6, 16, 387425) Strictly speaking there can be no birth for God.
('46', 183, 7, 17, 387474) 9. He who knows the secret of this My divine birth and action is not born again, after leaving the body; he comes to Me, O Arjuna.
('46', 183, 8, 18, 387605) For when a man is secure in the faith that Right always prevails, he never swerves therefrom, pursuing to the bitterest end and against serious odds, and as no part of the effort proceeds from his ego, but all is dedicated to Him, being ever one with Him, he is released from birth and death.
('46', 183, 9, 19, 387898) 10. Freed from passion, fear and wrath, filled full with Me, relying on Me, and refined by the fiery ordeal of knowledge, many have become one with Me.

('46', 188, 12, 17, 399304) This discourse is devoted to showing that renunciation of action as such is impossible without the discipline of selfless action and that both are ultimately one.
('46', 188, 12, 18, 399467) Arjuna said:

('46', 194, 1, 2, 411969) DISCOURSE VII
('46', 194, 2, 3, 411983) With this discourse begins an exposition of the nature of Reality and the secret of devotion.
('46', 194, 2, 4, 412077) The Lord said :
('46', 194, 3, 5, 412093) 1. Hear, O Partha, how, with thy mind rivetted on Me, by practising yoga and making Me the sold refuge, thou shalt, without doubt, know Me fully.
('46', 194, 4, 6, 412239) 4. Earth, Water, Fire, Air, Ether, Mind, Reason and Ego…thus eight fold is my prakriti divided.
('46', 194, 4, 7, 412335) This eightfold prakriti is substantially the same as the field described in XIII.5 and the perishable Being in XV.
('46', 194, 5, 8, 412450) 5. This is My lower aspect; but know thou My other aspect, the higher…which is jiwa (the Vital Essence) by which,O Mahabahu, this world is
('46', 194, 6, 9, 412589) sustained.
('46', 194, 7, 10, 412600) 6. Know that these two compose the source from which all beings spring; I am the origin and end of the entire universe.
('46', 194, 8, 11, 412720) 12. Know that all the manifestations of the three gunas, sattva, rajas, and tamas, proceed from none but Me; yet I am not in them, they are in Me.
('46', 194, 8, 12, 412867) God is not dependent on them, they are dependent on Him.
('46', 194, 8, 13, 412924) Without Him those various manifestations would be impossible.
('46', 194, 9, 14, 412986) 13. Befogged by these manifestations of the three gunas, the entire world fails

('46', 194, 13, 18, 413266) 25. Veiled by the delusive mystery created by My unique power, I am not manifest to all; this bewildered world does not recognize Me, birthless and changeless.
('46', 194, 13, 19, 413426) Having the power to create this world of sense and yet unaffected by it, He is described as having unique power.
('46', 194, 14, 20, 413539) 29. Those who endeavour for freedom from age and death by taking refuge in Me, know in full that Brahman, adhyatma and all karma.
('46', 194, 15, 21, 413669) 30. Those who know Me, including adhibhuta, adhidaiva, adhiyajna,
('46', 194, 16, 22, 413735) possessed of even mindedness, they know Me even at the time of passing away.

('46', 195, 0, 1, 414017) 196 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('46', 195, 1, 3, 414220) All his desires are extinguished in his vision of Him and he wins his freedom.

('46', 195, 11, 21, 415237) 1 Mahadev Desai explains: “Gandhiji has summed up in his brief note the gist of this quatrain for those who will not bother about technical terms.
('46', 195, 11, 22, 415384) A deeply spiritual friend has obliged me with an interpretation which lights up the apparent abracadabras with a deal of meaning: The shlokas describe the whole process in which the Absolute becomes conditioned and from the conditioned state becomes Absolute again.
('46', 195, 11, 23, 415650) (1) We have form the Impersonal, Unmanifest, Unconditioned Absolute; (2) It chose to reveal one of Its aspects…that aspect was primordial unmanifest prakriti…here called adhyatma; (3) Prakriti next became active this disturbance in the equilibrium of its gunas was karma work, action; (4) the next steps in the process were the countless manifestations of matter, with name and form…that is adhibhuta; (5) then the Absolute informed these with its Ego, i.e., became conditioned; that is adhidaiva; (6) but the conditioned had the potentiality to recover its pristine unconditioned state by means of giving of itself a pure sacrifice.
('46', 195, 11, 24, 416284) The culmination of this self sacrifice comes with the dissolution of the body and the merging or identification of the conditioned in the Unconditioned.
('46', 195, 11, 25, 416437) In short, it is the cycle of sacrifice that is described.
('46', 195, 11, 26, 416495) The Supreme Being sacrifices Himself in the first instance and ultimately the individual sacrifices himself to be merged in the original Essence.
('46', 195, 11, 27, 416641) III 15, which describes the same cycle of sacrifice.”

('46', 200, 10, 19, 426745) Mortal man can only imagine the Unmanifest, the Impersonal, and as his language fails him he often negatively describes It as ‘Neti’.
('46', 200, 10, 20, 426879) ‘Neti’ (Not That, Not That).
('46', 200, 10, 21, 426908) And so even iconoclasts are at bottom no better than idol worshippers.
('46', 200, 10, 22, 426979) To worship a book, to go to a church, or to pray with one’s face in a particular direction…all these are forms of worshipping the Formless in an image or idol.
('46', 200, 10, 23, 427139) And yet both the idol breaker and the idol worshipper cannot lose sight of thefact that there is something which is beyond all form, Unthinkable, Formless, Impersonal, Changeless.

('46', 201, 2, 3, 428066) 7. Of such, whose thoughts are centred on Me, O Partha, I become ere long the Deliverer from the ocean of this world of death.

('46', 201, 3, 5, 428376) ‘Practice’ (abhyasa) is the practice of the yoga of meditation and control of psychic processes; ‘knowledge’ (jnana) is intellectual effort; ‘concentration’ (dhyana) is devoted worship.

('46', 201, 4, 7, 428741) DISCOURSE XIII
('46', 201, 5, 8, 428756) This discourse treats of the distinction between the body (not Self) and atman (the Self).
('46', 201, 6, 9, 428847) 1. This body, O Kaunteya, is called the Field; he who knows it is called the knower of the Field by those who know.
('46', 201, 7, 10, 428963) 2. And understand Me to be, O Bharata, the knower of the Field in all the Fields; and the knowledge of the Field and the knower of the Field, I hold, is true knowledge.
('46', 201, 8, 11, 429132) 3. What that Field is, what its nature, what is modifications, and whence is what, as also who He is, and what His power…hear this briefly from Me.

('46', 203, 1, 2, 432365) Read in the light of discourses II, XI, and XII this shloka may not be taken to support any kind of libertinism.

('46', 203, 6, 17, 433864) DISCOURSE XIV
('46', 203, 7, 18, 433878) The description of prakriti naturally leads on to that of its constituents, the gunas, which form the subject of this discourse.
('46', 203, 7, 19, 434007) And that, in turn, leads on to a description of the marks of him who has passed beyond the three gunas.
('46', 203, 7, 20, 434111) These are practically the same as those of the man of secure understanding (II.
('46', 203, 7, 21, 434191) 54 72) as also those of the ideal bhakta (XII.
('46', 203, 7, 22, 434238) 12 20).
('46', 203, 8, 23, 434246) 19. When the seer perceives no agent other than the gunas, and knows Him who is above the gunas, he attains to My being.
('46', 203, 8, 24, 434367) As soon as a man realizes that he is not the doer, but the gunas are the agent, the ‘self’ vanishes, and he goes through all his actions spontaneously, just to sustain the body.
('46', 203, 8, 25, 434545) And as the body is meant to
('46', 204, 0, 1, 434573) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 205
('46', 204, 1, 2, 434616) subserve the highest end, all his actions will ever reveal detachment and dispassion.
('46', 204, 1, 3, 434702) Such a seer can easily have a glimpse of the One who is above the gunas and offer his devotion to Him.
('46', 204, 2, 4, 434805) 20. When the embodied one transcends these three gunas which are born of his
('46', 204, 3, 5, 434882) contact with the body, he is released from the pain of birth, death and age and attains
('46', 204, 4, 6, 434970) deathlessness.
('46', 204, 4, 7, 434985) Arjuna said:
('46', 204, 5, 8, 434998) 21. What, O Lord, are the marks of him who has transcended the three gunas?
('46', 204, 5, 9, 435074) How does he conduct himself?
('46', 204, 5, 10, 435103) How does he transcend the three gunas?
('46', 204, 6, 11, 435142) The Lord said:
('46', 204, 7, 12, 435157) 22. He, O Pandava, who does not disdain light, activity, and delusion when they come into being, nor desires them when they vanish;
('46', 204, 8, 13, 435289) 23. He who, seated as one indifferent, is not shaken by the gunas, and stays still and moves not, knowing it is gunas playing their parts;
('46', 204, 9, 14, 435428) 24. He who holds pleasure and pain alike, who is sedate, who regards as same earth, stone and gold, who is wise and weighs in equal scale things pleasant and unpleasant, who is even minded in praise and blame;
('46', 204, 10, 15, 435638) 25. Who holds alike respect and disrespect, who is the same to friend and foe, who indulges in no undertakings…that man is called gunatita.
('46', 204, 10, 16, 435778) 22 25 must be read and considered together.
('46', 204, 10, 17, 435822) Light, activity and delusion, as we have seen in the foregoing shlokas, are the products or indications of sattva, rajas and tamas, respectively.
('46', 204, 10, 18, 435968) The inner meaning of these verses is that he who has transcended the gunas will be unaffected by them.
('46', 204, 10, 19, 436071) A stone does not desire light, nor does it disdain activity or inertness; it is still, without having the will to be so.
('46', 204, 10, 20, 436192) If someone puts it into motion, it does not fret; if again it is allowed to lie still, it does not feel that inertness or delusion has seized it.
('46', 204, 10, 21, 436338) The difference between a stone and a gunatita is that the latter has full consciousness and with full knowledge he shakes himself free from the bonds that bind an ordinary mortal.
('46', 204, 10, 22, 436518) He has, as a result of his knowledge, achieved the repose of a stone.
('46', 204, 10, 23, 436588) Like the stone he is witness, but not the doer, of the activities of the gunas or prakriti.
('46', 204, 10, 24, 436680) Of such jnani one may say that he is sitting still, unshaken in the knowledge that it is the gunas playing their parts.
('46', 204, 10, 25, 436800) We who are every moment of our lives acting as though we were the doers can only imagine the state, we can hardly experience it.
('46', 204, 10, 26, 436929) But we can hitch our
('46', 205, 0, 1, 436950) 206 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 205, 1, 2, 436992) waggon to that star and work our way closer and closer towards it by gradually withdrawing the self from our actions.
('46', 205, 1, 3, 437110) A gunatita has experience of his own condition but he cannot describe it, for he who can describe it ceases to be done.
('46', 205, 1, 4, 437230) the moment he proceeds to do so, ‘self’ peeps in.
('46', 205, 1, 5, 437280) the peace and light and bustle and inertness of our common experience are illusory.
('46', 205, 1, 6, 437364) The Gita itself has made it clear in so many words that the sattvik state is the one nearest that of a gunatita.
('46', 205, 1, 7, 437477) Therefore everyone should strive to develop more and more sattva in himself, believing that some day he will reach the goal of the state of gunatita.

('46', 205, 3, 9, 437640) This discourse deals with the Supreme Form of the Lord, transcending kshara (perishable) and akshara (imperishable).

('46', 207, 2, 4, 441561) DISCOURSE XVII
('46', 207, 3, 5, 441576) On being asked to consider Shastra (conduct of the worthy) as the authority, Arjuna is faced with a difficulty.
('46', 207, 3, 6, 441688) What is the position of those who may not be able to accept the authority of Shastra but who may act in faith?
('46', 207, 3, 7, 441799) An answer to the question is attempted in this discourse.
('46', 207, 3, 8, 441857) Krishna rests content with pointing out the wocks and shoals on the path of one who forsakes the beaconlight of Shastra (conduct of the worthy).
('46', 207, 3, 9, 442002) In doing so he deals with faith and sacrifice, austerity and charity performed with faith, and their divisions according to the spirit in which they are performed.
('46', 207, 3, 10, 442166) He also sings the greatness of the mystic syllables AUM TAT SAT…a formula of dedication of all work to God.
('46', 207, 4, 11, 442274) 23. AUM TAT SAT has been declared to be the threefold name of Brahman and by that name were created of old the Brahmanas, the Vedas and sacrifices.
('46', 207, 5, 12, 442422) 24. Therefore, with AUM ever on their lips, are all the rites of sacrifice, charity and austerity, performed always according to the rule, by Brahmavadins.
('46', 207, 6, 13, 442578) 25. With the utterance of TAT and without the desire for fruit are the several rites of sacrifice, austerity and charity performed by those seeking Freedom.
('46', 207, 7, 14, 442735) 26. SAT is employed in the sense of ‘real’ and ‘good’; O Partha, SAT is also applied to beautiful deeds.
('46', 207, 8, 15, 442840) 27. Constancy in sacrifice, austerity and charity is called SAT; and all work for these purposes is also SAT.
('46', 207, 8, 16, 442950) The substance of the last four shlokas is that every action should be done in a spirit of complete dedication of God.
('46', 207, 8, 17, 443068) For AUM alone is the only Reality.
('46', 207, 8, 18, 443103) That only which is dedicated to It counts.
('46', 207, 9, 19, 443146) DISCOURSE XVIII
('46', 207, 10, 20, 443162) This concluding discourse sums up the teaching of the Gita.
('46', 207, 10, 21, 443222) It may be said to be summed up in the following: “Abandon all duties and come to Me, the only Refuge”: (66).
('46', 207, 10, 22, 443331) That is true renunciation.

('46', 207, 10, 24, 443476) Even the highest act of service must be dedicated to Him, without the desire.
('46', 207, 10, 25, 443554) That is tyaga (abandonment), that is sannyasa (renunciation).
('46', 208, 0, 1, 443616) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 209
('46', 208, 1, 2, 443659) 17. He who is free from all sense of ‘I’, whose motive is untainted, slays not nor is bound, even though he slay all these worlds.
('46', 208, 1, 3, 443790) This shloka though seemingly somewhat baffling is not really so.
('46', 208, 1, 4, 443855) The Gita on many occasions presents the ideal to attain which the aspirant has to strive but which may not be possible completely to realize in the world.
('46', 208, 1, 5, 444010) It is like definitions in geometry.
('46', 208, 1, 6, 444046) A perfect straight line does not exist, but it is necessary to imagine it in order to prove the various propostions.
('46', 208, 1, 7, 444163) Even so, it is necessary to hold up ideals of this nature as standards for imitation in matters of conduct.
('46', 208, 1, 8, 444271) This then would seem to be the meaning of this shloka: He who has made ashes of ‘self’, whose motive is undtainted, may slay the whole world, if he will.
('46', 208, 1, 9, 444425) But in reality he who has annilated ‘self’ has annihilated his flesh too, and he whose motive is untainted sees the past, present and future.
('46', 208, 1, 10, 444567) Such a being can be one and only one…God.
('46', 208, 1, 11, 444609) He acts and yet is no doer, slays and yet is no slayer.
('46', 208, 1, 12, 444665) For mortal man the royal road …the conduct of the worthy…is ever before him, viz., ahimsa…holding all life sacred.
('46', 208, 2, 13, 444780) 36. Hear now from Me, O Bharatarshabha, the three kinds of pleasure which is enjoyed only by repeated practice, and which puts an end to pain,
('46', 208, 3, 14, 444923) 37. Which, in its inception, is as poison, but in the end as nectar, born of the serene realization of the true nature of atman…that pleasure is said to be sattvik.
('46', 208, 4, 15, 445088) 47. Better one’s own duty, though uninviting, than another’s which may be more easily performed; doing duty which accords with one’s nature, one incurs no sin.
('46', 208, 4, 16, 445248) The central teaching of the Gita is detachment…abandonment of the fruit of action.

('46', 208, 4, 18, 445413) It is the spirit in which duty is done that matters, and its unattached performance is its own reward.

('46', 214, 7, 8, 454441) 162. A QUANDARY
('46', 214, 8, 9, 454457) A young man has written a long letter about the quandary facing him.
('46', 214, 8, 10, 454526) Following is its summary: I am 24. I passed the matriculation in 1923. Since then I have been in continuous employment.
('46', 214, 8, 11, 454646) I have been putting on pure khadi since 1921. I was married in 1924. We are four brothers and four sisters.
('46', 214, 8, 12, 454754) My mother is alive.
('46', 214, 8, 13, 454774) I came to understand my country and swadeshi since 1920 21. And thereafter I have worn khadi, regarding that as my duty.
('46', 214, 8, 14, 454895) But that much does not satisfy me.
('46', 214, 8, 15, 454930) I very much feel inclined to join the fight for swaraj.
('46', 214, 8, 16, 454986) But because of the immaturity of my thought and of vacillation between my duty to my parents and that to my country, I have had to mark time.
('46', 214, 8, 17, 455128) Our financial condition is not sound; on the contrary we are in debt.
('46', 214, 8, 18, 455198) But I feel that it is not easy to pay off the debts while having to meet expenses demanded by society.
('46', 214, 8, 19, 455301) The reason why I say all this to you is that since 1921, I was feeling that when my father’s economic condition permitted him to meet his daily wants comfortably and he had paid off his debts, I would join the fight for swaraj and be used up.
('46', 214, 8, 20, 455544) The plight to which the families in Orissa, Madras and other places have been reduced by the foreign Government’s
('46', 214, 9, 21, 455658) 1 In reply to a telegram dated June 28 from Nageshwara Rao and Garsan, Madras, recieved at Almora on June 29 which read: “Request early attention telegram and letter.

('46', 215, 0, 1, 455844) 216 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 215, 1, 2, 455886) policy of loot and plunder will also be ours and that of every family if that policy continues; because every year our country continues to waste its valuable manpower in addition to losing crores of rupees.
('46', 215, 1, 3, 456094) Hence in the present condition of the country, every man must, if for no other reason, at any rate for the benefit of his family, join in the fight for swaraj.
('46', 215, 2, 4, 456254) When I place these thoughts before my parents and seek their approval, they are deeply hurt and feel that I am not discharging my debt to them.

('46', 215, 2, 6, 456673) I have great regard for my family.

('46', 216, 1, 3, 458150) Would an adulterer commit adultery if he acted in accordance with his inner voice?
('46', 216, 1, 4, 458233) One should not hastily go against one’s father’s command or wish.

('46', 216, 1, 10, 458748) But a number of general rules can be suggested.
('46', 216, 1, 11, 458796) 1. Whenever parents give a piece of advice out of selfishness,it can be rejected courteously.
('46', 216, 1, 12, 458890) 2. When parents ask to be served and if this cannot be done in any other way, it is the son’s duty to serve them.
('46', 216, 1, 13, 459004) 3. But just as a son who has turned a sannyasi cannot run to the rescue of this parents even when they are in difficulty, so too the son who has dedicated his all to serving the country cannot abandon the service of his country.
('46', 216, 1, 14, 459233) 4. When parents expect more from their son than is required to meet their true needs, the son has a right to refuse their demand.
('46', 216, 1, 15, 459363) As for example, it is the son’s duty not to satisfy the wishes of his parents when they desire to incur undue expenditure on a wedding.
('46', 216, 2, 16, 459499) 5. If the parents want their son to commit adharma, it is never a duty to do it.

('46', 217, 1, 2, 460243) 163. SMALLPOX AND CHOLERA
('46', 217, 2, 3, 460269) A reader writes: 1
('46', 217, 3, 4, 460288) As long as we are ignorant and we malign women, the reign of superstition will continue.
('46', 217, 3, 5, 460377) Superstition is there even in educated Europe and America.
('46', 217, 3, 6, 460436) So long as man has the craving to live, etc., so long will superstition continue in greater or lesser degree.
('46', 217, 3, 7, 460546) But as we limit our cravings, so will superstition be on the decline.
('46', 217, 3, 8, 460616) But where a superstition can be recognized clearly, an attempt should be made to remove it.
('46', 217, 3, 9, 460708) Many people waste money in getting evil spirits exorcized during sickness and die prematurely.
('46', 217, 3, 10, 460803) In the case of a disease like smallpox, where generally no medicine is admini stered, superstition establishes a firmer sway.
('46', 217, 3, 11, 460929) Even the gooddess of smallpox gets a fair share of it.
('46', 217, 3, 12, 460984) The religious instinct is not at the bottom of this, but the craving to live.
('46', 217, 3, 13, 461062) I am firmly convinced that vows, etc., which are made merely to cure smallpox are a superstition and deserve to be discarded.
('46', 217, 3, 14, 461188) It has been proved that smallpox mostly results from insanitation.
('46', 217, 3, 15, 461255) In fact one whose blood has lost its vitality catches the infection.
('46', 217, 3, 16, 461324) The disease is not as devastating as is believed.
('46', 217, 3, 17, 461374) I have found no ground to modify what I have written in my book on health.
('46', 217, 3, 18, 461449) It is my experience in many cases that the disease is cured by proper care.
('46', 217, 3, 19, 461525) The patient ought to be provided enough air and light.
('46', 217, 3, 20, 461580) His clothes must be changed daily.
('46', 217, 3, 21, 461615) It is the experience of many doctors that hydropathy is beneficial.
('46', 217, 3, 22, 461683) Nowadays even chromo therapy is pressed into service.
('46', 217, 3, 23, 461737) But the object here is not to suggest remedies for smallpox, but to deprecate prevailing superstitions and to get them discarded as well as to lessen the fear of the disease.
('46', 217, 3, 24, 461912) Treatment must be sought at the hands of some knowledgeable and benevolent vaidya or doctor or one should acquire knowledge of hydropathy, etc., and master the treatment oneself.
('46', 217, 3, 25, 462091) Vaccination as a preventive remedy against smallpox is well known and, in general, doctors set great store by it.
('46', 217, 3, 26, 462205) In many countries, it has even been made compulsory.
('46', 217, 3, 27, 462258) I myself do not beleive in it.
('46', 217, 4, 28, 462289) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('46', 217, 4, 29, 462326) The correspondent had stated that there was an epidemic of smallpox and cholera and a number of superstitions were prevalent about these maladies.

('46', 220, 1, 4, 467704) How can one give up a religion in which the Vedas, the Upanishads and the Puranas were composed, in which myriads of men performed lifelong tapascharya, a religion whose adherents’ bones have added lustre to the Himalayas and blood has made the trees and flowers of the Himalayas blossom forth?
('46', 220, 1, 5, 467999) It is the reformers alone who have maintained this religion in a state of splendour by cutting down the dead wood of tradition.
('46', 220, 1, 6, 468127) In opposing tradition men like the Buddha, Mahavir, Shankar, Ramanuja, Kabir, Nanak, Chaitanya, Rammohan Roy, Ramakrishna, Dayananda, Vivekananda and others have pointed out the way to us.
('46', 220, 1, 7, 468316) These reformers, far from abandoning their religion, kept it fragrant and preserved it by breaking down bad traditions.
('46', 220, 1, 8, 468436) They were great; therefore they became famous as reformers.
('46', 220, 1, 9, 468496) We may not be known as reformers, but it is our duty within our limited field to save our religion by pulling down irreligion wherever the latter holds sway by usurping the place of religion.
('46', 220, 1, 10, 468688) “A Hindu Youth” should now understand: 1. The married state is not meant for the purpose of sexual indulgence.
('46', 220, 1, 11, 468799) It is for preserving the sacred love between man and woman and also for progeny.
('46', 220, 1, 12, 468880) Moreover, when both are possessed of passion, religion permits its satisfaction while observing certain limits.
('46', 220, 1, 13, 468992) People have held that the less such liberty is taken, the better it is.
('46', 220, 1, 14, 469064) Sexual union outside marriage or even union with one’s married partner merely for the satisfaction of one’s sexual urge is adultery.
('46', 220, 1, 15, 469197) 2. Adopting this attitude towards marriage, the “Youth” should seek a wife.
('46', 220, 1, 16, 469273) 3. He should make a vow not to offer even a cowrie or pice by way of bribe while making that quest.
('46', 220, 1, 17, 469373) 4. He should apply to his caste to secure such a girl for him.
('46', 220, 1, 18, 469436) 5. If he doe not secure one, having notified his caste, he should look for a girl belonging to the varna of his caste and should have confidence that if he has worth in him, he will get a suitable girl.
('46', 220, 1, 19, 469639) If he is not worthy, he should try to become so.
('46', 220, 1, 20, 469688) In doing this, his passion will abate and it will be easy for him to be patient in obtaining a girl.
('46', 220, 1, 21, 469789) 6. If he does not get a girl of the same varna since the varna system has now become weak and exists in name only, he should secure a girl from any other varna.
('46', 221, 0, 1, 469950) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 221, 1, 2, 469992) 7. If he cannot get a maiden, he should marry a widow.
('46', 221, 1, 3, 470047) 8. If he has the courage to effect reformin his caste, then even if he can get a girl from his own caste, he should, in order to break the practice of marrying from the circle of sub castes, insist on finding a girl of the same varna but from another caste.
('46', 221, 1, 4, 470305) 9. If he has the courage to introduce a reform in regard to widow remarriage and if he has the requisite fitness, he should insist on marrying no one but a widow belonging to the same or any other varna.
('46', 221, 1, 5, 470509) 10. Ultimately, he should firmly resolve that, if he does not get a girl despite observing the nine rules above and even disregarding caste restrictions,he will not forsake his dharma and will not indulge in adultery.

('46', 232, 7, 18, 489579) 180. THE KELLOGG PACT
('46', 232, 8, 19, 489601) In Young India of March 21st was printed an appeal issued at the
('46', 232, 9, 20, 489666) recent Conference of the Women’s International League for Peace and Freedom
('46', 232, 10, 21, 489742) in which occurs the following passage:
('46', 232, 11, 22, 489781) “The pact for the ‘renunciation of war’ has been signed by a large number of States.
('46', 232, 11, 23, 489866) The logical conclusion of this renunciation can only be disarmament.
('46', 232, 11, 24, 489935) And it is the only way to avoid fresh wars.” It is possible that some of the readers of Young India are not fully conversant with the
('46', 232, 12, 25, 490069) 1 From the reference to the statement given in court by Bhagat Singh and Dutta in the Assembly Bomb case, which was published in the Congress Bulletin dated July 1, 1929. 2 By Bhagat Singh, Dutta and some other prisoners in protest against the treatment meted out to them in jail
('46', 233, 0, 1, 490349) 234 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 233, 1, 2, 490391) genesis of this Pact, the Kellogg pact.
('46', 233, 1, 3, 490431) .On August 27, 1928, it was signed by fifteen States, and within five or six months, practically all the States of the world signified their intention of adhering to it.
('46', 233, 2, 4, 490601) It consists of only two very brief and simple articles, by the first of
('46', 233, 3, 5, 490673) which the signatories, in the names of their respective peoples, renounce war
('46', 233, 4, 6, 490751) as an instrument of national policy; while by the second, they agree never to
('46', 233, 5, 7, 490829) seek a settlement of any dispute, of whatever nature and whatever origin, save
('46', 233, 6, 8, 490908) by pacific means.
('46', 233, 6, 9, 490926) It thus stands as a clear and unqualified renuncaition of war.
('46', 233, 7, 10, 490989) How does all this affect India?
('46', 233, 7, 11, 491021) Do not her poverty and her subjection
('46', 233, 8, 12, 491059) make her powerless?
('46', 233, 8, 13, 491079) I think not....
('46', 233, 8, 14, 491095) Let the teachers in the schools and
('46', 233, 9, 15, 491131) colleges lead the way by seeing that the youths fully understand what this Pact
('46', 233, 10, 16, 491211) really is...When this knowledge has been assimilated by the educated, it will
('46', 233, 11, 17, 491289) in some form permeate the masses of the uneducated, preparing the way for the
('46', 233, 12, 18, 491367) stand India will take when she has attained her freedom.
('46', 233, 12, 19, 491424) I gladly publish L.E.’s contribution 1 and have no difficulty in agreeing that the Kellogg Pact has great possiblities, the patent insincerity of many signatories nothwithstanding.
('46', 233, 12, 20, 491605) I share to the full the apprehension about the Pact felt by the correspondent whose letter to Young India, L.E. has mentioned.
('46', 233, 12, 21, 491732) But this insincerity does not trouble me.
('46', 233, 12, 22, 491774) My difficulty is as to the suggestion made by L.E. about India’s part in promoting peace.
('46', 233, 12, 23, 491864) India’s contribution to peace must in the nature of things be different in kind from that of the Western nations.
('46', 233, 12, 24, 491978) India is not an independent nation.
('46', 233, 12, 25, 492014) And it may be inferred from her present position that she has not the will be independent.
('46', 233, 12, 26, 492105) The parties to the Pact are mostly partners in the exploitation of the peoples of Asia and Africa; India is the most exploited among them all.
('46', 233, 12, 27, 492248) The Peace Pact therefore in substance means a desire to carry on the joint exploitation peacefully.
('46', 233, 12, 28, 492348) At least that is how the Pact appears to me to be at present.
('46', 233, 12, 29, 492410) India has never waged war against any nation.
('46', 233, 12, 30, 492456) She has put up sometimes ill organised or half organized resistance in self defence pure and simple.
('46', 233, 12, 31, 492557) She has therefore not got to develop the will for peace.
('46', 233, 12, 32, 492614) She has that in abundance, whether she knows it or not.
('46', 233, 12, 33, 492670) The way she can promote peace is to offer successful resistence to her exploitation by peaceful means.
('46', 233, 12, 34, 492773) That is to say, she has to achieve her independence, for this year to be known as Dominion Status by peaceful means.
('46', 233, 12, 35, 492890) It she can do this, it will be the largest contribution

('46', 234, 1, 3, 493085) If my diagnosis is correct, it will be realized that the teaching such as L.E. wants in the schools can only be ineffective and what is worse, hypocritical.
('46', 234, 1, 4, 493242) Even if the teachers can make themselves believe in whay they may be called upon to teach, it will find no echo in the hearts of the boys and girls of their classes, even as a person who has never hurt a fly will fail to understand the meaning of an appeal made to him to will not to spill blood.
