('46', 234, 2, 6, 493561) 181. A PLEA FOR COMMON SENSE
('46', 234, 3, 7, 493590) A young man writes from Kashmir:
('46', 234, 4, 8, 493623) Some days ago, I bought a set of portraits of some of the great men of India.
('46', 234, 4, 9, 493701) Today I find that all these portraits are printed in Germany.
('46', 234, 4, 10, 493763) I am distressed to see what I have done…bought foreign things that were available in our own country, and the very sight of these portraits which was likely to inspire me with good ideas, is injuring my feelings.
('46', 234, 4, 11, 493976) My friends who are also of the same mind suggest to me to burn them; but this is a thing which my conscience does not allow, as these are the portraits of those great men who have sacrificed their lives for our country.
('46', 234, 4, 12, 494196) I request you to advise me in the matter.
('46', 234, 4, 13, 494238) I await your answer through your Young India.
('46', 234, 5, 14, 494284) Well may this young man want my answer through Young India.
('46', 234, 5, 15, 494344) I am glad the young man’s conscience has prevented him from burning the portraits.
('46', 234, 5, 16, 494427) It was no doubt wrong to have bought these portraits made in Germany.
('46', 234, 5, 17, 494497) But there is such a thing as common sense in the world.
('46', 234, 5, 18, 494553) Common sense is realized sense of proportion.
('46', 234, 5, 19, 494599) The way to redress such trivial mistakes as the young man fell into, is to be more careful in the future so as not to repeat them.
('46', 234, 5, 20, 494730) If the young man and his friends will search within and search also their surroundings, they will discover many more incongruities and foreign articles in and about them.
('46', 234, 5, 21, 494901) Let them begin the reformation by banishing the worst foreign things and the rest will go without an effort.
('46', 234, 5, 22, 495010) Here again, let these friends make use of common sense and understand that the adjective foreign is to be taken in its widest sense.
('46', 234, 5, 23, 495143) Anything that harms the inner being is foreign.
('46', 234, 5, 24, 495191) Do we not often strain at a gnat and swallow a camel?
('46', 234, 5, 25, 495245) Young India, 4 7 1929
('46', 235, 0, 1, 495267) 236 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 235, 1, 2, 495309) 182. MILL OWNERS AND BOYCOTT
('46', 235, 2, 3, 495338) Although I have before now dealt with this question in these pages, correspondents often inquire why the indigenous mills are not invited to take part in the foreign cloth boycott movement.
('46', 235, 2, 4, 495528) Others inquire what part these mills play in the movement.
('46', 235, 2, 5, 495587) Yet others ask why Congress workers should not directly encourage and advertise indigenous mill cloth side by side with khadi.
('46', 235, 2, 6, 495714) To take the last question first, these correspondents should remember that the Congress resolution contemplates the boycott through khadi.
('46', 235, 2, 7, 495853) There are sound reasons for this partiality.
('46', 235, 2, 8, 495898) Mill cloth alone has had its opportunity for the past fifty years and it has not brought boycott about.
('46', 235, 2, 9, 496002) Immediate boycott through the existing mills is an impossibility.
('46', 235, 2, 10, 496068) New mills cannot be started for the asking.
('46', 235, 2, 11, 496112) Therefore, if the boycott is to succeed, it can do so only through khadi.
('46', 235, 2, 12, 496186) Khadi cannot be pushed side by side with mill cloth.
('46', 235, 2, 13, 496239) Given the choice, it must be confessed with regret that the unthinking multitutde will prefer the apparently cheaper and easily obtainable calico to the apparently dearer and coarse looking and not easily obtainable khadi.
('46', 235, 2, 14, 496462) It follows therfore, that Congress workders, as far as their influence can reach…and it does not reach very far yet…must preach khadi to the exclusion of mill cloth.
('46', 235, 3, 15, 496628) This brings me to the second question.
('46', 235, 3, 16, 496667) But the exclusive preaching of khadi does not mean hostililty to the indigenous mill cloth.
('46', 235, 3, 17, 496759) Mill cloth is playing an important part in the movement whe ther the mill owners will or not.
('46', 235, 3, 18, 496853) The multitude buys it in competition with foreign cloth.
('46', 235, 3, 19, 496910) The mills have their agencies direct and indirect in all the parts of India.
('46', 235, 3, 20, 496987) As a distinguished mill owner once very properly remarked to me : “We do not want your help, we penetrate where you will perhaps never even make your voice heard.
('46', 235, 3, 21, 497150) If you preach our cloth, you simply invite us to raise our prices by creating a demand we cannot cope with.” He was silenced when I told him that I contemplated boycott not through mill cloth but through khadi.
('46', 235, 3, 22, 497361) He at once agreed that was quite a feasible proposition if I could produce enough khadi to displace foreign cloth and pupularize it.
('46', 235, 3, 23, 497494) Most mill owners recognize this as did the one I have quoted.
('46', 235, 3, 24, 497556) Any advocacy then on the part of Congressmen of mill cloth can only hinder boycott and ultimately even damage the mills by reason of the certain failure of the movement through the adoption of thoughtlesss
('46', 236, 0, 1, 497762) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 237
('46', 236, 1, 2, 497805) methods.
('46', 236, 1, 3, 497814) The reader should realize that repeated failures of the movement must result in deepening despondency and then making the people indifferent in their purchase of cloth.
('46', 236, 1, 4, 497983) We must avoid failure this time at any cost.
('46', 236, 1, 5, 498028) We may risk no avoidable mistake through sluggish or imperfect thinking.
('46', 236, 1, 6, 498101) It is the popular indifference that has given the foreign cloth dealer his vantage ground.
('46', 236, 1, 7, 498192) The moment the people are induced to think for themselves and make their choice, the boycott is a certainty.
('46', 236, 1, 8, 498301) The indigenous mills are therefore playing their part in the movement and profiting by it without assistance from Congressmen.
('46', 236, 1, 9, 498428) Now for the first question.
('46', 236, 1, 10, 498456) There is undoubtedly a way in which the mill owners can actively, deliberately and effectively help the movement.
('46', 236, 1, 11, 498570) An attempt was made last by Pandit Malaviyaji and Motilalji and myself to invite their active participation.
('46', 236, 1, 12, 498679) The attempt failed, perhaps because it was not in the nature of things possible for the mills actively to participate in terms of the Congress in any movement with which the Government do not openly associate themselves or which they are suspected of secretly disapproving.
('46', 236, 1, 13, 498953) The vast majority of them are under the influence of banking concerns which depend for their exestence on Government goodwill.
('46', 236, 1, 14, 499080) But if there are mills which can defy Government pressure, no matter how subtly exerted, here are the conditions under which they or anyone of them can directly participate in the movement wholly or partially : 1. They can sell khadi through their agencies; 2. they can lend their talents to the movement; 3. they can, by conference with the A.I.S.A., determine the varieties they should manufacture in terms of boycott; 4. they can cease to manufacture khadi whether in that name or any other; 5. they can standardize their prices so as neither to suffer loss nor to increase their profits; and 6. they can render financial assistance to the movement.
('46', 236, 2, 15, 499733) Several other ways may easily be deduced from the six chief ones I have mentioned.
('46', 236, 2, 16, 499816) This assistance can be given only if the mill owners and the shareholders are pariotically inclined and are prepared to limit their profits.
('46', 236, 2, 17, 499957) I am sure the majority of shareholders if they were properly canvassed would not object.
('46', 236, 2, 18, 500046) It is the capitalist who has
('46', 237, 0, 1, 500075) 238 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 237, 1, 2, 500117) therefore, really to decide.
('46', 237, 1, 3, 500146) As one of them told me, “We will come in when we must…not before.” He may be right.
('46', 237, 1, 4, 500230) Lastly, the reader should know that all mills because they are built on the Indian soil may not be called indigenous.
('46', 237, 1, 5, 500348) They are millsthat are indigenous only in name.
('46', 237, 1, 6, 500396) They are owned and managed by foreigners, their shareholders are foreigners, they exclude Indians from management or shares, the major part of their earnings is drained away from India.
('46', 237, 1, 7, 500582) The only thing that India gets out of their earnings is the paltry labourers’ wages.
('46', 237, 1, 8, 500667) These mills are no more indigenous than the existing Government.
('46', 237, 1, 9, 500732) These can never help the movement.
('46', 237, 2, 10, 500767) Young India, 4 7 1929
('46', 237, 3, 11, 500789) 183. DESTROY ALL HIMSA
('46', 237, 4, 12, 500812) Raja Mahendra Pratap is a great patriot.
('46', 237, 4, 13, 500853) For the sake of the country, this noble man has chosen exile as his lot.
('46', 237, 4, 14, 500926) He has given up his splendid property in Vrindavan for educational purposes.
('46', 237, 4, 15, 501003) Prem Mahavidyalaya now conducted by Acharya Jugalkishore is his creation.
('46', 237, 4, 16, 501077) The Rajasaheb has often corresponded with me.
('46', 237, 4, 17, 501123) And I have withheld from publication communications from him.
('46', 237, 4, 18, 501185) But the latest received from him I have not the heart to withhold.
('46', 237, 4, 19, 501252) Here therefore is his letter.
('46', 237, 5, 20, 501282) As a friend of humanity and your fellow countryman by birth, I demand of you kindly to publish the following thoughts in your worthy paper.
('46', 237, 5, 21, 501422) WHAT IS AHIMSA
('46', 237, 6, 22, 501437) I assert that I am a true follower of ahsima.
('46', 237, 6, 23, 501483) But it needs an explanation
('46', 237, 7, 24, 501511) of this word to clear my position.
('46', 237, 7, 25, 501546) It becomes still more necessary when I add
('46', 237, 8, 26, 501589) and affirm that many who call themselves the worshippers of this holy word
('46', 237, 9, 27, 501664) have no sense of its spirit.
('46', 237, 9, 28, 501693) Ahimsa, as I understand it, is not to give pain to anybody in mind or body by one’s though, talk or action.
('46', 237, 9, 29, 501801) However, to be a follower of this principle does not stop here.
('46', 237, 9, 30, 501865) A follower of ahimsa has to change all those conditions under which himsa is practised or becomes possible.
('46', 237, 9, 31, 501973) I call it worst kind of himsa, opposite of ahimsa,when a man tolerates or aids himsa of others.
('46', 237, 10, 32, 502069) Many people in India today deliver some very fine sermons on the beauties of ahimsa; however they do little to destroy the himsa of the British.
('46', 238, 0, 1, 502214) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 239
('46', 238, 1, 2, 502257) I say all such persons are abettors and aids to all that crime which the British commit in India against the weak, the hungry and the helpless.
('46', 238, 2, 3, 502401) Of course, no one can deny that our great leader Gandhiji has a very sincere desire to serve the Indian nation.
('46', 238, 2, 4, 502513) However, I am afraid that his methods alone, unsupported by some more energetic active programme, cannot bring relief to the people.
('46', 238, 3, 5, 502646) I highly appreciate and strngly endorse the khadi movement of Gandhiji.
('46', 238, 3, 6, 502718) It may or may not appreciably better the economic condition of the masses because there are today so many modern factors at work in our society; but in any case, the idea from the psychological standpoint is certainly admirable.
('46', 238, 3, 7, 502947) It directs the human thought to a simple life and awakens in the people a certain sense of unity.
('46', 238, 4, 8, 503045) I must, however, add that we need much more.
('46', 238, 4, 9, 503090) We have to destroy in the true spirit of ahimsa all that British organization which is himsa personified.
('46', 238, 5, 10, 503196) Let the nation as a whole strive to that end.
('46', 238, 5, 11, 503242) At the earliest possible moment let us put an end to the British brutalilty in India, in fact, in the whole world.
('46', 238, 5, 12, 503357) Let everyone perform his duty according to his natural endowments.
('46', 238, 5, 13, 503424) In the true spirit of ahimsa, I cannot force my will on others.
('46', 238, 5, 14, 503488) Let everyone find out for himself what one must do.
('46', 238, 5, 15, 503540) I can only point out the eternal truth that the Creator certainly wants the good of all his creatures…all the men and women…in our common human race.
('46', 238, 5, 16, 503690) If any man or group acts selfishly and oppresses others he surely misuses his gifts and acts against the wishes of the Creator.
('46', 238, 5, 17, 503818) I can only say: Let everyone try his or her best to destroy all himsa.
('46', 238, 5, 18, 503889) This is ahimsa.
('46', 238, 6, 19, 503905) Young India, 4 7 1929
('46', 238, 7, 20, 503927) 184. FOR SELF SPINNERS
('46', 238, 8, 21, 503950) A.I.S.A. members and all those who send self spun yarn as subscriptions or donations should be most careful about preparing and packing their yarn.
('46', 238, 8, 22, 504098) Every yard of yarn spun means so much added to the wealth of the country.

('46', 239, 4, 14, 505997) The marriage that was forced on Lakshmi Devi cannot be considered a religious marriage.
('46', 239, 4, 15, 506085) In a religious marriage, the girl should be told to whom she is getting married, her consent should be obtained for the marriage and if possible, she should be given an opporutnity to see the perspective bridegroom.
('46', 239, 4, 16, 506301) Nothing of the kind was done in Lakshmi Devi’s case.
('46', 239, 4, 17, 506354) Secondly, she was too young for wedlock.
('46', 239, 4, 18, 506395) Therefore she has a perfect right to refuse to countenance such a marriage, to refuse to recognize it as marriage.
('46', 239, 4, 19, 506510) The only heartening feature of this tragedy is that her mother is with her.
('46', 239, 4, 20, 506586) I congratulate the lady.

('46', 240, 2, 10, 507963) 186. FOREIGN SUGAR V. KHADI 1
('46', 240, 3, 11, 507993) A correspondent from the Meerut District writes:
('46', 240, 4, 12, 508042) Our family consists of about 30 or 32 members.
('46', 240, 4, 13, 508089) For several generations we have been following the vocation of sugar refiners.
('46', 240, 4, 14, 508168) We take crude molasses from the sugar planters and prepare white sugar from it by the indigenous process without employment of any machinery.
('46', 240, 4, 15, 508310) But for the last several years we have been hard hit by the competition of foreign and machine made sugar and the profits of our business do not suffice even to cover the ordinary wages of our labour.
('46', 240, 4, 16, 508511) The importation of foreign sugar further means a heavy drain of wealth from our country and yet you never open your lips on the subject which is rather surprising.
('46', 240, 4, 17, 508675) But that side of the question apart, we feel really at sea as to what we should do.
('46', 240, 4, 18, 508759) Our womenfolk still follow their traditional occupation
('46', 240, 5, 19, 508815) 1 Originally published in Hindi Navjivan, 4 7 1929, this and”The Running Sore”, 18 7 1929, appeared under the title”Notes from Hindi Navajivan” with the following introductory note by Pyarelal:”.

('46', 240, 5, 21, 509101) Apart from the fact that this special writing enables him to discharge his obligation towards a weekly of which he has been nominally editor all these years, he has found that it gives him an opportunity of coming into direct touch with the Hindi reading public and their peculiar problems which he could not do so well before.

('46', 241, 2, 3, 509692) I am sorry to have to advise these friends to give up their present occupation if sugar refining is truly an unprofitable concern.
('46', 241, 2, 4, 509823) For today, I really do not know how we can completely prevent the importation of foreign sugar into our country.
('46', 241, 2, 5, 509936) I consider sugar to be an unnecessary, even harmful article of consumption.

('46', 241, 3, 15, 510868) Unlike spinning, weaving provides a whole time occupation and what is more, it is a growing universal occupation with practically an unlimited scope before it.
('46', 241, 4, 16, 511028) As for the question of introducing khadi in his family to which the correspondent refers, it does not require much effort to spin fine yarn at home.
('46', 241, 4, 17, 511177) If only each member of the household in question will but make up his or her mind diligently to spend one hour daily on the spinning wheel, he or she can turn out the count that will suit his or her requirement and all the clothing needed in the family including fine saris, etc., can be had just for the charge of weaving yarn into cloth, while if like spinning, weaving is introduced in the household, as it well may be, it will constitute another big advance and simplify matters still further.

('46', 245, 3, 16, 517344) 192. THE OLD STORY 1
('46', 245, 4, 17, 517365) Elsewhere will be found a digest prepared by Mahadev Desai of reports of alleged oppression in the Dholka and Dashkroi taluks in connection with the recovery of taqavi advances.
('46', 245, 4, 18, 517543) In sending the digest Sjt.
('46', 245, 4, 19, 517570) Desai observes that he had hoped that the Government would have learnt wisdom from the Bardoli experience but that he had been sadly disillusioned.
('46', 245, 4, 20, 517718) In my opinion both the hope and the disappointment were wholly unwarranted.
('46', 245, 4, 21, 517794) The Government did not change its policy in the case of Bardoli, it was only compelled to yield under the pressure of organized resistance of the Bardoli peasantry and it is bound to do so again wherever such resistance is well organized.
('46', 245, 4, 22, 518033) Even so the peasantry of Dholka and Dashkroi taluks will find that no power on earth will dare to molest them once they have fully learnt the lesson of self respect.
('46', 245, 4, 23, 518199) The moral, however, which I want to draw from these happenings is that where the people have not shed their cowardice, they will continue to be oppressed, if not by a foreign Government, by their own kith and kin, a hundred Bardolis notwithstanding.
('46', 245, 4, 24, 518449) The first
('46', 245, 5, 25, 518459) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan, 7 7 1929. This is a translation by Pyarelal.

('46', 246, 1, 2, 518602) and foremost duty of national workers should therefore be to inculcate the lesson of fearlessness among the people.
('46', 246, 1, 3, 518718) We cannot have a Vallabhbhai to lead everywhere.
('46', 246, 1, 4, 518767) But every worker can in his own humble way try to emulate his qualities.
('46', 246, 1, 5, 518840) All may not have Vallabhabhai’s sagacity, his matchless courage and generalship but everyone can, and ought to be able to, develop a bit of his alertness and sleepless vigilance.
('46', 246, 1, 6, 519019) The Government, evidently, is determined to go on exacting more and more revenue so long as the people continue meekly to submit to its demands.
('46', 246, 1, 7, 519164) All that it cares for is the golden egg, no matter whether the goose that lays it lives or dies.

('46', 246, 1, 14, 519758) But the income of the Government falls short of its daily growing requirements and so its best brains are kept busy devising fresh ways and means of increasing taxation.
('46', 246, 1, 15, 519928) Unless, therefore, the present system of administration is completely changed, i.e., the expenditure considerably reduced, the oppression of the people will continue unabated even when the reins of Government have passed into Indian hands.
('46', 246, 1, 16, 520168) That is why I am never tired of repeating from the housetop that swaraj must mean a complete transformation of the present system of administration and not a mere change of hands.
('46', 246, 1, 17, 520348) But that will be possible only when the people have mastered the art of resisting unjust taxes.

('46', 246, 1, 19, 520594) Then when it becomes imperatively necessary, comes the undoubted right of the people to refuse to pay unjust taxes, undeterred by fines, prosecutions and worse.
('46', 246, 1, 20, 520755) But who is to teach this art to the people?

('46', 247, 1, 3, 521380) No general, however capable he may be, can fight a battle single handed.

('46', 253, 1, 2, 533761) 200. ALMORA IMPRESSIONS
('46', 253, 2, 3, 533785) HOSPITALITY When one meets with nothing but deep affection and great attention everywhere, it is difficult to give their respective measures.
('46', 253, 2, 4, 533927) I thought that Andhra Desha could not be equalled in this respect.
('46', 253, 2, 5, 533994) The experience of Almora following closely on the heels of Andhra compels a revision of the opinion.
('46', 253, 2, 6, 534095) For Almora did no less.
('46', 253, 2, 7, 534119) No pains were spared by the Almora friends to make my all too short a stay in the beautiful Himalayan hills most comfortable.
('46', 253, 2, 8, 534245) In one respect, they improved upon Andhra.
('46', 253, 2, 9, 534288) They would not make the reception expenses a charge upon.
('46', 253, 2, 10, 534346) They would not make the reception expenses a charge upon the various purses collected.
('46', 253, 2, 11, 534433) All the heavy motor expenses were borne by a few private friends.
('46', 253, 2, 12, 534499) The Committee would not listen to the expenses being paid of those who were travelling with me but were not of the staff and who were able to pay them.
('46', 253, 2, 13, 534651) “If they intend to pay, let them give what they choose to the khadi purse,” was the final reply.
('46', 253, 2, 14, 534748) Enough however of the necessary acknowledgment of this generous hospitality.
('46', 253, 2, 15, 534825) In these hills, Nature’s hospitality eclipses all that man can ever do.
('46', 253, 2, 16, 534897) The enchanting beauty of the Himalayas, their bracing climate and the soothing green that envelops you, leave nothing more to be desired.
('46', 253, 2, 17, 535035) I wonder whether the scenery of these hills and the climate are to be surpassed, if equalled, by any of the beauty spots of the world.
('46', 253, 2, 18, 535170) After having been for nearly three weeks in the Almora hills, I am more than ever amazed why our people need to go to Europe in search of health.
('46', 253, 3, 19, 535316) WHO IS UNTOUCHABLE?
('46', 253, 3, 20, 535336) Untouchability is a snake with a thousand mouths through each of which it shows its poisonous fangs.
('46', 253, 3, 21, 535437) It defies definition.
('46', 253, 3, 22, 535459) It needs no sanction from Manu or the other ancient law givers.
('46', 253, 3, 23, 535523) It has its own local smriti.
('46', 253, 3, 24, 535552) Thus in Almora a whole class of people, whose occupation is, even according to the Santana dharma so called, innocent, are untouchables.
('46', 253, 3, 25, 535689) They are all cultivators owning their own holdings.
('46', 253, 3, 26, 535741) They are called shilpi, i.e., farmers.
('46', 253, 3, 27, 535780) Another similar class of people called Boras suffer in the same manner although they do not even eat carrion or take liquor and observe all the rules of sanitation as well as any.
('46', 253, 3, 28, 535960) Tradition has condemned these as untouchables.
('46', 253, 3, 29, 536007) Hinduism that refuses to think accepts the tradition unquestioningly
('46', 254, 0, 1, 536076) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 255
('46', 254, 1, 2, 536119) and exposes itself to merited ridicule and worse.
('46', 254, 1, 3, 536169) Reformers are trying to cope with the evil.
('46', 254, 1, 4, 536213) I feel, however, that much more drastic methods are needed than are employed to rid Hinduism of the blot.
('46', 254, 1, 5, 536319) We are needlessly afraid to wound the susceptibilities of orthodoxy.
('46', 254, 1, 6, 536388) We have to shed the fear, if we expect to end the evil in our own generation.
('46', 254, 1, 7, 536466) This untouchability naturally recoils on the heads of those who are responsible for it.
('46', 254, 1, 8, 536554) In Almora, the choka…untouchability at the time of dining…has worked its insidious way even among castes and sub castes till at last every man makes himself an untouchable.
('46', 254, 1, 9, 536727) This choka exercises its evil sway even in national institutions like the Prem Vidyalaya.
('46', 254, 1, 10, 536817) I was considerably relieved when upon inquiry I found that none of the trustees believed in the choka, and that they were tolerating it so as not to scare the parents of the boys attending the institution.
('46', 254, 2, 11, 537023) NAYAKS Just as there is in the South a caste which dedicates to a life of shame girls euphemistically called Devadasis, so is there in Almora a caste called Nayak that similarly brings up its girls without anyeuphemism.
('46', 254, 2, 12, 537243) Nevertheless, it too defends the practice on religious grounds and thus drags with the girls religion too in the mire.
('46', 254, 2, 13, 537362) If God was a capricious person instead of being the changeless and unchangeable living Law, He would in sheer indignation wipe out all those who in the name of religion deny Him and His law.
('46', 254, 2, 14, 537553) The Servants of India Society is trying to wean the Nayak parents from the sin of degrading their daughters.
('46', 254, 2, 15, 537662) The progress made is slow, because the public conscience is asleep and man’s lust provides material reward for the indecency.
('46', 254, 3, 16, 537788) Young India, 11 7 1929

('46', 255, 18, 22, 539702) But the workers should bear in mind that the secret of the success of boycott through khadi lies in the recognition of the fact that we have to be manufacturers as we are consumers.

('46', 256, 2, 4, 540601) 202. SELF SUPPORTING EDUCATION
('46', 256, 3, 5, 540632) The Almora district Board address, which narrated the story of how it educated the children under its charge, and its very laudable attempt to instruct the boys in wool spinning and weaving, prompted me to repeat with greater emphasis than hitherto the opinion expr essed before by me that education should be self supporting.
('46', 256, 3, 6, 540959) The opinion has gathered force during my wanderings.
('46', 256, 3, 7, 541012) If the State has to bear the cost of education of millions of children, it will never be able to raise enough money by any conceivable measure of taxation.
('46', 256, 3, 8, 541168) That it is the primary duty of the State to bring to its schools every boy and girl and give them proper, not perfunctory (as now), education is an axiomatic truth.
('46', 256, 3, 9, 541333) But in a country like India such education must largely if not wholly pay itself.
('46', 256, 3, 10, 541415) And if we could but shed the hypnotic spell which our English tutors have cast over us, we should not find any difficulty in discovering ways and means of achieving the end.
('46', 256, 3, 11, 541589) With the best motives in the world, the English tutors could not wholly understand the difference between English and Indian requirements.
('46', 256, 3, 12, 541728) Our climate does not require the buildings which they need.
('46', 256, 3, 13, 541788) Nor do our children brought up in predominantly rural environment need the type of education the English children brought up in surroundings predominantly urban need.
('46', 256, 3, 14, 541955) When our children are admitted to schools, they need, not slate and pencils and books, but simple village tools which they can handle freely and remuneratively.
('46', 256, 3, 15, 542116) This means a revolution in educational methods.
('46', 256, 3, 16, 542164) But nothing short of a revolution can put education within reach of every child of school going age.
('46', 256, 3, 17, 542265) It is addmitted that the so called knowledge of the three R’s that is at present given in Government schools, is of little use to the boys and girls in after life.
('46', 256, 3, 18, 542429) Most of it is forgotten inside of one year, if only for want of use.
('46', 256, 3, 19, 542498) It is not required in their village surroundings.
('46', 256, 3, 20, 542548) But if a vocational training in keeping with their surroundings was given to the children, they would not only repay the expenses incurred in the schools but would turn that training to use in after life.
('46', 256, 3, 21, 542753) I can imagine a school entirely self supporting, if it became say a
('46', 257, 0, 1, 542821) 258 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 257, 1, 2, 542863) spinning and weaving institution with perhaps a cotton field attached to it.
('46', 257, 1, 3, 542940) The scheme I am adumberating does not exclude literary training.
('46', 257, 1, 4, 543005) No course of primary instruction would be considered complete that did not include reading, writing and arithmetic.
('46', 257, 1, 5, 543121) Only, reading and writing would come during the last year when really the boy or girl is the readiest for learning the alphabet correctly.
('46', 257, 1, 6, 543260) Handwriting is an art.
('46', 257, 1, 7, 543283) Every letter must be correctly drawn, as an artist would draw his figures.
('46', 257, 1, 8, 543358) This can only be done if the boys and girls are first taught elementary drawing.
('46', 257, 1, 9, 543439) Thus side by side with vocational training which would occupy most of the day at school, they would be receiving vocal instruction in elementary history, geography and arithmetic.
('46', 257, 1, 10, 543619) They would learn manners, have object lessons in practical sanitation and hygiene, all of which they would take to their homes in which they would become silent revolutionists.
('46', 257, 1, 11, 543796) The District Board of Almora and any other such Board which is unhampered by restrictions and which has a clear nationalist majority may try the experiment if it has faith and some members who will make it their business to see it through.
('46', 257, 1, 12, 544036) Above all, it is a question national educational institutions must tackle if they would justify their existence.
('46', 257, 1, 13, 544149) They have to conduct original researches, not reproduce clumsy imitations of those which they condemn and seek to replace.
('46', 257, 1, 14, 544272) No originality is claimed for the method advocated here.
('46', 257, 1, 15, 544329) Booker T. Washington tried it with considerable success.
('46', 257, 1, 16, 544386) If I recollect rightly, even the higher education he gave was self supporting.
('46', 257, 1, 17, 544465) In America, it is the most usual thing for even college boys to pay fully for their education by engaging in some kind of remunerative work.
('46', 257, 1, 18, 544606) The plan is different but the idea underlying is not.
('46', 257, 1, 19, 544660) Young India, 11 7 1929
('46', 257, 2, 20, 544683) 203. SYLHET INUNDATED

('46', 260, 1, 2, 549585) 1. How can a sanatani Hindu who is well versed in the doctrines of

('46', 260, 14, 19, 550991) The shrutis and smritis do not become scriptures merely because they are known by these respectable names.

('46', 260, 14, 22, 551345) In them are found statements that go against morality and reason.

('46', 261, 4, 19, 553701) 206. WIDOWS AND WIDOWERS
('46', 261, 5, 20, 553726) Even since I xpressed my views about widow remarriage 3 I have been receiving lots of questions.
('46', 261, 5, 21, 553823) Many which I feel do not need answering, I forget.
('46', 261, 5, 22, 553874) But the following questions deserve consideration:
('46', 261, 6, 23, 553925) 1. Up to what age should widows be permitted to remarry?
('46', 261, 7, 24, 553982) 1 Man of steadfast intellect 2 Those who have become one with Brahman; Vide Bhagavad Gita, II, 55 72.
('46', 261, 8, 25, 554084) 3 Vide “A Few Questions”, 20 6 1929
('46', 262, 0, 1, 554120) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 263
('46', 262, 1, 2, 554163) 2. If, after widow remarriage has been socially approved, a widow past the specified age should desire to remarry and insists on doing so, how can she be stopped?
('46', 262, 2, 3, 554326) 3. After widow remarriage has been socially approved, should widows with children, or those who are no longer young be allowed to remarry if they want to?
('46', 262, 3, 4, 554481) 4. An article written by Shri Ramanand Chatterjee, Editor, Modern Review, has appeared in Widow’s Cause, an English paper published from Lahore.
('46', 262, 3, 5, 554626) The article suggests that widows should be allowed to remarry up to the age of thirty five.
('46', 262, 3, 6, 554718) Is this right?
('46', 262, 4, 7, 554733) 5. Once the custom of widow remarriage becomes established, widows will wish to remarry and even those widows who had not so far considered remarriage out of respect for custom will start doing so.
('46', 262, 4, 8, 554931) There is no need to answer these questions separately for they are all prompted by a misunderstanding of my views.
('46', 262, 4, 9, 555046) The rights or latitude allowed to widowers should also be allowed to widows.
('46', 262, 4, 10, 555123) Otherwise, widows become victims of coercion and coercion is violence, out of which only harm can come.
('46', 262, 4, 11, 555227) The questions raised about widows are not raised about widowers.
('46', 262, 4, 12, 555292) It can only be because laws applying to women have been framed by men.
('46', 262, 4, 13, 555363) If law making had been the business of women they would not have given themselves fewer rights than men enjoy.
('46', 262, 4, 14, 555474) In countries where women have a hand in law making they have had the necessary laws enacted for themselves.
('46', 262, 4, 15, 555582) Thus the answer to the above questions is that it is the duty of the father to marry off his young widowed daughter.
('46', 262, 4, 16, 555699) As regards the rest no obstacles should beplaced in the way of those who wish to remarry.
('46', 262, 4, 17, 555789) There is no reason to believe that when such an arrangement comes into effect all widows would remarry.
('46', 262, 4, 18, 555893) In those countries where widow remarriage is allowed all the widows do not remarry, nor do all the widowers.
('46', 262, 4, 19, 556002) Only when widowhood is observed voluntarily is it worthy of praise.
('46', 262, 4, 20, 556070) Enforced widowhood is to be condemned and leads to promiscuity.
('46', 262, 4, 21, 556134) I know of many widows who do not wish to remarry though there are no restrictions imposed on them.

('46', 266, 1, 2, 560774) 213. MEANING OF THE TERM ‘FADDIST’
('46', 266, 2, 3, 560809) Readers have provided useful assistance in giving the meaning of the word ‘faddist’.
('46', 266, 2, 4, 560894) The equivalent of this word in Gujarati (dhuni) was sent in by four persons.
('46', 266, 2, 5, 560971) One of themis a lady who does not know English.
('46', 266, 2, 6, 561019) However, from the definition that I had given of it, she readily thought of the word 1dhuni’ and that is the word which comes nearest in meaning to the word ‘faddist’.
('46', 266, 2, 7, 561187) Some others had suggested the Gujarati equivalent of the word ‘crazy’ (chakram).
('46', 266, 2, 8, 561268) A faddist is never a crazy individual.
('46', 266, 2, 9, 561307) In English, there is a good word for the latter type of person…a ‘madcap’.
('46', 266, 2, 10, 561382) The other word that was suggested was dadharigo; that, however, will not do.
('46', 266, 2, 11, 561459) For those who know both English and Gujarati, it will be an interesting pastime to find out the equivalents in one language of words in the other, and if anyone compiles such a dictionary, it will be a useful thing.
('46', 266, 2, 12, 561675) It is not the function of the dictionary I have in mind to make sentences and thereby give the meaning of a Gujarati word in English and vice versa.
('46', 266, 2, 13, 561824) In the dictionary which I visualize, only the equivalents of words that are used in daily life in either of those two languages are given in both languages.
('46', 266, 2, 14, 561981) Anyone who is a diligent lover of the language can compile such a concise dictionary within a short period of time.
('46', 266, 2, 15, 562097) Such a small dictionary will prove very useful to those like me who do not wish to use English words while speaking Gujarati.
('46', 266, 2, 16, 562223) Anyone who has the ability, the interest and the time to spare should compile such a dictionary.
('46', 266, 2, 17, 562320) If it is sent over to me and if it is found useful, Navajivan will be prepared to publish it and pay something for it.
('46', 266, 2, 18, 562439) [From Gujarati]
('46', 266, 3, 19, 562455) Navajivan, 14 7 1929
('46', 266, 4, 20, 562476) 214. HOW TO DESCRIBE THEIR MAJESTY?
('46', 266, 5, 21, 562512) Although both Simla and Darjeeling are in the Himalayas, in neither of these places could I get an idea of their grandeur.
('46', 266, 5, 22, 562635) I stayed in these places only for a short while and they looked like British colonies to me.
('46', 266, 5, 23, 562728) It was in Almora that I got some idea of what the Himalayas are.
('46', 266, 5, 24, 562793) But for the Himalayas, there would be no Ganga, Jamuna, Brahmaputra and Indus; if the Himalayas were not there, there would be no rainfall and these rivers would not be there, and without rainfall India would become a desert like the Sahara.
('46', 266, 5, 25, 563035) Our far 
('46', 267, 0, 1, 563044) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 267, 1, 2, 563086) sighted ancestors who knew this and who were always grateful to God for the gifts that were bestowed on them turned the Himalayas into a place of pilgrimage.
('46', 267, 1, 3, 563244) Thousands of Hindus have sacrificed their lives in these parts in their search for God.

('46', 268, 4, 7, 565776) 215. IF SPINNERS ALSO WEAVE?
('46', 268, 5, 8, 565805) Shri Jethalal Govindji’s self confidence and enthusiasm are most extraordinary.
('46', 268, 5, 9, 565885) He has sent me the following report 1 which deserves consideration.
('46', 268, 6, 10, 565953) Where a spinner can weave, he is being encuraged to do so; however, it should be admitted that this is not being done with the same amount of fervour as shown by Shri Jethalal.

('46', 268, 6, 12, 566190) It is obviously desirable that all the processes involved in making khadi, including weaving it, should find a place in the farmer’s household.
('46', 268, 6, 13, 566334) It is for the sake of weaving that emphasis is laid on carding and spinning.

('46', 268, 6, 15, 566530) Once the activity of spinning becomes established, weaving will automatically find a place in the farmer’s household.
('46', 268, 6, 16, 566648) An army commander who has besieged a wall, does not start shelling the entire wall, but rather concentrates his attack upona small portion of it and makes a hole in it.
('46', 268, 6, 17, 566817) He regards himself as having triumphed when the first hole is made.
('46', 268, 6, 18, 566885) The mason who is engaged in the process of demolishing a wall does not bring down his hammer upon all the bricks but rather strikes a blow at a single key brick; once that crumbles, in an instant he knocks down all the rest with the help of a crowbar.
('46', 268, 6, 19, 567137) A somewhat similar argument applies to the stress laid on spinning.
('46', 268, 6, 20, 567205) This argument does not apply to Shri Jethalal.
('46', 268, 6, 21, 567252) He should not limit his self confidence at all.
('46', 268, 6, 22, 567300) It does, however, apply to the patience of those who feel dizzy on reading this
('46', 268, 7, 23, 567380) 1 Not translated here.

('46', 269, 4, 18, 568811) 216. ABOUT “NAVAJIVAN”
('46', 269, 5, 19, 568834) I have before me a pile of opinions sent by “lovers of Navajivan” regarding the publishing of news in this magazine.
('46', 269, 5, 20, 568951) Every day I am inundated with letters on this subject.
('46', 269, 5, 21, 569006) The readers have discussed the matter well and in an interesting manner.
('46', 269, 5, 22, 569079) If numbers alone are to be considered, the majority welcomes the suggestion for the inclusion of news items.
('46', 269, 5, 23, 569188) However, the number of persons who have opposed this idea is not small either.
('46', 269, 5, 24, 569267) And the reader will well understand that it is likely that there is deeper reflection behind the negative answers.
('46', 269, 5, 25, 569382) One of these is as follows: 1
('46', 269, 6, 26, 569412) Another gentleman has written in Hindi to this effect: ‘I read Navajivan in order to find happiness from a vision of truth.
('46', 269, 6, 27, 569536) I do not at all like the suggestion made by the “lover of Navajivan”.’ The above mentioned letters contain much that is in the same strain.
('46', 269, 6, 28, 569676) I have merely given the substance of these.
('46', 269, 6, 29, 569720) Let us put aside
('46', 269, 7, 30, 569737) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('46', 269, 7, 31, 569774) The correspondent had stated that during the nine years that he had been reading Navajivan he had no difficulty in understanding an article because no news items had been published along with them.
('46', 269, 7, 32, 569972) Young India and Navajivan were better than Indian Opinion because they contained “sacred articles” and no news.
('46', 270, 0, 1, 570084) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 271
('46', 270, 1, 2, 570127) their praise of Navajivan.
('46', 270, 1, 3, 570154) The sum and substance of their opinions is as follows: ‘The scope of Navajivan has already been defined.
('46', 270, 1, 4, 570259) By adding to its size, it would lose both ways.’ I feel that this argument is correct.
('46', 270, 1, 5, 570346) The temptation to include news items is indeed great.
('46', 270, 1, 6, 570400) However, it appears to be some sort of a craze.
('46', 270, 1, 7, 570448) No periodical can serve several purposes.
('46', 270, 1, 8, 570490) The task of Navajivan is to serve the cause of swaraj.
('46', 270, 1, 9, 570545) Hence my dharma is to engage my colleagues’ time merely in trying to achieve that end.
('46', 270, 1, 10, 570632) To utilize their energy even for other worthy causes would be as good as retarding the cause of swaraj.
('46', 270, 1, 11, 570736) This then is a fundamental consideration.
('46', 270, 1, 12, 570778) While considering the matter with Shri Mohanlal, I find that there are many practical difficulties too.
('46', 270, 1, 13, 570882) News items cannot at all be included without increasing the price of Navajivan and this I regard as undesirable.
('46', 270, 1, 14, 570995) Some persons are indeed of opinion that news items should be included even if it means increasing the price of Navajivan.
('46', 270, 1, 15, 571117) However, such generosity should not be taken advantage of.
('46', 270, 1, 16, 571176) Navajivan has to reach even the poorest of the poor sections of society.
('46', 270, 1, 17, 571249) If at all it were possible for me to do so, I would lowers its price, but would not increase it.
('46', 270, 1, 18, 571346) Moreover, there is a difficulty in the selection of news items.
('46', 270, 1, 19, 571410) What items are to be included and what are to be excluded?
('46', 270, 1, 20, 571469) The tone of the letters written by many persons implies that, since we do not get correct reports these days, Navajivan will be able to do that job.
('46', 270, 1, 21, 571618) This is an illusion.
('46', 270, 1, 22, 571639) The latter too, would have to depend upon inland and foreign telegrams and newspapers.
('46', 270, 1, 23, 571726) Navajivan is not in a position to employ its own correspondents and get reports from them.
('46', 270, 1, 24, 571817) No newspaper in India is in such a position.
('46', 270, 1, 25, 571862) The cables sent by Reuter and such other agencies are not reliable.
('46', 270, 1, 26, 571930) Almost all of them are motivated by self interest, are hurriedly despatched, involve partiality and are provocative.
('46', 270, 1, 27, 572047) Which of such news items should be included and which excluded?
('46', 270, 1, 28, 572111) I see other practical difficulties also.
('46', 270, 1, 29, 572152) Hence, I have finally arrived at the conclusion that there is no room for news items in Navajivan.
('46', 270, 1, 30, 572251) However, I found this discussion most interesting.
('46', 270, 1, 31, 572302) I am indebted to those who took part in it.
('46', 270, 1, 32, 572346) In particular, I have been enabled to understand my responsibility.
('46', 270, 1, 33, 572414) Much remains to be done in the way in which Navajivan is being conducted.
('46', 270, 1, 34, 572488) I shall attempt to do this if possible.
('46', 270, 1, 35, 572528) I have to abandon many subjects owing to lack of time and to my tours.
('46', 270, 1, 36, 572599) I shall try and take them up.
('46', 270, 1, 37, 572629) And I shall take care to
('46', 271, 0, 1, 572654) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('46', 271, 1, 3, 572847) In this manner, there will be no difficulty in understanding the subject matter.
('46', 271, 1, 4, 572928) My suggetion to those who hanker after news is that they should get it from elsewhere and they will lose nothing if they give up craving for it.

('46', 275, 9, 21, 579671) work you know…also that he was born in Bombay in 1847, returned to India as a missionary in Ahmednagar in 1875, and retired to America in 1926. He had been active until recently.

('46', 275, 11, 31, 580544) ANTI VACCINATION Sjt.
('46', 275, 11, 32, 580566) Krishnagopal Dutt of Sialkot wires:
('46', 275, 12, 33, 580602) Secretary, Anti vaccination League, Palghat, was imprisoned because he refused getting his son vaccinated.
('46', 275, 12, 34, 580709) Refer my statements Associatied Press.
('46', 275, 13, 35, 580748) 1 Non possessiveness
('46', 276, 0, 1, 580769) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 277
('46', 276, 1, 2, 580812) Pity people regard things other than political unimportant.
('46', 276, 1, 3, 580872) Poor Secretary imprisoned, noble cause, but country’s Press callously silent.
('46', 276, 1, 4, 580950) Kindly express your strong feelings in Press.
('46', 276, 2, 5, 580996) I congratulate the Secretary on his incarceration for the sake of conscience.
('46', 276, 2, 6, 581074) But I have no anger in me for the indifference of the public or the Press over the incident.
('46', 276, 2, 7, 581167) I am and have been for years a confirmed anti vaccinationist but I recognize that I must not expect public support for my views.
('46', 276, 2, 8, 581296) Anti vaccination has no backing from the orthodox medical opinion.
('46', 276, 2, 9, 581363) A medical man who expresses himself against vaccination loses caste.
('46', 276, 2, 10, 581432) Tremendous pecuniary interests too have grown round vaccination.
('46', 276, 2, 11, 581497) A sort of temporary immunity from smallpox is gained by vaccination though at much cost otherwise to the body and certainly to moral fibre.
('46', 276, 2, 12, 581637) But all this argument often based on solid experience counts for nothing against the tangible though temporary immunity from smallpox, which the person who has the filthy vaccine injected into his body gets.
('46', 276, 2, 13, 581845) It will be thus to the end of the world.

('46', 280, 0, 1, 590839) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 281

('46', 280, 1, 4, 591063) It is a rape of the word ‘law’.

('46', 281, 1, 5, 593379) But they may rest assured that I have taken in whatever was new and acceptable in their suggestions.
('46', 281, 1, 6, 593480) Several have asked me for further information on the progress of my experiment.
('46', 281, 1, 7, 593560) The experiment still continues.
('46', 281, 1, 8, 593592) There have been moments when I have weakly doubted the wisdom of continuing it.
('46', 281, 1, 9, 593672) This was when extreme weakness had overtaken me during the Andhra tour.
('46', 281, 1, 10, 593744) But my faith in the correctness of the theory behind unfired food and my partiality for it are so great that I would not easily give up the experiment.
('46', 281, 1, 11, 593896) For it has for me a value not merely sanitary but also economic and moral or spiritual.
('46', 281, 1, 12, 593984) It is of great importance to national workers who have to work in different parts of the country often in trying circumstances.
('46', 281, 1, 13, 594112) This food surmounts all the difficulty arising from the different food habits of the different provinces.
('46', 281, 1, 14, 594218) But of this more if I can write of the experiment with fairly absolute confidence.
('46', 281, 1, 15, 594301) At the time of writing, all I can say is that it seems to have done me no harm.
('46', 281, 1, 16, 594381) Dr. Ansari, who knows my body well, examined it carefully whilst I was in Delhi on the 5th instant and was of opinion that he had never found me to be in better health than now.
('46', 281, 1, 17, 594559) My blood pressure (systolic) which after the breakdown at Kolhapur 1 had never been found to be below 155 was now registered at 118, pulse pressure at 46. Though 118 he thought to be subnormal, it was not bad sign as I had just risen from a slight attack of malaria and I was then living on juicy fruits only.
('46', 281, 1, 18, 594869) My resolve to continue the experiment has been considerably strengthened by reading Dr. Muthu’s great work on tuberculosis and Colonel McCarrison’s instructive and carefully written food primer.
('46', 281, 1, 19, 595064) The former contains an illuminating chapter on diet and the latter which is dedicated to the children of India is popularly written and gives in a very concise manner all the information on nutrition that a layman need possess.
('46', 281, 1, 20, 595292) It is a book which needs to be read with caution.
('46', 281, 1, 21, 595342) It puts, naturually for the author but unduly according to my experiences, much emphasis on the necessity of animal food such as meat or milk.

('46', 285, 3, 9, 602113) It is certain that the charity of the wealthy does not put down poverty and famine relief measures do not put an end to conditions which cause famines.
('46', 285, 4, 10, 602265) The whole raison d’etre of the National Congress is to put an end to such terrible conditions by removing the root causes.
('46', 285, 4, 11, 602388) The Congress is convinced that only by changing the whole system of government and the structure of society can poverty be conquered and a measure of social well being introduced .
('46', 285, 4, 12, 602569) it is for this reason that the Congress associates itself with other organizations like the League against Imperialism, which also attack the root cause of poverty and inequality.
('46', 285, 4, 13, 602749) If the Government at present functioning in India were really desirous of attacking and eradicating poverty they would do something much more and vastly different from the petty relief they give in times of acute distress.
('46', 285, 4, 14, 602972) They would feel that in a country where there is such terrible poverty it is a tragic absurdity to have an expensive and top heavy system of administration.
('46', 285, 4, 15, 603129) They would feel that the whole political and economic system they have built up in the country, and the social structure they have bolstered up, have impoverished the country with great efficiency and rapidity, and this process continues.
('46', 285, 4, 16, 603368) They would realize that the responsibility for this poverty is theirs and therefore the speediest way of ending it is to remove themselves from the scene of action, liquidate their Government and make room for others who can tackle the problem with greater disinterestedness and competence than they have shown.
('46', 285, 5, 17, 603680) You will want a surer remedy giving more permanent results than the quack’s nostrum.
('46', 285, 5, 18, 603765) I trust that you will appreciate that this sure remedy lies in the complete replacement of the present system of government and a change in the social structure ..
('46', 285, 5, 19, 603929) Your co operation, moral and material, as well as the co operation of all others who object to the exploitation of a country or a people or a class by another will be welcome.

('46', 287, 7, 23, 607679) A Maheshwari young man from Sholapur referring to the question of marriages of child girls with old men writes: 3
('46', 287, 8, 24, 607793) Will you please advise as to the best way peaceful satyagraha can be offered in this behalf?
('46', 287, 9, 25, 607886) What, in your opinion, should be considered to be the proper age limit
('46', 287, 10, 26, 607957) for the bride and the bridegroom, respectively, for marriage?
('46', 287, 10, 27, 608019) And in what
('46', 287, 11, 28, 608031) circumstances would you recommend the offering of satyagraha for the
('46', 287, 12, 29, 608100) prevention of unequal marriages?.
('46', 287, 12, 30, 608134) Would you kindly let us have your opinion on all these points in the columns of Hindi Navajivan?
('46', 287, 13, 31, 608231) 1 V.S. Srinivasa Sastri 2 Originally published in Hindi Navajivan, 18 7 1929, this appeared under the title”Notes from Hindi Navajivan”.
('46', 287, 13, 32, 608368) For Pyarelal’s introductory note, Vide footnote on “Foreign Sugar v.
('46', 287, 13, 33, 608437) Khadi”, 8 8 1929 3 Only excerpts are reproduced here
('46', 288, 0, 1, 608490) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 289
('46', 288, 1, 2, 608533) There is no doubt that satyagraha is the right thing in such cases.
('46', 288, 1, 3, 608601) But how to offer it is another question.
('46', 288, 1, 4, 608642) I have more than once dilated, in my writings, on the limits of satyagraha.
('46', 288, 1, 5, 608718) Satyagraha presu pposes self discipline, self control, self purification, and a recognized social status in the person offering it.
('46', 288, 1, 6, 608850) A satyagrahi must never forget the distinction between evil and the evil doer.
('46', 288, 1, 7, 608929) He must not harbour ill will or bitterness against the latter.
('46', 288, 1, 8, 608992) He may not even employ needlessly offensive language against the evil person, however unrelieved his evil might be.
('46', 288, 1, 9, 609108) For it should be an article of faith with every satyagrahi that there is none so fallen in this world but can be converted by love.
('46', 288, 1, 10, 609240) A satyagrahi will always try to overcome evil by good, anger by love, untruth by truth, himsa by ahimsa.
('46', 288, 1, 11, 609345) There is no other way of purging the world of evil.
('46', 288, 1, 12, 609397) Therefore a person who claims to be a satyagrahi always tries by close and prayerful self introspection and self analysis to find out whether he is himself completely free from the taint of anger, ill will and such other human infirmities, whether he is not himself capable of those very evils against which he is out to lead a crusade.
('46', 288, 1, 13, 609734) In self purification and penance lies half the victory of a satyagrahi.
('46', 288, 1, 14, 609806) A satyagrahi has faith that the silent and undemonstrativ action of truth and love produces far more permanent and abiding results than speeches or such other showy performances.
('46', 288, 1, 15, 609985) But although satyagraha can operate silently, it requires a certain amount of action on the part of satyagrahi.
('46', 288, 1, 16, 610097) A satyagrahi, for instance, must first mobilize public opinion against the evil which he is out to eradicate, by means of a wide and intensive agitation.
('46', 288, 1, 17, 610251) When public opinion is sufficiently roused against a social abuse even the tallest will not dare to practise or openly to lend support to it.
('46', 288, 1, 18, 610393) An awakened and intelligent public opinion is the most potent weapon of a satyagrahi.
('46', 288, 1, 19, 610479) When a person supports a social evil in total disregard of a unanimous public opinion, it indicates a clear justification for his social ostracism.
('46', 288, 1, 20, 610627) But the object of social ostracism should never be to do injury to the person against whom it is directed.
('46', 288, 1, 21, 610734) Social ostracism means complete non co operation on the part of society with the offending individual; nothing more, nothing les, the idea being that a person who deliberately sets himself to flout society has no right to be served by society.
('46', 288, 1, 22, 610978) For all practical purposes this should be enough.
('46', 288, 1, 23, 611028) Of course, special action may be indicated in special cases and the practice may have to be varied to suit the peculiar features of each individual case.
('46', 289, 0, 1, 611182) 290 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 289, 1, 2, 611224) But what about the sensual old man who even in his decrepitude cannot help his sensuality?
('46', 289, 1, 3, 611315) Sensuality is blind; it cannot discriminate, it seeks satisfaction anyhow and at any cost.
('46', 289, 1, 4, 611406) How should society deal with such a man?
('46', 289, 1, 5, 611447) The reply is, by refusing to provide him with hapless victims.
('46', 289, 1, 6, 611510) The rule about not giving in marriage any girl below twenty and against her will should be rigorously enforced.
('46', 289, 1, 7, 611622) The question as to what the old man should do if no girl should be willing to marry him of her own accord naturally arises.
('46', 289, 1, 8, 611746) Society has no answer to such a question; it is not bound to furnish any.
('46', 289, 1, 9, 611820) It is concerened only with saving hapless girls from falling victims to blind lust.
('46', 289, 1, 10, 611904) It is no part of its duty to provide means for the satisfaction of the latter.
('46', 289, 1, 11, 611983) In practice, however, it will be seen that when purity pervades the social atmosphere it will serve largely to quell the lust of the lustful.
('46', 289, 1, 12, 612125) Young India, 8 8 1929

('46', 292, 4, 17, 616777) SUPPLEMENT TO “NAVAJIVAN” What Kakasaheb decided long ago has at last been put into effect today.
('46', 292, 4, 18, 616875) Hence along with this issue, the reader will receive with no extra cost a supplement to Navajivan entitled Shikshan ane Sahitya.
('46', 292, 4, 19, 617004) The management of Navajivan have taken a risk by resolving in this manner to publish this supplement, because Navajivan is not going to receive any financial benefit by doing so.
('46', 292, 4, 20, 617183) Behind this venture is, indeed, the expectation that lovers of literature will purchase more copies of these issues of Navajivan for the sake of this supplement.
('46', 292, 4, 21, 617345) Regardless of whether that hope materializes or not, it will be brought out every month around the full moon day.
('46', 292, 4, 22, 617459) I hope that everyone will go through the supplements carefully and preserve them.
('46', 292, 4, 23, 617541) It will be Kakasaheb’s constant endeavour to make this supplement more and more useful from the educational standpoint.
('46', 292, 4, 24, 617661) Ultimately, it is hoped that it will wholly become the organ of the expanding activities of the Vidyapith.
('46', 292, 4, 25, 617768) It will also contain news of the Vidyapith and the various national schools running in india.
('46', 292, 4, 26, 617862) There is, however, no need for me to anticipate the future.
('46', 292, 4, 27, 617922) The reader himself will see and evaluate the improvements that will be made in these issues from month to month.
('46', 293, 0, 1, 618035) 294 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 293, 1, 2, 618077) SAGRIFICIAL SPINNERS’ DHARMA Although everyone is aware of the story of bundle of sticks, it is worth refreshing one’s memory about it from time to time.
('46', 293, 1, 3, 618231) Even a delicate child can break a single stick.
('46', 293, 1, 4, 618279) However, even a giant like Ramamurthi 1 cannot break a whole bundle of sticks.
('46', 293, 1, 5, 618358) A single stick cannot even heat a little water, whereas a bundle can cook cereals for thousands of persons.
('46', 293, 1, 6, 618466) Similarly, sacrificial spinning practised by a single individual may well prove ineffective.
('46', 293, 1, 7, 618559) Sacrificial spinning practised by large number of persons can keep out cloth imported from Manchester, Japan and such other places and save one hundred million rupees which go out of India every year.
('46', 293, 1, 8, 618760) The Charkha Sangha has been founded following the worldly law which knows of no exceptions.
('46', 293, 1, 9, 618852) The very word ‘Sangha’ indicates the strength that underlies it.
('46', 293, 1, 10, 618917) Hence, those who believe in the strength of the spinning wheel, those who have faith in sacrificial spinning, should join the Sangha at this juncture and increase its strength.
('46', 293, 1, 11, 619094) And those who have already joined it should invite their neighbours to follow suit.
('46', 293, 1, 12, 619178) It should be borne in mind that even youths have a place in it.
('46', 293, 1, 13, 619242) Though youth associations have been formed at various places in the country, I do not find young men making proper or full use of the strength that lies in unity.
('46', 293, 1, 14, 619405) If all boys and girls studying in school realize the strength that underlies the takli, thousands of persons can enter the fold of the Charkha Sangha and a beautiful mountain of yarn can be raised every day.
('46', 293, 1, 15, 619613) In this manner, every man, woman, child or aged person can readily do this in addition to his or her regular occupation and thus contribute one’s share in the sacrificial offering that is swaraj.
('46', 293, 1, 16, 619809) Will power alone is required.
('46', 293, 1, 17, 619839) Hence if you do not spin already, you should start doing so, inspire others to do so, start wearing khadi if you do not already do so, inspire others to do so, join the Charkha Sangha if you do not already belong to it and invite others to follow suit.
('46', 293, 1, 18, 620092) Remember that spinning cotton yarn implies carding cotton and making it into strong even strands.
('46', 293, 1, 19, 620190) Strands that have been spun anyhow or which appear to be like a rope are not yarn.

('46', 294, 2, 5, 621036) 239. RESULTS OF THE VICTORY AT BARDOLI
('46', 294, 3, 6, 621075) It is only gradually that we shall come to know the importance of the victory gained at Bardoli.
('46', 294, 3, 7, 621172) 1 The final decision of the Gover nment of Bombay which it has communicated in its correspondance with Shri Shroff 2 is the necessary result of the triumph at Bardoli.
('46', 294, 3, 8, 621340) It will have its effect on the revenue department in the entire country.
('46', 294, 3, 9, 621413) And if there is real improvement in this department, if that department is freed from corruption, it would amount to securing three fourths of swaraj.
('46', 294, 3, 10, 621564) This is because a foreign government largely depends upon money for its very existence.
('46', 294, 3, 11, 621652) No one would run the government of another country merely for the pleasure of doing so, certainly not the British.
('46', 294, 3, 12, 621767) They have withdrawn their settlements from places where they have not earned any money.
('46', 294, 3, 13, 621855) One will rarely find in another department the chaos that is found in the Indian revneue department.
('46', 294, 3, 14, 621956) The peasants of Bardoli have shed light on this darkness.
('46', 294, 3, 15, 622014) However, there is nothing to be cheerful about the letter addressed to Shri Shroff.
('46', 294, 3, 16, 622098) No great hopes can be pinned on it.
('46', 294, 3, 17, 622134) Those in authority are experts in giving verbal promises and then violating them in practice; under the pretext of dispensing justice and introducing reforms, theyhave been found to perpetuate their real position and even to strengthen it further.
('46', 294, 3, 18, 622382) As a result of the Montagu Chelmsford reforms, officers have increased their salaries, consolidated their own positions, added to the expenditure of the army and strengthened the roots of their own businessmen.
('46', 294, 3, 19, 622593) Hence caution will be necessary to see to it that the hopes that the letter from the Government has raised in regard to reforms in the land revenue system are realized.
('46', 294, 3, 20, 622762) Bardoli has shown the way and cleared it.
('46', 294, 3, 21, 622804) Swaraj lies on that route alone and that alone is the cure for starvation.

('46', 295, 0, 1, 623012) 296 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 295, 1, 2, 623054) 240. WHAT IS ONE’S DHARMA?
('46', 295, 2, 3, 623081) The following letter 1 has been written by a friend to Shri Valji Desai.
('46', 295, 2, 4, 623154) There is a verse in the Gita which says that even the learned become exhausted in the process of reflecting on the real meaning of karma.
('46', 295, 2, 5, 623292) Here karma may be taken to mean dharma.
('46', 295, 2, 6, 623332) In my opinion, dharma means morality.
('46', 295, 2, 7, 623370) I do not know of any dharma which is opposed to or goes beyond morality.
('46', 295, 2, 8, 623443) Dharma is morality practised to its ultimate limits.
('46', 295, 2, 9, 623496) And morality in its turn means truth and non violence.
('46', 295, 2, 10, 623551) While the end is truth, non violence is the means of attaining it.
('46', 295, 2, 11, 623618) In such matters, however, the means cannot be separated from the end.
('46', 295, 2, 12, 623688) Hence I have written that truth and non violence are the two sides of the same coin.
('46', 295, 2, 13, 623773) However, the distinction between violence and non violence cannot always be definitely demarcated.
('46', 295, 2, 14, 623872) Non violence would hardly have any value if it was easy to make this distinction.
('46', 295, 2, 15, 623954) It is a fascinating field as it has no limits and countless persons have got tired exploring it.
('46', 295, 2, 16, 624051) Many others have laid down their lives while doing so.
('46', 295, 2, 17, 624106) Hence it always triumphs.
('46', 295, 2, 18, 624132) However, just because the field is so vast, some who have tried to dabble in it have also been misled.
('46', 295, 2, 19, 624235) This should be no cause for despondency but rather for special efforts.
('46', 295, 2, 20, 624307) My Jain brethren regard non violence as their monopoly; hence whenever I happen to transgress the boundaries of their non violence and attribute non violence to something beyond these limits, some of them are puzzled and some are annoyed, while others pity me.
('46', 295, 2, 21, 624568) I would like to tell all these three cateogories of people that, if they will have a little patience, the riddle of non violence can be solved to some extent.
('46', 295, 2, 22, 624727) I am a seeker and a worshipper, not one who has already attained the end; hence I am liable to make mistakes and deserve to be forgiven.
('46', 295, 2, 23, 624864) In this age of discoveries and exchange of ideas, no one will be harmed if I express my ideas.
('46', 295, 2, 24, 624959) If I have committed any mistakes, I
('46', 295, 3, 25, 624995) 1 This is not translated here.
('46', 295, 3, 26, 625026) The correspondent had asked whether uncooked food contained life in it, whether pulses soaked in water and sprouting should not be avoided.
('46', 295, 3, 27, 625166) These questions arose from Gandhiji’s article,”Raw v.
('46', 295, 3, 28, 625220) Cooked Food”, Vide “ Raw v.
('46', 295, 3, 29, 625248) Coolked Food”, 6 6 1929
('46', 296, 0, 1, 625272) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 297
('46', 296, 1, 2, 625315) shall correct them.
('46', 296, 1, 3, 625335) If there is any substance in my belief, other seekers will benefit thereby.
('46', 296, 1, 4, 625411) Let me now come to the subject matter.
('46', 296, 1, 5, 625450) My humble opinion is that perhaps there is some mistake in the prevalent Jain belief regarding diet.
('46', 296, 1, 6, 625551) From the standpoint of non violence, I feel that one commits an offence in killing plant life for the sake of food.
('46', 296, 1, 7, 625667) The least amount of violence is involved when anything that is edible is eaten directly after it is plucked from the tree.
('46', 296, 1, 8, 625790) All storage is full of violence.
('46', 296, 1, 9, 625823) There is untold violence in the touch of fire.
('46', 296, 1, 10, 625870) There is violence even in lighting a fire.
('46', 296, 1, 11, 625913) Then to consign green or dried substances to the fire involves even greater violence.
('46', 296, 1, 12, 625999) All this is self evident.
('46', 296, 1, 13, 626025) In not bringing vegetables near fire and not drying them, there is less processing of them.
('46', 296, 1, 14, 626117) All needless processing is stained with violence.
('46', 296, 1, 15, 626167) Anyone who eats vegetable products after drying or cooking them is not free from the original taint.
('46', 296, 1, 16, 626268) By killing vegetable matter when it is outside of one’s physical body and consuming it, one incurs the sin of killing it.
('46', 296, 1, 17, 626390) Pulses allowed to germinate are not rendered stale; pulses prior to germination are not lifeless.
('46', 296, 1, 18, 626488) Hence I see no objection in permitting these to germinate.
('46', 296, 1, 19, 626547) How cooked vegetables affect the body is a separate matter and one which deserves consideration.
('46', 296, 1, 20, 626644) My experience and that of other experimenters suggest that the body does not get the same satisfaction from eating cooked vegetables as it does from eating them fresh and tree ripened.
('46', 296, 1, 21, 626829) Whatever is cooked over fire has an intoxicating element within it.
('46', 296, 1, 22, 626897) hence it readily arouses passionate feelings.
('46', 296, 1, 23, 626943) My experience of the last four years goes to show that as soon as I started eating cooked food I lost the freedom from passions which I had acquired while eating raw vegetables.
('46', 296, 1, 24, 627121) I am again attaining to that passionless state now.
('46', 296, 1, 25, 627173) I have before me similar experiences which doctors have reported.
('46', 296, 1, 26, 627239) However I do not wish to add to the length of this article by quoting them.
('46', 296, 1, 27, 627315) If anyone wishes to read the literature, I shall give him the names of the books.
('46', 296, 1, 28, 627397) I have no defence for the use of honey.
('46', 296, 1, 29, 627437) I believe that it would be better if one could avoid it.
('46', 296, 1, 30, 627494) I do not recommend eating it to healthy persons.
('46', 296, 1, 31, 627543) Since I had not given it up, I started talking it when the doctor at Yervda specially recommended it to me and I still take it.
('46', 296, 1, 32, 627671) However, at the end of this experiment, I hope to give up honey.
('46', 296, 1, 33, 627736) I have already decreased the dosage.
('46', 296, 1, 34, 627773) I regard honey as being less harmful than sugar.
('46', 296, 1, 35, 627822) Both doctors and vaids are of opinion that, from
('46', 297, 0, 1, 627871) 298 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 297, 1, 2, 627913) the standpoint of health, it is preferable to sugar.
('46', 297, 1, 3, 627966) However, if this experiment succeeds, I will readily get from the items that are included in the experiment the same food value which I get from honey.
('46', 297, 1, 4, 628118) Not a single bee is harmed if honey is extracted by the improved technique, but this is no justification for taking honey.
('46', 297, 1, 5, 628241) I do not differentiate as between health, non violence and the ultimate aim of life.
('46', 297, 1, 6, 628326) Whatever is health giving should further the cause of non violence and should not be opposed to the ultimate aim of life.
('46', 297, 1, 7, 628448) What is in question here is health in its pure and real sense.
('46', 297, 1, 8, 628511) In this poor country, where society has become disorganized and millions are dying of starvation, the question of the ultimate end has become a difficult one.
('46', 297, 1, 9, 628670) However, it is required for the success of this experiment that it should be within the reach of the poor as well.
('46', 297, 1, 10, 628785) This, however, is a long term position.
('46', 297, 1, 11, 628825) I myself cannot conduct this experiment taking into account only the body.
('46', 297, 1, 12, 628900) I wish neither to survive nor to win swaraj by practising what I consider to be opposed to my dharma.
('46', 297, 1, 13, 629002) I consider it to be a man’s achievement to harmonize dharma and the ultimate aim of life, truth and swaraj; swaraj and government by all, the welfare of the country and the welfare of all.
('46', 297, 1, 14, 629191) That alone is the path that leads to moksha, that alone is what interests me.
('46', 297, 1, 15, 629269) None of my activities are carried on with any other end in view.
('46', 297, 1, 16, 629334) I do not know about the discovery made by Rishabhdev Swami.
('46', 297, 1, 17, 629394) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 21 7 1929
('46', 297, 2, 18, 629431) 241. PRODUCTION OF KHADI IN GUJARAT
('46', 297, 3, 19, 629467) Nowadays, there is an all round increase in the sale of khadi, but its production has not kept pace with it.
('46', 297, 3, 20, 629576) Gujarat has laid the foundation of the khadi movement but has not been able to build a solid structure over it.
('46', 297, 3, 21, 629688) One reason for this is quite clear.
('46', 297, 3, 22, 629724) Gujarat is the centre of the cotton textile industry.
('46', 297, 3, 23, 629778) If Bombay too is regarded as a part of Gujarat, 99 per cent of the cotton textile mills are located in Ahmedabad and Bombay.
('46', 297, 3, 24, 629903) It is for this reason that Gujaratis started wearing mill made cloth earlier and, as compared to other provinces, Gujarat shelves the spinning wheel sooner.
('46', 297, 4, 25, 630060) However, Gujarat has taken up the message of swaraj with entthusiasm.
('46', 297, 4, 26, 630130) Its contribution to constructive activity is very large.
('46', 298, 0, 1, 630187) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 299
('46', 298, 1, 2, 630230) Hence it is befitting that Gujarat should also attain a place that is worthy of it in the matter of khadi production.
('46', 298, 1, 3, 630348) Gujarati cannot possibly compete with Tamilnad and other regions.
('46', 298, 1, 4, 630414) It can, however, make as much progress as it wishes in the method of self reliance and in sacrificial spinning.
('46', 298, 1, 5, 630526) It does not matter if the spinning wheel is not adopted in Gujarat as a form of labour.
('46', 298, 1, 6, 630614) For the method of self reliance and sacrificial spinning, some sort of idealism is necessary.
('46', 298, 1, 7, 630708) If this idealism is generated and if the idea takes root that swaraj is bound up with yarn, the methods of self reliance and sacrificial spinning will succeed without the least difficulty.
('46', 298, 1, 8, 630897) Why cannot the municipalities of Gujarat and other places imitate what is being practised in Almora?
('46', 298, 1, 9, 630998) Why cannot those of us who have plenty of spare time learn to spin and start spinning regularly every day?
('46', 298, 1, 10, 631105) It is necessary to propagate this idea in every house.
('46', 298, 1, 11, 631160) Those who are engaged in door to door hawking of khadi should take up the task of producing khadi.

('46', 302, 7, 15, 636605) 250. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, KADI
('46', 302, 8, 16, 636641) Tuesday, July 23, 1929 I have been anxious to visit this institution 1 for the past year.
('46', 302, 8, 17, 636731) Ever since I heard that Shri Chhaganbhai Pitambardas and other individuals are devoting their entire life to this institution, I have been eager to come here.
('46', 302, 8, 18, 636890) It is laudable that this institution should be protected and nurtured by the citizens of Kadi and the people of Baroda State.
('46', 302, 8, 19, 637016) Your children will receive a good education if you are prepared to send them here.
('46', 302, 8, 20, 637099) Here you will find purity of thought and conduct which are even more valuable than a knowledge of the alphabet.
('46', 302, 8, 21, 637211) Along with the congratulations that I wish to offer to the secretary and the management of this institution on the simplicity and clarity of its report, I should also like to say how sorry I am that they have not yet been able to solve the problem of untouchability.
('46', 302, 8, 22, 637478) Hinduism cannot be conceived of without the abolition of untouch ability.
('46', 302, 8, 23, 637552) If this untouchability is not destroyed in this age of reason, when one religion comes into contact with and is compared to
('46', 302, 9, 24, 637676) 1 The Kadva Patidar Ashram
('46', 303, 0, 1, 637703) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 303, 1, 2, 637745) another, any religion which is greatly polluted or whose roots are rotten cannot survive.
('46', 303, 1, 3, 637835) If Hindusim were rotten at the roots, I would have abandoned it.
('46', 303, 1, 4, 637900) I am not content with having been born in a Hindu family.
('46', 303, 1, 5, 637958) As a human being one may swim in one’s father’s well but not get drowned in it.
('46', 303, 1, 6, 638038) If it harbours this ignorance, we must sacrifice our lives in order to remove it.
('46', 303, 1, 7, 638120) This institution with which Chhaganbhai is associated may tolerate untouchability because of social pressure.
('46', 303, 1, 8, 638230) In the welfare of the Kadva Patidar community lies the welfare of Hinduism and of all human beings.
('46', 303, 1, 9, 638330) By assuming that in the welfare of one community lies the welfare of all others, one should regard this as a matter of pride.
('46', 303, 1, 10, 638456) You will not be able to serve the Kadva Patidar community if you regard any human being as untouchable.

('46', 303, 1, 12, 638757) It is not prevalent all over the country.

('46', 303, 1, 23, 639589) It is such that it can give those who live in the country a share in something worth doing and always welcome.

('46', 304, 0, 1, 640352) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 305
('46', 304, 1, 2, 640395) In this State the income from liquor is large.
