('46', 308, 1, 3, 649771) The author’s second proposition that “the question of physcial existence cannot be solved by the charkha” cannot hold water.
('46', 308, 1, 4, 649896) On the contrary that question can only be answered by the charkha or its equivalent.
('46', 308, 1, 5, 649981) Every writer of note whether Indian or European has admitted the necessity of cottage industries, if India is to live physically.
('46', 308, 1, 6, 650111) The writer of the articles in question has done less than justice to himself, to Mr. Gregg and to his own country by summarily dismissing Mr. Gregg’s dispassionate thesis.
('46', 308, 1, 7, 650283) Mr. Gregg has conside rable engineering experience and he has shown conclusively that it will be suicidal, it must mean certain death to millions of India’s population, if the solar power stored in the hands and feet of her three hundred million inhabitants is allowed to run to waste in the impossible attempt to replace it with steam or such other power for the purpose of sustaining physical existence.
('46', 308, 1, 8, 650689) It would be on a par with theattempt made by a man not to use his hand for bringing food to the lips but to let a machine do the work of the hand and run the risk in the bargain of sometimes burning his lips for want of the automatic protection that the sensory nerves connecting the hand with the brain afford against overhot dishes.
('46', 308, 1, 9, 651024) The third proposition is now simply answered.
('46', 308, 1, 10, 651070) “The conditions attached to the charkha” not only make no “large claims on the prevailing tendencies and human nature”, but they are based on “the prevailing tendencies and human nature” as they are to be found in India.
('46', 308, 1, 11, 651291) Were it otherwise, in the midst of confusion and disappointment running through so many national activities the charkha would not have spread through 2,000 villages nor would it have shown the steady, though necessarily slow, progress it had demonstrably made during the past eight years’ revival.
('46', 308, 1, 12, 651589) In the fourth proposition the writer justifies the worship of the machine age not for the reason that it may meet the “internal needs of a country” but because it means an “invasion and capturing of foreign markets”.
('46', 308, 1, 13, 651806) Unfortunately or fortunately for India there are no foreign markets to invade and capture.
('46', 308, 1, 14, 651897) The consummate exploiters of the West have “done the trick”.
('46', 308, 1, 15, 651958) We may invade and capture the foreign manufacturing countries.
('46', 308, 1, 16, 652021) And if writer has anysuch grand scheme in contemplation, me thinks it is more difficult of
('46', 309, 0, 1, 652112) 310 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('46', 311, 17, 27, 658084) 256. A VICIOUS BOOK
('46', 311, 18, 28, 658104) Three correspondents have written to me urging me to give my opinion on a book called Swami Dayanand, A Crititcal Study of His Life and Teachings, by F. K. Durrani, B.A., Muslim missionary.
('46', 311, 18, 29, 658294) The author is the Secretary of Tabligh Literature Society, Lahore.
('46', 311, 18, 30, 658361) A fourth correspondent has given me a copy of the book.
('46', 311, 18, 31, 658417) One of them reminds me that I had no hesitation about expressing my opinion on Rangila Rasuland tells me that therefore I should have none in giving it on Mr. Durrani’s volume.
('46', 311, 18, 32, 658594) I have gone through the volume with as much
('46', 311, 19, 33, 658638) 1 Only excerpts from it are reproduced here.
('46', 312, 0, 1, 658683) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 313
('46', 312, 1, 2, 658726) patience as I could command and I have come to the conclusion that it is a vicious, libellous book which should never have been written by a resposnible man and published by a responsible society.
('46', 312, 1, 3, 658923) The author protests in his preface that he will approach his subject in a scientific and dispassionate spirit.
('46', 312, 1, 4, 659034) But he breaks that promise in the preface itself.
('46', 312, 1, 5, 659084) He says, “We intend neither to praise nor to condemn.” But in the very next page this is what he has to say on Satyartha Prakash.
('46', 312, 1, 6, 659214) “It is a worthless book and the teachings and ideas contained in it are so absurd and so amusingly childish that one finds it hard to believe that a man who became the founder of such a powerful organization as the Arya Samaj could be the author of such drivel.” The author has not hesitated to accuse the great reformer of falsehood, trickery, incapacity and addiction to bhang “whose narcotic juice often kept him insensate.”.
('46', 312, 1, 7, 659643) “The account of his life left by himself is pure fiction.” “A pall of mystery hangs over his origin and early years.” He has not one good word to say of the Swamiji or the Arya Samaj.
('46', 312, 1, 8, 659827) He has gone out his way even to abuse Hindus and Hinduism.
('46', 312, 1, 9, 659886) But I may not multipy proofs.
('46', 312, 1, 10, 659916) Almost every page of the book furnishes ample ground for condemning it.
('46', 312, 1, 11, 659988) The author lets the cat out of the bag in his concluding chapter.
('46', 312, 1, 12, 660054) He says:
('46', 312, 2, 13, 660063) If we love our motherland, if we want to make India a great and a
('46', 312, 3, 14, 660129) civilized country, it is our duty to wash it clean of the stains of anciet
('46', 312, 4, 15, 660204) superstitions of Hinduism and reach out the healing of Islam to every child of
('46', 312, 5, 16, 660283) the motherland...Islam is a conquering force and the Muslims were born to
('46', 312, 6, 17, 660357) freedom and empire.
('46', 312, 6, 18, 660377) Both can come to us, if we exert ourselves to expand our
('46', 312, 7, 19, 660434) numerical strength.
('46', 312, 7, 20, 660454) We are the children of the soil of India and we owe a duty
('46', 312, 8, 21, 660513) to the motherland.
('46', 312, 8, 22, 660532) Like other lands, she too should have a place of equality in
('46', 312, 9, 23, 660593) the comity of nations.
('46', 312, 9, 24, 660616) Hindu India will never be able to do that.
('46', 312, 9, 25, 660659) She can be
('46', 312, 10, 26, 660670) free and raise to power and glory only under the banner of Islam.

('46', 315, 3, 11, 666202) 259. SPEECH ON COMPROMISE RESOLUTION, A.I.C.C. MEETING, ALLAHABAD
('46', 315, 4, 12, 666268) July 27, 1929
('46', 315, 5, 13, 666282) The resolution moved by Mahatma Gandhi runs that: In view of the general situation in the country this meeting of the A.I.C.C. is of opinion that the time has come when all national effort should be concentrated on the preparation of the country for a campaign on non violent non co operation after 31st December, 1929, and agrees with the Working Committee that all Congress members of the various legislatures, central and provincial, should resign their seats to give effect to this campaign; but having regard to the views expressed by a considerable body of Congress members of the legislatures and some members outside them this Committee resolves that the question of withdrawal from the legislatures do stand over till the forthcoming Congress at Lahore.
('46', 315, 6, 14, 667045) This Committee further desires the public in general and the members of the legislatures in particular to prepare for complete withdrawal from legislatures, should such a course be necessary, on and from the 1st of January next.
('46', 315, 7, 15, 667274) Provided that nothing herein contained shall prevent members of the Congress Party in any legislature from resigning their seats before the Congress is held at Lahore if they consider it necessary to do so on any new issue that may arise hereafter.
('46', 315, 8, 16, 667523) Speaking in Hindi on the resolution, Mahatma Gandhi said that many would have been surprised at the resolution and as many would have also felt pain at it.
('46', 315, 8, 17, 667679) Personally, he too felt pain at putting the resolution before the Committee.
('46', 315, 8, 18, 667756) But it was
('46', 316, 0, 1, 667767) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 317
('46', 316, 1, 2, 667810) the duty of the Working Committee to take into consideration all the circumstances before arriving at any decision.
('46', 316, 1, 3, 667926) The opinion expressed by the members of the Councils was, he said, very strong.
('46', 316, 1, 4, 668006) They would have resigned their seats in the legislatures if they were forced to do so by the Congress Committee but they would have at the same time kept a grievance and the result would have been that the Congress, which hitherto could boast of unity in its camp, would have been exposed to the danger of a split in its ranks.
('46', 316, 1, 5, 668334) The Mahatma said: Such a situation, none was prepared to face.
('46', 316, 1, 6, 668397) At least I was not prepared to face it.
('46', 316, 2, 7, 668437) Proceeding, Mahatma Gandhi said that the Working Committee had also invited the Congress members in the legislatures to put their case before it.
('46', 316, 2, 8, 668583) Some of them presented their case to the Working Committee and also to him and their case was to the effect that the time had not come when the members should be asked to resign their seats in the legislatures although his personal view was that such a time had arrived and the country would be greatly benefited by severing connection with the legislatures.
('46', 316, 2, 9, 668942) What opinion the President had now, he (Mahatma) held before and even then.
('46', 316, 2, 10, 669018) But they had also to see that the Congress organization could not be conducted smoothly by enforcing individual views only.
('46', 316, 2, 11, 669142) Mahatma Gandhi said: You know that when the Swaraj Party came into existence and I came out of the jail, I entered into a compromise with your President and Mr. C.R. Das.

('46', 316, 2, 13, 669377) Though I am not bending my head today before them but before those persons who think that they should not resign their seats in legislatures at this moment.
('46', 316, 2, 14, 669534) We want to work with them.
('46', 316, 3, 15, 669561) It was this anxiety to maintain solidarity that prompted him to advise the Working Committee yesterday that although the time had arrived to take action suggested by the Committee, they should do what the Congress members of the legislatures desired today.
('46', 316, 4, 16, 669818) Proceeding, Mahatma Gandhi said that today they had postponed consideration of the question of resignations but the resolution authorized the members to resign of their own accord without asking the Working Committee in case any new issue arose necessitating their withdrawal from the legislatures before the Lahore Congress.
('46', 316, 5, 17, 670144) The resolution, he continued, also urged that it was their religious duty that they should start preparation from the 1st of January, 1930. They should prepare themselves to do from today what they would be required to do from the 1st January.
('46', 316, 5, 18, 670388) On the 31st of August next, people would be called upon to give an account of their efforts for the enrolment of members for the Congress.

('46', 321, 3, 19, 682011) I am aware of my own limitations, and I consider myself fortunate in doing whatever I can while keeping within these limits.

('46', 327, 1, 2, 689927) 274. ‘IS SWARAJ WORTH HAVING?’
('46', 327, 2, 3, 689958) The following letter1 will be read with painful interest.
('46', 327, 3, 4, 690016) I am a native of Vikrampur, and my home is only a few miles away from the home of Deshbandhu.
('46', 327, 3, 5, 690110) I belong to the Namashudra community .
('46', 327, 4, 6, 690149) The clerks in the office, where I am working, numbering 50, are all so called high caste Hindus .
('46', 327, 5, 7, 690247) I am looked upon here as a despised insect ..
('46', 327, 5, 8, 690293) Even the servant refuses to wash and clear away my plates .
('46', 327, 5, 9, 690353) Although in cleanliness and decency I am not in any way inferior to any .
('46', 327, 6, 10, 690427) Is swaraj worth having when the mentality of the people is so cruel towards their fellow countrymen?
('46', 327, 6, 11, 690528) Will not the treatment of the so called higher classes who occupy most of the top positions towards the so called lower classes be terrible when the power is in their hands?.
('46', 327, 7, 12, 690703) I am in intense agony of mind.
('46', 327, 7, 13, 690734) Please reply sharp and also advise me what I am to do here.
('46', 327, 8, 14, 690794) As the writer does not wish to have his identity disclosed I have erased some parts of the letter.
('46', 327, 8, 15, 690893) There is no doubt that what is happening to this Namashudra friend is the lot of many who are similarly placed.
('46', 327, 8, 16, 691005) Though untouchability is undoubtedly going, the suppressed classes who are daily growing more and more conscious and naturally resentful of the terrible treatment meted out to them by the so called higher classes are becoming restive.
('46', 327, 8, 17, 691240) Their fear, too, that if the things remain as they are when swaraj is attained, the reformer’s may be a voice in the wilderness and blind orthodoxy may reduce to nought even the little progress that has been made, has a surface justification.
('46', 327, 8, 18, 691483) I wish the “suppressed” friends could be made to see that the fear is in reality groundless.
('46', 327, 8, 19, 691576) They do not give sufficient credit to the reformers.
('46', 327, 8, 20, 691629) It is not the quantity that will count when freedom is gained.
('46', 327, 8, 21, 691692) It is the determination of the few that is going to be the deciding factor.
('46', 327, 8, 22, 691768) Surely he who runs may see that in the forefront of the fight for freedom are to be found the reformers and not the reactionaries who even now seek the protection of the foreign power for sustaining their reactionary policy which they miscall religion.
('46', 327, 8, 23, 692021) When therefore swaraj is attained it will be the reformers who must have the reins of Government in their hands.
('46', 328, 0, 1, 692134) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 329
('46', 328, 1, 2, 692177) Again the suppressed classes should know that in any constitution that can be conceived, there are bound to be full legal safeguards for their rights.
('46', 328, 1, 3, 692328) And lastly, they may not feel helpless and dependent on the aid of reformers.
('46', 328, 1, 4, 692406) They have a just cause and they have themselves to defend it.
('46', 328, 1, 5, 692468) True meaning of swaraj is that evey member of the commonwealth is capable of defending his liberty against the whole world.
('46', 328, 1, 6, 692592) Swaraj is an inward growth.
('46', 328, 1, 7, 692620) their restiveness is the surest and the hopefullest sign of their and India’s coming freedom.
('46', 328, 1, 8, 692714) Healthy discontent is the prelude to progress.
('46', 328, 1, 9, 692761) But meanwhile it behoves all the clerks and others who come in contract with these classes to treat them with exemplary consideration and courtesy.
('46', 328, 1, 10, 692909) Young India, 1 8 1929
('46', 328, 2, 11, 692931) 275. WHO SHOULD WEAR THE CROWN 1
('46', 328, 3, 12, 692964) The occupation of the Congress chair is becoming more and more onerous year after year.
('46', 328, 3, 13, 693052) It is a serious question who should wear the crown for the next year.
('46', 328, 3, 14, 693122) It is all thorns and no roses.
('46', 328, 3, 15, 693153) I have noticed my name asone of the possibilities.
('46', 328, 3, 16, 693204) When I first saw it amongst the nominees of some committee, I did not treat it seriously.
('46', 328, 3, 17, 693294) But now I find friends speaking to me seriously and pressing me even to ask for the crown even if it is not offered to me.
('46', 328, 3, 18, 693417) I need not discuss here the reasons advanced in favour of the proposal.
('46', 328, 3, 19, 693489) I admit the weightiness of some of them.
('46', 328, 3, 20, 693530) I have given them all the consideration I was capable of giving them, but I must own I have neither the courage nor the confidence in my ability to shoulder the burden.
('46', 328, 3, 21, 693699) I feel that I have become almost unfit for attending to the details of office work which I must do, as is my nature, if I accepted the office.
('46', 328, 3, 22, 693842) I know too that I am not keeing pace with the march of events.
('46', 328, 3, 23, 693905) There is therefore a hiatus between the rising generation and me.
('46', 328, 3, 24, 693971) I look a back number in their company.
('46', 328, 3, 25, 694010) Not that I believe myself to be a back number.
('46', 328, 3, 26, 694057) But when it comes to working in their midst, I know that I must take a back seat and allow the surging wave to pass over me.
('46', 328, 3, 27, 694182) I have mentioned two decisive reasons for my reluctance to shoulder the burden.
('46', 328, 3, 28, 694262) There are others which I do not put in the same category as
('46', 328, 4, 29, 694322) 1 This was written before July 29, 1929, Vide “Letter to Jawaharlal Nehru”, 29 7 1929
('46', 329, 0, 1, 694408) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 329, 1, 2, 694450) But I hold these two as sufficient to eliminate me from the list of nominees.
('46', 329, 1, 3, 694528) In my opinion the crown must be worn by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru.
('46', 329, 1, 4, 694593) If I could have influenced the decision, he would have occupied the chair even for this year.
('46', 329, 1, 5, 694687) But the imperative demand of Bengal compelled the senior partner to capitulate.
('46', 329, 1, 6, 694767) Older men have had their innings.
('46', 329, 1, 7, 694801) The battle of the future has to be faught by younger men and women.
('46', 329, 1, 8, 694869) And it is but meet that they are led by one of themselves.
('46', 329, 1, 9, 694928) Older men should yield with grace what will be taken from them by force if they do not read the signs of the times.
('46', 329, 1, 10, 695044) Responsibility will mellow and sober the youth, and prepare them for the burden they must discharge.
('46', 329, 1, 11, 695145) Pandit Jawaharlal has everything to recommend him.
('46', 329, 1, 12, 695196) He has for years discharged with singular ability and devotion the office of secretary of the Congress.
('46', 329, 1, 13, 695300) By his bravery, determination, application, integrity and grit he has captivated the imagination of the youth of the land.
('46', 329, 1, 14, 695423) He has come in touch with labour and the peasantry.
('46', 329, 1, 15, 695475) His close acquaintance with European politics is a great asset in enabling him to assess ours.
('46', 329, 1, 16, 695570) But say the older heads: “When we are likely to have to enter into delicate negotiations with various groups and parties outside the Congress, when we might even have to deal with British diplomacy, when we have yet the Hindu Muslim knot to undo, we must have someone like you as the head.” In so far as there is force in this argument, it is sufficiently answered by my drawing attention to the fact that whatever special qualities I may possess in the direction indicated, I shall be able to exercise more effectively by remaining detached from and untrammelled by, than by holding, office.
('46', 329, 1, 17, 696163) So long as I retain the affection and the confidence of our people, there is not the slightest danger of my not being without holding office to make the fullest use of such powers as I may possess.
('46', 329, 1, 18, 696361) God has enabled me to affect the life of the country since 1920 without the necessity of holding office.
('46', 329, 1, 19, 696466) I am not aware that my capacity for service was a whit enhanced by my becoming President of the Congress at Belgaum.
('46', 329, 2, 20, 696583) And those who know the relations that subsist between Jawaharlal and me know that his being in the chair is as good as my being in it.
('46', 329, 2, 21, 696718) We may have intellectual differences but our hearts are one.
('46', 329, 2, 22, 696779) And with all his youthful impetuosities, his sense of stern
('46', 329, 3, 23, 696839) 1 In 1924
('46', 330, 0, 1, 696849) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 331
('46', 330, 1, 2, 696892) discipline and loyalty make him an inestimable comrade in whom one can put the most implicit faith.
('46', 330, 1, 3, 696992) “Will not Jawaharlal’s name be a red rag to the English bull?”… whispers another critic.
('46', 330, 1, 4, 697081) We give English statesmen little credit for common sense and diplomatic skill and betray less faith in ourselves when we think like the imaginary critic.
('46', 330, 1, 5, 697235) If a decision is really right for us, it ought to be right for the whole world.
('46', 330, 1, 6, 697315) If in choosing our President we have to take into consideration what English statesmen will think of our choice, we show little courage of our convictions.
('46', 330, 1, 7, 697471) Personally I have a higher estimate of English character than that assumed by the critic.
('46', 330, 1, 8, 697561) The Englishman prizes honesty, bravery, grit and outspokenness all of which Jawaharlal has in abundance.
('46', 330, 1, 9, 697666) Even if therefore British statesmen are to be considered in making our choice, Pandit Jawaharlal suffers from no disqualification.
('46', 330, 1, 10, 697797) Lastly, a President of the Congress is not an autocrat.
('46', 330, 1, 11, 697853) He is a representative working under a well defined constitution and well known traditions.
('46', 330, 1, 12, 697945) He can no more impose his views on the people than the English King.
('46', 330, 1, 13, 698014) The Congress is a forty five year old organization and has a status above its most distinguished Presidents.
('46', 330, 1, 14, 698123) And it is the Congress as a whole with which, when the time is ripe, British statesmen will have to deal.
('46', 330, 1, 15, 698229) They know this probably better than we do.
('46', 330, 1, 16, 698272) All things considered therefore my advice to those concerned is to cease to think of me and to call Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru to the high office with the fullest confidence and hope.
('46', 330, 2, 17, 698453) Young India, 1 8 1929
('46', 330, 3, 18, 698475) 276. A.I.S.A. PRIZE
('46', 330, 4, 19, 698495) The reader may recall that some years ago Sjt.
('46', 330, 4, 20, 698542) Revashankar Jagjivan Jhaveri had offered a prize of Rs. 5,000 for a spinning wheel that would do for the spinners what Singer’s Sewing Machine does for the housewife.
('46', 330, 4, 21, 698709) Many tried to win the prize.
('46', 330, 4, 22, 698738) A skilled man was admitted to the Ashram and given every facility to make his experiment under the best of auspices.
('46', 330, 4, 23, 698855) The attempt however failed.
('46', 330, 4, 24, 698883) But hope of finding a suitable cottage wheel was not given up.
('46', 330, 4, 25, 698946) Revashankar Jagjivan is one of those who never lose hope.
('46', 330, 4, 26, 699004) He has succeeded in persuading the Council of the Association to announce a prize that would attract even the Western inventors to compete for it.
('46', 330, 4, 27, 699151) Consequently the reader will find elsewhere the A.I.S.A. advertisement
('46', 331, 0, 1, 699222) 332 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 331, 1, 2, 699264) announcing a prize of Rs. 1,00,000 or its present equivalent (roughtly) £7,700. This figure will be maintained on the expiry of the time limit irrespective of the fluctuations that the fickle rupee may undergo meanwhile.
('46', 331, 1, 3, 699485) I hope that the prize will produce a spinning Singer who would raise the income of the village spinner eightfold.
('46', 331, 1, 4, 699599) Young India, 1 8 1929
('46', 331, 2, 5, 699621) 277 “BRITISH TRUSTEES”
('46', 331, 3, 6, 699644) It is a real pleasure to give elsewhere Mr. Pennington’s letter.

('46', 333, 3, 5, 703637) Nagindas Amulakhrai, the milk enthusiast, continues his well thought out agitation for procuring a cheaper and purer milk supply for Bombay.
('46', 333, 3, 6, 703778) He has drawn up a memorandum showing that if the railway company would adopt a reasonable and responsive attitude it can very materially help cheaper production, i.e., by reducing the freight for milk and supplying cheap facilities for carrying milk from the suburban stations to Bomaby.
('46', 333, 3, 7, 704066) He says 1 that it is owing to bad freight policy.
('46', 333, 4, 8, 704116) that places between Palghar (58 miles) and Bulsar (125 miles), although fully grass areas,....
('46', 333, 4, 9, 704211) have no dairies started for milk supply to Bombay; that suppliers of milk in bulk have no alternative but to keep themselves and their buffaloes (16,003) confined in the stables (96) in the heart of the city in very unnatural conditions where there is no grazing area and the rent for accommodation of each buffalo in the stable is Rs. 9 or Rs. 10 per month resulting in a distinct additional loss at the rate of Rs. 240 per each of the 12 buffaloes that go dry every month after the lactation period out of a lot of 100 buffaloes in milk; and that the milk production from more than 26,000 buffaloes and supply thereof from year to year is being entirely stopped though they would again come into calf and produce milk to the same extent as before within a very short time if not slaughtered and wasted.
('46', 333, 5, 10, 705016) ontends that
('46', 333, 6, 11, 705029) Bombay milk rate is the maximum in the world.

('46', 333, 7, 13, 705093) than in New York and London.
('46', 333, 7, 14, 705122) It is 50% dearer even than in Calcutta .
('46', 333, 8, 15, 705163) result is the highest infant mortality of the poor of Bombay and nearly total
('46', 333, 9, 16, 705241) extinction of the best breed of buffaloes .
('46', 333, 9, 17, 705285) I understand that a Joint Committee consisting of a sub committee of the Railway Local Advisory Board and a certain number of the members of the Bombay Corporation has been brought into being to consider this question.
('46', 333, 9, 18, 705504) The question of cheap and pure milk supply for Bombay is a vital question.

('46', 342, 5, 10, 723561) 292. LETTER TO MILLIE GRAHAM POLAK
('46', 342, 6, 11, 723596) AHMEDABAD, August 3 [1929] 1
('46', 342, 7, 12, 723625) MY DEAR MILLIE, I am writing this as I am watching the glorious rain descending in torrents before me.
('46', 342, 7, 13, 723728) It will gladden the hearts of millions of men and women.
('46', 342, 7, 14, 723785) There was a great dread of a most severe famine overtaking Western India.
('46', 342, 7, 15, 723859) In the twinkling of an eye, all that fear has gone.
('46', 342, 7, 16, 723911) It has given place to boundless joy.
('46', 342, 7, 17, 723948) This rain is a veritable deliverance for millions upon millions of cattle.
('46', 342, 7, 18, 724023) There is probably no place on earth that is so dependent on rain as India.
('46', 342, 7, 19, 724098) You will now understand what part this rain must have played in giving me health.
('46', 342, 7, 20, 724180) I have suffered agonies ≈ all due to my own follies.
('46', 342, 7, 21, 724233) The punishment was adequate to the wrong done by me to the body.
('46', 342, 7, 22, 724298) Through a faulty experiment I was suffering from dysentery.
('46', 342, 7, 23, 724358) Whilst I was getting over it, I ate when I should have refrained and that brought on the inevitable crisis.
('46', 342, 7, 24, 724466) I am so reduced in body and I have now to build up anew but there is no cause of anxiety.
('46', 342, 7, 25, 724556) I am convalescent and regularly taking some nourishment and daily increasing the quantity and I hope to be able to walk alone in ten days’ time.
('46', 342, 7, 26, 724701) You ask me about nursing.

('46', 357, 0, 1, 746928) 358 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 357, 1, 2, 746970) 316. NOTES
('46', 357, 2, 3, 746981) VACCINATION Anti vaccination enthusiasts rate me for having said that vaccin ation confers “a sort of temporary immunity from smallpox”.
('46', 357, 2, 4, 747118) 1 The correspondents ignore the phrase “a sort of” and repudiate my claim to describe myself as an anti vaccinationist.
('46', 357, 2, 5, 747238) I would urge my enthusiastic friends to appreciate the fact that a person may be a good anti vaccinationist although he may believe in a sort of temporary immunity provided that he renounces the benefit of such immunity.
('46', 357, 2, 6, 747459) For myself I do not believe in vaccination giving any real immunity temporary or otherwise.
('46', 357, 2, 7, 747551) It gives a seeming immunity because those who submit to the unclean process in numerous cases believe that they have escaped smallpox because they see some of their neighbours getting it.
('46', 357, 2, 8, 747739) Who can persuade these fear stricken men that even without vaccination they might have escaped the infection like the rest of their numerous unvaccinated neighbours?
('46', 357, 2, 9, 747905) In my note I merely mentioned a psychological fact.
('46', 357, 2, 10, 747957) Anti vaccinationists will ensure reform in tolerably good time, if they will be absolutely accurate about their facts, take due account of popular prejudices and fears and patiently cultivate public opinion against compulsory vaccination.
('46', 357, 2, 11, 748196) But for the apathy in such matters of educated India there would never be compulsion in a matter in which respectable medical opinion favours the reformer’s view and statistics exist which at least make out a reasonable case against compulsion.
('46', 357, 2, 12, 748441) I can understand my compulsory segregation if my neighbours fear infection from me, but I cannot understand my being compelled to undergo an operation against which I have a religious or hygienic objection.
('46', 357, 2, 13, 748648) A community has a right to protect itself from me but it has no right to impose an obligation on me merely for my protection.
('46', 357, 2, 14, 748774) The essence of my freedom consists in my right to err so long as my error endangers no one else.
('46', 357, 3, 15, 748871) A PATRIOT’S DEATH A correspondent writes: 2
('46', 357, 4, 16, 748915) 1 Vide “Notes” sub title Anti Vaccination
('46', 357, 5, 17, 748957) 2 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('46', 358, 0, 1, 748994) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 359
('46', 358, 1, 2, 749037) I am sure it will cause you genuine grief to know that L. Banke Dyal, editor of Weekly Jhang Sial and selfless Congress worker in the Punjab, is no
('46', 358, 2, 3, 749185) he acted as your Private Secretary to collect and sift evidence in certain villages of the Punjab in connection with the Congress Committee report regarding martial law atrocities.
('46', 358, 2, 4, 749366) Banke Dyal lived a life of poverty and even starvation.
('46', 358, 2, 5, 749422) Could you possibly stir up the Punjab Congress or Indian philanthropists to do something to relieve the misery of his dependants?
('46', 358, 2, 6, 749552) I have a vivid recollection of Lala Banke Dyal when I was in the Punjab in connection with the Martial Law Congress Inquiry, and can bear out what the correspondent says about his services.
('46', 358, 2, 7, 749742) I tender my condolences to the family of the deceased.
('46', 358, 2, 8, 749797) There is no doubt that it is the duty of moneyed Congressmen in the Punjab to investigate the condition of the family and make whatever provision may be necessary.
('46', 358, 2, 9, 749961) All genuine patriotic workers should be able to feel that their true service is the surest insurance for their legitimate survivors.
('46', 358, 2, 10, 750094) And relief should always be local.
('46', 358, 2, 11, 750129) There is something wrong when the family of a patriot in Karachi has to be supported from Dibrugarh.
('46', 358, 2, 12, 750230) FOR A.I.S.A. DEFAULTERS The Secretary, A.I.S.A., complains that many members are anxious to retain their membership but they are not prompt in complying with the rules.
('46', 358, 2, 13, 750399) In spite of extension, several have failed to send in their yarn and ask for further indulgence.
('46', 358, 2, 14, 750496) I have reluctantly authorized the Secretary to extend the time till 21st instant when the Council meets.
('46', 358, 2, 15, 750601) But an organization weakens if its members continuously seek indulgence.
('46', 358, 2, 16, 750674) I know that procrastination among members is the bane of most institutions.
('46', 358, 2, 17, 750750) But an association which seeks to serve individually three hundred million men and women cannot afford to be lax regarding the observance of terms of membership.
('46', 358, 2, 18, 750912) Nor is the condition severe if the members will spin regularly.
('46', 358, 2, 19, 750976) Many allow arrears to accumulate and then fancy that they will be able to make up by giving many hours at a stretch.
('46', 358, 2, 20, 751093) Unfortunately for them those many hours never come and they find themselves in default.
('46', 358, 2, 21, 751181) Regular spinning for half an hour daily is no strain and it should be a joy to be able to renew from day to day through the wheel a vital contact with the millions of paupers.
('46', 358, 2, 22, 751357) I hope that the members will realize the truth of my remark and hasten to make up for arrears and make a promise to themselves never again to fall into arrears.
('46', 358, 2, 23, 751518) Young India, 8 8 1929
('46', 359, 0, 1, 751540) 360 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 359, 1, 2, 751582) 317. INCURABLE
('46', 359, 2, 3, 751597) Having read carefully the Governor’s speech and the Revenue Member’s on the proposed Land Revenue legislation and thereanent on the Bardoli Inquiry report, the conclusion forces itself upon me that the Government is incurable.
('46', 359, 2, 4, 751824) The Bombay Government has accepted the Committee’s report as it were at the point of the sword.
('46', 359, 2, 5, 751920) It knows full well that rejection of the report would mean a resuscitation of the whole agitation in a much more serious form than before.
('46', 359, 2, 6, 752059) There is no grace or dignity about the acceptance.
('46', 359, 2, 7, 752110) Indeed the Revenue Member had the hardihood to say that the Government had accepted the report in order to close the matter though it could draw conclusions just the opposite of what Messrs Broomfield and Maxwell had drawn on the data collected and accepted by them.
('46', 359, 2, 8, 752377) There is not one word of regret for the many acts of oppression committed by the officials or for the gross errors of Settlement officers which cost the people a protracted struggle involving terrible hardships.
('46', 359, 2, 9, 752589) In the teeth of published letters of the ex Governor, the Revenue Member dares to suggest that the inquiry was granted not under pressure but because there were definite allegations about the settlement being unlawful and the assessment being based on erroneous figures.
('46', 359, 2, 10, 752860) He forgets that the ex Governor had repudiated these charges and defended the settlement with unbecoming energy and had with equally unbecoming rashness prophesied that if any inquiry was granted the finding would show a higher figure.
('46', 359, 2, 11, 753096) The speeches make it abudantly clear that the Government does not believe in doing justice for its own sake.
('46', 359, 2, 12, 753205) In important matters affecting its existence, it will yield only to pressure which if successfully exerted would place its existence in greater jeopardy than the justice demanded would.
('46', 359, 2, 13, 753391) Thus it yielded to the Bardoli agitation because its pressure had become more dangerous for its existence than the reluctant grant of barest justice.
('46', 359, 2, 14, 753541) But the niggardly justice done to Bardoli has involved embarrassing implications.
('46', 359, 2, 15, 753623) It has now been obliged to announce that it will bring in a revenue bill at an early date in order to obviate in future the errors discovered by Messrs Broomfield and Maxwell.
('46', 359, 2, 16, 753799) But the faint outline given of the forthcoming bill by the Revenue Member need not enthuse us.

('46', 361, 3, 6, 756670) 319. UNFIRED FOOD
('46', 361, 4, 7, 756688) The interest evinced in my experiment in unfired food and the testimony received in support are truly remarkable.
('46', 361, 4, 8, 756802) Some corresp ondents even send their experiences for publication.
('46', 361, 4, 9, 756868) But I refrain.
('46', 361, 4, 10, 756883) I have found among enthusiasts a tendency towards exaggeration.
('46', 361, 4, 11, 756947) They often build their conclusions on insufficient data or see a connection between a result and their experiment not warranted by actuality.
('46', 361, 4, 12, 757089) Whilst therefore these experiences are very helpful to me, as I am able to check them by my own, I am chary of sending them out as a guide to fellow seekers.
('46', 361, 4, 13, 757247) I therefore propose periodically to give the verified results of my own experiences and observation coupled with the caution that even they are liable to variation.
('46', 361, 4, 14, 757412) I have found after prolonged experiment and observation that there is no fixed dietetic rule for all constitutions.
('46', 361, 4, 15, 757528) All that the wisest physicians claim for their advice is that it is likely to benefit in a given case as in a majority of cases they have found it to answer fairly well.
('46', 361, 4, 16, 757698) In no branch of science is the scientist so hampered in his research as in the medical.
('46', 361, 4, 17, 757786) He dare not speak with certainty of the effect of a single drug or food or of the reactions of human bodies.
('46', 361, 4, 18, 757895) It is and will always remain empirical.
('46', 361, 4, 19, 757935) The popular saying that one man’s food may be another’s poison is based on vast experience which finds daily verification.
('46', 361, 4, 20, 758058) Such being the case, the field for experiment on the part of intelligent men and women is limitless.
('46', 361, 4, 21, 758159) Laymen ought to acquire a workable knowledge of the body which plays such an important part in the evolution of the soul within.
('46', 361, 4, 22, 758288) And yet about nothing are we so woefully negligent or ignorant as in regard to our bodies.
('46', 361, 4, 23, 758379) Instead of using the body as a temple of God we use it as a vehicle for indulgences, and are not ashamed to run to medical men for help in our effort to increase them and abuse the earthly tabernacle.
('46', 362, 0, 1, 758580) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 363
('46', 362, 1, 2, 758623) But now for noting the results to date: 1. There are now twenty two in the Mandir making the experiment with me.
('46', 362, 1, 3, 758736) Most of them have given up milk.
('46', 362, 2, 4, 758769) 2. They are now having bananas added to their diet and the quantity of cocoanut taken has been increased.
('46', 362, 3, 5, 758875) 3. It can be stated with tolerable confidence that when milk is retained there is no danger of weakness or any other untoward result.
('46', 362, 4, 6, 759009) 4. There is no difficulty about digesting uncooked sprouted grains and pulses and uncooked green vegetables.
('46', 362, 5, 7, 759118) 5. Cases of constipation have in most cases yielded to the elimination of grains and pulses and a liberal use of cocoanut milk and green vegetables such as dudhi (marrow), pumpkin, cucumber, etc., all taken with their skins well washed.
('46', 362, 5, 8, 759355) Cocoanut milk is prepared by grating an undried cocoanut fine and mixing it with its own or other clean water and straining and pressing through a stout cloth.
('46', 362, 5, 9, 759515) A whole cocoanut may be thus taken without the slightest injury or discomfort.
('46', 362, 5, 10, 759594) 6. In the majority of cases weight has been lost, but the medical authorities who favour unfired food assert that the loss of weight is a healthy reaction up to a point and is a sign of the body throwing off poisonous matter.
('46', 362, 5, 11, 759820) 7. The majority still experience weakness but persist in their experiment, believing in the above mentioned authorities that weak ness is an intermediate stage in this experiment.
('46', 362, 5, 12, 760000) There is no doubt that the stomach which has undergone distension through overfeeding with starchy and fatty foods feels an emptiness till it resumes its natural size.
('46', 362, 5, 13, 760168) 8. The experiment is not an easy thing nor does it yield magical results.
('46', 362, 5, 14, 760242) It requires patience, perseverance and caution.
('46', 362, 5, 15, 760290) Each one has to find his or her own balance of the different ingredients.
('46', 362, 6, 16, 760364) 9. Almost every one of us has experienced a clearer brain power and refreshing calmness of spirit.
('46', 362, 7, 17, 760463) 10. Many have found the experiment as a decided help in allaying animal passion.
('46', 362, 7, 18, 760544) 11. Too much stress cannot be laid on the imperative necessity of thorough mastication.
('46', 362, 7, 19, 760632) I observe that even many of the careful inmates do not know the art of mastication and have therefore bad
('46', 363, 0, 1, 760738) 364 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 363, 1, 2, 760780) teeth and spongy gums.
('46', 363, 1, 3, 760803) A few days of hard and conscientious chewing of the cocoanut and green vegetable has brought about wonderful results in this direction.
('46', 363, 1, 4, 760939) Several physicians are taking an interest in my experiment.
('46', 363, 1, 5, 760999) They send me texts from Ayurvedic writings for or against the articles I have been using.
('46', 363, 1, 6, 761089) Two or three have sent me the identical text against taking honey mixed with hot water and pronouncing dire results.
('46', 363, 1, 7, 761206) When I ask them whether they have verified the text from their own experience they are silent.
('46', 363, 1, 8, 761301) My own experience of taking honey mixed with hot water extends to more than four years.
('46', 363, 1, 9, 761389) I have experienced no ill effect whatsoever.
('46', 363, 1, 10, 761434) Objection has also been raised against the use of honey on humanitarian grounds.
('46', 363, 1, 11, 761515) This objection has, I admit, considerable force though the Western method of gathering honey is cleaner and less open to objection.

('46', 372, 3, 11, 778933) 331. THE EFFICACY OF VOWS 1
('46', 372, 4, 12, 778961) A correspondent who seems to be a regular and careful reader of Navajivan writes:
('46', 372, 5, 13, 779043) I spin regularly, but the question is whether or not I should bind myself to it by a vow.
('46', 372, 5, 14, 779133) If I take a vow to spin regularly for one hour every day, I suppose I must do an hour’s honest spinning unfailingly, come what may.
('46', 372, 5, 15, 779265) Suppose now, having taken the vow I am required to go out on a long journey, how can I fulfil my vow about spinning?
('46', 372, 5, 16, 779382) Or again, suppose I fall seriously ill, even then I must do my spinning, or else be guilty of breaking my vow before man and God.
('46', 372, 5, 17, 779512) On the other hand if I do not take a vow, what guarantee is there that my resolution would not give way and betray me at a critical moment?
('46', 372, 6, 18, 779652) You will perhaps say that one’s resolution ought to be made of sterner stuff.
('46', 372, 6, 19, 779730) But when even the acknowledged leaders of the country are seen hourly breaking their resolutions, what can expect from the rank and file?
('46', 372, 6, 20, 779868) What are lesser mortals like myself to do?
('46', 372, 6, 21, 779911) Would you kindly resolve my dilemma?
('46', 372, 6, 22, 779948) Being accustomed from very childhood to taking vows I confess I have a strong bias in favour of the practice.
('46', 372, 6, 23, 780058) It has come to my rescue in many a crisis; I have seen it save others from many a pitfall.
('46', 372, 6, 24, 780149) A life without vows is like a ship without anchor or like an edifice that is built on slip sand instead of a solid rock.
('46', 372, 6, 25, 780270) A vow imparts stability, ballast and firmness to one’s character.
('46', 372, 6, 26, 780336) What reliance can be placed on a person who lacks these essential qualities?
('46', 372, 6, 27, 780413) An agreement is
('46', 372, 7, 28, 780429) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan, 11 8 1929. This is a translation by Pyarelal
('46', 373, 0, 1, 780529) 374 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 373, 1, 2, 780571) nothing but a mutual interchange of vows; simultanteously one enters into a pledge when one gives one’s word to another.
('46', 373, 1, 3, 780692) It old days, the word of mouth of illustrious persons was regarded as good as a bond.
('46', 373, 1, 4, 780778) They concluded transactions involving millions by oral agreements.
('46', 373, 1, 5, 780845) In fact our entire social fabric rests on the sanctity of the pledged word.
('46', 373, 1, 6, 780921) The world would go to pieces if there was not this element of stability or finality in agreements arrived at.
('46', 373, 1, 7, 781031) The Himalayas are immovably fixed for ever in their place.
('46', 373, 1, 8, 781090) India would perish if the firmness of the Himalayas gave way.
('46', 373, 1, 9, 781152) The sun, the moon and other heavenly affairs would come to a standstill.
('46', 373, 1, 10, 781225) But we know that the sun has been rising regularly at its fixed time for countless ages in the past and will continue to do so in future.
('46', 373, 1, 11, 781363) The cooling orb of the moon will continue always to wax and wane as it has done for ages past with a clock work regularity.
('46', 373, 1, 12, 781487) That is why we call the sun and the moon to be witness to our affairs.
('46', 373, 1, 13, 781558) We base our calender on their movements, we regulate our time by their rising and setting.
('46', 373, 2, 14, 781649) The same law, which regulates these hevenly bodies, applies equally to men.
('46', 373, 2, 15, 781725) A person unbound by vows can never be absolutely relied upon.
('46', 373, 2, 16, 781787) It is overweening pride to say, ‘This thing comes natural to me.
('46', 373, 2, 17, 781852) Why should I bind myself permanently by vows?
('46', 373, 2, 18, 781898) I can well take care of myself at the critical moment.
('46', 373, 2, 19, 781953) Why should I take an absolute vow against wine?
('46', 373, 2, 20, 782001) I never get drunk.
('46', 373, 2, 21, 782020) Why should I forgo the pleasure of an occasional cup for nothing?
('46', 373, 2, 22, 782086) A person who argues like this will never be weaned from his addiction.
('46', 373, 2, 23, 782157) To shirk taking of vows betrays indecision and want of resolution.
('46', 373, 2, 24, 782224) One never can achieve anything lasting in this world by being irresolute.
('46', 373, 2, 25, 782298) For instance, what faith can you place in a general or a soldier who lacks resolution and determination, who says, ‘I shall keep guard as long as I can’?
('46', 373, 2, 26, 782452) A householder, whose watchman says that he would keep watch as long as he can, can never sleep in security.
('46', 373, 2, 27, 782560) No general ever won a victory by following the principle of ‘being vigilant so long as he could’.
('46', 373, 2, 28, 782658) I have before me innumerable examples of spinners at will.
('46', 373, 2, 29, 782717) Every one of them has come to grief sooner or later.
('46', 373, 2, 30, 782770) On the other hand, sacramental spinning has transformed the entire life of those who have taken to it; mountains of yarn stored up by them tell the tale.
('46', 373, 2, 31, 782924) A vow is like a right anger.
('46', 373, 2, 32, 782953) An insignificant right angle will make all the difference between ugliness and elegance, solidity and
('46', 374, 0, 1, 783055) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 375
('46', 374, 1, 2, 783098) shakiness of a gigantic structure.
('46', 374, 1, 3, 783133) Even so stability or instability, purity or otherwise of an entire career may depend upon the taking of a vow.
('46', 374, 1, 4, 783244) It goes without saying that moderation and sobriety are of the very essence of vow taking.
('46', 374, 1, 5, 783335) The taking of vows are not feasible or that are beyond one’s capacity would betray thoughtlessness and want of balance.
('46', 374, 1, 6, 783455) Similarly a vow can be made conditional without losing any of its efficacy or virtue.
('46', 374, 1, 7, 783541) For instance there would be nothing wrong about taking a vow to spin for at least one hour every day and to turn out not less than 200 yards daily except when one is travelling or is sick.
('46', 374, 1, 8, 783730) Such a vow would not only be quite in form but also easy of observance.
('46', 374, 1, 9, 783802) The essence of a vow does not consist in the difficulty of its performance but in the determination behind it unflinchingly to stick to it in the teeth of difficulties.
('46', 374, 1, 10, 783971) Self restraint is the very key stone of the ethics of vow taking.
('46', 374, 1, 11, 784037) For instance, one cannot take a vow of self indulgence, to eat, drink and be merry, in short, to do as one pleases.
('46', 374, 1, 12, 784153) This warning is necessary because I know of instances when an attempt was made to cover things of questionable import by means of vows.
('46', 374, 1, 13, 784289) In the heyday of non co operation one even heard the objection raised, ‘How can I resign from Government service when I have made a covenant with it to serve it?
('46', 374, 1, 14, 784451) Or again, ‘How can I close my liquor shop since I have bound myself by contract to run it for five years?
('46', 374, 1, 15, 784557) Such questions might appear puzzling sometimes.
('46', 374, 1, 16, 784605) But on closer thinking it will be seen that a vow can never be used to support or justify an immoral action.
('46', 374, 1, 17, 784714) A vow must lead one upwards, never downwards towards perdition.
('46', 374, 1, 18, 784778) The correspondent has concluded by having a fling at the ‘acknowledged leaders’ of the country and cited their so called fickleness to justify his position.
('46', 374, 1, 19, 784935) This sort of reasoning only betrays weakness.
('46', 374, 1, 20, 784981) One should try to emulate and imitate only the virtues of one’s leaders, never their faults.
('46', 374, 1, 21, 785074) Our national leaders do not claim to be paragons of perfection.
('46', 374, 1, 22, 785138) They occupy the position of eminenece that they do in public life by virtue of certain qualities which they exhibit in their character.
('46', 374, 1, 23, 785274) Let us ponder over those qualities and try to assimilate them, let us not even think of their shortcomings.
('46', 374, 1, 24, 785382) No son can be called a worthy son of his father who only imbibes the shortcomings of his parents or pleads inability to keep clear of them.
('46', 374, 1, 25, 785522) It is the virtues, not the faults of one’s parents, that constitute one’s true legacy.
('46', 374, 1, 26, 785609) A son who only adds to the debts of his parents would be written down as unworthy.
('46', 374, 1, 27, 785692) A worthy son would liquidate and increase the legacy left by them.
('46', 374, 1, 28, 785759) Young India, 22 8 1929

('46', 375, 2, 3, 785851) A correspondent has addressed me several posers for answers in Navajivan.

('46', 375, 3, 5, 785944) The fateful 1st of January 1930 is approaching fast, but you are still harping on your incantatory formula of “khadi, khadi and again khadi”, and refuse to give any effective lead to the country.

('46', 375, 3, 7, 786278) Why not give a mandate to youthful leaders like Jawaharlal Nehru and Subhas Chandra Bose to raise a force of one crore national volunteers who would be ready to lay down their lives for the sake of the country?

('46', 375, 3, 10, 786746) I do not mind that.

('46', 375, 3, 12, 786888) Simultaneously with this I would suggest that leaders like Vallabhbhai should be called upon to organize labour and peasantry, and you will find that they would rise up and stand together like one man to face the ordeal of fire without flinching, even as the brave cultivators of Bardoli did last year.
('46', 375, 4, 13, 787191) I am sorry to say that even if khadi gets on one’s nerves, as it is alleged by the correspondent to do, I have no other remedy to suggest in its place.
('46', 375, 4, 14, 787343) I cannot conceive of swaraj without khadi, for the simple reason that without it the lot of the peasantry is bound to remain precarious in India, and it constitutes more than eight tenths of her entire population.
('46', 375, 4, 15, 787557) Nor is it true to say that the country is utterly fed up with khadi, and that khadi has begun to get on the people’s nerves.

('46', 375, 4, 18, 787894) The foundation of India’s nationality is to be laid knot in her towns but in her villages, and the only movement that is at present actively going on among India’s villages is that of khadi.
('46', 375, 4, 19, 788085) It is daily expanding.

('46', 377, 5, 14, 791154) TO THE PERSON WHO HAS GIVEN HIS NAME Although doctors very often regard marriage as a cure, they are, I think, gravely mistaken in this matter.

('46', 378, 3, 7, 792723) This is the second question put by the very same gentleman to whom khadi is like poison: 1
('46', 378, 4, 8, 792814) It is my confirmed opinion that non violent non co operation is the strength not of the weak but especially of the strong.

('46', 378, 4, 10, 792966) We practise it all the time, consciously or unconsciously.
('46', 378, 4, 11, 793025) Current history takes note of wars waged by kings.
('46', 378, 4, 12, 793076) The history of the people of the nation has to be written hereafter.
('46', 378, 4, 13, 793145) When such history is written, we shall come across non violent non co operation on every page of it.
('46', 378, 4, 14, 793246) What a wife who refuses to submit to a cruel husband does, constitutes non violent non co operation.
('46', 378, 4, 15, 793347) The history of the Quakers 2 has been made glorious by non violent non co operation.
('46', 378, 4, 16, 793432) The history of the Vaishnavas in India bears testimony to the very same thing.
('46', 378, 4, 17, 793511) The whole world can do what these people have been able to do.
('46', 378, 4, 18, 793574) Those who look into the matter can clearly see that the world is moving in the direction of peace.
('46', 378, 4, 19, 793673) Although cast in human form, the human race has not yet given up its bestial instincts; it has no alternative but to give them up.
('46', 378, 4, 20, 793804) Hence the example of cats and dogs is irrelevant and ill befits us.
('46', 378, 4, 21, 793872) We are not cats and dogs but creatures who stand crect on two legs, who strive to realize the self and are endowed with the capacity to reason.

('46', 379, 2, 24, 796221) 336. EXPERIMENT IN UNCOOKED FOOD
('46', 379, 3, 25, 796254) I cannot give a report of progress only in regard to this experiment this week.
('46', 379, 3, 26, 796334) I have had to ask two persons to give up the experiment, as I was not competent enough to deal with their weak state and their constipation and had to accept defeat.
('46', 379, 3, 27, 796500) From the experiments on my own system and those of some others, I had concluded that coconut milk and raw greens would be able to cure their constipation.
('46', 379, 3, 28, 796655) But that did not happen.
('46', 379, 3, 29, 796680) Despite taking a large quantity of the above, their constipation could not be cured.
('46', 379, 3, 30, 796765) On my own system, it is having just the opposite result.
('46', 379, 3, 31, 796822) There is no sign of
('46', 379, 4, 32, 796842) 1 A Gujarati phrase meaning ‘an impossibility’
('46', 380, 0, 1, 796889) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 381
('46', 380, 1, 2, 796932) constipation whatever; coconut milk and green vegetables are having too much the contrary effect.
('46', 380, 1, 3, 797030) That too is not a good sign.
('46', 380, 1, 4, 797059) I cannot also note much progress in the experiments carried out by others.
('46', 380, 1, 5, 797134) Despite this, I am convinced that this is a good field anddeserves to be explored.
('46', 380, 1, 6, 797217) Cooked food can never be as nourishing and tasty as food which is uncooked.
('46', 380, 1, 7, 797293) As the field is a new one, we have before us relatively few experiences of it.
('46', 380, 1, 8, 797372) Hence this experiment can be tried through patience alone.
('46', 380, 1, 9, 797431) Those who are carrying on this experiment should exercise caution in doing so, not stick to it obstinately, and should give it up if they do not have the capacity to carry it on.
('46', 380, 1, 10, 797610) It can be safely stated that vegetables and pulses, if eaten, should be eaten raw; hence wheat would the only item which would have to be cooked.
('46', 380, 1, 11, 797756) No harm and no weakness would result from taking a diet of rotis, milk, raw vegetables and sprouted pulses.
('46', 380, 1, 12, 797864) The quantity of pulses should be small; vegetables too should be taken in small quantities, i.e., about three tolas of the former and about five of the latter.

('46', 394, 3, 5, 822273) 358. SOME RELIGIOUS QUESTIONS
('46', 394, 4, 6, 822303) A gentleman has sent the following questions:
('46', 394, 5, 7, 822349) 1. What is the true nature and aim of dharma?
('46', 394, 6, 8, 822395) The evils perpetrated in the name of religion today are really amazing.
('46', 394, 6, 9, 822467) We bring in religion in extremely minor matters.
('46', 394, 6, 10, 822516) But are there any men today who understand the aim and nature of religion?
('46', 394, 6, 11, 822591) This is all due to lack of religious education.
('46', 394, 6, 12, 822639) I hope you will take the trouble of expressing your views on this and the following other questions in Hindi Navijivan.
('46', 394, 7, 13, 822759) 2. What are the ways of attaining peace for one’s soul and achieving one’s object in this world and the next?
('46', 394, 8, 14, 822869) 3. Do you think a man can escape the punishment for his past misdeeds if he atones for them?
('46', 394, 9, 15, 822962) 4. What should be the prime aim and duty of man in his life?
('46', 394, 9, 16, 823023) It is a matter of joy and wonder that among the readers of Young India, Gujarati Navajivan and Hindi Navajivan it is mostly the Hindi reader who ask questions regarding religion.
('46', 394, 9, 17, 823202) It does not necessarily mean that people from other provinces lack curiosity in matters of religion.
('46', 394, 9, 18, 823303) It is, however, true that it is the readers of Hindi Navajivan, more than others, who love relgious discussions and expect my help in solving their religious problems.
('46', 394, 9, 19, 823471) I cannot claim a deep direct knowledge of the scriptures.
('46', 394, 9, 20, 823529) But of course I do claim to be trying to abide by religious principles.
('46', 394, 9, 21, 823601) In my attempt to do so if the experience gained by me can be of any help to the readers they are most welcome to it.
('46', 394, 9, 22, 823718) Having thus mentioned my limitation in this regard I will now attempt to answer the questions.
('46', 394, 9, 23, 823813) 1. It is true that we lack religious education in the country.
('46', 394, 9, 24, 823876) Religious instruction can only be imparted through the practice of religion, not by exhibiting mere learning.
('46', 394, 9, 25, 823986) That’s why someone has said: What is there that satsang 1 cannot do for a man?
('46', 394, 9, 26, 824065) Who does not know the emphasis Tulsidas laid on the importance of satsang?
('46', 394, 9, 27, 824140) This does not mean that there is no need to read and understand religious books.
('46', 394, 9, 28, 824221) But the need for books, etc., arises only after a man has had
('46', 394, 10, 29, 824283) 1 Association with good or good persons
('46', 395, 0, 1, 824323) 396 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 395, 1, 2, 824365) satsang and has purified himself to a certain extent.
('46', 395, 1, 3, 824419) If one starts studying religious books before this stage then istead of bringing peace this study could hinder the growth.
('46', 395, 1, 4, 824542) This means that an intelligent man should put his religion into practice straightaway instead of worrying himself with all manner of questions.
('46', 395, 1, 5, 824686) Then according to the maxim “as with the individual so with the world”, one is bound to influence the other.
('46', 395, 1, 6, 824795) If each one of us was to take care of one’s self, nobody would need to worry about the others.
('46', 395, 1, 7, 824890) 2. Only by living a saintly life can one obtain peace.
('46', 395, 1, 8, 824945) This is the way to fulfilment in this world and the next.
('46', 395, 1, 9, 825003) A saintly life is that in which we practise truth, ahimsa and restraint.
('46', 395, 1, 10, 825076) Enjoyment of pleasures can never be one's dharma.
('46', 395, 1, 11, 825126) Dharma has its source in renunciation only.
('46', 395, 1, 12, 825170) 3. It is possible to atone for one's past misdeeds and it is our duty to do so.
('46', 395, 1, 13, 825250) Atonement is not supplication, nor crying or whimpering, though there is some scope for fasting, etc., in it.
('46', 395, 1, 14, 825360) Repentance is the true atonement.
('46', 395, 1, 15, 825394) In other words the resolve not to commit the mistake again is without doubt the true penance.
('46', 395, 1, 16, 825488) The results of the misdeeds are wiped out to some extent.
('46', 395, 1, 17, 825546) Until we atone for a sin it goes on accumulating like compound interest.
('46', 395, 1, 18, 825619) This stops once we do the penance.
('46', 395, 1, 19, 825654) 4. The aim of man in his life is self realization.
('46', 395, 1, 20, 825705) The one and the only means of attaining this is to spend one’s life in serving humanity in a true altruistic spirit and lose oneself in this and realize the oneness of life.

('46', 395, 2, 22, 825920) 359. TRLU WORSHIP 1
('46', 395, 3, 23, 825940) A correspondent writes:
('46', 395, 4, 24, 825964) It is a common enough sight in this country to see men and women offering worship to stocks and stones and trees, but I was surprised to find that even educated women belonging to the families of enthusiastic social workers were not above this practice.
('46', 395, 4, 25, 826218) Some of those sisters and friends defend the practice by saying, that since it is founded on pure reverence for the divine in nature and no false beliefs,it cannot be classed as superstition, and they cite
('46', 395, 5, 26, 826424) 1 The Hindi original of this appeared in Hindi Navajivan, 15 8 1929. This is a translation by Pyarelal.
('46', 396, 0, 1, 826528) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 397
('46', 396, 1, 2, 826571) the names of Satyavan and Savitri whose momory, they say, they commemorate in that way.
('46', 396, 1, 3, 826659) The argument does not convince me.
('46', 396, 1, 4, 826694) May I request you to throw some light on the matter?
('46', 396, 2, 5, 826747) I like this question.
('46', 396, 2, 6, 826769) it raises the old, old question of image worship.
('46', 396, 2, 7, 826819) I am both a supporter and opponent of image worship.
('46', 396, 2, 8, 826872) When image worship degenerates into idolatry and becomes encrusted with false beliefs and doctrines, it becomes a necessity to combat it as a gross social evil.
('46', 396, 2, 9, 827033) On the other hand image worship in the sense of investing one’s ideal with a concrete shape is inherent in man’s nature, and even valuable as an aid to devotion.
('46', 396, 2, 10, 827195) Thus we worship an image when we offer homage to a book which we regard as holy or sacred.
('46', 396, 2, 11, 827286) We worship an image when we visit a temple or a mosque with a feeling of sanctity or reverence.
('46', 396, 2, 12, 827382) Nor do I see any harm in all this.
('46', 396, 2, 13, 827417) On the contrary, endowed as man is with a finite, limited understanding, he can hardly do otherwise.
('46', 396, 2, 14, 827518) Even so, far from seeing anything inherently evil or harmful in tree worship, I find in it a thing instinct with a deep pathos and poetic beauty.
('46', 396, 2, 15, 827664) It symbolizes true reverence for the entire vegetable kingdom, which with its endless panorama of beautiful shapes and forms, declares to us as it were with a million tongues the greatness and glory of God.
('46', 396, 2, 16, 827871) Without vegetation our planet would not be able to support life even for a moment.
('46', 396, 2, 17, 827954) In such a country especially, therefore, in which there is a scarcity of trees, tree worship assumes a profound economic significance.
('46', 396, 2, 18, 828089) I therefore see no necessity for leading a crusade against tree worship.
('46', 396, 2, 19, 828162) It is true that the poor simple minded women who offer worship to trees have no reasoned understanding of the implications of their act.
('46', 396, 2, 20, 828299) Possibly they would not be able to give any explanation as to why they perform it.
('46', 396, 2, 21, 828382) They act in the purity and utter simplicity of their faith.
('46', 396, 2, 22, 828442) Such faith is not a thing to be despised; it is a great and powerful force that we should treasure.
('46', 396, 2, 23, 828542) Far different, however, is the case of vows and prayers which votaries offer before trees.
('46', 396, 2, 24, 828633) The offering of vows and prayers for selfish ends, whether offered in churches, mosques, temples or before trees and shrines, is a thing not to be encouraged.
('46', 396, 2, 25, 828792) Making of selfish requests or offering of vows is not related to image worship as effect and cause.
('46', 396, 2, 26, 828892) A personal selfish prayer is bad whether made before an image or an unseen God.
('46', 396, 2, 27, 828972) Let no one, however, from this understand me to mean that I advocate tree worship in general.
('46', 396, 2, 28, 829066) I do not defend tree worship because

('46', 398, 3, 6, 830894) All the same I repeat here that I am nobody’s representative and I did not go to Bombay as anybody’s representative.
('46', 398, 3, 7, 831011) I wish to assure you that I will do nothing that will bind other people.
('46', 398, 3, 8, 831084) I have no remedy for those who may consider themselves bound by any action of mine.
('46', 398, 3, 9, 831168) In the course of my life it has often happened that people have accepted me as their representative because of some service I may have rendered and considered themselves bound by my actions.
('46', 398, 3, 10, 831359) I have even liked that.
('46', 398, 3, 11, 831383) Of course such people consider me their representative when they want and dismiss me when they want.

('46', 401, 13, 21, 836067) 371. RURAL EDUCATION
('46', 401, 14, 22, 836088) Kakasaheb wishes to serve a number of purposes through this supplement.
('46', 401, 14, 23, 836160) One of these is that persons who have passed what is ordinarily regarded as the school age, who are householders, are engaged in a profession or otherwise and are employed…the men and women living in about ten thousand villages of Maha Gujarat…should receive some kind of education which it is possible to give them.
('46', 401, 14, 24, 836477) The term education in this sense should be interpreted in a wider sense.
('46', 401, 14, 25, 836550) It is something distinct from a knowledge of the alphabet.
('46', 401, 14, 26, 836609) Villagers
('46', 401, 15, 27, 836619) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('46', 401, 16, 28, 836646) 2 In reply to his telegram dated August 17, which read: Kindly wire Mahatmaji’s health.” 3 In reply to her telegram dated August 17, which read: “All anxious for your health.
('46', 401, 16, 29, 836821) Please forget all experiments.”
('46', 402, 0, 1, 836853) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 403
('46', 402, 1, 2, 836896) today have no practical knowledge in many fields and we find, instead, that often ignorant superstition has established a hold over them.
('46', 402, 1, 3, 837034) Through this supplement, Kakasaheb intends to rid them of these superstitions and give them some useful knowledge.
('46', 402, 1, 4, 837149) From the standpoint of health, the condition of villages is deplorable.
('46', 402, 1, 5, 837221) One of the chief causes of our poverty is the non availability of this essential knowledge of hygiene.
('46', 402, 1, 6, 837324) If sanitation in villages can be improved, lakhs of rupees will easily be saved and the condition of people improved to that extent.
('46', 402, 1, 7, 837457) A sick peasant can never work as hard as a healthy one.
('46', 402, 1, 8, 837513) Not a little harm is being done because we have a higher death rate than the average.
('46', 402, 1, 9, 837599) It is held that our economically backward condition is responsible for our deplorable insanitation and that if the former is bettered, the latter will improve automatically.
('46', 402, 1, 10, 837773) Let this be said in order to malign the Government or to put all the blame on it, but there is not even fifty percent truth in that statement.
('46', 402, 1, 11, 837916) In my opinion based on experience,our poverty plays a very small part in our insanitary condition.
('46', 402, 1, 12, 838015) I know what part it plays and where, but I do not wish to go into it here.
('46', 402, 1, 13, 838090) The purpose of this series of articles is to point out the ways and means of eradicating those diseases for the incidence of which we are responsible and which can be readily eradicated at little or no expense.
('46', 402, 1, 14, 838301) Let us examine the state of our villages from this standpoint.
('46', 402, 1, 15, 838364) Many of these are found to be like heaps of garbage.
('46', 402, 1, 16, 838417) People urinate and defecate at all places in the villages, not excluding even their own courtyards.
('46', 402, 1, 17, 838517) Where this is done, no one takes care to cover up the faeces.
('46', 402, 1, 18, 838579) The village roads are never well maintained and one finds heaps of dust everywhere.
('46', 402, 1, 19, 838663) We ourselves and our bullocks find it difficult even to walk on them.
('46', 402, 1, 20, 838733) If there is a pond, people wash their utensils in it, cattle drink, bathe and wallow in it; children and even adults clean themselves in it after evacuation; they even defecate on the ground near it.
('46', 402, 1, 21, 838933) This same water is used for drinking and cooking purposes.
('46', 402, 1, 22, 838992) No rules are observed while building houses.
('46', 402, 1, 23, 839037) Neither the convenience of neighbours, nor residents’ facilities for light and air are considered when buildings are put up.
('46', 402, 1, 24, 839162) Because of a lack of co operation among villagers, they do not even grow things which are essential to ensure their own hygienic
('46', 403, 0, 1, 839291) 404 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 403, 1, 2, 839333) conditions.
('46', 403, 1, 3, 839345) Villagers do not put their leisure hours to good use, or perhaps they do not know how to do so, as a result of which their physical and mental capacity is depleted.
('46', 403, 1, 4, 839510) For want of general knowlege of hygiene, when there is an incidence of a disease, instead of employing some home remedies very often the villagers seek the help of magicians or get involved in the web of mantras and spend money and in return the disease is merely aggravated.
('46', 403, 1, 5, 839786) In this series, we shall examine all these reasons and see what can be done in the matter.
('46', 403, 1, 6, 839877) [From Gujarati]

('46', 403, 6, 16, 840498) 373. NEED FOR FAR SIGHTEDNESS
('46', 403, 7, 17, 840528) A reader makes the following comment on Shri Jivram Kayanji's “Correction”published in Navajivan dated 4 8 29: 2
('46', 403, 8, 18, 840641) 1 Not translated here.
('46', 403, 8, 19, 840664) Thakkar Bapa had acknowledged receipt of Rs. 24,000 and explained how it was used for distribution of rice, and encouraging spinning in flood stricken Assam.
('46', 403, 8, 20, 840822) 2 The letter is not translated here.
('46', 403, 8, 21, 840859) The correspondent had stated how harde or myrobalan, used in dyeing, tanning, etc., was exported by Indian traders, while Europeans processed the stuff and imported it into India for use in the dye industry, making enormous profits.
('46', 404, 0, 1, 841092) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 405
('46', 404, 1, 2, 841135) The above does not apply to Shri Jivram's argument.
('46', 404, 1, 3, 841187) He merely argued that he had gone over to Orissa not in order to wipe out the prevalent impression that he had done an injustice to the labourers, but rather because he was touched by their sufferings.
('46', 404, 1, 4, 841389) Those from whom he had purchased the harde were not labourers serving under him but persons who collected it on their own and sold it to him.
('46', 404, 1, 5, 841531) The problem posed by the above correspondent is a separate but important one; hence I have published the letter.
('46', 404, 1, 6, 841644) It is largely true that, although by collecting raw material and exporting it abroad, individuals may benefit themselves, the country as a whole is a loser rather than a gainer and is robbed of its wealth.
('46', 404, 1, 7, 841850) However, such things also grow in India as cannot be utilized and for the utilization of which we do not have sufficient facilities.
('46', 404, 1, 8, 841983) We should certainly export such items abroad and import them in the form of new products.
('46', 404, 1, 9, 842073) I do not see any use for the craze that we should process all items that are grown in India.
('46', 404, 1, 10, 842166) We may even do harm to ourselves by doing so.
('46', 404, 1, 11, 842212) Whether harde is something that should be exported or not is a different question.
('46', 404, 1, 12, 842295) I am unable to give an opinion on it.
('46', 404, 1, 13, 842333) However, cotton is the most important item which should not be exported at all; so long as we are guilty of this offence, the export of other minor items is hardly of any significance.
('46', 404, 1, 14, 842518) To take such small items into account is to do business without any sense of proportion.
('46', 404, 1, 15, 842607) If we were far sighted, we would devote all our time and all our talent for the present to the utilization of our cotton in our villages.
('46', 404, 1, 16, 842745) If we can take care of this one factor, the rest will take care of itself.
('46', 404, 1, 17, 842820) We should realize that, just as various small poisonous plants which thrive under the shade of a poisonous tree are automatically destroyed along with the destruction of the main tree, similar is the case of unscrupulous trading in cotton.
('46', 404, 1, 18, 843060) While considering this question, I have so far only taken in to account cloth that is imported from England and have shown that by doing so we throw away sixty crores of rupees.
('46', 404, 1, 19, 843238) If we take into account the cloth that is imported from Japan and other countries, the figure would reach one hundred crores.
('46', 404, 1, 20, 843364) However, that is not the whole story.
('46', 404, 1, 21, 843402) In addition to this, lakhs of rupees are sent abroad as a result of this trade.
('46', 404, 1, 22, 843482) This leaves out all the amount that the country spends on this Rs. 100 crores by way of insurance premia paid to foreign agencies and many more similar activites that are carried on.
('46', 404, 1, 23, 843665) Businessmen as a class are the greatest hurdle in the way of solving this important question.
('46', 404, 1, 24, 843759) They are not prepared to give up their
('46', 405, 0, 1, 843798) 406 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 405, 1, 2, 843840) trade in foreign cloth or change it for something else.
('46', 405, 1, 3, 843896) They adopt many means, both fair and unfair, in order to keep up that trade and arguments can be found to support such practices.
('46', 405, 1, 4, 844026) Again, just as we import our cloth from abroad, we also adopt foreign ideas.
('46', 405, 1, 5, 844103) What we find here mostly are English newspapers and magazines full of beautiful pictures, well printed and written with great skill.
('46', 405, 1, 6, 844236) As the owners of these journals have large sums of money at their disposal, it is but natural that their articles are clever.
('46', 405, 1, 7, 844362) Hence, momentarily our own ideas appear insipid to us, whereas we are dazzled by their.
('46', 405, 1, 8, 844450) And what more could we ask for when these ideas further our self interest?
('46', 405, 1, 9, 844525) Things being in such a pitiable condition, actually the main task is to bring about a change of heart in business men who deal in foreign cloth; in other words, our task in achieving swaraj will become most simple when business men introduce the concept of the welfare of others in their business and give national welfare an important place in it.
('46', 405, 1, 10, 844874) [From Gujarati]
('46', 405, 2, 11, 844890) Navajivan, 18 8 1929

('46', 413, 8, 15, 857539) In British territory I know we can exert some influence on the happenings, big and small, and so I write about them whenever I find it necessary.
('46', 413, 8, 16, 857685) I write nothing about the Native States because I know that nothing can be done publicly about even the most glaring cases of oppression there.
('46', 413, 8, 17, 857829) But to say that since I write nothing I do nothing betrays ignorance.
('46', 413, 8, 18, 857899) I am doing what I can according to my lights.

('46', 413, 8, 20, 858009) I can therefore understand the criticism by persons like you.
