('46', 415, 0, 1, 860723) 416 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 415, 1, 2, 860765) 395. UNFIRED FOOD 1
('46', 415, 2, 3, 860785) Instead of hopeful progress, I have to report a tragedy this week.
('46', 415, 2, 4, 860852) In spite of great carefulness in experimentation along an unbeaten track, I have been laid low.
('46', 415, 2, 5, 860948) A mild but persistent attack of dysentery has sent me to bed and not only to cooked food but also to goat’s milk.
('46', 415, 2, 6, 861062) Dr. Harilal Desai used all his skill and patience to save me from having to go back to milk, which I had left last November in the hope of not having to go back to it, but he saw that he could not reduce the mucus and the traces of blood that persistently appeared in the bowels without making me take curds.
('46', 415, 2, 7, 861371) At the time of writing this therefore I have had two portions of curds, with what effect I shall note at the foot of this article which is being written on Sunday 2 night.
('46', 415, 2, 8, 861543) It appears that I was not digesting the raw foods I was taking, and what I had mistaken for good motions were precursors of dysentery.
('46', 415, 2, 9, 861678) The other conditions including vitality being good, I had no cause to suspect any evil.
('46', 415, 2, 10, 861766) My companions too have one after another fallen off, except four, of whom one has been on raw food for nearly a year with great success as he thinks.
('46', 415, 2, 11, 861916) The companions have left off because they were feeling weak and were losing weight week by week.
('46', 415, 2, 12, 862013) Thus Sjt.
('46', 415, 2, 13, 862023) Gopalrao’s claim that unfired food is suitable for any stomach and can be taken with impunity by young and old, sick and healthy, is to say the least of it ‘unproven’.
('46', 415, 2, 14, 862191) This apparent failure should serve as a warning to the zealots that they should move most cautiously and be scrupulously exact in their statements and careful in their deductions.

('46', 417, 5, 13, 866080) The recently published Press report that my weight was reduced to 80 lb.
('46', 417, 5, 14, 866153) and that I had fainted was utterly baseless but it succeeded in giving a fright to probably hundreds of well wishers.
('46', 417, 5, 15, 866271) I have wires from all over India, including Burma, making anxious inquiries.
('46', 417, 5, 16, 866348) On more than one occasion, Press agencies have in my case rendered themselves liable to legal action by giving currency to false and harmful news.
('46', 417, 5, 17, 866495) Often has my anger against them got the better, for a moment, of my non co operation.
('46', 417, 5, 18, 866581) It is cruel to give a shock to the credulous public by spreading false reports.
('46', 417, 5, 19, 866661) Good faith and ignorance are no excuse when thousands of men and women are concerned.
('46', 417, 5, 20, 866747) Reporters are bound to take every precaution possible to ensure accuracy.
('46', 417, 5, 21, 866821) In the case in point, it was easy enough to ask a responsible person at the Udyoga Mandir or Dr. Harilal Desai as to my exact condition and much grief and anxiety could have been avoided.
('46', 417, 5, 22, 867009) I suggest to the agencies that they warn their reporters that they would be fined or dismissed for repeated offences of the character I have described.

('46', 418, 1, 2, 867249) 398. OUR CHOICE
('46', 418, 2, 3, 867265) An American correspondent has sent me a cutting from an old number of The World Tomorrow (August 1928).
('46', 418, 2, 4, 867369) It is a remarkable article on “Pacifism and National Security”by John Nevin Sayre which is worthy of perusal by every patriot.
('46', 418, 2, 5, 867496) The following opening paragraphs 1 show which way the writer would lead us:
('46', 418, 3, 6, 867572) Pacifism, first of all, askes people to consider whether national
('46', 418, 4, 7, 867638) armament can really conduce to security in a civilization which uses the tools
('46', 418, 5, 8, 867717) of twentieth century science.
('46', 418, 5, 9, 867747) No matter what may be said for defence by
('46', 418, 6, 10, 867789) armament in the past, we believe that it is an utterly obsolete and extremely
('46', 418, 7, 11, 867867) dangerous way of attempting to attain security now.
('46', 418, 7, 12, 867919) In the world in which we
('46', 418, 8, 13, 867944) live and in the decades immediately ahead, it is open to the double objection:
('46', 418, 9, 14, 868023) (1) mounting cost and (2) diminishing effectiveness for defence.
('46', 418, 9, 15, 868088) .every time the hands of the clock traverse twenty four hours, the United States spends £2.000,000 [on] upkeep for army and navy.
('46', 418, 10, 16, 868218) There is also an increasing human cost not measurable in dollars.
('46', 418, 10, 17, 868284) today military strategists plan to conscript the activity of the entire manpower of the nation.
('46', 418, 10, 18, 868380) Compulsory military training in time of peace and the invasion of schools and colleges by military departments run by the Department of War are requisitioning study time of youth, and tending to regiment youth’s thinking.
('46', 418, 10, 19, 868602) The post office, the newspapers, the radio, the movies, artists and men of science are in danger of being drawn in to give their support to the building of war’s preparedness machine.
('46', 418, 10, 20, 868786) All this means an increasing cost to human liberty, to freedom of thought and discussion, to the possibility of social advance.
('46', 418, 10, 21, 868914) Even worse is the fact that increase of expenditure for armament does not in the modern world purchase increase of security.
('46', 418, 10, 22, 869039) It may do so, possibly, for a score of years, but the policy is subject to a law of diminishing returns and leads straight towards a climax of disaster.
('46', 418, 10, 23, 869192) Senator Borah in discussing ‘What is Preparedness?’ recently called attention to the huge public debts and constantly increasing tax burdens which governments are putting on their peoples thoroughtout the world.
('46', 418, 11, 24, 869404) The fashion nowadays is to take for granted that whatever America and England are doing is good enough for us.
('46', 418, 11, 25, 869515) But the figures given by the writer of the cost to America of her armament are too terrible to contemplate.

('46', 427, 1, 2, 885139) 410. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA
('46', 427, 2, 3, 885166) August 23, 1929
('46', 427, 3, 4, 885182) BHAI GHANSHYAMDAS, I have your letter.
('46', 427, 3, 5, 885221) Do give up worrying on my account.
('46', 427, 3, 6, 885256) People fall sick even when they take regular diet.
('46', 427, 3, 7, 885307) What does it matter if the same happens to me in the pursuit of truth?
('46', 427, 3, 8, 885378) I am taking plenty of curds these days.
('46', 427, 3, 9, 885418) May I tell you that even milk and curds are admissible only to a certain extent.
('46', 427, 3, 10, 885499) They are not man’s natural food.
('46', 427, 3, 11, 885532) The argument you advance in support of milk is the same as that in support of beef tea and liquor because some physical benefit is derived for the time being from all of them.
('46', 427, 3, 12, 885708) But physical benefit [is not] everything.
('46', 427, 3, 13, 885750) The abatement of carnal desires experienced by so many people while taking raw cereals is not the result of starvation.
('46', 427, 3, 14, 885870) During the four years I was on fruit diet I used to walk forty miles daily and experienced the same mental peace.
('46', 427, 3, 15, 885984) But I do not wish to emphasize this point overmuch.
('46', 427, 3, 16, 886036) The mere physical benefit is not the only consideration in my experiement.
('46', 427, 3, 17, 886111) I shall not change over hastily to raw cereals nor shall I give up milk in a hurry.
('46', 427, 3, 18, 886195) At the moment many doctors are taking interest in this experiment.
('46', 427, 3, 19, 886262) Many have sent me literature [on this subject].
('46', 427, 3, 20, 886310) If I resume the experiment, it shall be under Dr. Haribhai's supervision.
('46', 427, 3, 21, 886384) Yours, MOHANDAS
('46', 427, 4, 22, 886400) From Hindi: C.W. 6175. Courtesy: G. D. Birla

('46', 429, 1, 2, 888478) 414. LETTER TO SATIS CHANDRA DAS GUPTA
('46', 429, 2, 3, 888517) [Before August 24, 1929]
('46', 429, 3, 4, 888542) MY DEAR SATIS BABU, I have wired about your astounding letter.
('46', 429, 4, 5, 888605) I know nothing about any business letter from Hemprabhadevi.
('46', 429, 4, 6, 888666) Even if she wrote a business letter, I should take a long time before taking it as such.
('46', 429, 4, 7, 888755) As it is, her letters to me have been all love and no business.
('46', 429, 4, 8, 888819) Your business letters too have been love letters for me.
('46', 429, 4, 9, 888876) Such I have believed to be the relations between you and me.
('46', 429, 4, 10, 888937) I had never thought you to be capable of misunderstanding me.
('46', 429, 4, 11, 888999) Krishnadas’s other suggestion seems to me to be equally mischievous.
('46', 429, 4, 12, 889068) How he has drawn deductions passes my comprehension.
('46', 429, 4, 13, 889121) His behaviour is inscrutable.
('46', 429, 4, 14, 889151) Your taking him on trust regarding my doings and without reference to me is painful.
('46', 429, 4, 15, 889236) I can say nothing of Niranjan till you tell me what he has told you.
('46', 429, 4, 16, 889305) You should take it from me that I have told them nothing that I have not told you about your decision regarding Ram Binod.
('46', 429, 5, 17, 889428) You may come and see me about this if you are still not satisfied.
('46', 429, 5, 18, 889495) Henceforth in all matters no matter who is concerned, never believe telltales.
('46', 429, 5, 19, 889574) And those are telltales who regale their company with irrelevant tales about others.
('46', 429, 5, 20, 889659) Again never believe anything against anybody without first referring the damaging statement to him.
('46', 429, 5, 21, 889759) So you remember what I did when I heard unworthy suggestions about Dadabhai?
('46', 429, 6, 22, 889836) Say now your owe me ten thousand apologies for being so cruel as to believe things of me of which I have not ever dreamt.
('46', 429, 7, 23, 889958) With love,
('46', 429, 8, 24, 889969) BAPU [PS.] My health [is] improving.

('46', 431, 0, 1, 891429) 432 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 431, 1, 2, 891471) 417. A KATHIAWARI’S WAIL 1
('46', 431, 2, 3, 891498) An enraged Kathiawari youth writes: 2
('46', 431, 3, 4, 891536) I must painfully tell you that you have put us in a very awkward fix by sealing our lips, and unless you release us from this disability you will unman us altogether.
('46', 431, 3, 5, 891703) Even the restrictions imposed by Sjt.
('46', 431, 3, 6, 891741) Mansukhlal which you decried were far more liberal than the disabilities that you have now impo sed.
('46', 431, 3, 7, 891842) Is it not rather curious that whereas in British India the slightest wrong is enough to make you flare up in righteious indignation,you won’t allow even a single condemnatory syllable to be uttered against any individual State though it might perpetrate the worst tyranny on its innocent ryots?
('46', 431, 3, 8, 892137) It is time that you reconsidered your self denying ordinance.
('46', 431, 3, 9, 892199) And if you cannot withdraw it altogether you should at least revise it to the extent of restoring the liberty to protest against cases of “flagrant injustice”.
('46', 431, 3, 10, 892359) Remember, at Bhavnagar you undertook to obtain a redress of our grievances.
('46', 431, 3, 11, 892435) Now that you have been disappointed in your efforts, does it not become your sacred duty to ventilate those questions before the public?
('46', 431, 3, 12, 892572) But that duty you have not discharged yet and have prevented others from discharging.
('46', 431, 3, 13, 892658) That is why we are today ground down by oppression.
('46', 431, 3, 14, 892710) Freedom of public discussion is our sacred and inalienable right and you ought to teach the Kathiawar public to exercise that right.
('46', 431, 3, 15, 892843) But you are doing just the reverse and by your curious silence are in fact conniving at the wrong.
('46', 431, 3, 16, 892942) In moments of despair, I am tempted to charge you with showing an undue partiality towards the States.
('46', 431, 4, 17, 893045) Won’t you remember and make good the promise you made at
('46', 431, 5, 18, 893102) Bhavnagar?
('46', 431, 5, 19, 893113) The Kathiawari friend in question has an undoubted right to write to me as he has done, just as it is my duty to give a patient hearing to what the youth might have to say.
('46', 431, 5, 20, 893286) Every duty performed confers upon one certain rights, whilst the exercise of every right carries with it certain corresponding obligations.
('46', 431, 5, 21, 893426) And so the never ending cycle of duty and right goes ceaselessly on.
('46', 431, 5, 22, 893495) In the present case for instance the Kathiawari youth began by exercising his right to pour forth his grief to me.
('46', 431, 5, 23, 893610) I discharge my duty by giving him a patient hearing, with the result that the right to speak out my mind to the Kathiawari youth has now accrued to me, and it is the duty of the
('46', 431, 6, 24, 893788) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan, 25 8 1929. This is a translation by Pyarelal.
('46', 431, 6, 25, 893889) 2 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('46', 432, 0, 1, 893926) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 433
('46', 432, 1, 2, 893969) Kathiawari youth in question to hear and try inwardly to digest and assimilate what I might have to say.
('46', 432, 1, 3, 894074) I very well remember the promise I made at Bhavnagar.
('46', 432, 1, 4, 894128) I have not yet lost hope.
('46', 432, 1, 5, 894154) My efforts still continue, but their result is not in my hands, but in the hands of God who alone controls results.
('46', 432, 1, 6, 894270) Nor is it necessary that my efforts in this direction should be before the public or involve my personally meeting the rulers in question.
('46', 432, 1, 7, 894409) They may or may not even be direct, indeed they may begin and end with a heart felt prayer.
('46', 432, 1, 8, 894501) Let no one laugh at this.
('46', 432, 1, 9, 894527) I want to enter into no special pleading on my behalf.
('46', 432, 1, 10, 894582) I mention this method of work because it is part and parcel of my life.
('46', 432, 1, 11, 894654) For years together in South Africa my efforts consisted practically only in waiting and prayer, and it is my firm conviction that that period of silent prayer was the most fruitful for that work.
('46', 432, 1, 12, 894850) It constituted the bedrock on which whatever little was accomplished was based.
('46', 432, 1, 13, 894930) Even today, perhaps I may be said to be doing nothing tangible for the attainment of Hindu Musim unity, yet it is my claim that I am striving for it ceaselessly.
('46', 432, 1, 14, 895092) Even so in the matter of the Indian States, I am always on the look out for an opportunity.
('46', 432, 1, 15, 895184) Opportunities have always come to me for the waiting and praying.
('46', 432, 1, 16, 895250) Let no one therefore be led away to think that I have ceased to concern myself about the question of the Indian States or to do anything in that behalf.
('46', 432, 1, 17, 895403) But I know that the impatient reader can judge my efforts only in the light of concrete tangible results.
('46', 432, 1, 18, 895509) He may therefore well feel angry if he fails to understand my way of doing things.
('46', 432, 1, 19, 895592) I must hold my soul in patience.
('46', 432, 1, 20, 895625) I may not here enter into a discussion of Mansukhlal’s restrictions.
('46', 432, 1, 21, 895694) My opinion in that respect has not undergone the least change.
('46', 432, 1, 22, 895757) But circumstances alter cases.
('46', 432, 1, 23, 895788) I have simply laid down the indispensable conditions for the holding of conferences in the Indian States.
('46', 432, 1, 24, 895894) If such conferences must be held at all without observing these restrictions, I maintain that it is not possible as yet to hold conferences within the boundaries of the States.
('46', 432, 1, 25, 896071) But these restrictions apply to conferences only; they do not affect individual action.
('46', 432, 1, 26, 896159) Anyone in his individual capacity has always perfect liberty to criticize as much as he likes any Indian prince, subject only to the measures of his own strength and consideration of sobriety and common sense.
('46', 433, 0, 1, 896369) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 433, 1, 2, 896411) Again I have never suggested that individual rulers of Indian States may never be criticized or that conferences untrammelled by any restrictions may not be held at all.
('46', 433, 1, 3, 896581) On the contrary I hold that there is nothing improper in holding in British territory conferences at which individul States may be freely criticized.
('46', 433, 1, 4, 896731) There is also the undoubted right of the subjects of any State to criticize the administration of that State within its own border.
('46', 433, 1, 5, 896863) That this right is not fully exercised today is a matter of deep sorrow.
('46', 433, 1, 6, 896936) It is true that personally I do not through Navajivan or otherwise criticize individual rulers.
('46', 433, 1, 7, 897032) But that is a different matter altogether.
('46', 433, 1, 8, 897075) I claim to be a practical man.
('46', 433, 1, 9, 897106) I have got a fair measure of my strength and I know how to conserve it.
('46', 433, 1, 10, 897178) I have deliberately cultivated the habit of avoiding a useless or superfluous word.
('46', 433, 1, 11, 897262) I do not hesitate unsparingly to denounce all wrongs great and small in British territory because I know that such denunciation is backed by consciousness of potential strength.
('46', 433, 1, 12, 897440) In the case of the States, though I am not unaware of the terrible things going on in some of them, I have no strength to back my exposure of the wrongs.
('46', 433, 1, 13, 897594) I disclaim any undue partiality for the States.
('46', 433, 1, 14, 897642) At the same time I owe them no grudge; I do not desire their destruction.
('46', 433, 1, 15, 897716) There is an abundant scope for reform in them which it should not be impossible to effect today.
('46', 433, 1, 16, 897813) But it is my firm belief that it is impossible to reform the States in the true sense while India is in bondage.
('46', 433, 1, 17, 897926) It may be possible to obtain redress here and there in cases of flagrant injustice by leading a crusade against it.
('46', 433, 1, 18, 898042) But such tinkering does not interest me.
('46', 433, 1, 19, 898083) It gives me no satisfaction.
('46', 433, 1, 20, 898112) I am therefore today concentrating all my energy on the root evil.
('46', 433, 1, 21, 898179) If I can effectively touch the root, the branches will in time drop down of their own accord.
('46', 433, 1, 22, 898273) Whereas on the contrary to divert public attention from the root evil and mobilize it against the branch evils in the States would mean lending an additional lease of life to the former.
('46', 433, 1, 23, 898460) That is a risk that I for one am not prepared to run.
('46', 433, 1, 24, 898514) Let no one, however, understand me to mean from this that no action whatsoever is at present possible in the case of the States.
('46', 433, 1, 25, 898643) I shall repeat here what I have already said.
('46', 433, 1, 26, 898689) Wherever the subjects of States are ready for it they can and ought to organize an agitation against maladministration in that State especially if they have the strength to make use of the never failing weapon of satyagraha.
('46', 433, 1, 27, 898914) But it is a matter of deep sorrow to me that today the ruled are often tools in the hands
('46', 434, 0, 1, 899004) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 435
('46', 434, 1, 2, 899047) of wicked rulers.
('46', 434, 1, 3, 899065) Grinding oppression has rendered the people nerveless.
('46', 434, 1, 4, 899120) No one has yet been able to save goats from the clutches of tigers.
('46', 434, 1, 5, 899188) The goats’ emancipation would be possible only if one could envisage the goat world itself giving birth to its would be emancipator.
('46', 434, 1, 6, 899321) Though reduced to the position of the goat man is today in this country, especially in the States, all hope is not lost forhim.
('46', 434, 1, 7, 899449) He belongs to a higher species.
('46', 434, 1, 8, 899481) Strength lies dormant in the weak.
('46', 434, 1, 9, 899516) If they find an environment in which bipeds exactly like them exhibit strength, it is not unlikely that they will catch the infection.
('46', 434, 1, 10, 899651) Bardoli was only a modest forerunner…a beam from the powerful sun.
('46', 434, 1, 11, 899718) If Bardoli exhibited the full strength and qualifications necessary for full satyagraha, its example would spread throughout the length and breadth of the land, and we should find ourselves, including the people of the States, a free nation.
('46', 434, 1, 12, 899960) Young India, 29 8 1929
('46', 434, 2, 13, 899983) 418. MY NOTES
('46', 434, 3, 14, 899997) EVIL MINDED GOVERNMENT Bhai Mahadev has given in this issue a summary of some noteworthy corresondence between Sardar Vallabhbhai and the Government on the report 1 presented by the official inquiry committee on Bardoli and Chorasi.
('46', 434, 3, 15, 900230) It is worth pondering over.
('46', 434, 3, 16, 900258) There are two points in it: one about redressing the injustice done to several villages through oversight, and the other about the benefits, if any, likely to accrue to Bardoli and Chorasi as a result of the new changes proposed to be made by the Government.
('46', 434, 3, 17, 900517) The Government has returned a negative reply in regard to both the matters.
('46', 434, 3, 18, 900593) It would not even hear the plea of injustice.
('46', 434, 3, 19, 900639) It is not willing to concede the benefits of future changes.
('46', 434, 3, 20, 900700) Even if a rope is burnt, its twist endures.
('46', 434, 3, 21, 900744) 2 The Government is aware that, if it cannot remove through negotiations the injustice done to certain villages, the Sardar will definitely not have recourse to a weapon like satyagraha.
('46', 434, 3, 22, 900931) Such a weapon cannot be used in this way.
('46', 434, 3, 23, 900973) Being thus free from fear the Government declines to do justice.
('46', 434, 3, 24, 901038) Because of its policy of not doing justice until its hands are forced, the Government has become unpopular and is becoming more so.
('46', 434, 3, 25, 901170) The officials are not inclined to understand the simple thing that
('46', 434, 4, 26, 901237) 1 The Broomfield Maxwell Report 2 A Gujarati saying
('46', 435, 0, 1, 901289) 436 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 435, 1, 2, 901331) the Government does not stand to suffer any loss if a slightly reduced revenue was received from three or four villages.
('46', 435, 1, 3, 901452) Their “prestige” 1 stands in the way.
('46', 435, 1, 4, 901490) The other thing concerns the future.
('46', 435, 1, 5, 901527) Just as we cannot launch satyagraha for the sake of particular villages only, we cannot but do so if the future benefits do not go to Bardoli and Chorasi.
('46', 435, 1, 6, 901682) Then satyagraha will become inevitable.
('46', 435, 1, 7, 901722) Hence the Sardar has told the Government politely but firmly that, if the new legislation proves to be beneficial and if Bardoli and Chorasi do not receive its benefits, satyagraha will surely be launched for their sake.
('46', 435, 1, 8, 901943) There is one small legal loophole in the case of the villages of Bardoli.
('46', 435, 1, 9, 902017) The Sardar cannot expose it, but if it exposes itself, the above mentioned villages can perhaps take advantage of it.
('46', 435, 1, 10, 902135) Therefore, it is a different matter if the loophole exposes itself.
('46', 435, 1, 11, 902203) Else those villages should be ready to put up with this injustice and if it becomes necessary to launch satyagraha, Bardoli should be ready for it.
('46', 435, 1, 12, 902351) No one knows when the future will become the present.
('46', 435, 1, 13, 902405) The legislation which the Government had promised to enact has hung fire for a number of years.
('46', 435, 1, 14, 902501) But Bardoli has yet to discharge its original debt.
('46', 435, 1, 15, 902553) The swaraj yajna commenced by Bardoli has still remained unifinished.
('46', 435, 1, 16, 902623) If it gets ready to complete it, there is no need even to talk of the miniature satyagraha of the future.
('46', 435, 2, 17, 902729) ANOTHER TEMPLE THROWN OPEN
('46', 435, 3, 18, 902756) Thanks to Shri Jamnalalji’s efforts, the famous Lakshminarayan Temple at Wardha was thrown open to Antyaja brothers and sisters.
('46', 435, 3, 19, 902885) Now owing to his efforts, even the well known Dattatreya Temple at Elichpur in Berar has been thrown open.
('46', 435, 3, 20, 902992) Elichpur was the old capital of Berar.
('46', 435, 3, 21, 903031) It has even today a population of 38,000. At a public meeting held on July 1, the temple was thrown open.
('46', 435, 3, 22, 903137) Dr. Patwardhan of Amaraoti presided over the meeting.
('46', 435, 3, 23, 903191) The ceremony of declaring the temple open was performed by Jamnalalji.
('46', 435, 3, 24, 903262) The temple was built fifteen years ago at a cost of Rs. 83,000. Its management is in the hands of a committee of twenty four members.
('46', 435, 3, 25, 903396) The resolution to throw it open to the Antyajas was voted by eighteen out of twenty four.
('46', 435, 3, 26, 903486) There are five trustees, all of whom were unanimous in regard to the decision to throw it open.

('46', 443, 3, 8, 915179) 1 What you write about ghee and milk is quite correct.
('46', 443, 3, 9, 915234) Ginning is certainly coming to life in the footsteps of spinning.

('46', 444, 7, 14, 916738) 433. THE ANGLO INDIAN
('46', 444, 8, 15, 916760) Some Anglo Indian friends have often complained to me that I do not give the Anglo Indian friends sufficient notice in these columns.
('46', 444, 8, 16, 916894) I have always repudiated the charge.
('46', 444, 8, 17, 916931) It is not my lukewarmness towards them that I do not often mention them in Young India.
('46', 444, 8, 18, 917019) Indeed I have the honour to have many friends among them.
('46', 444, 8, 19, 917077) My conception of swaraj requires the same consideration for them as for any other group.
('46', 444, 8, 20, 917166) Only they stand in little need of any advocacy in these columns.
('46', 444, 8, 21, 917231) Those who are despised in the country, those who are neglected by the Government or those whose interests are hostile to those of the Government claim a lien upon these columns.
('46', 444, 8, 22, 917409) Just as Englishmen do not need the protection of these columns, so do the powerful Anglo Indian interests stand in no need of it.
('46', 444, 8, 23, 917539) I can mention several such indigenous interests that stand in little need of the assistance of Young India.
('46', 444, 8, 24, 917647) But this general assurance I have tendered more than once that in these columns there never would be any sacrifice advocated or encouraged of a single legitimate interest.
('46', 444, 8, 25, 917819) I note in the constitution of the Anglo Indian League the definition of the phrase Anglo Indian community which I had not known hitherto.
('46', 444, 8, 26, 917957) It “means and includes”:
('46', 445, 0, 1, 917982) 446 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 445, 1, 2, 918024) (1) All persons of mixed European and Indian descent whose father, grandfather or more remote lineal ancestor in the paternal line shall have been of European, American or Colonial birth, and
('46', 445, 2, 3, 918216) (2) Europeans, Colonial British subjects of European descent, and Americans domiciled in India.
('46', 445, 2, 4, 918312) In the circumstances these friends of the League really need not only no advocacy from these columns, but they have ranged themselves against the millions of India in so far as the European interest may be regarded as against that of India.
('46', 445, 2, 5, 918553) If the half borns claim the rights and privileges of the ruling race, theirs is an interest which as the occasion may demand will, if the ruling race can help it, override that of the indigenous inhabitants whenever the latter is in conflict with theirs.
('46', 445, 2, 6, 918808) These columns stoutly resist such usurpation, no matter by whom advanced.
('46', 445, 2, 7, 918882) At any rate the Anglo Indian of the League may regard himself as well protected as the ruling race.
('46', 445, 2, 8, 918982) But I know that the Anglo Indian not represented by the League is in an overwhelming majority.
('46', 445, 2, 9, 919077) He does claim my sympathy, friendship and even pity in several cases.
('46', 445, 2, 10, 919147) The half born who takes the hue of his Indian parent and has no money is in a most unenviable condition.
('46', 445, 2, 11, 919252) His political right is in no danger.
('46', 445, 2, 12, 919289) It is his social status which is non existent.
('46', 445, 2, 13, 919336) He frets over his Indian parentage and he is disowned by the European race.
('46', 445, 2, 14, 919412) He is therefore between Scylla and Charybdis.
('46', 445, 2, 15, 919458) I often meet him.
('46', 445, 2, 16, 919476) He is washed out in the process of living above his means and trying to live the European life and look like Europeans.
('46', 445, 2, 17, 919596) I have pleaded with him to make his choice and to throw in his lot with the vast multitude.
('46', 445, 2, 18, 919688) If these men and women will have the courage and the foresight to appreciate this very simple and natural position, they will serve themselves, they will serve India and they will be spared the galling position in which they find themselves.
('46', 445, 2, 19, 919930) The greatest problem before the dumb Anglo Indian is that of determining his social status.
('46', 445, 2, 20, 920022) He is saved, the moment he recognizes himself as an Indian and lives like one.
('46', 445, 2, 21, 920101) To the vocal Anglo Indian of the League I submit that the activities of the League are a mere tinkering with the grave problem.
('46', 445, 2, 22, 920229) The League should, if it will truly represent the bulk of the Anglo Indian community, revise its policy radically, change the definition to which I have adverted and step forward boldly and unequivocally on behalf of the glorious battle for India’s freedom.
('46', 445, 2, 23, 920487) Today in my opinion the League is attempting the impossible.
('46', 445, 2, 24, 920548) Young India, 29 8 1929
('46', 446, 0, 1, 920571) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 447
('46', 446, 1, 2, 920614) 434. NOTES
('46', 446, 2, 3, 920625) A MUTE REFORMER Sjt.
('46', 446, 2, 4, 920646) Manilal Kothari writes:
('46', 446, 3, 5, 920670) You will remember that, writing on the Bhil situation in Rajputana in Young India in 1922, you recommended pardon for the Bhil leader, Motilal.
('46', 446, 4, 6, 920814) In 1924 Sir R. E. Holland, the A. G. G. in Rajputana, after sympathetic consideration of the whole case and in view of the peaceful situation then prevailing in Rajputana, advised the States concerned to pardon Motilal, so that some time later, his influence could be utilized for some useful social work amongst the ignorant and backward Bhils.
('46', 446, 4, 7, 921160) I understand that all the Rajputana States, including Mewar, agreed to the proposal, and I was distinctly told by Sir R. E. Holland as well as by his successor Lt.
('46', 446, 4, 8, 921324) Patterson that I had their authority to tell the Government of Bombay that Rajputana had no objection to pardon being granted to Motilal by the Bombay States, viz., Idar and Danta.
('46', 446, 4, 9, 921505) It is, therefore, surprising that of all the States, Mewar should now keep him under detention and that too without any trial.
('46', 446, 5, 10, 921632) The authorities allege that you had disowned Motilal.
('46', 446, 5, 11, 921686) I believe it is not a fact.
('46', 446, 5, 12, 921714) You have, I believe, known him personally and something of his work.
('46', 446, 5, 13, 921783) I would, therefore, request you kindly to clear the misunderstanding and advise the Mewar Durbar to take a sympathetic view of the case and release the reformer.
('46', 446, 6, 14, 921945) The reader is not llikely to know Motilal.
('46', 446, 6, 15, 921988) Well, he is an unassuming, ignorant social reformer among the Bhils of Rajputana.
('46', 446, 6, 16, 922070) His passion is to wean them from meats and drink.
('46', 446, 6, 17, 922120) At one time he exercised among them very great influence.
('46', 446, 6, 18, 922178) And now though it is not as great, his name commands respect among his tribesmen.
('46', 446, 6, 19, 922260) who owe so much of their social transformation to him.
('46', 446, 6, 20, 922315) I have had the privilege of meeting Motilal after my discharge from Yeravda.
('46', 446, 6, 21, 922392) He is no man of letters and hardly talks to anyone.
('46', 446, 6, 22, 922444) But he means business and believes in himself and his people.
('46', 446, 6, 23, 922506) I am afraid that there is a colouring of truth in the imputation that I had disowned him in 1922. I had said that he had no authority to use my name which he was alleged in 1922 to have done.
('46', 446, 6, 24, 922698) But after that and when I had come to know something of his mission I had strongly recommended that he should be pardoned.
('46', 446, 6, 25, 922821) I had flattered myself with the belief that Sir R. E. Holland’s recommendation had something to do with the Young India paragraph.
('46', 446, 6, 26, 922952) Be that as it might, I had hoped that Motilal was pardoned,
('46', 446, 7, 27, 923012) 1 Vide “Notes” sub title The “Bhils” of Rajpuatana
('46', 447, 0, 1, 923063) 448 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 447, 1, 2, 923105) and that the incident of 1922 was wholly forgotten by the States concerned.
('46', 447, 1, 3, 923181) If therefore surprises me that Mewar States has arrested and detained him not for anything he has done since but for the offences alleged against him in 1922. Apart from every other consideration, surely the Mewar State will avoid the charge of bad faith which the simple Bhils will bring against it, if their beloved leader is now detained under custody for what they have been led to believe had been pardoned.
('46', 447, 1, 4, 923594) So far as I am aware Motilal has done nothing to deserve detention.
('46', 447, 1, 5, 923662) I trust therefore that this simple and sincere reformer will be released and encouraged in his prosecution of social reforms among his own people.

('46', 449, 2, 4, 928207) ANTI UNTOUCHABILITY CAMPAIGN 1
('46', 449, 3, 5, 928238) Jamnalalji, the Secretary of the Congress Anti untouchability Committee, has succeded in having the famous Dattatreya temple of Elichpur, the former capital of Berar, thrown open to the so called untouchables.
('46', 449, 3, 6, 928448) He performed the opening ceremony before a distinguished gathering on 31st July last.
('46', 449, 3, 7, 928534) The temple is one of the biggest in Elichpur which has a population of 38,000. It was built 15 years ago at a cost of Rs. 83,000 by the efforts of Swami Vimalanand.
('46', 449, 3, 8, 928699) The Committee of Management consists of 24 of whom 18 voted for the opening.
('46', 449, 3, 9, 928776) There is a board of 5 trustees who were unanimous in their decision in favour of the opening.
('46', 449, 3, 10, 928870) The new signboard put up at the entrance reads:
('46', 449, 4, 11, 928918) This temple is thrown open from today for free access to Mangs, Mahars, Chamars and all Hindus alike for purposes of darshan, bhajan, for offering worship and prayers and for attending religious discourses, etc.
('46', 449, 4, 12, 929130) The opening ceremony was preceded by a public meeting presided over by Dr. Patwardhan of Amaraoti.
('46', 449, 5, 13, 929229) The organizers of the ceremony deserve congratulations for the service they have rendered to Hinduism and the nation.
('46', 449, 5, 14, 929347) Let us hope that Jamnalalji will be able to induce the trustees of other temples to follow the example of Wardha and now of Elichpur.
('46', 449, 5, 15, 929481) This beginning is but a drop in the ocean.
('46', 449, 5, 16, 929524) For there are lakhs of temples that await this initial purification of lifting the ban on ‘untouchables’.
('46', 449, 5, 17, 929630) Hindus must hang down their heads in shame so long as the curse of untouchability persists.
('46', 449, 5, 18, 929722) SELF SPINNING IN RAJPUTANA Sjt.
('46', 449, 5, 19, 929754) Mulchandji who is organizing self spinning in Ringas sends an interesting report of the work done there from which I condense the following information: The work was commenced in March 1928. It was started with a school through which contact was sought to be established.
('46', 449, 5, 20, 930026) But it was found that direct contact with the elders was essential.
('46', 449, 5, 21, 930094) So the workers visited the homes of the peasantry after they had returned from their fields.
('46', 449, 5, 22, 930187) They had spinning wheels which were in danger of being put away.
('46', 449, 5, 23, 930252) The work was
('46', 449, 6, 24, 930265) 1 Vide also “My Notes” sub title Another Temple Thrown Open”
('46', 450, 0, 1, 930326) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 451
('46', 450, 1, 2, 930369) however commenced by inviting them to learn carding.
('46', 450, 1, 3, 930422) This some of them undertook to learn.
('46', 450, 1, 4, 930460) Teaching was imparted at night between 7 and 10. This however excited the jealousy of the professional pinjaras who spread all kinds of wild rumours among the credulous peasantry.
('46', 450, 1, 5, 930640) Nothing daunted, the workers called a meeting of the whole peasantry and explained the philanthropic object of their mission.
('46', 450, 1, 6, 930766) Confidence was restored and the work went on smoothly.
('46', 450, 1, 7, 930821) As a result in a population of 5, 289 in 61 villages, 410 families out of 933 had taken part in the movement up to the time for which the report has been drawn up.
('46', 450, 1, 8, 930985) Of these 67 families have had all their clothing made out of self spun yarn.
('46', 450, 1, 9, 931062) This means 349 souls.
('46', 450, 1, 10, 931084) 595 men and women had a portion of their cloth prepared from self spun yearn.
('46', 450, 1, 11, 931162) 915 persons learnt carding during the period under review, i.e., eight months.
('46', 450, 1, 12, 931241) Altogether 2, 398 yards of khadi was thus woven.
('46', 450, 1, 13, 931290) This is encouraging progress, and shows how by patient toil contract can be established with eople, and they can be persuaded to take an interest in their own well being.
('46', 450, 1, 14, 931461) What has been possible in the villages surrounding Ringas is surely possible more or less throughout India.

('46', 451, 4, 14, 933837) 435. THE DEVADASI
('46', 451, 5, 15, 933855) The indefatigable Dr. S. Muthulakshmi Reddi writes: 1
('46', 451, 6, 16, 933909) As you have been openly denouncing the Devadasi system in the Hindu temples, I make bold to appeal to you for help in the great task of getting rid of that evil.
('46', 451, 6, 17, 934071) In this Presidency, I find it an uphill task, as the so called educated men and even some of the most prominent Congressmen oppose my reform measures and defend that infamous institution.
('46', 451, 7, 18, 934259) My Devadasi Bill, which has now become an Act, deals only with the Inam holding Devadasis, but there is a section of that community which practise dedication under the cloak of religion simply to make a living out of prostitution.
('46', 451, 7, 19, 934490) This is nothing but traffic in children; because children are even bought and adopted (adoption by Devadasi is allowed by our Hindu Law) .
('46', 451, 7, 20, 934629) I have had many memorials and petitions from the enlightened section of that community asking me to bring about legislation to punish such wicked people who trade upon the children's souls and bodies.
('46', 451, 8, 21, 934830) The Penal Code Sections 372 and 373 have proved ineffective.
('46', 451, 8, 22, 934891) Hence, I have given notice of another Bill for the success of which I want your blessings.
('46', 451, 8, 23, 934982) Some may argue that legislation is no good so long as the people
('46', 451, 9, 24, 935047) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('46', 452, 0, 1, 935084) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 453
('46', 452, 1, 2, 935127) do not realize the evil in that custom; but my contention is that a good section of our people perceive the injustice.
('46', 452, 2, 3, 935246) Among the Devadasi community itself there is a great awakening, and they have been doing propaganda on a large scale, but I am pained to observe that the high caste people do not help them in that community's efforts to reform themselves.
('46', 452, 2, 4, 935485) And further, our laws for the protection of children are almost nil in this Presidency .
('46', 452, 3, 5, 935574) I heartily endorse the writer's proposal.
('46', 452, 3, 6, 935616) Indeed I do not think that the proposed legislation will be in advance of public opinion.
('46', 452, 3, 7, 935706) The whole of the enlightened public opinion that is vocal is against the retention of the system in any shape or form.
('46', 452, 3, 8, 935825) The opinion of the parties concerned in the immoral traffic cannot count, just as the opinion of keepers of opium dens will not count in favour of their retention, if public opinion is otherwise against them.
('46', 452, 3, 9, 936034) The Devadasi system is a blot upon those who countenance it.
('46', 452, 3, 10, 936095) It would have died long ago but for the supineness of the public.
('46', 452, 3, 11, 936161) Public conscience in this country somehow or other lies dormant.
('46', 452, 3, 12, 936226) It often feels the awfulness of many a wrong, but is too indifferent or too lazy to move.
('46', 452, 3, 13, 936316) But if some active spirit like Dr. Reddi moves, that conscience is prepared to lend such support as indifference can summon up.
('46', 452, 3, 14, 936444) I am therefore of opinion that Dr. Reddi's proposal is in no way premature.
('46', 452, 3, 15, 936520) Such legislation might well have been brought earlier.
('46', 452, 3, 16, 936575) In any case I hope that she will receive the hearty support of all lovers of purity in religious and general social life.
('46', 452, 3, 17, 936697) Young India, 29 8 1929
('46', 452, 4, 18, 936720) 436. IMAGE WORSHIP
('46', 452, 5, 19, 936739) An inquirer writes:
('46', 452, 6, 20, 936759) 1. What ritual would you suggest or the kind of image worship which you
('46', 452, 7, 21, 936831) support?
('46', 452, 7, 22, 936840) Would it be enought just to have the darshan of the image or would you also
('46', 452, 8, 23, 936916) recommend the offering of food, etc.?
('46', 452, 8, 24, 936954) Considering that the image cannot eat, how far
('46', 452, 9, 25, 937001) is it proper to offer it food?
('46', 452, 9, 26, 937032) A. I have no specific ritual for the worship of an image.
('46', 452, 9, 27, 937090) Each man or society can create his or its own ritual.
('46', 452, 9, 28, 937144) And this is what usually happens.
('46', 452, 9, 29, 937178) The ritual indicates the person's or the society's conception of good form.
('46', 452, 9, 30, 937254) It is after all mostly a matter of convention.
('46', 452, 9, 31, 937301) The devotee, as the saying goes, conceives of his deity in his own image,
('46', 453, 0, 1, 937375) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 453, 1, 2, 937417) which means that it is a matter of imagination, but so long as imagination holds sway it represents the real.
('46', 453, 2, 3, 937527) 2. Inasmuch as man is an embodied being, even the greatest of men is bound to
('46', 453, 3, 4, 937605) have a few defects.
('46', 453, 3, 5, 937625) As I see it, the worship of him will result in the transmission of
('46', 453, 4, 6, 937692) these defects to the worshipper, because both the merits and defects of the worshipped
('46', 453, 5, 7, 937779) tend to be transmitted to the worshipper.
('46', 453, 5, 8, 937821) Do you approve of this kind of worship?
('46', 453, 5, 9, 937861) A. For the object of one's worship one can choose either an ideal, that is, an imaginary figure, or a historical person.
('46', 453, 5, 10, 937982) I prefer the former.
('46', 453, 5, 11, 938003) Krishna conceived as a Sampurnavatara, i.e.
('46', 453, 5, 12, 938047) a plenary incarnation of God is an ideal, that is, an imaginary incarnation.
('46', 453, 5, 13, 938124) A historical Krishna may have defects.
('46', 453, 5, 14, 938163) I agree that the merits and defects of the worshipped tend to be transmitted to the worshipper.
('46', 453, 6, 15, 938259) 3. The body with the jivatma 1 is called chetana, i.e.
('46', 453, 6, 16, 938314) the sentient, and after the
('46', 453, 7, 17, 938342) soul has departed from it, it is called jada, i.e.
('46', 453, 7, 18, 938393) the inert.
('46', 453, 7, 19, 938404) If it is contended that the all 
('46', 453, 8, 20, 938437) pervading divine Principle is present also in the lifeless image, how can one who
('46', 453, 9, 21, 938519) considers God to be all pervading limit Him merely to the image?
('46', 453, 9, 22, 938584) Would it not
('46', 453, 10, 23, 938597) amount to an insult to an emperor if one were to call him the ruler of a small village?
('46', 453, 10, 24, 938685) A. It is true that we cannot limit the authority of an emperor to just a village, but he is ruler of a small village in the same degree as he is of countless villages.
('46', 453, 10, 25, 938853) And it is quite possible that the resident of a particular village may be completely ignorant of the existence of other villages.
('46', 453, 10, 26, 938983) The prince of devotees, Tulsidas, had for his God the bow bearing Ramachandra and not the discus wielding Krishnach andra.
('46', 453, 10, 27, 939106) That is why he had the darshan of Ramachandra even when he looked at the image of Krishnachandra.
('46', 453, 11, 28, 939204) 4. You often say that for success in the tasks that we have undertaken, such as
('46', 453, 12, 29, 939284) Hindu Muslim unity, people should pray to God.
('46', 453, 12, 30, 939331) That being so, will you say that the
('46', 453, 13, 31, 939368) people who worship trees and other things should pray to them for selfish or
('46', 453, 14, 32, 939445) altruistic ends?
('46', 453, 14, 33, 939462) A. There is no detachment in a petitionary prayer.
('46', 453, 14, 34, 939513) There is in it an element of attachment and necessarily therefore of aversion.
('46', 453, 14, 35, 939592) My ideal prayer is free from attachment and is therefore addressed to the all pervading and unknowable Divine.
('46', 453, 14, 36, 939703) But those who worship trees and other things may pray to them for success in such altruistic prayers as for Hindu Muslim unity.
('46', 453, 15, 37, 939831) 1 Individual self
('46', 454, 0, 1, 939849) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 455
('46', 454, 1, 2, 939892) 5. Along with faith, is not discrimination also necessary?
('46', 454, 1, 3, 939951) Won't you say that faith devoid of discrimination is blind faith or superstition?
('46', 454, 1, 4, 940033) And is not blind faith responsible for many evils in the world?
('46', 454, 1, 5, 940097) A. My faith includes both knowledge and discrimination.
('46', 454, 1, 6, 940153) Faith has no place in things which can be dealt with by reason.
('46', 454, 1, 7, 940217) It is thus clear that blind faith is not faith at all.
('46', 454, 2, 8, 940272) 6. You prescribe the way of truth and non violence as the only true way for all men.
('46', 454, 2, 9, 940357) Could you not similarly prescribe some specific form of upasna 1 …no matter what language is used for ritual or prayer?
('46', 454, 2, 10, 940477) A. Truth and non violence represents a universal principle.
('46', 454, 2, 11, 940537) Upasna, however, is only a means, though a necessary and powerful means, evolved by man.
('46', 454, 2, 12, 940626) It is therefore determined by time and place.
('46', 454, 2, 13, 940672) It admits of variation, and rightly too, though the final result is the same.
('46', 454, 2, 14, 940750) Just as the waters of all rivers flow into the sea, even so do the prayer and adoration offered to the different deities find their way to Keshava.

('46', 456, 7, 13, 943680) Your letter is absolutely innocent.

('46', 456, 7, 18, 944069) That file is lying on my table right before me.

('46', 456, 7, 23, 944470) I have not yet been able to attend to them, but now I am giving up that desire.

('46', 456, 8, 27, 944712) From a copy of the Gujarati: Kusumbehn Desai’s Diary.
('46', 456, 8, 28, 944766) S.N. 32577/144 An argument advanced by the mill owners is that even today the mills are running at a loss.
('46', 456, 8, 29, 944873) I regard the evidence given in support of this as rather weak.
('46', 456, 8, 30, 944936) It is possible that a few mills are running at a loss; but the majority of them would not incur losses.

('46', 457, 1, 2, 945167) depreciation were not deducted before declaring the dividend and if nothing can be taken to the Reserve Fund, I would not place these as losses as against the wages of labourers.
('46', 457, 1, 3, 945346) I must mention one point here.
('46', 457, 1, 4, 945377) Labour had put forward two arguments in support of its demand.
('46', 457, 1, 5, 945440) I have already discussed one of them.
('46', 457, 1, 6, 945478) The second was that mills were at present making such profits that they should withdraw the wage cut.
('46', 457, 1, 7, 945580) Labour, on its part, could not prove this and on this the panch has given a unanimous verdict.

('46', 457, 2, 14, 946441) Finally since unrest is spreading among the labouerers as a result of the delay in the decision, the Sarpanch is requested to give his decision as early as possible.
('46', 457, 2, 15, 946607) I have to tour the U.P. till the 24th of November, but if the Sarpanch wants to ask me anything, he should write to me careof the Satyagraha Ashram, whence the letter will be forwarded to me wherever I am and I shall send the Sarpanch whatever replies I may have to after consulting my colleague.

('46', 458, 1, 2, 947118) APPENDICES
('46', 458, 2, 3, 947129) APPENDIX I
('46', 458, 3, 4, 947140) GOSEVA SANGHA
('46', 458, 4, 5, 947154) The Cow protection Conference held at Belgaum on 28th December 1924
('46', 458, 5, 6, 947222) resolved to found a permanent body called ‘All India Cow protection Association’
('46', 458, 6, 7, 947303) and appointed a committee to frame a constitution for it.
('46', 458, 6, 8, 947361) the Committee met in Delhi
('46', 458, 7, 9, 947388) on 26th and 28th January 1925, and the constitution drafted by it was adopted with
('46', 458, 8, 10, 947471) some amendments at a public meeting held in Madhavbag, Bombay, on 28th April
('46', 458, 9, 11, 947548) 1925. This ‘All India Cow protection Association’, having not been able to
('46', 458, 10, 12, 947623) command such public attention and sympathy as to entitle it to be called an all India
('46', 458, 11, 13, 947709) organization, its members met at the Satyagraha Ashram, Sabarmati, on 25th July,
('46', 458, 12, 14, 947790) 1928, disbanded it and adopted the following resolution:
('46', 458, 13, 15, 947847) “Inasmuch as the All India Cow protection Association has not been able to command public attention and sympathy commensurate with the all India character it has claimed, and inasumuch as its activities have been confined to the slow spread of the objects of the Association and especially to helping to conduct a dairy and tannery at the Satyagraha Ashram in terms of the objects of the Association, and inasmuch as the subscriptions and donations are mainly confined to friends who are interested in the experiment, and inasmuch as the numerous goshalas and pinjrapoles which were expected to respond to and be affiliated to the Association have nearly entirely failed to do so, the existing members of the Association resolve to disband it, and not retaining the existence of the Association in any shape or form, to adopt the less pretentious title of Goseva Sangha (Cow service Society) and irrevocably to entrust the affairs, management and control of the funds and stock of the Association to the following Permanent Standing Committee of management of the Society (for names of the members, see below), with full powers to disburse the funds, conduct the said experiments, to add to their number, to fill up vacancies caused by the resignation or the death of a member, to expel a member by a majority vote and otherwise carry out the objects of the expiring Association and to frame a constitution and rule for the management of the Society and to make such amendments thereof as may from time to time be required.”
('46', 458, 14, 16, 949372) In pursuance of this resolution the Standing Committee of the Cow service Association hereby adopts the following constitution for it:
('46', 458, 15, 17, 949507) The object of the Cow service Association and the means by which it shall carry on its work are identical with the object and the means of the late All India cow protection Association, which are as follows:
('46', 459, 0, 1, 949715) 460 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 459, 2, 2, 949757) Whereas the Hindus have failed in cow protection which is an obligation
('46', 459, 3, 3, 949829) imposed on them by their religion, and whereas the cows in India and their progeny
('46', 459, 4, 4, 949912) are deteriorating day by day:
('46', 459, 5, 5, 949942) The All India Cow protection Sabha is formed for the proper fulfilment of the
('46', 459, 6, 6, 950020) religious obligation of cow protection.
('46', 459, 7, 7, 950060) The object of the Sabha shall be to protect the cow and her progeny by all
('46', 459, 8, 8, 950135) moral means.
('46', 459, 9, 9, 950148) ‘Cow protection’ shall mean the protection of the cow and her progeny from
('46', 459, 10, 10, 950223) cruelty and slaughter.
('46', 459, 11, 11, 950246) It will be against the fundamental policy of the Sabha to bring physical
('46', 459, 12, 12, 950319) force or pressure to bear on those communities whose religion does not prohibit, or
('46', 459, 13, 13, 950403) regards as obligatory, cow slaughter.
('46', 459, 14, 14, 950441) The Sabha shall carry on its work by the following means:
('46', 459, 15, 15, 950499) 1. by pleading with those who may be ill treating cows, bullocks, etc., and
('46', 459, 16, 16, 950575) by carrying on propaganda against such ill treatment by means of leaflets, lectures,
('46', 459, 18, 17, 950660) 2. by taking charge of diseased and disabled cows and oxen from their owners
('46', 459, 19, 18, 950737) wherever the latter cannot afford to maintain them;
('46', 459, 20, 19, 950789) 3. by superintending and inspecting the administration of existing
('46', 459, 21, 20, 950856) pinjrapoles and cow protection institutions, and by helping in their better
('46', 459, 22, 21, 950932) organization and management, as also by establishing fresh institutions;
('46', 459, 23, 22, 951005) 4. by breeding model cows and draught cattle by means of cattle farms, etc., and by providing clean and cheap milk through properly kept dairies;
('46', 459, 24, 23, 951151) 5. by opening tanneries for tanning hides of dead cattle and thereby stopping or reducing the export abroad of disabled cattle;
('46', 459, 25, 24, 951279) 6. by enlisting men of character and education in the cause, and founding scholarships, etc., for training them in the work;
('46', 459, 26, 25, 951404) 7. by holding an inquiry into the causes of the disappearance of grazing lands and into the advantages or disadvantages thereof;
('46', 459, 27, 26, 951533) 8. by investigating into the necessity or otherwise of the practice of castrating bulls, and if found necessary and useful, investigating into the possibilities of discovering a harmless method of castration or a wholsesome modification in the present method;
('46', 459, 28, 27, 951793) 9. by collecting funds; and
('46', 460, 0, 1, 951821) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 461
('46', 460, 1, 2, 951864) 10. by taking whatever other steps as may be necessary for the work of cow proection.
('46', 460, 1, 3, 951950) MEMBERSHIP
('46', 460, 2, 4, 951961) Any person of the age of eighteen years, who subscribes to the object of the Association, and
('46', 460, 3, 5, 952055) 1. who pays to the Association an annual subscription of five rupees; or
('46', 460, 4, 6, 952128) 2. who sends to the Association 12,000 yards of even and well twisted self spun yarn; or
('46', 460, 5, 7, 952217) 3. who sends to the Association every year two cow or bull hides whether raw or tanned,
('46', 460, 6, 8, 952305) shall be a member of the Association.
('46', 460, 7, 9, 952343) Any person who pays to the Association in advance a consolidated amount of Rs. 500 shall be a life member of the Association.
('46', 460, 8, 10, 952469) DUTIES OF MEMBERS
('46', 460, 9, 11, 952487) This Association has been conceived as a body of servants, who have not so
('46', 460, 10, 12, 952562) much rights as duties, or to whom duties should be as rights.
('46', 460, 10, 13, 952624) The following therefore
('46', 460, 11, 14, 952648) shall be the dutgies of members:
('46', 460, 12, 15, 952681) 1. They shall, as far as may be, use only cow’s milk whenever they have an
('46', 460, 13, 16, 952756) occasion to use milk or milk products.
('46', 460, 14, 17, 952795) 2. Whenever they have to use leather articles for personal use they shall
('46', 460, 15, 18, 952869) use only the hides of dead cattle and never use the hides of slaughtered cows or
('46', 460, 16, 19, 952950) bullocks.
('46', 460, 16, 20, 952960) With regard to other things made of leather, they shall also, as far as may
('46', 460, 17, 21, 953036) be, use only dead cattle hide.
('46', 460, 18, 22, 953067) 3. If members keep cattle for milk, they shall keep cows only and not
('46', 460, 19, 23, 953137) buffaloes.
('46', 460, 19, 24, 953148) They will reason with buffalo keepers to replace buffaloes with cows.
('46', 460, 20, 25, 953218) 4. They will carry the message of the Association to pinjrapoles, goshalas
('46', 460, 21, 26, 953293) and similar humanitarian organizations.
('46', 460, 22, 27, 953333) 5. In case they follow cow keeping as a profitable occupation, they will
('46', 460, 23, 28, 953406) devote all profits beyond their maintenance to the cause of cow protection so long as
('46', 460, 24, 29, 953492) cow protection in India has not been placed on a satisfactory footing.
('46', 460, 25, 30, 953563) 6.They will induce moneyed men to take up dairying and tanning for
('46', 460, 26, 31, 953630) humanity’s sake.
('46', 460, 27, 32, 953647) 7. They will try to acquire the knowledge requisite for carrying on dairying or tanning, and will, wherever possible, seek to maintain themselves through the service of the cow.
('46', 461, 0, 1, 953825) 462 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 461, 1, 2, 953867) SYMPATHIZERS
('46', 461, 2, 3, 953880) Any person, who, while approving of the duties laid on members, is unable to discharge them fully but is anxious to acquire the ability to shoulder them, may be a sympathizer of the Association, provided that he fulfils the conditions of membership in other ways.

('46', 461, 23, 24, 954749) with full powers to disburse the funds, to conduct dairying and tanning
('46', 461, 24, 25, 954821) experiments and otherwise carry out the objects of the Association, to add to their
('46', 461, 25, 26, 954905) number, to fill up vacancies caused by the resignation or death of a member or
('46', 461, 26, 27, 954984) otherwise, to remove a member by a majority vote on proper and sufficient grounds,
('46', 461, 27, 28, 955067) to frame a constitution and rules for the management of the Association and to make
('46', 461, 28, 29, 955151) such amendment thereof as may be required from time to time.
('46', 461, 29, 30, 955212) Only members of the Association shall be eligible for appointment to and
('46', 461, 30, 31, 955285) continuance on the Standing Committee.
('46', 461, 31, 32, 955324) Five members shall form the quorum for a meeting of the Committee.
('46', 461, 32, 33, 955391) In case of emergency the president shall have the power of taking necessary action without waiting for calling a meeting of the Committee, and also when there is
('46', 462, 0, 1, 955553) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 463
('46', 462, 1, 2, 955596) no quorum at a meeting actually called.
('46', 462, 1, 3, 955636) The President however shall immediately inform the members of action thus taken.
('46', 462, 2, 4, 955717) Whenever it is difficult or unnecessary to convene a meeting of the Committee, the Secretay shall have the power to circulate a resolution among members and obtain their votes by correspondence.
('46', 462, 2, 5, 955912) Such resolution shall be considered as duly agreed to if none of the members objects.
('46', 462, 2, 6, 955998) If a member does not reply within a fortnight, he will be held to have waived his right to object.
('46', 462, 3, 7, 956097) The books of the Association shall be open to public inspection and shall be audited by competent auditors every year.
('46', 462, 3, 8, 956216) A statement of accounts shall be published every six months.
('46', 462, 4, 9, 956277) The treasurer shall be responsible for the account of all the receipts and disbursements, all amounts exceeding one thousand rupees to be kept depositedin a bank of his approval.
('46', 462, 5, 10, 956456) All communications relating to the Association should be addressed to the undersigned.
('46', 462, 6, 11, 956543) VALJI GOVINDJI DESAI
('46', 462, 7, 12, 956564) UDYOGA MANDIR SECRETARY,
('46', 462, 8, 13, 956589) SABARMATI COW SERVICE ASSOCIATION

('46', 462, 10, 15, 956645) APPENDIX II LETTER FROM SATIS CHANDRA DAS GUPTA
('46', 462, 11, 16, 956693) [Before August 24, 1929]
('46', 462, 13, 17, 956718) I have your letter on Niranjan Babu's affairs.
('46', 462, 13, 18, 956765) I welcome your decision about him.
('46', 462, 13, 19, 956800) I have been trying to help him in my own way.
('46', 462, 13, 20, 956846) I suggested to him that he should readjust his family obligations if he wants to stick to khadi and avoid similar grief in future.
('46', 462, 14, 21, 956977) Kristodasji saw me yesterday.
('46', 462, 14, 22, 957007) He told me about a letter Hamprabha wrote to you.
('46', 462, 14, 23, 957057) You took this letter to be a business one, being of the nature of an invitation to you to take up the responsibility of Pratishthan's ownership!
('46', 462, 14, 24, 957202) I laughed loudly and heartily over it, for it was a love letter, pure and simple.
('46', 462, 14, 25, 957284) Could love be so dull as to mistake it?
('46', 462, 14, 26, 957324) And what was the origin of this?
('46', 462, 14, 27, 957357) Hemprabha felt an yearning to be near you and being unable to take the journey and desiring all at Sodepur to be benefited by your presence, she desired that you should regard Sodepur as your own place and grace it with your presence for the spiritual uplift of all the inmates.
('46', 463, 0, 1, 957636) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('46', 463, 1, 2, 957678) But the matter of this letter was not all.
('46', 463, 1, 3, 957721) I could not laugh away all the rest that Kristodasji said.
('46', 463, 1, 4, 957780) He reported to me the conversation he had with you at Almora in which myself and Pratishthan were drawn in.
('46', 463, 2, 5, 957888) Niranjan Babu on his way back from Sabarmati met me.
('46', 463, 2, 6, 957941) He also told me about your sarcasm about my Utkal report which I did not then understand at all, although what he said jarred painfully.
('46', 463, 2, 7, 958078) Now after Kristodasji's interview Niranjan Babu's utterances become explicable.
('46', 463, 2, 8, 958158) You have wronged yourself hopelessly in all these.
('46', 463, 2, 9, 958209) But let time pass.
('46', 463, 3, 10, 958228) As I woke up this morning and was going to the prayer ground a thought of Marcus Aurelius came across my mind and from the depth of my heart I repeated, "Today I shall meet with blows .
('46', 463, 3, 11, 958414) But I cannot be injured by anyone of them." At 2 p.m.
('46', 463, 3, 12, 958468) Kristodasji came and blows there were sure enough.
('46', 463, 3, 13, 958519) My pranams, SATIS
('46', 463, 4, 14, 958537) From a microfilm: S.N. 15194
('46', 463, 5, 15, 958566) APPENDIX III LETTER FROM M.R. JAYAKAR Private THAKURDWAR BOMBAY, August 23, 1929
('46', 463, 6, 16, 958647) DEAR MAHATMAJI,
('46', 463, 7, 17, 958663) I am writing this letter to you because I feel certain that you will not misunderstand its motives.
('46', 463, 7, 18, 958763) It is nowadays the fashion in Bombay to condemn, as a communalist, any Hindu who happens to speak in favour of his community.
('46', 463, 7, 19, 958889) Mahommedan leaders, of course, are immune from this charge.
('46', 463, 7, 20, 958949) I am sure that you will not judge me by such a partial test.
('46', 463, 8, 21, 959010) My purpose in writing this letter to you is to make you acquainted with the apprehensions of a very large body of Hindus (outside the Hindu Mahasabha) that any atempt at this time to vary the solution of the Hindu Muslim question adopted in the Nehru's Committee's report is fraught with far reaching consequences.
('46', 463, 8, 22, 959325) I am sure, you are aware that many Hindus, who were against the continuance of communal representation, accepted the Nehru's Committee's solution as a kind of compromise for the sake of peace and harmony.
('46', 463, 8, 23, 959530) As I said in my speech at the Calcutta session of the All Parties Convention last December, with reference to Mahommedan demands, that compromise had proceeded on four well recognized principles, and that the demands set up by the Mahommedans at the Calcutta session were flagrant variations from those principles.
('46', 463, 8, 24, 959845) These demands were then only five or six in number.
('46', 463, 8, 25, 959897) They have since risen to 14. Even when they were five or six, they were turned down at Calcutta by an overwhelming majority of All India delegates, including Sikhs and Christians.
('46', 464, 0, 1, 960077) VOL. 46 : 12 MAY, 1929 31 AUGUST, 1929 465
('46', 464, 1, 2, 960120) One of the grounds of their decision was that the Mahommedans were divided, on these demands, into four well known groups.
('46', 464, 1, 3, 960243) Three of them were against joint electorates at any price.
('46', 464, 1, 4, 960302) It was therefore not clear on whose behalf Mr. Jinnah spoke, and what bulk of the entire Mahommedan community would be placated if his demands were conceded.
('46', 464, 1, 5, 960460) My own opinion in the matter is that it would be desirable for us all to concentrate on the Nehru Committee's report, accepting it on all essential points.
('46', 464, 1, 6, 960616) If any minor adjustments are needed in its proposals about the Hindu Muslim question, which, if met, have a possibility of being accepted by the bulk of the Mahommedans, these may be considered when we reach the stage of finality, I mean in the sense that the stage is arrived at when the representatives of the Hindus, Mahommedans and Government meet and in a spirit of give and take, arrive at a compromise which is final and forms the terms of our future Constitution.
('46', 464, 1, 7, 961088) I refer to this feature of finality, because to me the danger of making any further concessions to Mahommedans at this stage appears to be great.
('46', 464, 1, 8, 961234) The Government will clearly pick out all these concessions and make them parts of a constitution entirely different from the one of which they were intended to be a part.
('46', 464, 1, 9, 961405) Hindus then will be regarded as being stopped from raising objections on the ground that the items objected to are a matter of agreement between Hindus and Muslims.
('46', 464, 1, 10, 961570) Past experience shows that this fear is not without justification apart from what may have happened at and after the Lucknow Pact of 1916, I will quote a very fresh instance.
('46', 464, 1, 11, 961745) You will remember that Mr. Jinnah, the Muslim League spokesman at Calcutta, openly claimed that, although the separation of Sind was, in the Nehru Committee’s report, conditional on India having the Constitution recommended therein, Mahommedans ought to have the liberty of accepting Separation of Sind, even if Government made it a part of a totally different Constitution.
('46', 464, 1, 12, 962120) This makes clear the danger I am referring to.
('46', 464, 1, 13, 962167) I have good reasons to believe that Muslims will not get from Government any undue privileges this time.
('46', 464, 1, 14, 962272) A section of that community is therefore anxious to make it appear that the concessions they want have been agreed to by the Congress.
('46', 464, 1, 15, 962407) Hence the need of caution.
('46', 464, 1, 16, 962434) These are a few considerations which I thought it was my duty to respectfully urge on your attention.
('46', 464, 1, 17, 962536) Perhaps you are yourself well aware of them all.
('46', 464, 1, 18, 962585) Offering you my apology for disturbing you in this matter in the present state of your health.
('46', 464, 1, 19, 962680) I am, Yours sincerely,
('46', 464, 2, 20, 962703) M.R.J. MAHATMA GANDHI SABARMATI
('46', 464, 3, 21, 962735) Jayakar's Private Papers, Correspondence File No.
